HEADLINE: CONCLUDING THE U.P.S. STRIKE: THE CUSTOMERS;
Strained Loyalties Are Likely To Endure

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
For many small businesses, going back to United Parcel Service is a bit like jump-starting a romance. There is a mutual need that never went away, even during the separation, but things may never be quite the same again.
"This was a great relationship, but definitely there are some open wounds that need to be healed," Norman Toline, head of a business in the Manhattan garment district, said today. "They've helped open our eyes to other shipping methods." 
 Intentionally or not, Mr. Toline chose words befitting a man who makes his living by romance, which he does as the president of Betty Wales Bridal Veils. But when he spoke of "a new dawning" with the end of the strike, he was talking like a cold-eyed businessman. Having said he lost $25,000 in the strike, he said he would never again rely exclusively on U.P.S..
Neither will many other small businesses across the country, said executives who had turned to other shipping companies and the United States Postal Service in the past two weeks. Direct-mail and catalogue merchants, especially, have learned the danger of overdependence, said Connie Heatley, senior vice president of the Direct Marketing Association, a trade group based in New York.
But some big companies said they would continue to depend heavily, if not exclusively, on U.P.S. Some are so big that only U.P.S., the world's largest package-delivery company, can fill their needs economically and efficiently.
Lands' End Inc., the mail-order clothing merchant, welcomed the end of the strike, even though it lauded the service provided by the postal system during the walkout.
"We will switch back to U.P.S., absolutely," Charlotte LaComb, a spokeswoman for Lands' End said today. "There is not a replacement that can offer the same kind of service U.P.S. does at the cost that they do."
Ms. LaComb cited U.P.S.'s tracking system and ubiquitous brown trucks, but she acknowledged that Lands' End would continue to evaluate its shipping options.
And the J. Crew Group, the New York merchant of upscale clothing, will "gradually fade back into U.P.S. over the next week," said Arthur Cinader Jr., the operations manager. Mr. Cinader said J. Crew was undecided about whether to diversify its shipping.
A smaller clothing company hundreds of miles away made that decision long ago, and was thankful for it during the walkout. Jim Eastham, the vice president of Faith Mountain Company in Sperryville, Va., said his company began diversifying its shipping a couple of years ago.
Mr. Eastham said the strike illustrated the danger of all-or-nothing relationships.
"If there is any lesson to be learned, that is it" -- and that his company had been able to switch fairly easily to the Postal Service's Priority Mail during the strike because U.P.S. has accounted for only about 60 percent of its shipments.
But other small companies, purveyors of anything a person can think of and some things he never would, depend almost solely on U.P.S. and greeted the strike's end as deliverance. Some of these are too small to have much leverage with other shippers. Others deal in goods that the post office cannot handle: liquor, for example, or packages weighing more than 70 pounds or measuring more than 108 inches combined length and girth.
National shipments of gourmet smoked catfish pate from the Crown Restaurant in Indianola, Miss., were almost at a standstill during the last two weeks, said the restaurateur, Evelyn Roughton. Her establishment sells 1,400 pounds of the delicacy a week, a quarter of it by mail order to individual buyers.
Ms. Roughton did make other arrangements, but she said she wanted to resume the U.P.S. habit.
"We have a perishable product, so shipping schedules matter a lot," she said.
"Hooray!" was how Robert Alcala, owner of a Western-wear shop in Chicago, reacted to the strike's end. He turned to Federal Express and the Postal Service for two weeks, but said he needed U.P.S.
So does Albert Karoll, owner of a custom clothing shop in Chicago. He used the Postal Service during the strike and said he was "pleasantly surprised." But he said he liked U.P.S.'s service and would rely on the company again. Still, he conceded that the strike made him realize how vulnerable his company was in its dependence on one shipping company.
John Hart Wines, a small retail company in Chicago, never had the choice of switching from U.P.S. to the post office because alcoholic beverages cannot be legally mailed. And other shippers gave first priority to their bigger clients, said John Hart's shipping director, Rick Nelson, explaining his relief at the end of the walkout.
The strike affected hospitals and health-care companies. VHA Inc., a Texas company that acts as a group buyer for 1,500 health-care organizations across the country, said some hospitals had to cancel elective surgeries and were having trouble getting shipments of supplies and sending out surgical instruments for repair and replacement.
Some VHA sales workers served as "pack mules," delivering supplies to hospitals in their own cars, said Lynn Gentry, a company spokesman.
Some medical supplies are difficult to send through the mail. The Postal Service has stringent packing regulations for equipment like needles and vials, said Lou Eberhardt, a Postal Service spokesman in Chicago.
Alliance Medical, a $10 million-a-year company that ships medical supplies to ambulance services and fire departments across the country from its base in Russellville, Mo., had sent about 90 percent of its 300 packages a day by U.P.S. and successfully rerouted them during the strike, said its marketing manager, Larry Dahl Jr.
The strike taught Alliance a lesson, Mr. Dahl said, and U.P.S. will not get as much of his company's business in the future.
"We could not have grown like we have without a company like U.P.S.,' he said. "But when something like this happens, it hurts us and everybody else."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Striking United Parcel Service driver Sean Matsabayashi wore his sentiment on his back as he watched a driver leave the San Francisco hub on Tuesday. Some businesses are now wary of relying too much on U.P.S. (Associated Press)

INTERNATIONAL A3-14
 
Space Agency Struggles With New Mir Trouble
After six months of near-disasters on Russia's Mir space station, officials of the Russian Space Agency are acknowledging the sorry state of the craft's onboard systems. A1
 
Rockets Land in Northern Israel
Islamic guerrillas fired dozens of rockets into northern Israel to avenge a deadly attack Monday by militiamen aligned with Israel. The attack caused only minor damage and injuries, but the barrages were by far the heaviest since clashes between Hezbollah guerrillas and Israeli forces in southern Lebanon erupted into full-scale battle in April 1996. Israel said it was not preparing immediate retaliation. A14 

Work on Korean Reactor
Delegates from the United States and other democratic nations broke ground in North Korea on a construction project to give the isolated nation two modern nuclear reactors. The project is being built for North Korea in exchange for giving up older reactors that experts believed were merely a front for making nuclear weapons. A6
 
Cambodian Skirmish Continues
Cambodian forces loyal to an ousted leader, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, fought to defend their last stronghold against troops backing the nation's strongman, Hun Sen. Forces loyal to Prince Ranariddh, who lost power to Hun Sen in a coup this summer, dug in along a ridge two miles south of O Smach, but military analysts said it was only a matter of time before they were routed by Hun Sen's superior numbers and fire-power. A6
 
Pope Target of Political Ire
Umberto Bossi, leader of Italy's separatist Northern League, has garnered his share of scandal from his blistering political speech. But some Italian newspapers, politicians and the Catholic church said he had gone too far when he launched an attack on John Paul II, accusing him of meddling in politics and referring to him as "the Polish Pope." A7
 
Caribbean Evacuation to Begin
Ash, gas and steam spurted from the Soufriere Hills volcano on Montserrat as Britain's Royal Navy prepared to mount a voluntary evacuation of the stricken island. Britain said refugees would be given the choice of settling in Britain or elsewhere in the Caribbean. (Reuters)
 
River Project Condemned
A panel of independent experts criticized a major river-widening project proposed by Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay and Bolivia, saying that official studies have minimized possibly catastrophic environmental consequences. Convened by pressure groups from the United States and Brazil, the environmental experts said the studies into the Hidrovia Paraguay-Parana were flawed. They challenged the view that there would be little impact on one of the world's richest ecosystems. The Hidrovia works involve dredging a deeper channel between Brazil and Uruguay. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A16-20, D17-19
 
Specter of Further Losses Prodded U.P.S. to Settle
As 185,000 teamsters prepared to return to work at the United Parcel Service after a 15-day strike, company officials acknowledged that fears of hundreds of millions of dollars in additional losses led them to back away from a long-held demand on pensions and to make other concessions on pay and part-time workers. Company officials also said that as many as 15,000 workers might be laid off to compensate for losses resulting from the strike. A1
 
Ron Carey, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said what all of organized labor was waiting to hear: the union's settlement with United Parcel Service will be as much of a boon to labor as the failed air traffic controllers' strike of 1981 was a bust. A1
 
A New Power in Washington
Andrew F. Brimmer, who has emerged as the real power in the District of Columbia, is under pressure from both ends of the political spectrum as he leads the city's financial control board. But Dr. Brimmer, the son of a sharecropper who went on to teach economics at Harvard and to serve on the Federal Reserve Board, is not inclined to explain himself. "I don't engage in public debate," he said. "Why should I produce drama when I can produce action?" A1
 
A Failure of Supervision
A fire begun and nourished by oxygen generators caused the crash of a Valujet plane in Florida last year, but the accident, which killed 110 people, ultimately resulted from supervisory failures by the airline and the Federal Aviation Administration, the National Transportation Safety Board said. A16
 
Counsel Named for Inquiry
The chairman of the House committee investigating Democratic fund-raising practices selected a new chief counsel, Richard D. Bennett, who was the United States Attorney in Maryland in the Bush Administration and one of scores of Federal prosecutors replaced by President Clinton in 1993. A17
 
Cuba Feared U.S. Invasion
Intelligence documents provide evidence that Cuba's President, Fidel Castro, put his military forces on high alert after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy because he feared that the United States would blame Cuba and launch an invasion. A18
 
Catholic Pastor Resigns
A priest criticized for suggesting that parents shared responsibility for any sexual abuse of 11 boys by another priest has resigned as a church pastor and will hold no church offices, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Dallas said. The pastor, Msgr. Robert C. Rehkemper, 73, once the diocese's No. 2 official, was a witness in a civil trial in which the jury awarded $119.6 million to 10 men and the family of a man who committed suicide at age 20. The jury found that the diocese had ignored evidence of abuse and then tried to conceal it. The diocese is appealing. (AP)

Police Torture Allegation Is Issue at Mayoral Forum
The allegations that New York City police officers savagely attacked a Haitian immigrant 11 days ago emerged as central issue in the mayoral campaign as three Democratic candidates used a televised forum to pummel Mayor Giuliani and his law-enforcement policies. B1
 
Police Commissioner Howard Safir said he would move more black officers into the Brooklyn precinct rocked by the torture allegation, including officers who had been sent to Haiti to wean that police force away from such abuses. B3

BUSINESS DAY D1-16
 
Fed Keeps Rates Unchanged
The Federal Reserve voted to leave interest rates unchanged, continuing a remarkable economic experiment in which the central bank has kept interest rates low despite shrinking unemployment and unusually strong economic growth. The meeting of the Fed's policy-making body marked the third time in a row that the central bank has passed up an opportunity to raise short-term interest rates. The last increase in the key short-term rate controlled by the Fed came in March, a quarter-point rise to 5.50 percent. A1
 
Stocks Climb for 2d Day
Stocks continued to rebound from their recent slide as the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 114.74 points, or 1.5 percent, to 7,918.10. D1

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 583 words

HEADLINE: Settlement at U.P.S.

 BODY:
Labor leaders exulted yesterday in the settlement of the 15-day strike at United Parcel Service, for understandable reasons. The teamsters won most of their demands -- for wage increases, pension protections and especially for upgrading thousands of jobs from part time to full time. More than that, the union dramatized what it sees as a pernicious trend, the growing reliance of companies on two-tiered work forces in which significant numbers of employees receive lower wages or benefits. It was far from clear, however, that the labor movement will be able to build on its victory to help workers elsewhere who have felt left out by the extraordinary economic boom of recent years.
President Clinton and Labor Secretary Alexis Herman played a constructive role in pushing for a settlement of a strike that had begun to hurt many businesses. But one of the most remarkable facts about the walkout at the world's largest package delivery company was the extent of public support generated by the 185,000 strikers. Some surveys showed that Americans supported them by a margin of 2 to 1. Mr. Clinton was probably correct in warning that public approval might soon reach its limits, but news of widespread sympathy for the strikers galvanized people on the picket lines and no doubt contributed to United Parcel's decision to make significant concessions. 
 Some of that sympathy turned on unusual aspects of this particular strike. An enormous number of Americans come into contact with United Parcel Service, and their esteem for the company turns out to be connected directly to the employees themselves. Ron Carey, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, skillfully advanced the most sympathetic spokesmen for the cause -- hard-working part-time employees who said they simply wanted to be paid at the same rate as their full-time colleagues. It was a genuine feat for a union plagued by a reputation for corruption. The image of the workers in this case was in marked contrast to what the public felt was sullen behavior by the air traffic controllers in 1981 and the high-paid baseball players of more recent vintage.
More broadly, the issue of part-time employment touched a nerve among people worried about job security and lagging wages. Despite recent small improvements in wage levels for middle- and lower-level workers, the corporate downsizing of the 1990's has undeniably made Americans more doubtful about their employers and more sympathetic to those whose wages have not kept up. That was one reason portable health insurance and the minimum wage won bipartisan support in Congress last year. Politicians and companies would do well not to ignore this larger trend.
It will be tempting for many analysts to say that the labor movement is on the mend after decades of decline. Labor's legislative victories, including its battles against steep cuts in Medicare, have certainly been impressive. But the country's current sympathy for the problems of some workers does not necessarily open a new chapter in industrial relations. It will still be difficult to reconcile the age-old conflict between union pressure for higher wages and the fear of inflation in financial markets and corporate boardrooms. Strikes, of course, involve issues of economics and issues of perception. This strike's most lasting benefit might well be in persuading corporate employers that the public judges them by the treatment of their lower-paid and most vulnerable workers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

HEADLINE: CONCLUDING THE U.P.S. STRIKE: THE OVERVIEW;
U.P.S. SAYS FEARS OF BIGGER LOSSES MADE IT CUT DEAL

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
As 185,000 teamsters prepared to return to work at the United Parcel Service, company officials acknowledged today that fears of hundreds of millions of dollars in additional losses pushed them to back off a long-held demand on pensions during marathon talks on Monday, helping end the 15-day strike.
Though company officials said that 15,000 workers may be laid off because of business lost from the strike, they acknowledged that they had made concessions on pay, pensions and part-time workers, which the teamsters asserted were a major victory. 
 At a news conference at U.P.S. headquarters in Atlanta, James P. Kelly, the company's chairman, said, "The bottom line is that we have a contract that is good for our people, gets us back in business, and will keep us competitive in the coming years."
Millions of American consumers and companies welcomed the end to the strike, which paralyzed the world's largest parcel delivery company. The strike prevented many shop owners from restocking their shelves, hospitals from receiving supplies, and grandparents from shipping gifts to grandchildren.
The 50-person bargaining committee of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and officials from more than 200 teamsters locals ratified the tentative agreement tonight after Ron Carey, the union's president, said it gave the union most of what it sought during the nation's largest strike in more than a decade.
In the agreement, the teamsters persuaded U.P.S. to convert thousands of part-time jobs to full time, to raise part-timers' starting wage for the first time since 1982 and to let U.P.S. workers remain in the union's multi-employer pension plans while raising retirement benefits.
"This fight with U.P.S. shows what working people can accomplish when they all stick together," Mr. Carey said at a news conference at the union's headquarters in Washington.
The agreement is unusual because it awards lower-paid part-time workers a larger raise than full-timers. The part-time workers receive a 37 percent raise over five years, the full-timers, 15 percent.
Gary Burtless, an economist with the Brookings Institution, said, "It sounds to me that the union got most of what it wanted and that U.P.S. did not get most of what it wanted, which most of all was to withdrawal from the teamster pensions funds."
While teamsters around the nation applauded the settlement, U.P.S. officials dampened the celebration by warning of layoffs.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Kelly said he feared that the company might lose 5 percent of its market share, at least temporarily, as a result of the strike. He said that could force the layoff of 5 percent of the company's domestic work force of about 300,000.
Ken Sternad, the company's spokesman, said in an interview, "We're taking the attitude that no one wins in a strike."
After two weeks of clashing bitterly, Mr. Kelly and Mr. Carey vowed today to work together to win back business from competitors like Federal Express and the Postal Service.
Giving his blessing to the settlement, President Clinton said, "I would say it is a victory for the proposition that you can have good strong labor relations and treat your employees well and make money in this economy of ours."
If there was an indisputable victor in the strike, it was Labor Secretary Alexis Herman, who steadfastly urged the two sides to stay at the bargaining table during more than 80 hours of intense talks from Thursday to Monday.
But union officials also had kind words for the White House for prodding the two sides to negotiate and for resisting the company's pleas to seek a back-to-work injunction under the Taft-Hartley Act.
"The Secretary of Labor has gotten a lot of well-deserved praise and attention, but this was really a team effort by the Administration," said Gerry Shea, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s assistant to the president for governmental affairs.
Several labor leaders said U.P.S. miscalculated by bargaining hard in the belief that it could easily defeat the teamsters in a strike because the union was badly divided and its strike fund was depleted. That fund received a much-needed infusion of cash when the nation's labor unions pledged to lend the teamsters $10 million a week.
U.P.S. executives asserted, however, that Mr. Carey was dead set on calling a strike to unite the union behind him and distract people from an investigation into the financing of his re-election campaign.
In claiming victory, Mr. Carey noted that U.P.S. agreed to convert 10,000 part-time jobs into full-time ones over the next five years, after U.P.S. had originally offered to convert 1,000 such jobs over that period. The union's demand was to transform 10,000 part-time jobs to full-time ones over four years.
During the strike, the union put U.P.S. on the defensive by arguing that the main issue was U.P.S.'s large-scale creation of part-time jobs that did not pay enough to support a family. This focus was one reason that the American public, according to public polls, backed the strikers by a 2-to-1 margin.
Today, even after the settlement, Mr. Kelly bristled at the union's charges that the company did not treat its workers well. "If you talk about downsizing and throw-away jobs and temporary jobs, that doesn't exist at U.P.S.," he said. "We've created tens of thousands of jobs. We were set up to serve as an example of what's wrong with America, but you wonder why they chose us because we're one of the few companies that doesn't fit into that category."
In the settlement, the company agreed to raise the wages of full-time drivers, who average $19.95 an hour, by $3.10 an hour over five years. For part-time workers, who average $11 an hour, pay is to rise $4.10 an hour over five years. For loaders, whose starting pay has not changed since 1982, the starting wage will rise to $8.50 an hour, from $8.
Teamster officials said they also emerged victorious by getting the company to forswear most contracting out and by persuading it to drop its demand that U.P.S. drivers lose their right to honor other unions' picket lines. Mr. Carey said the biggest concession the union made was agreeing to a five-year contract -- the union had originally call for a three-year deal, but began pushing for a four-year contract shortly before the strike began on Aug. 4.
According to Mr. Kelly, the company's largest concession was withdrawing its demand to pull out of the union's multi-employer pension plans and set up a U.P.S.-only plan for all the unionized workers. The company said it would increase pensions by an average of 50 percent in a U.P.S.-only pension plan, but the union bitterly fought on this matter, contending that the company's withdrawal could weaken the multi-employer plans.
"The pension issue," Mr. Kelly said, "got the most press, and that was the one where we compromised the most."
Mr. Kelly said the company decided to back off the demand to reach a settlement after seeing that it would not persuade the union to have the rank and file vote on what the company called its "last, best and final offer."
Ken Hall, the teamsters' chief negotiator, said the company's negotiators surprised him and Mr. Carey on Sunday when they asked, hypothetically, what the union would trade if the company dropped its demand to withdraw from the multi-employer plans.
For much of Sunday, Mr. Hall said, the two sides talked hypothetically about which demands they would trade if the other side gave up some of its demands. It was an interlocking puzzle with dozens of pieces and demands flying around the table, the negotiators said.
Mr. Hall, who is the director of the teamsters' parcel and small package department, said that finally, around 3 P.M. Monday, after talking nearly nonstop for three days, the two sides began making serious trades and an overall package emerged.
"I was relieved -- and exhausted," Mr. Hall said.
At his second news conference of the day, Mr. Carey presented himself as one of the nation's most successful labor leaders, one who planned to use this agreement to persuade workers ranging from apple pickers in Washington to Federal Express employees to join the teamsters.
Even some of Mr. Carey's many opponents in the often-fractious union acknowledged today that he would emerge stronger from the U.P.S. battle. Mr. Carey's opponents have sought to overturn his election last December as president, after Federal prosecutors charged two campaign aides with illegally diverting union money into his campaign coffers. Nancy Stella, a Carey spokeswoman, said he had no knowledge of such machinations.
Among the workers, there was widespread relief that the strike was over and general support for the agreement.
Charlie Mosiman, a full-time U.P.S. driver in Seattle, said, "I want to go back to work, but I'm no fan of U.P.S. The real issue is how we get treated right here. But from everything we've heard, the offer is a lot better than U.P.S.'s first 'last, best offer."'
Sam Figueroa, a full-time driver in Manhattan, said he was elated with the agreement but weary after standing on the picket line every day for eight hours.
"I feel like we achieved what we were after," he said. "All the men and women across America who are teamsters stood tall."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
For the Mets, A Melting Pot Celebration

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH 

 BODY:
WHEN the Mets started promoting their current homestand as a celebration of various ethnic groups, calling it International Week, it underscored that team's recognition of its residence in America's most diverse urban melting pot.
At first glance, two impressions leap out. What fun, what with the costumes, the music, the pageantry, the pride, starting last evening with Italian night as the ethnically diverse Mets met the equally diverse Dodgers. 
 Alas, the second immediate impression was -- given baseball's fine-tuned sensitivity in this, the year of Jackie Robinson -- how is it that the Mets could not find room to celebrate African-American culture during a homestand on which the Irish, Italian, German, Hispanic and Asian communities will be honored?
This is the sport that has focused keenly on its relationship with African-Americans and other minority groups who have turned away from the game because of benign neglect and lack of interest on the part of the sport. Baseball has vowed to revive such relationships because it makes economic sense and solidifies a claim to truly be the national pastime.
So a call was put in to Mark Bingham, the Mets' vice president in charge of marketing and broadcasting, to ask how the team, in making its choices, opted not to include African-Americans.
Questioning the Mets about their selections was not a unique idea, it turns out.
"The first three calls were from Jewish groups," Bingham said.
It's not easy being a baseball executive commanded not only to grow new fans, but also to do so on the front lines of a tart ethnic pie chart.
"We knew when we created this, there would be people who felt left out, which is why the last day is a multinational day, for groups that might feel left out," Bingham said.
Bingham, knowing a potential for growth when he sees one, said this is a roster that is by no means set. A gate of 40,000 might make Hispanic night a happy necessity for 1998 and beyond. But Polish-Americans might get the call next year. Black Americans, too. It's all about marketing, after all, and in that sense, the only color that really counts is green.
Still, Bingham said: "I hate to be so fearful that by having an Hispanic night that you're going to tick off Poles or Jews or any group. The whole purpose of the whole week is to talk about New York as a melting pot. And hopefully that's what people think about, how when you go from one street corner to another, you hear African rhythms, Irish rhythms, Spanish rhythms. That's what it's all about."
That said, there was the matter of making the cutdown. And, again, it was all about group sales and the relations the Mets have with Irish groups, Asian groups, etc.
"And where we had focused our efforts with the African-American community was for Jackie Robinson Day," Bingham said, recalling Shea's 50th-anniversary celebrations of Robinson's breaking the color barrier.
"Really, we very much thought about the issue," Bingham said. "And we thought if we were going to put our efforts into a day, we were going to put it into Jackie Robinson Day. And in a group-sale effort, we felt to go back a month and a half later would be going to the well too many times."
As for the Jewish community, Bingham said deliberations were made. "And the question was, how do we do it?" he said. "Is it a religion, an ethnic group?"
Bingham added: "It's one of those you can't win. But while honesty and sincerity may not always win the day, may not always win people over, I know in my heart what I said about why and how we came up with this week."
Does it need polishing? "I'm not sure that it is a smart thing to say, about Jackie Robinson night, and our decision there, because I thought Jackie Robinson Day was for all Americans and all New Yorkers," Bingham acknowledged. "But we knew from a group-sale perspective to focus on the African-American groups for that day."
So the Mets farm for new fans, in fits and starts, just like all of baseball. But at least they try. And their two celebrations of Robinson are two more than New York's other major league baseball team has held. So the Mets have celebrated African-American contributions to the game. A wider celebration of the contributions to American culture would be nice, too. But again, fits and starts are better than nothing. So let the celebrations begin.

HEADLINE: New Bank Fraud Wrinkle in Antigua: Russians on the Internet

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: ST. JOHN'S, Antigua and Barbuda

 BODY:
When it opened for business here three years ago, the European Union Bank marketed itself as the first offshore bank on the Internet and claimed to be the wave of the future. But now the bank has collapsed, two of its Russian directors and depositors' money have disappeared, and the Government of Antigua has belatedly issued a fraud alert.
The scandal comes as little surprise to regulators in North America and Europe who have long warned that the Russian mafia, Colombian drug traffickers and other international criminals have been laundering money through Antigua's flourishing banking sector. More than 50 offshore banks are chartered here, many consisting of little more than a telephone and a computer behind a brass plate on an office door. 
 Dominated politically and economically by the Bird family since the mid-1940's, this former British colony 300 miles southeast of Puerto Rico has a reputation as a haven for intrigue and dubious businesses, notwithstanding the passage of money-laundering legislation last year. A recent State Department report describes Antigua, an island nation of 65,000 people, as "a weak link in efforts to combat drug trafficking and money laundering" and notes "a surge in questionable banking operations."
European Union Bank was founded in June 1994 as the East European International Bank by two Russians, Aleksandr P. Konanikhin and Mikhail B. Khodorovsky. In bank documents on file here, both described themselves as brokers of oil, metals and construction supplies and officers of the Menatep Bank of Moscow, which American and British officials have said is linked to Russian organized crime.
American officials said Mr. Konanikhin was arrested in the United States on visa violation charges and is accused of having embezzled more than $8 million from a Moscow bank. Both severed their formal connections with the European Union Bank, and two other Russians, Sergei Ushakov and Vitali Papsouev, who have disappeared, were listed as the bank's directors when it collapsed.
At the bank's office above a dentist's office and Nio's Bar and Restaurant, a notice on the locked door said, "European Union Bank Inc. has been placed in receivership effective this 8th day of August 1997."
On its now-dormant Internet site, www.eubank.ag, the bank had emphasized the benefits of the lax regulatory climate here. "Since there are no government withholding or reporting requirements on accounts, the burdensome and expensive accounting requirements are reduced for you," the web page said.
Through the Internet, the bank allowed clients anywhere in the world to open accounts, transfer money, write checks by computer and obtain credit cards around the clock.
Citing confidentiality laws, Government officials here declined to say how many depositors the bank had had or how much money it had reported in accounts.
John E. St. Luce, the Minister of Finance, said he did not get directly involved "in this sort of thing," and Keith Hurst, Financial Secretary, declined to discuss the collapse.
Bank records here, however, make it clear that the bank ran afoul of the rules almost from the beginning, but was allowed to stay in business until depositors began complaining recently that they no longer had access to their accounts. An official letter sent by the Ministry of Finance in October 1995 noted that the bank had failed to file an audited financial statement for 1994.
Those initial indications were followed by other, more public warnings. Last year, the Bank of England reportedly issued a statement cautioning investors "to be careful about putting any money into the EUB," and in May the Idaho Department of Finance declared the bank to be operating illegally and ordered it to stop soliciting deposits from Idaho residents over the Internet.
"There was a lack of disclosure, a lack of information on the principals, a lack of any of the licenses or charters that would have allowed this bank to conduct business legally in this state or this country," Gavin Gee, director of the department in Idaho, said in a telephone interview from Boise. "While the Internet is a wonderful means of obtaining information and doing business, it is also a means for fraud, and to the extent we have jurisdiction, we have a duty to protect our residents," he said.
In an interview here, Agnes James, permanent secretary of the Ministry of Finance, said the Government of Antigua had taken several steps to prevent similar cases, including "a stricter watch on quarterly reports." She said there were also plans for the ministry's two bank inspectors to get additional help so "they can go in on a monthly basis" to "check on the banks indicated for this type of treatment."
Earlier this year, responding to pressure from Washington, Prime Minister Lester Bird said a thorough investigation would be made of about a half-dozen banks identified as being linked to Russian crime groups. But the inquiry remains incomplete.
As a result of the European Union Bank case, Mrs. James said, "there will be some changes, some tighter sanctions as far as due diligence is concerned" when applications to charter a bank here are made.
Mr. St. Luce, the Finance Minister, said: "All that is needed has been set in motion. We have just passed very, very strong legislation, vetted by the Americans and the British, on money laundering. We have a committee looking into these things, and are getting everything that is needed operating."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 13, 1998, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Aug. 20 described the operations of the European Union Bank, an offshore institution based in Antigua. The article said two of the bank's original directors, Aleksandr P. Konanikhin and Mikhail B. Khodorovsky, were officers of the Menatep Bank of Moscow. It quoted unidentified British and American officials who said Menatep had links to Russian organized crime.
In fairness, The Times should have sought a response from Menatep, Mr. Khodorovsky and Mr. Ko nanikhin.
Mr. Khodorovsky has since said the allegations about Menatep were "baseless" and "entirely false." He said last fall that Menatep had earned a B+ rating from Thomson Bank Watch, an international rating service, and had recently gained approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell stock in the United States. He added that the bank had ties to the World Bank and was a "respected, reputable financial institution."
Mr. Khodorovsky said he withdrew as a director of the European Union Bank in 1994, a week after its registration, and played no role in its operations before then.
Mr. Konanikhin said the allegations against him, including an arrest in the United States, visa violations and Russian charges of having embezzled $8 million, resulted from "disinformation" by Russian intelligence, which influenced or duped officials at the United States Department of Justice.
This editors' note was delayed pending the outcome of a lawsuit in London against The International Herald Tribune over the article. The Times was not sued, and the suit has now been settled.

SECTION: Section C; Page 11; Column 3; Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1780 words

HEADLINE: A Song Sails Forth From Cuba;
Despite Restrictions, the Island's Arts Find a Growing U.S. Audience

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS 

 BODY:
Cubans call it "Cubanitis," a cultural virus that affects outsiders. The signs are obvious: foreigners, Europeans, or, sometimes, United States citizens, get lost in the culture and try to become Cuban, wearing beads from the Santeria religion, learning the newest dances, even marrying a Cuban. (There are towns in Spain where a growing portion of the female population is Cuban: first the barber went and found a wife, then the butcher . . .)
But Cubanitis does not just affect individuals. In the United States today, interest in Cuban culture, while a far cry from the days when the mambo ruled and Desi Arnaz sang "Babalu," is beginning to grow. The old romance between the United States and Cuba, changed by the cold war, is stirring, ahead of any political rapprochement. (Although the Clinton Administration said it was considering an easing of the ban on travel to Cuba during the Pope's visit there in January, no permanent reduction was expected in the restrictions.) 
 The growing interest in Cuban culture may be due in part to a sense among some people that political change may be coming to the island and with it an opening up to the world. Meanwhile, for many Americans, it still is a forbidden zone that puts on a spectacular party with powerful indigenous music. Because the United States Government's loosening of visa restrictions on traveling Cuban musicians, more Americans are experiencing the music firsthand.
This new interest is still far from the mainstream; it is limited to people who are open to influences from abroad and who seem to be tapping into a longstanding cultural relationship between the two countries. It can be counted in record sales in the thousands, not millions, and in in a growing number of concerts and club dates in a few major cities.
This summer the United States has welcomed some of the best of Havana's performers -- including NG La Banda, Pablo Milanes and Issac Delgado -- tour the country, drawing large audiences. And because of a loophole in the Helms-Burton Act, which prohibits trade between the United States and Cuba, American record companies have been able to license recordings by Cuban musicians, circumventing the embargo, and much of the best contemporary Cuban music is available in this country or soon will be.
On a smaller scale, too, interest in Cuban culture is expanding quickly. At Caribbean Music and Dance, a San Francisco-based organization that specializes in educational tours of Cuba, business has flowered.
"We did one workshop in Cuban folklore six years ago when we started; now we do 11 events," said Melissa Daar, the company's president. "The first one had 30 people from the Bay Area, and now we have 300 people a year from all over the country. The kinds of people have also changed. The interest is broader, and people want to go to all the major cultural centers, like Matanzas and Santiago. They're getting more sophisticated."
At Descarga, a mail-order company in Brooklyn that specializes in recordings from the Spanish-speaking Caribbean, business has tripled over the last three years.
"I sell as much as I can get," said Bruce Polin, the owner. "But I can't get enough stock. I'm always sold out of Cuban material, and I could sell, for example, 2,000 copies immediately of a new Los Van Van if I had it. And I'm just a mail-order company."
Intellectuals and celebrities are making the pilgrimage to Havana, flying first to Cancun or the Bahamas to evade the United States restrictions on travel to Cuba and using the annual Havana Film Festival, which features work from across Latin America, as an excuse for going, or the Havana Biennial, an art show whose reputation is steadily rising.
"When I lived in Havana, between the years of 1993 and 1995, I saw a huge increase in Americans coming to Havana, writing pieces and researching books," said Jon Lee Anderson, an American who lives in Spain. He is the author of "Che" (Grove Press), the recent biography of Che Guevara, the Argentine radical who helped propel the Cuban revolution. "Tourism tripled while I was there, but there was this ever-growing river of journalists and academics pounding on our doors to get at the story."
This is happening against a backdrop of political efforts by anti-Castro Cuban exiles in the United States to shape American public policy on Cuba. In Miami and Houston, where there are large and vocal Cuban communities, concerts by Cuban artists are regular targets of demonstrations. Many Cuban artists no longer bother to perform in Miami.
What this all signals is the resurgence of the long, complicated relationship between the two countries, one formed in part by contentious politics going back to the Spanish-American War of 1898, after which the United States recognized Cuba's independence from Spain but exerted a dominant economic interest of its own there.
From cigars to literature, Havana and New York were long regular trading partners. The Cuban poet and patriot Jose Marti spent time early in this century in New York City. And Cuba was a fabled spot for Americans like Ernest Hemingway. The Mafia moved in; gambling and prostitution gave Havana one form of notoriety, while the constant revolutions in Cuban music made their way north.
Even the breakdown of relations after the revolution, with the Cuban missile crisis and the Bay of Pigs operation, paradoxically joined the countries together. Not only do the two countries share some of the more intense moments of the cold war, but the subsequent attempts by the United States Government to sever cultural ties has made Cuba a forbidden place that inspires more than curiosity; discovering it is like coming across a long-lost relative.
For all the political oppression, the country still fascinates, and that's because Cuba and the United States share more than a few things. In some senses, President Fidel Castro has been a romantic figure to some Americans, who first saw him as a David fighting a Goliath.
And in Cuba's racial mix, its cosmopolitanism, its dual respect for both its European tradition and its native identity, the country seems remarkably similar to the United States, only 90 miles away.
"I think Cuba is part of our psyche, our own historical landscape, and it inhabits part of our imagination as no other place does," said Mr. Anderson. "Cuba was to parents of the baby-boomer generation where they'd go for dirty weekends or a honeymoon. The recently ended cold war imprinted Cuba in the public imagination in another way."
 
Wandering Into A Parallel Universe
American visitors to Havana often find themselves wandering into what seems like a parallel universe with a highly intelligent population, but one oddly untouched by modernity. There is a sense that, for all of its problems, the place has some sort of prelapsarian innocence, one that could vanish with the fall of Mr. Castro.
"There's a sense there of something we've lost," said Mr. Anderson. "It's so undeveloped, it has avoided the Latin shantytown syndrome, the American cultural death due to monoculturalism, the spread of the subdivisions and the rampant overdevelopment of coasts, all the things that have devastated our own country."
But the growing interest in the country also comes from what is seen as a cultural flowering there. Wandering around Havana, some visitors feel a change in the air, an excitement that is immediately recognizable, even if political oppression abounds, along with a feeling of despair and stagnation generated by a society where social mobility is equal to exile.
"There's a tremendous interest in Cuban art now, and it's building," said Jeffry Keough, the director of exhibitions at the Massachusetts College of Art in Boston, which has had several exhibits of Cuban works. Although many young artists have had to leave Cuba to work freely, "the ones that are still there are being watched carefully, by both the Government and by galleries outside the country," he said. "They're the most exotic of the exotics."
Ned Sublette, the owner of Qbadisc, a company in Manhattan that specializes in Cuban music, spends a portion of each year in Cuba doing business. "The creativity of the street is incredible," he said.
 
A Land Rich In Culture
Cubans "have an education, but they don't have much information," he said. "The information they do have is about themselves. But if you're going to go inward, it's hard to think of a better place, because it is so rich culturally. And right now there is no better expression of the Cuban commitment to the arts than in music."
An exemplar of that music, NG La Banda, the group that revolutionized Cuban popular music in the early 90's, played at Lincoln Center last month. Pablo Milanes, the political singer-songwriter and one of Cuba's most famous musicians, will be performing there, too. Los Van Van, which played New York City last year, toured the West Coast this summer, drawing large crowds. The American trumpeter Roy Hargrove spent the summer touring with a partially Cuban band and used the musicians on an album. In Havana, musicians from the United States spend weeks studying the music and soaking up the new sounds.
David Bither, a vice president of Nonesuch Records in New York, licensed three Cuban albums from a company in England; one is a collaboration between the American guitarist Ry Cooder and a group of Cuban musicians.
"I haven't felt this sort of interest in a project in years," said Mr. Bither. "I sent a few promotional copies out recently, and we had an overwhelming response. It feels primed to explode."
And that sort of interest translates into politics.
 
A Warming Based on Music
"If the barriers between the two countries come down, it'll in part be because of the musicians," said Mr. Sublette. "The history of the opening will be in part the history of the desire of audiences here to experience all this music from there."
Bill Martinez, a lawyer in San Francisco who, with his company, Latino Entertainment Partners, specializes in Cuban music, sees the change. "There's a lot more accommodation by the State Department about letting Cuban artists and bands into the United States now," he said. "I actually haven't heard of one request that has been refused.
"I think, speculating a bit, that the State Department feels that it's stupid to shut the door on musicians. To be a bit paranoid, by letting the musicians in here, we're probably fomenting change in Cuba, because the musicians have seen how the other side lives, and they take the story back with them. We may be used by the Government, but we're also giving the people what they want."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Strength in Mexican Economy Bolsters Peso Against Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar dropped to a 10-month low against the Mexican peso yesterday on signs of an economic rebound in Mexico.
It also fell against the yen amid fears of escalating trade friction between the United States and Japan. 
 Traders said foreign investors were encouraged by a report of unexpected economic growth in Mexico and by higher interest rates in Mexico's bond market.
In late New York trading, the dollar settled at 7.7450 pesos, down from 7.750 on Tuesday and its lowest level since 7.7410 on Oct. 21.
On Monday, Mexico's Government reported that growth in gross domestic product exceeded expectations in the second quarter, putting the economy on pace to surpass the Government's projections for the year.
Also in New York, the dollar was quoted at 117.75 yen, down from 118.21 late on Tuesday. It rose to 1.8567 marks from 1.8388 on Tuesday, as investors expected the Bundesbank, the German central bank, to remain reluctant to raise interest rates.
The dollar weakened early against the yen after the Clinton Administration publicly criticized Japan for a delay in the opening of its auto parts market.
The dollar reached an intraday low of 117.53 yen before rebounding slightly later in the day, even after the Commerce Department reported that the United States trade deficit with Japan rose sharply in June.
Commerce Secretary William M. Daley and Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, complained in a letter to Japan's transportation minister about the slow pace in reducing red tape that impedes the access of foreign companies to Japan's auto parts market.
Mr. Daley said the United States would seek faster deregulation when officials of both countries meet in September to review a 1995 agreement that was aimed at increasing sales of American-made cars and parts in Japan.
Against the mark, the dollar was again buoyed by the German central bank's decision to leave a key short-term interest rate unchanged on Tuesday. Traders said they expected the Bundesbank to do the same at another meeting today.

HEADLINE: Two Colombian Cabinet Ministers Forced Out in New Scandal

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Two Cabinet ministers have been forced to resign after they were secretly recorded discussing awarding radio frequencies to friends of the administration of President Ernest Samper. The frequencies were supposed to be up for public auction.
The two, Saulo Arboleda, the Communications Minister, and Rodrigo Villamizar, the Minister of Mining and Energy, stepped down Tuesday night after a part of their 12-minute conversation was published in the newsweekly magazine Semana. Congress prepared a motion of censure, while Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the Nobel Prize-winning author, withdrew a bid that he and a group of friends had jointly submitted to renew their license for a television news program. 
 The Attorney General's office pledged to investigate the process by which the Government awarded 85 FM radio frequencies on July 24. Mr. Arboleda came under widespread criticism for his handling of the bidding after he voided the results twice. He rebuffed accusations of favoritism by insisting he was upholding the fairness of the auction.
On the tape, however, Mr. Arboleda is heard discussing a "50-50 split," presumably of the total number of licences, between the station owners and "friends of the President." Mr. Villamizar is heard to agree: "We'll see how we'll distribute it."
The magazine said the tape was made a few days before the awarding of the bids -- at the same time as Mr. Arboleda was publicly protesting his innocence. The tape was broadcast on television news programs on Tuesday night.
At one point in the conversation, the two men say they do not understand why President Samper favors Mauricio Guzman, the Mayor of Cali, to win one of the frequencies. Mayor Guzman is under investigation for illicit enrichment, the usual charge for accepting money from drug dealers.
The resignations were the latest blow for a beleaguered administration. In addition to the President's long-standing conflict with Washington, which has never hidden its belief that Cali drug barons bankrolled his election, the country is engulfed in violence and the economy has ground to a virtual halt. So far, 12 of Mr. Samper's top officials have had to resign amid scandal.
This week's revelations came after the Government had already faced criticism for using its control over television stations to retaliate for aggressive reporting on the investigation into Mr. Samper's campaign finances. In the spring, the Government announced it would withdraw some broadcast news programs and subject future ones to twice yearly reviews for objectivity and public service.
After the scandal broke, the President ordered the state intelligence service and the Defense Ministry to track down whoever made the recording and determine how it reached the press. As the criticisms grew throughout Tuesday, some in Congress called for the President's resignation, and even allies of Mr. Samper, like his former Interior Minister, Horacio Serpa, demanded that the ministers resign.
Criticizing an apparent lack of impartiality, Mr. Garcia Marquez told a local radio station that he had withdrawn his bid to renew the QAP television news program's license.
"If this was the official behavior with radio, it can't be any different when it comes to television news programs," Mr. Garcia Marquez said. "They can't have one set of morals for radio and another for television."

HEADLINE: Merril Eisenbud, 82, Safety Expert Known for Work on Atomic Energy

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Merril Eisenbud, an environmental scientist who was the first health and safety chief of the United States Atomic Energy Commission and the first head of New York City's Environmental Protection Agency, died on Friday at the Carolina Meadows retirement community in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 82 and a former resident of Sterling Forest, N.Y.
The cause was leukemia, his family said. 
 In a career lasting six decades, he also taught and worked for 25 years at New York University Medical Center and the university's Institute of Environmental Medicine upstate, retiring in 1984.
Professor Eisenbud, the author of books, book chapters and about 200 scientific articles, had continued to write and teach.
He was a practical man who sought to balance ideals and realities in environmental matters -- an attitude that did not always sit well with partisans on either side. His arguments were laid out most recently in "How Clean Is Clean? How Safe Is Safe?: A Review of Environmental Priorities" (Cogito Books, 1993).
In his view, pristine conditions, even if they could be regained, were no practical choice. Rather he looked for the best possible solutions in terms of economic and political feasibility in an overpopulated world.
His focus professionally, governmentally and academically was on the effects of chemical and radioactive pollution on human health, a field that was largely unstudied when he began his career.
A native of Manhattan, he graduated in electrical engineering from N.Y.U. in 1936. He spent the next 10 years as an industrial hygienist for the Liberty Mutual Life Insurance Company. War came and so did atomic weapons tests, and with the mushroom clouds arose environmental concerns. His work took him to the field, to factories and mines, to rivers and lakes marred by industrial pollutants, and to places near where atomic explosions had spread their deadly rays.
In 1947, the Atomic Energy Commission recruited him to direct its health and safety laboratory. The topics of his papers then turned from purely industrial safety to concerns about radioactive dust from nuclear detonations and related subjects. He contributed significantly to scientific methods of measuring such fallout and its effects.
The commission reassigned him in 1957 to New York to manage its operations in the Northeast. In 1959, he joined the staff at N.Y.U. as a professor and director of the laboratory for environmental studies at its Institute of Environmental Medicine.
Professor Eisenbud took a leave of absence in 1968, when Mayor John V. Lindsay put him in charge of the city's newly formed Environmental Protection Agency. It was one of Mr. Lindsay's superagencies, bringing the Departments of Sanitation, Water Resources and Air Resources under a single administrator. He stayed in that post until 1970.
His books included "An Environmental Odyssey: People, Pollution, and Politics in the Life of a Practical Scientist" (1990), "Environmental Radioactivity: From Natural, Industrial and Military Sources" (3d edition, 1987), and "The Human Environment Past, Present, and Future" (1983). All remain in print.
He was an adviser on radiation hazards to the World Health Organization from 1956 to 1980, and a past member of the National Council on Radiation Protection and Measurements, and the New York State Health Advisory Council.
He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Irma Onish Eisenbud; their three sons, Elliott, of Sacramento, Calif., Michael, of Stamford, Conn., and Frederick, of Fort Salonga, N.Y.; his brother, Leon, of Naples, Fla.; a sister, Elsa LaPook of Manhattan; and eight grandchildren.

HEADLINE: First Part of Thai Bailout Is Authorized by the I.M.F.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund today approved the first part of a $16 billion international rescue package for Thailand, and the Clinton Administration announced that it would help provide short-term loans, if needed, to help Thailand stem a currency crisis that has threatened other nations in Southeast Asia.
The action taken by the I.M.F today, which was expected, authorized up to $4 billion in loans to the Thai Government following the devaluation of its currency last month. Japan and other Asian nations said last week that they would take the primary responsibility for bailing out Thailand, without American or European help, in return for a commitment from the Thai Government to enact strict financial controls. 
 But it appears increasingly likely that Thailand may need a "bridge loan" of roughly $1 billion dollars before aid from the I.M.F., the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank is available. Late today, the Bank for International Settlements, the Swiss-based coordinator of the world's central banks, said it was prepared to provide that financing.
About a quarter of that sum, or roughly $250 million, could come from the Treasury Department's Exchange Stabilization Fund, the same fund that was used to finance the bailout of Mexico two years ago. By comparison to the Mexican case, however, the United States participation in the Thai rescue package is minuscule; Mexico borrowed more than $12 billion from Washington. All of those funds have since been paid back.
American officials have said repeatedly that they wanted Japan to bear the brunt of the Thai bailout, because Japanese banks are major creditors in Thailand and Japanese companies have a large stake there. But in a statement issued today, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said that "the United States is prepared to participate in a short-term, multilateral bridging facility, if needed and under appropriate conditions, to provide liquidity in support of Thailand's program."
Mr. Rubin, who is on vacation, approved the move last week, Administration officials said. The short-term loans would be repaid, officials said, by funds from the international aid package.
The relatively small American participation in the Thai bailout is partly intended to avoid the political firestorm that accompanied the loans to Mexico in early 1995. When Congress refused to approve the use of taxpayer funds for direct loans, President Clinton acted on his own, authorizing the use of the Exchange Stabilization Fund, which is primarily intended to protect the value of the United States dollar.
In return for the $16 billion loan package, Thailand has agreed to a series of fiscal changes, including higher taxes and the closings of scores of financial institutions that made unsound loans or investments in the Thai economy, one of the fastest growing in the world until a few years ago. Last month, the country abandoned its efforts to defend its currency, which had been linked to the value of the United States dollar. The currency, the baht, has since dropped in value by more than 20 percent.
The program the I.M.F. approved today will make a loan of $1.6 billion available immediately. The second phase of the loan will be approved in late November, if Thailand meets the economic targets it has committed to in recent weeks.
In a statement, the I.M.F. said that its credits would only be used to "help finance the balance of payments gap and to rebuild the official reserves of the Bank of Thailand," which were depleted in the failed effort to defend the baht. But that will free money for Thailand to help some of its reeling private banks.
That is the part of the program that makes American officials nervous. Since the Mexican bailout, Mr. Rubin and his staff have talked often of the "moral hazard" created by rescue plans, because they often save large creditors and investors from huge losses. They have urged those investors and creditors be forced to suffer large losses, as a warning that they cannot depend on being bailed out by the I.M.F. and other international institutions.
"If you say you are going to have more market discipline, you have to make sure someone takes a hit," said Morris Goldstein, a former I.M.F. official who now studies international financial rescue plans for the Institute for International Economics in Washington.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Trade Data Cause a Dip In Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities turned lower in light trading yesterday, after a strong trade report suggested that the economy might be expanding quickly enough to accelerate inflation and thus increase chances that the Federal Reserve might raise short-term rates this year.
Talk that an Asian central bank was selling bills also weighed on the market, especially the long end. 
 By late in the day the 30-year bond dropped 13/32 to a price of 97 27/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, rose to 6.54 percent, from 6.51 percent on Tuesday.
The trade deficit for June narrowed by 14.5 percent, to a smaller-than-expected $8.2 billion from a revised $9.5 billion in May. Exports jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent to a record, as imports declined seven-tenths of 1 percent, thanks to moderating domestic demand. Some market participants saw the jump in exports as suggesting that robust demand for American-made goods could bolster manufacturing and speed up the economy.
Some economists have already begun revising upward their estimates for second-quarter growth, based on yesterday's trade numbers. Analysts said that the appearance of a resurgence in economic growth could change the Fed's view of the economy and lead it to raise rates in an effort to avert inflation. On Tuesday, the Fed's Federal Open Market Committee left short-term interest rates unchanged. Its next meeting is scheduled for Sept. 30.
"The combined impact of the lower trade gap and higher inventories than the Commerce Department estimated initially will cause second-quarter G.D.P. growth to be revised upward to 3 to 3.5 percent," Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, said. Growth in the gross domestic product had been initally projected at a 2.2 percent rate for the second quarter.
The narrower trade deficit will add about 1 percentage point to the second-quarter G.D.P. revision, said Cheryl R. Katz, senior economist at Merrill Lynch & Company. "It now looks like G.D.P. grew about 4 percent, given a smaller trade deficit and higher inventory accumulation than previously assumed."
Patricia DeBlank Klink, president of Advisors Capital Management, which specializes in fixed-income portfolio management, said that even though the trade number had raised third-quarter estimates for G.D.P. to slightly more than 3 percent, from 2 percent several months ago, she expected that the fourth quarter might slip a bit. "There seems to be a self-correcting mechanism taking place," she said.
"No one can argue that bonds are expensive now in relation to current calendar rates of inflation," Ms. Klink added.
Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of government bond trading at Cowen & Company, said that early talk of an Asian central bank selling in the front end of the curve dragged down the market, "while the Treasury's announcement today on the size of next week's note auctions gave market participants something else to worry about."
The Treasury said it would auction $15.5 billion of two-year notes on Tuesday and $11.5 billion of five-year notes on Wednesday. In when-issued trading ahead of those auctions, the two-year maturity was being offered at a price to yield 5.87 percent, and the 5-year at a price to yield 6.11 percent.
The notion of increased supply added some downward pressure in the market yesterday, as dealers and traders sought a yield level that would encourage distribution of the securities next week.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The greatest good for the greatest number? Try Lojack.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IF you wire your home and put a warning decal on the window, you're less likely to be burglarized. But frustrated thieves are more likely to break into the house next door. What would happen, though, if you carefully concealed a silent alarm linked to a security service?
Burglars wouldn't be deterred from entering your house but they would be more likely to be caught in the act. And you'd be doing your neighbors a favor by reducing the number of bad guys on the street. In the language of Econ 101, there would be a "positive externality" to your choice of alarms. 
 In fact, deterrence is most of the point of having a house alarm: nobody wants to confront a thief in the kitchen. But auto theft is another matter. And a company based in Massachusetts, called Lojack, is trying to revolutionize protection against car thefts with its own version of the silent alarm.
It apparently works better than anyone anticipated. Two researchers, Ian Ayes of Yale and Steven Levitt of the University of Chicago, estimate that adding the Lojack system to three cars in a high-crime area reduces auto theft by one car a year. The only catch: individual car owners must pay for the installation, even though the biggest share of the benefits go to others.
Lojack retrieval is built around a small homing beacon. Hidden in the car, the beacon waits passively until the vehicle is reported stolen and is remotely activated from a radio signal tower. Then, police cruisers equipped with tracking receivers can identify the stolen vehicle by a five-digit code.
Since the company was founded in 1986, it has marketed the system in 12 metropolitan areas with serious auto theft problems -- Boston; Miami; Newark; Los Angeles; Chicago; Atlanta; Detroit; New York; Washington; Providence, R.I.; Tampa, Fla., and Norfolk, Va. The company would not disclose how many cars had been protected in each city. But it did provide the data to the two researchers for the year 1994, and they used it to isolate Lojack's impact from other statistical factors influencing rates of car theft.
The results, published by the National Bureau of Research, were remarkable. Boston experienced a 50 percent decline in thefts, transforming it from an auto-theft capital to a city with a theft rate only slightly higher than average. According to Mr. Ayres and Mr. Levitt's estimates, going from no hidden protection to Lojack in 2 percent of cars -- roughly the company's average market penetration -- reduces theft losses by 40 percent in central cities and about 13 percent within the range of Lojack's metropolitan coverage.
These numbers sound too good to be true, and in one sense they are. For while Lojack installation triples the probability of arresting a thief, it isn't much of a direct deterrent because relatively few cars are protected even in the high-penetration areas. Indeed, in Boston, the city with the most cars equipped with Lojack systems, the chance of being caught in a randomly selected stolen car has risen by less than one percentage point.
What the Lojack beacon apparently does do very effectively, though, is to disrupt recidivism. Career criminals account for a disproportionate share of auto thefts, stealing dozens or even hundreds of cars a year. So even a small rise in the probability of getting caught during each theft can have a large impact on the number of professionals in prison.
More important, most cars are stolen for their parts rather than resold intact. Theft rings typically operate centralized stripping centers. Hence, putting a "chop shop" out of business can lead to the recovery of dozens of cars, along with arrests of professional thieves.
According to the company, Lojack has led to raids on 53 chop shops in the Los Angeles area alone. That helps to explain why auto thefts fell 20 percent there in the four years after the company entered that market in 1990.
If Lojack is such a blessing, what is stopping people from buying its system? According to the researchers, 90 percent of the benefits go to non-buyers in the form of lower community-wide theft rates.
Having a Lojack system in your own car does increase the probability of it being recovered quickly, reducing the average loss from about $5,000 to $1,000. But since insurance usually covers all but a small deductible, paying $595 for Lojack amounts to an act of good citizenship rather than self-interest.
The key to making the market for Lojack work efficiently, the researchers suggest, is to require insurers to pass on the benefits in the form of premium discounts. Massachusetts, New York, New Jersey and Rhode Island do mandate discounts, but they are only loosely linked to the neighborhood benefits. And until 1996, Illinois actually banned insurance discounts, a fact that likely explains Lojack's poor sales in Chicago.

HEADLINE: A Free-Speech Senator Fights Limits on Donations

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
"To Common Cause, I'm Darth Vader," says Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who indeed radiates a certain pride and cunning in his eagerness to stand up once more against efforts to rein in the current system of financing political campaigns.
"But to the American Civil Liberties Union, I'm Luke Skywalker," he adds, smiling mischievously at having assembled a most motley political cadre to lead next month in the name of protecting unfettered political speech. 
 Reformers plan to test whether their call to limit big-money campaigning has taken on any life from the Senate's hearings this summer into campaign abuses. Senator McConnell and his backers -- from anti-abortion lobbyists to civil libertarians -- plan to demonstrate that it has not.
"I'm very confident this bill is not going to pass," he said, taking aim at the McCain-Feingold bill after a decade of combatting campaign spending restrictions. The 55-year-old master of Kentucky politics has become the dominant figure and closet hero on the issue in Congress, where most members dare not speak up so forthrightly for the incumbent-friendly fund-raising system that helps keep them here.
Far from being defensive, the Senator argues that current spending on campaigns is hardly scandalous but, rather, "minuscule." It amounts to perhaps 1 percent of all television advertising, he says, averaging $3.89 per eligible Congressional voter last year -- the price of a fast-food "value meal," as he likes to put it.
As a political combatant, he does not shrink from Darth Vader comparisons, having directed the ethics inquiry into former Senator Bob Packwood's women-groping scandal with an unapologetic rejection of the public hearings demanded by critics. On the Skywalker ledger of libertarians, Mr. McConnell's appreciation of the First Amendment free-speech guarantee has seen him come out in opposition to Congress's perennial attempts to overturn the Supreme Court's protection of flag burning.
Braced by the Supreme Court's firm ruling that equates uncrimped campaign spending and free speech, Senator McConnell argues tenaciously that the political spending should not be curtailed.
"I don't think it's a scandal at all," the Senator said of modern political spending, which reached an estimated $2 billion last year for the Presidential and Congressional races, nearly double the spending of 1992. "I think it ought to be applauded and encouraged. For Americans to contribute to the party they believe in and the candidate of their choice, bearing in mind these contributions are limited and fully disclosed, I think is something that is healthy for democracy."
Through the Senate hearings on campaign abuses last month, Senator McConnell could hear the reformers' drumbeat growing, intended to galvanize support for the McCain-Feingold bill, which would impose spending limits. Newspaper editorials acid with moralizing denunciations of the current system were distributed daily at the hearings alongside exhibits on the Clinton re-election campaign's return of funds improperly raised abroad.
The hearings have come up with nothing sensational enough to seize the public imagination and certainly nothing to impress the vast majority of Republican lawmakers opposed to the McCain-Feingold bill. The measure tries a carrot-and-stick approach around First Amendment obstacles, inviting candidates to accept voluntary spending limits in return for limited but free television time and reduced-rate campaign mailings.
Thus far, the hearings by the Governmental Affairs Committee have laid bare some of the frenzied searches by both parties for large sums donated to general party coffers as "soft money," unregulated money supposedly generic -- that is, for parties, not specific candidates -- but used increasingly for candidate strategems.
"There's been an explosion in soft money because of the restrictions on hard money," Mr. McConnell contended, referring to regulated money donated directly to candidates. "What we need to do is dramatically free up the parties to operate in hard money." He says the contribution limits set two decades ago should be tripled to allow for inflation.
"I'm open to some restrictions on soft money," he said, providing hard money is liberalized.
"You can't dam up speech," said the Senator, noting that the Supreme Court found in its 1976 decision in Buckley v. Valeo that "the First Amendment denies Government the power to determine that spending to promote one's political views is wasteful, excessive or unwise."
In Mr. McConnell's view, the last Presidential campaign was most remarkable for its great chase after soft money as a loophole strategy to circumvent the reforms of public financing and voluntary spending limits already in place -- strictures that reformers now want to apply to Congress.
"So what happened?" Mr. McConnell asked of the Presidential race. "Candidates took the public money, agreed not to speak too much and then used every trick in the book to get around it."
A total of $250 million in Presidential soft money, triple that of the 1992 race, was spent in addition to the $62 million that the two major Presidential candidates each received in hard money from taxpayers.
Political speech, the Senator insists, "has gone in the soft money direction and that has produced these mega-contributions which tend to get everybody's attention and which I don't particularly like either."
But, far from seeing the rise in political spending as proof of the buying and selling of influence, Mr. McConnell is preparing to argue before his fellow politicians and the nation that money is the root of popular, not special, interest.
"The numbers go up when there's healthy competition," he said, "And we have much healthier political competition than we had five or six years ago."
