HEADLINE: NATO TROOPS RAID SERB HARD-LINERS IN A BOSNIAN CITY

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: BANJA LUKA, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Aug. 20

 BODY:
British soldiers backed by armored vehicles seized six police sites in this city today, effectively wiping out the local power base of Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader who is wanted on war-crimes charges.
The move by the NATO-led force openly pits the 31,000 peacekeepers against the wartime leaders, based in Pale, who still command loyalty among thousands of police officers and wield near-total control of the economy in the Serbian-controlled portion of Bosnia. 
 NATO officials did not say whether they planned any action against the stronghold in Pale. And some expressed concern that today's raid in Banja Luka would incite Dr. Karadzic's supporters to violence.
Bosnia, which seceded from Serbian-dominated Yugoslavia in 1992, consists of a Bosnian Serb republic and a Muslim-Croat federation. The raid, at dawn, split the Bosnian Serb sector into areas controlled by Dr. Karadzic and by his successor as the sector's president, Biljana Plavsic.
Some 350 heavily armed British troops, with American Apache helicopter gunships hovering overhead, burst unannounced into the boxy Banja Luka police headquarters, the police academy, a special police barracks and three district police stations.
The troops swiftly herded unarmed Bosnian Serb policemen in blue uniforms from the buildings. There was no resistance.
The decision to take over police installations, confiscate truckloads of weapons from Karadzic supporters and build a police force loyal to Mrs. Plavsic adds up to a far more muscular, interventionist role for the NATO-led forces.
"It's a gamble," said a senior United Nations official, "and a very risky one. We have cut the enclave into two factions, and we don't yet know how all this will play out. We cannot rule out violence."
The outside world has expressed support for Mrs. Plavsic in her campaign against Dr. Karadzic, whom she accuses of rampant corruption and mismanagement, including pocketing tens of millions of dollars from the sale of cigarettes and gasoline.
Despite having formally relinquished power, Dr. Karadzic retains an iron grip on the Bosnian Serb republic. Western officials agree that as long as he wields influence behind the scenes, there is little chance for progress toward fulfilling the requirements of the Dayton peace accords, which ended the war in Bosnia in late 1995.
Under the agreement, Bosnia was to become a loose federation with joint institutions that would permit refugees to return to their homes and would bring war criminals to justice.
Instead, Bosnia remains partitioned into hostile Serbian, Croatian and Muslim enclaves. In the Serbian enclave, refugees have been almost entirely prevented from returning, and war criminals move freely.
Among the NATO-led force -- including about 8,000 Americans -- which is to withdraw from Bosnia next spring, there is a growing sense of urgency to make the peace work. The peacekeeping troops, although they arrested a Bosnian Serb war-crimes suspect in July and shot another who resisted arrest, have largely taken a passive role until today.
They were accompanied on their sweep by about 50 unarmed United Nations international police monitors, who spent the day hauling away rocket launchers, boxes of new sniper rifles, 800 hand grenades and dozens of assault rifles that had been delivered to the police stations in the last two days, the monitors said.
Capt. Bob McConnachie, a British explosives expert, was unloading the confiscated ordnance this afternoon at the main British base outside Banja Luka. On the asphalt in front of him lay rocket-propelled grenades, hand grenades, booby-trapped books and clocks, heavy machine guns and anti-personnel mines.
"This is enough for about 2,000 heavily equipped troops," he said. "We were all stunned by the enormity of the weapons being stockpiled. It looks like they had started a small explosives factory, and there were boxes of new sniper rifles and assault rifles. This isn't the kind of stuff used in normal police duties."
The weapons, Mrs. Plavsic said tonight, "were meant to be used against us, against all who opposed the Pale leadership. These people in Pale wanted bloodshed."
Disarming the police by no means ends the threat they pose. Bosnia is awash with weapons, and the forces loyal to Dr. Karadzic have ample arsenals at their disposal.
The decision to move against the police stations was made late Tuesday night by Mrs. Plavsic and Robert Gelbard, the United States envoy to the region, in a meeting in Banja Luka.
Although Mrs. Plavsic has been little more than a figurehead President, she now appears able to secure a real power base in Banja Luka with NATO assistance.
The Karadzic-controlled state television in Pale tonight led its news broadcast with a blistering attack against Mrs. Plavsic, saying she had staged a coup. It called the NATO-led peacekeeping troops "an occupation force."
The Bosnian Serb cabinet, dominated by Dr. Karadzic's supporters, compared Mrs. Plavsic to Mussolini.
"These events can be considered a state coup," the broadcast said. "They are much more than that actually, because now it is obvious that what is at work is an attempt at foreign occupation with the help of domestic collaborators."
American officials say they are ready to hand Mrs. Plavsic some $9 million in aid for the area around Banja Luka that she now controls. By backing her in the current power struggle, international officials hope to push Dr. Karadzic to the margins and carry out the Dayton accords. They have hinted that he may soon be captured and turned over for trial in the International War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague.
But Mrs. Plavsic is an odd ally of the West. She was a zealous supporter of the war and the effort to annihilate the Muslims in Sarajevo, Bosnia's capital, arguing that they belonged to an inferior civilization that should be eradicated.
She is a deeply religious woman who has strong backing from the Serbian Orthodox Church, one of the institutions that championed the Serbian campaign that left more than 200,000 dead and more than a million Muslims homeless. When she was appointed to run for President by Dr. Karadzic, she was described by a senior United States official as a "stooge."
She says that she only wants to "protect the Serb republic" and that a wealthy clique of warlords in Pale is destroying the enclave by taking money that should be used to pay teachers, hospital employees and government officials.
She does not speak to her Bosnian Serb followers about letting Muslim and Croat refugees return or carrying out other controversial aspects of the Dayton agreement.
Mrs. Plavsic called earlier this month for elections in an attempt to replace the Karadzic-controlled Bosnian Serb assembly, which refused to endorse her call to dismiss the hard-line Interior Minister, Dragan Kijac, a close ally of Dr. Karadzic.
The assembly ignored her demand, and on Friday the Bosnian Serb Constitutional Court ruled against her call for new elections.
The decision to take over the police stations started out Sunday as an effort to curb the excesses of Mrs. Plavsic and her supporters.
On Sunday a well-equipped special police unit loyal to Mrs. Plavsic occupied the main Banja Luka police headquarers, saying there was evidence that the police were tapping the President's phones and had intimidated the members of the Constitutional Court. This was later confirmed by NATO officials who said they had found hundreds of audio and video surveillance tapes.
NATO forces moved in on Sunday afternoon, stripped the police unit of its weapons and expelled it from the building.
International officials said more than 100 pro-Karadzic police officers quickly arrived in Banja Luka and seized control of the main police station, which tonight was in the hands of NATO troops and a few police officers loyal to Mrs. Plavsic.

HEADLINE: Cambodian Ruler Demands Ouster of U.N. Rights Team

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 20

 BODY:
After promising that international groups could work freely in his country, the Cambodian leader, Hun Sen, struck a decidedly more confrontational tone today and asked the United Nations to replace its human rights team in Phnom Penh.
In a radio broadcast in Cambodia, Mr. Hun Sen demanded an apology from the United Nations for reporting that his forces had executed at least 40 supporters of Prince Norodom Ranariddh, whom Mr. Hun Sen unseated as his co-Prime Minister in a violent coup in July. 
 In his address, he went on to criticize the United States for calling the ouster of Prince Ranariddh undemocratic, and reached back to the Vietnam War years to taunt Washington.
"Don't be proud of yourself that you are a democracy and have human rights and freedom when you dropped bombs on our heads," he said, according to a translation of his speech by Reuters.
And he also criticized Asian leaders for meeting with Prince Ranariddh, and said that he was not prepared to wait until after an election in Cambodia next year to join the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, a group that deferred action on Cambodia's membership after the coup.
Earlier, in the days immediately after the coup when he was trying to win outside support for his actions, Mr. Hun Sen had promised diplomats and foreign governments that human rights groups would be free to work in Cambodia.
Today at the United Nations, Juan Carlos Brandt, a spokesman for Secretary General Kofi Annan, said that the organization's human rights monitor for Cambodia hoped to meet with Mr. Hun Sen in Phnom Penh in the next few days to discuss the issue. The monitor, Thomas Hammarberg of Sweden, has condemned the coup and accused Mr. Hun Sen of ruling by "fear and intimidation."
Mr. Hammarberg is in the process of compiling a report on the human rights situation in Cambodia for the next session of the General Assembly, which opens in mid-September.
Mr. Hun Sen's more belligerent tone follows a visit to Beijing last week, where he failed to win the approval of Cambodia's monarch, Norodom Sinhanouk, for the appointment of Ung Huot, the former Foreign Minister, to replace Prince Ranariddh, the King's son, as First Prime Minister.
In a statement circulated Tuesday to Cambodians abroad, the King, who has been under medical treatment in China since the beginning of the year, announced that he planned to return to Cambodia by the end of August to take up residence at Siem Reap, near the ancient temples of Angkor and "far from the politicians in Phnom Penh."
The King has traditionally been a unifying and influential, if powerless, figure in Cambodia. Diplomats say that it is hard to predict at this point what effect his return will have.
In recent weeks, Mr. Hun Sen has been trying to shore up support in diplomatic missions abroad by staffing them with supporters. At the United Nations, an important mission for the Cambodians, who are dependent on foreign aid for half their national budget, a standoff continues between the head of the mission, Ambassador Sisowath Sirirath, also a prince but from a different branch of the royal family, and Ouch Borith, formerly his deputy and a Hun Sen supporter, who is attempting to unseat him.
The case is an unusual one for the General Assembly credentials committee, which may be asked to decide which faction can claim recognition.
Until the events of July, Mr. Hun Sen and the Prince shared power as co-Prime Ministers in an arrangement worked out with the help of the United Nations. The dispute, then, is neither a peaceful transfer of power, after which ambassadors are often routinely replaced, nor the complete overthrow, when a new government simply claims the seat.
The challenge from Cambodia on human rights comes on the heels of similar confrontations with Congo, formerly named Zaire, and Burundi over the presence of international monitoring teams.
Human rights groups and some diplomats are critical of Secretary General Annan for allowing the new leader of Congo, Laurent Kabila to veto the choice of the monitor for a United Nations team assembled to investigate reports of massacres by Mr. Kabila's troops during the war that brought him power.
Soon after, Pierre Buyoya, who seized power a year ago in Burundi, which borders Congo, also began criticizing the United Nations human rights team there.
Today, the United Nations announced in Geneva that a new team, composed of Atsu-Koffi Amega, a former Supreme Court judge from Togo; Andrew Chigovera, Deputy Attorney General of Zimbabwe, and Reed Brody, an American with experience on other United Nations missions, would go to Congo on Aug. 23.
In Cambodia, there were problems two years ago after the United Nations Center for Human Rights was established in Phnom Penh, the first of its kind anywhere. Some Cambodian politicians wanted it closed, but the dispute was resolved and the center has gained considerable authority, most recently as the main channel for the reporting of abuses after the July coup.
Officials at the center have also compiled information on the high-ranking Khmer Rouge officials who have defected to Mr. Hun Sen's Cambodian People's Party, a left-wing organization formed by former Khmer Rouge members in the 1970's. Mr. Hun Sen justified his overthrow of Prince Ranariddh by asserting that the Prince's royalist party was making deals with the Khmer Rouge.

HEADLINE: Adapting to Fees for Enjoying Public Lands

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: GOOSE PRAIRIE, Wash.

 BODY:
It still costs more to catch the latest action film at the local octoplex than to launch a boat under a volcano in Northern California, watch brown bears paw at salmon in Alaska or stroll along the Trail of the Ancients at the Anasazi Heritage Center in Colorado. But for the first time, most of America's natural wonders are no longer free.
From the White Mountains of New Hampshire to the William O. Douglas Wilderness area here in the Cascade Mountains, the backpacker trails, wildlife refuges and historic sites on more than 500 million acres of American public land now come with an admission price. 
 As of this summer, it costs $6 a car to catch the view from 14,000 feet on the highest paved road in North America in the Arapaho National Forest of Colorado, $8 a head to visit Mount St. Helens in this state and $3 a day to hike in the Sandia Mountains east of Albuquerque, N.M.
But while some people complain about an admission charge to enjoy land where logging, grazing and mining are still heavily subsidized by the Federal Government, most recreational users seem willing to pay something for using public land, according to preliminary surveys across the country.
In national parks, most of which have long charged admission fees, there has been a 5 percent increase in visitors thus far this year over last, despite a doubling of fees at some of the most popular sites and the introduction of fees at some areas that were previously free.
It is on Forest Service land, wildlife refuges and the arid country managed by the Bureau of Land Management -- the big open land that was always free to visitors -- that Federal officials most feared a backlash to the new pay-per-see policy that is being tried out for the next three years.
The idea of charging $4 a head to watch buffalo chew grass in the National Bison Range in Montana, for example, struck some people as a violation of the home-on-the-range spirit of public land.
Free use of public land is the essence of the American West, some critics of the new policy have said.
As Bill Hall, a popular columnist for The Tribune of Lewiston, Idaho, wrote recently: "A river that belongs to everyone should not have an admission charge. That's like charging people a fee to use their own homes."
Most of the money from the new fees goes into funds to maintain the sites where the fees are being collected, and for that reason, random interviews indicate, people seem not to mind having to pay.
There have been some protests, mainly by local people who are used to treating the public land in their backyards as an extension of their own property. The word "tax" has been scrawled onto posted notices of the new fees.
It costs $14 a night to camp at Russell Pond in the White Mountain National Forest in New Hampshire, and $5 to use the pond, a source of some complaints. "In a state with a slogan like 'Live Free or Die,' we have had some trouble," said Greg Super, a recreation economist with the Forest Service.
The Government decided to charge for using public land after millions of people discovered what a bargain such lands were -- the last best free place -- straining the maintenance budgets supposed to maintain them. With little hope of receiving an increase in their financing, the agencies embraced the idea of having the people who use the lands most pay for their upkeep, an idea backed both by the Clinton Administration and Congress.
Though the land agencies still devote the bigger portions of their budgets to subsidizing logging, grazing and mining, recreational users are the biggest users of public land.
Last year, for example, the Forest Service recorded 829 million visits to the 191 million acres run by the agency, an all time high. The Park Service, Bureau of Land Management and Fish and Wildlife -- the three other agencies that are part of the fee experiment -- also registered a record volume of visitors.
Human-powered outdoor recreation is a $40 billion business. The Forest Service now claims its land is used for 75 percent of the gross domestic product of that industry, providing the destination for skiing, hunting, fishing, hiking, mountain-biking, bird watching and camping.
"We have suffered from a public perception that all we're really about is timber-cutting," said Jim Lyons, the Under Secretary for natural resources at the Agriculture Department, which runs the Forest Service. "Timber is not the agenda of the future. Recreation is."
Still, many outdoor users chafe at paying user fees when Congress has authorized spending another $200 million for subsidized road-building into national forests on behalf of the timber industry.
"People accept these new user fees, but that vote to continue building new roads for loggers really ticked off a lot of our members," said Dan Nelson, a spokesman for the Washington Trails Association, which represents 4,000 backpackers.
But the Government agencies say their future is with the users of public land, despite Congressional loyalty to timber and grazing interests. The Bureau of Land Management, for example, has just begun to charge for use of such areas as the slick-rock canyons around Moab, Utah, known as the mountain-biking mecca of the world.
In this, the first full year of the fee experiment, the bureau expects to take in $3.8 million from recreational users -- on just a handful of sites -- compared with the $13.9 million it collects from ranchers who graze livestock on nearly 150 million acres of the agency's land. The Forest Service expects to collect about $13 million in user fees this year, and the Fish and Wildlife Service projects taking in $2.5 million.
At the end of the three years, Congress will decide where to go with the program. It could be ended, expanded or modified. The money is a drop in the bucket in the overall budget of all the public land agencies. But because a full 100 percent of the fees collected by the Bureau of Land Management and 80 percent of those collected by the Forest Service and Fish and Wildlife are supposed to go back into the sites where they were collected, the money can have a big impact in certain overused areas. In some places, a working toilet is a sea change.
"When we first announced this, there was a very strong reaction against it," Mr. Lyons said. "At Flaming Gorge near the Wyoming border, for example, they nearly tarred and feathered the rangers and ran them out on a rail. But after the docks there were fixed up, people really came around."
Most of the fees are no more than $5. In the Northwest, the Forest Service sells a season pass, good for all national forests in the region, that costs $30. It can be bought at outdoor stores like Recreational Equipment Inc. in Seattle, where the Forest Service and National Park Service now have employees amid the backpacks and espresso machines.
One of the higher entry fees is for the main Forest Service road to Mount St. Helens, where it costs $8 a head to enter the visitor center near the volcano, which blew up in 1980. For a family of four, that is a $32 Sunday drive for what used to be free. In other places, the new fee structure can be somewhat confusing. A hiker entering Olympic National Park from an adjacent Forest Service road, for example, has to pay $3 to one agency for use of the parking lot and then $2 for a back-country permit, $10 for entering the park and $5 for a processing fee.
"Olympic National Park seems to be going out of its way to make people mad at them," Mr. Nelson said.
Still, a review of the major recreation sites around the country shows that visitor use is increasing, rather than decreasing, in most of the new fee areas. The exceptions are Yellowstone, Yosemite and Grand Canyon National Parks, where the carload fee has doubled to $20. Park officials attribute the decline to a drop in foreign visitors, kept away by the high dollar.
"Over all, the whole experiment is a home run," Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt said. "It has exceeded our best expectations."
Beyond the criticism of some people who believe that their taxes already pay for public land, there is also some concern that Forest Service rangers, trained in biology and land management, have taken on more duties as fee collectors, spending their hours as Smokey the Cop in pursuit of scofflaws.
"The only time people see our green now is when we put a ticket on their cars," said a Forest Service ranger in New Hampshire.
As fee enforcers, though, rangers and wildlife agents have proved to be a soft touch so far this year. Here at the trailhead of the William O. Douglas Wilderness, where it costs $5 to park at the base of a trail that climbs to stunning views of Mount Rainier, every single car in the dusty lot one weekend was given a yellow ticket for failure to display a stub showing that the fee had been paid. The notice, a warning only, reminded hikers that it now costs to enter the place where Mr. Douglas, a Supreme Court Justice, roamed as boy. Repeat violators can be fined $100.
"We're not into being law enforcers," said Mr. Super of the Forest Service. "Mostly, we're just giving out warning tickets. We tell people it's still free to fish, hunt and hike in the woods, but the parking lot will cost you."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Investment Firm to Buy Corning Consumer Lines
Corning, whose name has for decades been synonymous with Pyrex, Corning Ware and other household brands, said that it would sell a controlling interest in its consumer products operations as it focuses instead on high-technology businesses.
The buyer is AEA Investors, an investment firm that is paying $975 million, considerably more than analysts had expected. [Page D4.] 

Rhone-Poulenc to Buy All of Unit
Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, the American unit of the French chemical and drug company Rhone-Poulenc, accepted a sweetened buyout bid of $4.3 billion from its parent for the shares that Rhone-Poulenc does not now own. [D5.]
 
Exemption Is Sought for Liggett
The attorneys general of 20 states asked the White House to support an exemption of Liggett Group, the smallest of the nation's major cigarette makers, from the financial terms of the proposed $368.5 billion settlement with the tobacco industry. [A19.]
 
A.M.A. Uneasy Over Endorsements
Stung by criticism, top executives of the American Medical Association have decided that the association should not endorse health care products and will recommend that an exclusive endorsement deal with one such manufacturer, Sunbeam, be scaled back. [A1.]
 
Optimism on French Oil Driller
Bouygues Offshore of France, which builds oil platforms, was already benefiting from the global quest for oil through deep sea drilling. Then Elf Aquitaine announced a major discovery off the shores of Angola. Its shares surged, and those of Bouygues, one of Elf's suppliers, rose, too. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Brokerage Firm Is Subject of Inquiry
JB Oxford, a brokerage firm raided by American and Swiss agents, is under S.E.C. investigation for its role in possible stock manipulation, a Swiss official said. [D4.]
 
I.M.F. Approves Stage of Thai Deal
The I.M.F. approved the first part of a $16 billion international rescue package for Thailand, and the Clinton Administration announced that it would help provide short-term loans, if needed, to help Thailand stem a currency crisis that has threatened other nations in Southeast Asia. [D2.]
 
Disappointing News Corp. Results
The News Corporation reported weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings, as its movie division was hurt by flops like "Speed 2" and "Volcano" and as it revamped its struggling HarperCollins publishing unit. [D5.]
 
Lots of Work, for Now, at U.P.S.
As tens of thousands of teamsters returned to work at the United Parcel Service, company officials said they were experiencing a surge in business from backlogged packages. But they re-emphasized their predictions of a drop in business, and a wave of layoffs, once the backlog is cleared. [A22.]
 
Chrysler Avoids California Penalty
Chrysler said that California regulators had overturned proposed sanctions against the company over charges that it had violated California's "lemon law." The penalty could have prevented the company from shipping vehicles to the state for 45 days. [D6.]
 
Debate Over Food-Safety Programs
The Federal investigation into the possible contamination of 1.2 million pounds of ground beef at a Hudson Foods processing plant in Nebraska has raised new questions about the effectiveness of the Government's efforts to safeguard food production. [A29.]
 
Dorfman in Settlement
Dan Dorfman, the columnist dismissed last year by Money magazine for failing to tell his editor where he got information for his reports, has settled the dispute with the magazine's parent, Time Inc. [D6.]
 
Random House Delays Eisner Book
Random House has taken the unusual step of postponing the publication of the autobiography of Michael Eisner, the Disney chief, which had been scheduled for fall. [D5.]

HEADLINE: State Plan for Con Ed Deal Would Cut Rates More

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 20

 BODY:
State utility regulators signaled today that they intend to lower electric rates for residences and small businesses in New York City and Westchester County by as much as 6 to 7 percent, or about double the savings included in a proposed agreement with the Consolidated Edison Company.
Members of the State Public Service Commission, which governs the utility industry and has the power to set rates, said they wanted to make a number of changes in the proposed agreement for a sweeping restructuring of the state's largest power supplier. 
 The deal would, over five years, open to competition the region that Con Ed has held as a monopoly, much as long-distance telephone companies compete for customers. Commission members said they wanted the pact revised to allow for competition more quickly, saying it will produce much lower rates in the long run.
The proposed agreement would divide Con Ed into separate companies -- one for power generation, one to own and maintain the system of wires and one as a retail power provider -- though they would be owned by a single holding company.
States across the country are breaking down the traditional utility monopolies, allowing wholesale electric and gas companies to enter the retail market and for neighboring retail companies to compete in each other's markets.
The proposed agreement, reached in March between the commission's staff and Con Ed, came under fierce attack from consumer and environmental groups. The commission's proposals today were meant in part to blunt the charge that the deal did not do enough for consumers, but the commissioners said little about the environmental concerns, leaving it unclear how they will be resolved.
"I think it's clear that there are specific concerns that the commissioners have," said the chairman, John F. O'Mara, as he directed the commission staff to renegotiate aspects of the deal with Con Ed. He said a new proposed agreement should be ready by Aug. 29, to be voted on by the commission on Sept. 10.
Joan S. Freilich, a senior vice president of Con Ed, said she was confident an agreement could be reached that would satisfy the commission.
The March pact called for an immediate 25 percent electric rate reduction for large industrial customers. Large commercial users like office buildings and hospitals would get a 10 percent reduction, phased in over five years, and residents and small businesses would get a 3.3 percent drop, also phased in over five years.
Commission members said favoring large businesses was necessary to promote economic development and protect jobs, but consumer groups, like the American Association of Retired Persons and the New York Public Interest Group, objected.
While the four members of the commission all said today that they wanted to narrow the disparity, they did not say by how much.
But they did discuss taking about $350 million that Con Ed had hoped to gain through accounting maneuvers and committing that to consumer savings, a figure that industry analysts said would translate to about an additional 3 percent residential and small business reduction, for a total of 6 to 7 percent.
But consumer advocates, who had said the agreement should provide at least a 10 percent reduction for ordinary consumers, said they were still dissatisfied.
Environmental groups attacked the earlier agreement in part because it greatly reduced the amount of money Con Ed would have to spend on energy efficiency programs, like advising businesses how to use less power and providing rebates for buying energy-efficient appliances. The state has already allowed the program to be cut by about half, from a high of $125 million in 1993, and the proposed deal would have dropped it to $6 million in 1999.
The Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group, has negotiated a deal with Con Ed to increase that commitment to an average of $37 million a year over the next three years, which could mean a somewhat smaller rate reduction, and the plan requires commission approval. The commissioners said little about the efficiency programs today, and nothing about the proposed deal with the Defense Council.
"We remain very concerned that there's not the support for energy efficiency that we would like from the commission," said Ashok Gupta, an economist with the group.
Other environmental groups did not approve the agreement with Con Ed, because they did not think it went far enough. They noted that several other states that are going through the restructuring process, including New Jersey, Massachusetts and California, have required much larger investments in energy efficiency.

HEADLINE: Defying Israel, Arafat Embraces Islamic Militants

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG 

DATELINE: GAZA, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Defying Israeli and American demands that he crack down on Islamic militants, Yasir Arafat kissed and applauded leaders of the Hamas and Islamic Holy War movements today and warned that Palestinians were prepared to resume their violent revolt against Israel.
At a conference of Palestinian factions here, Mr. Arafat returned to the combative language of the seven-year uprising against Israeli occupation, which ended in 1994 with the beginning of Palestinian self rule. 
 "There was an uprising for seven years," Mr. Arafat told the conference, which he called to protest the policies of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel. "Who did it? The lion cubs, our children -- this glorious uprising. Seven years. We can erase and do it again from the beginning. There is nothing far from us. All options are open to us."
As he has many times in his career, Mr. Arafat was fighting on several fronts at once.
His remarks came just days after Dennis B. Ross, the American mediator, prodded him to renew security cooperation with the Israelis and take action against Hamas and other hard-line Islamic groups that have carried out terrorist bombings in Israel. Mr. Arafat met Tuesday with the head of Shin Bet, the Israeli domestic security agency, as he began to comply with that request.
But at today's session in Gaza, called the National Unity Conference to Confront the Challenges, Mr. Arafat was lining up support from a broad array of factions, including the militant Islamic groups who favor a more confrontational stance toward the Israelis. The Islamic groups said they saw the meeting as a means of resisting the crackdown by the Palestinian Authority that Israel and the United States are demanding.
[In Washington, senior American officials were dismayed by Mr. Arafat's remarks. "It simply makes an already difficult situation more difficult," one official said. "We have a crisis of confidence, so no party should do or say things that undermine confidence about a peaceful resolution of their differences."
[James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said the United States remained convinced that Mr. Arafat's would carry out his pledge to cooperate with the Israelis against terrorism. "We are going to judge, in the area of security cooperation and anti-terrorist cooperation, Chairman Arafat by deeds," he said. "Deeds are the coin of the realm when it comes to fighting terrorism."]
Today's conference in Gaza was significant because it marked the first time Islamic Holy War, a militant group that operates primarily in Gaza, had joined a meeting of Palestinian factions under Mr. Arafat's leadership. Unlike Hamas, which has both social programs and a military wing, Islamic Holy War has devoted itself almost exclusively to attacks on Israel.
At the conference, representatives of Hamas and Islamic Holy War, who are political leaders of their organizations, not members of their clandestine military wings, exchanged customary kisses with Mr. Arafat after their speeches.
They said later that their participation in Mr. Arafat's conference did not mean they were renouncing violence, as the Palestinian leader did in reaching an accord with the Israelis. The delegates said they remain implacably opposed to the agreement reached in Oslo in 1993 between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.
"This is not a conference to support Oslo, but to support the stance of our people against the American and Israeli pressures on the Palestinian Authority to arrest and crack down on the Islamic movements," said Abdel Aziz al-Rantisi, a Hamas leader.
The relationship between Mr. Arafat and the Israeli Government, which had been strained, worsened considerably last month after a suicide bombing in a Jerusalem market on July 30 in which 14 people and the two attackers were killed.
Israel demanded that Mr. Arafat take action against Hamas and Islamic Holy War and it imposed economic sanctions and other punitive measures that the Palestinian leader condemned as a declaration of war against his people.
The measures included closing borders, demolishing houses of Palestinians on the grounds that they were built without permits, and freezing payments of taxes and other money to the Palestinian Authority.
Israel's moves united Palestinians of all political stripes behind Mr. Arafat. Many perceive him as standing up to heavy Israeli and American pressures to suppress the militants.
United States officials have backed the Israeli demands, but they have also urged Israel to rescind economic sanctions that are not directly linked to its security. To ease the economic pressure, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt pledged Tuesday to give the Palestinian Authority $10 million.
Israeli officials criticized Mr. Arafat for inviting Hamas and Islamic Holy War to the Gaza conference, asserting that his invitation of groups responsible for bombings that killed scores of Israelis contradicted his commitment to fight terrorism. Mr. Arafat is "giving the terrorist organizations a stamp of approval," said David Bar-Illan, communications director for Prime Minister Netanyahu.
Mr. Arafat and his aides might think that "appeasing, pacifying and placating these organizations will do the trick," Mr. Bar-Illan added, "but they already tried that, and we found that all this dialogue does is give these organizations the respectability and legitimacy which makes it easier for them to continue their terrorist activity with impunity."
But Tayeb Abdel Rahim, a close aide of Mr. Arafat who was chairman of the conference, rejected the Israeli criticism. "None of the speakers advocated explosions or terrorism," he said. "They all protested the Israeli policy that disregards the peace process. They agreed on a common denominator of rejecting the policy of dictation."
The speakers, apparently following rules agreed upon in advance, did not call explicitly for violence against Israel, but instead urged "resistance," "confrontation" and "struggle" against the Israeli "enemy."
Many called on Mr. Arafat to stop security cooperation and negotiations with the Israelis, and urged a boycott of Israeli products in response to the Israeli border closures. They criticized American officials for what they described as a stance that favors Israel, and they urged Mr. Arafat to resist Israeli "dictates" backed by the Americans to crack down on militant groups.
Mr. Arafat has recently renewed security contacts at the urging of the Americans, and he met on Tuesday with Ami Ayalon, the head of Shin Bet, the Israeli security service. But before the conference delegates he vowed never to submit to Israeli economic and political pressures.
"In the name of our children," he said, "the children of the uprising, I say: No one can humiliate the Palestinian people, no one can defeat the Palestinian people, no one can make our Palestinian people bow!"

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
New York City Jobs Up by 9,100 in July

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
New York City employment surged higher in July, with 9,100 more jobs than in June. It was the biggest monthly gain since January, and it reversed a short-term trend in which city residents were passed over for jobs in favor of people from the suburbs, according to a report by Alan G. Hevesi, the New York City Comptroller.
In a separate employment report a week ago, Mr. Hevesi said that employment among city residents had fallen by more than 20,000 during the first half of the year, even though 21,900 jobs had been created in that period. The earlier report said that suburban residents were filling most of the new jobs in finance, data processing and other fields that require special skills. 
 Advisers to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said the Comptroller's earlier study was flawed. The Mayor said in a statement that the new data showed that the city "is experiencing sustained and steady job growth."
John Marlin, the Comptroller's chief economist, said about 12,000 more city residents were employed at jobs in the city than in June, meaning that they had not only gained more of the new jobs than suburban applicants but had displaced many suburban workers who had been employed in the city. But he said the July increase reflected a sudden improvement, rather than steady job growth for city residents. THOMAS J. LUECK

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Hudson Park's Beginning

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
Construction of the first section of a five-mile-long park along the Hudson River from the Battery to 59th Street will begin in April, state officials said yesterday, as they hired a landscape architect to prepare final drawings for the park's first segment.
The Hudson River Park Conservancy, a subsidiary of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, awarded a $4.4 million contract to Abel Bainnson Butz Landscape Architects, of Manhattan, to prepare blueprints for construction of a 3,300-foot esplanade between Clarkson and Horatio streets in Greenwich Village. Building that segment is expected to cost $46 million, more than half of which will pay for rebuilding three to five rotting piers and shoring up bulkheads. 
 Work will begin once the state has finished construction of the adjacent section of Route 9A.
Of the three companies named as finalists for the contract, Abel Bainnson Butz gave the highest bid, but a conservancy spokeswoman said that the company's experience on Riverbank State Park in Manhattan and on several other New York City parks made it the most qualified. DAVID M. HALBFINGER

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Fell in June, but Not With Asians

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit narrowed markedly in June as exports rebounded to a new record and imports subsided for the first time this year, the Commerce Department reported today.
The decline in the deficit, to $8.2 billion from $9.54 billion in May, followed two sizable increases and reflected what analysts said was the faster growth of the American economy in the spring than had initially been estimated. Stocks rose and the dollar advanced against most leading currencies. Yields on Treasury bonds increased. 
 "This shows a lot of strength," said James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at J. P. Morgan & Company. "The trend in exports is booming," he added, despite the dollar's strength and the lackluster performance of various trading partners whose economies have only begun to revive.
Despite the decline in June, the most recent month for which figures are available, the trade deficit for the first half of 1997 was still about 6 percent larger than in the corresponding period of 1996, though below the level of the first half of 1995.
And while the deficits narrowed with Canada and Mexico, two of the country's biggest trade partners, imbalances with China and Japan increased significantly, prompting fresh expressions of displeasure by the Clinton Administration.
The trend toward widening deficits with Asian countries could increase, economists said, because of economic difficulty accompanying currency crises in several South and South Asian nations.
Nonetheless, the report provided further evidence of the American economy's recent strength, showing that demand for goods and services from overseas was helping to keep growth rolling along.
Indeed, combining the latest trade data with figures showing a larger buildup in inventories than had been thought, analysts now say that the economy probably grew at a rate upward of 3.5 percent in the April-June quarter, perhaps by as much as 4 percent.
That would be considerably above the 2.2 percent pace the Commerce Department estimated at the end of July. If borne out, it could undermine a widely held view that the economy had slowed substantially, as policy makers desired, from a first-quarter growth rate of 4.9 percent, which raised concerns about resurgent inflation.
And if consumer spending revives, as it shows signs of doing, analysts said the Federal Reserve could decide to cool the economy by raising interest rates. On Tuesday, the Fed made no change in rates, apparently preferring to sit tight without clearer evidence of inflation. The next policy meeting is scheduled for Sept. 30.
Today's trade report showed a June deficit nearly $2 billion smaller than had been expected. In addition, the May deficit was revised downward by $700 million from an initial figure of more than $10 billion.
But despite the overall decline, the Clinton Administration continues to be stymied in its efforts to reduce the trade deficits with big Asian nations. "Our trade with China is problematic," Secretary of Commerce William M. Daley said at a briefing. He noted that exports so far this year had risen 3 percent while imports from China jumped 26 percent.
"There is no reason why our products cannot have a higher presence in the Chinese market, as they do in ours," said Mr. Daley, who plans to visit China in October.
June was only the fourth time that the American deficit with China surpassed the deficit with Japan. Major contributors to the China deficit, which was up $500 million to $4.3 billion, were imports of clothing, shoes and toys, the Commerce Department said.
With Japan, the American deficit swelled $500 million to $4.1 billion -- with the imbalance in auto trade, now about $2.5 billion, and in office machines accounting for much of the increase.
Mr. Daley urged Japan to be "more aggressive" in opening its economy and not rely on exports for growth. On Friday, the Administration sent a letter to the Japanese complaining about slow application of an agreement to open the Japanese market to American automotive products.
In contrast to the imbalances with Asians, the United States sold record exports to Mexico, reducing that deficit by $500 million in June, to $1.2 billion. The deficit with Canada, the other partner in the North American Free Trade Agreement, eased $100 million, to $1.4 billion.
Over all, exports climbed nine-tenths of 1 percent, to $78.4 billion, while imports eased seven-tenths of 1 percent from May's record, to $86.6 billion, the report showed.
Analysts were surprised by the lower imports because an earlier report showed a big jump in inventories held by wholesalers for the month. Imported goods tend to enter the country through these middlemen.
About two-thirds of the revision in the May deficit, to $9.5 billion from $10.2 billion, reflected stronger exports, the department's report also showed.
As usual, the June deficit would have been far bigger without surpluses in services and in advanced technology products, of $6.8 billion and $2.4 billion, respectively.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Something Constant in a Procession of Styles

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

DATELINE: WOODSTOCK, N.Y.

 BODY:
DURING his long career, Philip Guston passed through many artistic phases, some better than others. He veered from figuration to abstraction and, in the last 15 years of his life, back to figuration, charting a course that is by now well known. Yet throughout these twists and turns Guston displayed an often startling thematic and artistic consistency.
His consistency is crystal clear in two small but intriguing exhibitions at the Woodstock Artists Association here. One show features a recently rediscovered cache of Gustoniana: a series of illustrations of troops in naval training and workers in a wartime factory commissioned by the United States Navy and Fortune magazine in 1943 (several of the images were published in Fortune in late 1943 and early 1944). Presumed lost, the drawings were discovered four years ago in an old portfolio in an abandoned studio that Guston used when he moved to Woodstock in the late 1940's. 
 These 25 gouaches and drawings are exhibited with a selection of lithographs that Guston made with Gemini G.E.L., a print publisher in Los Angeles, in 1979 and '80, the year he died. The combined effect of these two shows is quite powerful. Formally and psychologically, the late prints echo the earlier drawings to a surprising degree, confirming that although Guston changed, he never really left anything behind; he just kept transforming his lifelong subject, which was life's tensions and conflicts, and increasing the physical immediacy of his style.
Except for the serene rosy-fingered abstractions of the early 1950's -- a crucial hiatus during which Guston gave himself over as never before to the physical pleasures of paint and color -- he depicted these tensions in one form or another nearly all the time. They are visible in monumental figurative works from the late 1930's that borrow from Michelanglo and de Chirico to give his depictions of Ku Klux Klansmen a sinister grandeur. They are also present in the more introspective images of the early 1940's: paintings like "Gladiators" and "Martial Memory," which show children staging mock battles, and "Sancutary," with its anxious, wide-eyed insomniac lying on a rumpled bed.
Similar tensions are present in the commissioned illustrations of 1943. They straightforwardly depict young draftees engaged in the business of becoming soldiers: floating in water while inflating their knotted clothes into makeshift life preservers, jumping overboard in abandon-ship drills, lining up at the open door of a paratrooper plane, or climbing into cockpits with rounds of ammunition slung over their shoulders.
These works are executed in an assured, rather conventional figurative style in keeping with the socially aware realism of the 1930's and 40's (Ben Shahn's, for example). But their main attraction lies in Guston's emotional empathy.
His subjects are grave, brawny men training to kill and keep from being killed, and he captures the quiet, sweaty-palmed terror of their task. For example, an image of G.I.'s wedged together as if on a troop transport shows one soldier looking around while his companions nervously offset their anxieties by smoking, eating or drinking. Of course, these activities would figure repeatedly in Guston's late paintings, which often depict the artist himself chain-smoking and staring at plates of food or bottles of wine.
Formally, the naval-training illustrations seem important to Guston's later work in their frequent repetition of the human figure. Guston's image of the dozen or so trainees floating on their backs during the clothes-inflation drill evokes the piles of heads, clustered on the horizon or drifting among ocean waves, that recur in his works from the 1970's, even before the late lithographs confirm the connection.
In the prints, the repeating bodies of the earlier images -- trainees jumping, showering, sitting or standing in line -- rise to the surface again, not only as heads, but also as piles of shoes or legs. The violent, amputated nature of these images is of course softened by the artist's bumptious, cartoon-flavored style -- a style, like Goya's or Daumier's, that seems implicitly optimistic in its formal power, despite the black humor.
Guston's stylistic peregrinations sometimes earned him the unflattering adjective "opportunistic," especially after his late conversion to Abstract Expressionism. There's something of that in these illustrations, as Guston, the social critic of the 1930's, becomes an unquestioning patriot, enthusiastically depicting the war effort. But it could be argued that most ambition, certainly artistic ambition, is opportunistic. Artists take what they need wherever they find it. With luck and diligence, it leads them to what lies within.
As Guston matured, his themes of social conflict became increasingly internal and specific, turning first psychological and then artistic. Finally his tensions centered on himself, and the existential doubt that was, for him, exemplified by the very act of painting. His war drawings forced him briefly off this track, into the world, where he depicted not children playing at war, but young men preparing for the real thing. But characteristically, he found something to use, and, working in a relatively reportorial, documentary style, continued to lay the foundations for his last, and most lasting statement.
"Philip Guston: Brave New World, 1943" and "Philip Guston: Gemini Prints, 1980" remain at the Woodstock Artists Association, 28 Tinker Street, Woodstock, N.Y., through Sept. 7.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Philip Guston's untitled 1943 illustration of G.I.'s wedged together waiting, smoking and drinking, at the Woodstock Artists Association. (D. James Dee/Woodstock Artists Association)

HEADLINE: Keynes the Optimist? Wait, There's a Catch

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Dr. Doom Becomes Dr. Pangloss," Michael M. Weinstein's Aug. 18 Editorial Notebook on the current optimism of economists, brings to mind a passage from John Maynard Keynes.
It was 1932. Things had never been worse. Yet, in a preface to "Essays in Persuasion," Keynes declared that "the Economic Problem, as one may call it for short, the problem of want and poverty and the economic struggle between classes and nations, is nothing but a frightful muddle. . . . For the Western World already has the resources and the technique, if we could create the organization to use them, capable of reducing the Economic Problem which now absorbs our moral and material energies, to a position of secondary importance." 
 Keynes reckoned that "the Economic Problem may be solved, or be at least within sight of solution, within a hundred years."
It is one-half century since enactment of the Keynesian Employment Act of 1946. We have had ups and downs, but never a serious recession. As Mr. Weinstein notes, unemployment is at a seven-year low and inflation at a 30-year low. It begins to look as if Keynes, even if revised, may have been right!
Quite unintentionally, however, the master offered a warning that "the day is not far off when the Economic Problem will take the back seat where it belongs, and that the arena of the heart and head will be occupied, or re-occupied, by our real problems -- the problems of life and of human relations, of creation and behaviour and religion."
Life. Creation. Religion. Hmm? Looking about the world, the thought occurs that we may one day long for the age of the General Strike.
 
DANIEL PATRICK MOYNIHAN
Pindars Corners, N.Y., Aug. 19, 1997
 
The writer is United States Senator from New York.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Off as German Bank Reinforces Its Mark Defenses

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the mark yesterday after the German central bank modified its practice on a key money-market rate, giving itself more flexibility to defend the lagging currency. It suffered, too, from slumping American securities markets.
The German bank said it would now set the benchmark securities-repurchase rate on a weekly basis, rather than every two weeks as it has done for the last three years. 
 While the change was not a surprise, it worried currency traders because it meant that the bank could change the rate on shorter notice.
"If the dollar pops up, this is a mechanism to keep people from selling" the mark, said Tom Hoge, a corporate currency trader at the Bank of New York. "They're wringing this out for all they can get."
Concern over higher German rates also intensified after the Ifo Institute of Munich, an influential research center, forecast that the central bank was likely to raise the repurchase rate half a percentage point by early next year.
"The Ifo's report took a little cream off the dollar," said Karl Halligan, chief currency trader at CIC Bank in New York.
Higher interest rates would prop up the mark by making mark-denominated assets more appealing. German central bankers have hinted that they might raise rates to keep the dollar from extending its 20 percent climb against the mark this year.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.8382 marks, down from 1.8567 on Wednesday. The British pound eased to $1.5935 from $1.5940.
The dollar extended its losses as American bonds fell and stocks reversed three days of gains. "The dollar's trading off the back of weak asset markets," Mr. Halligan said.
It also fell against the Japanese yen, settling yesterday at 117.20 yen, compared with 117.75 late Wednesday, dragged down by concern over the American trade deficit with Japan. The Commerce Department reported on Wednesday that the monthly deficit with Tokyo increased 12 percent in June from May.
"The widening trade deficit made people afraid of pushing the dollar to the 120-yen level," said Ben Strauss of Bank Julius Baer.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Confront The Gangsters

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS; A.M. Rosenthal's column will resume shortly.

 BODY:
Late, but far better than never, the United States and its friends are getting serious about the Dayton agreements on Bosnia. They are acting against the Serbian gangsters who waged the genocidal war and have obstructed the peace.
That is the significance of the seizure by NATO-led forces of six police buildings in Banja Luka, the largest city in the Bosnian Serb republic. The soldiers found thousands of weapons stockpiled by police under the control of Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb President charged with genocide and crimes against humanity. 
 The Dayton agreements went into effect in December 1995. For a year and a half after that the peacekeeping forces did nothing to carry out such terms as the right of refugees to return to their homes and the obligation to surrender accused war criminals. Dr. Karadzic, though required by Dayton to leave public life, built up a 3,000-man paramilitary police force and acted more and more openly to block the peace process.
Then, starting last month, came a series of moves that reflected a sharp change in NATO policy. British soldiers arrested one war crimes suspect and killed another who shot at them. Peacekeepers began protecting refugees who returned to their homes, so they would not be driven out by terrorist mobs.
The move against the Karadzic police in Banja Luka was the most dramatic sign of the newly interventionist policy. It put NATO squarely on the side of Biljana Plavsic, the elected President of the Bosnian Serb republic, in her struggle with Dr. Karadzic.
Peacekeeping officials had already endorsed one daring move by Mrs. Plavsic. When the Karadzic-controlled assembly planned to remove her from office, she dismissed the assembly and called new elections for October. Under pressure from Dr. Karadzic -- including a brutal assault on one judge -- the entity's Constitutional Court held the dismissal unconstitutional. But Mrs. Plavsic, with Western support, ignored that ruling.
The logic of the new NATO policy, and of the situation in Bosnia, requires two further steps. The first is to shut down the Karadzic propaganda machine. The second is to arrest Dr. Karadzic.
Television was a crucial instrument in arousing Bosnian Serbs to attack Muslim and Croat neighbors with whom they had lived in peace, many intermarrying. And television from Pale, the Bosnian Serb capital, is one of Dr. Karadzic's main instruments of power today, pouring out messages of hate. Through relay stations across the Serbian entity, it dominates the media audience.
The time has come for the NATO-led force to shut down those relay stations. That is a hard thing for a believer in the First Amendment to say. But we have no more obligation there than we would have had in postwar Germany to let Goebbels stay on the air.
The need for action on the Karadzic propaganda machine is acute because of the assembly election called by Mrs. Plavsic. If the election campaign is dominated by hate messages on Pale television, Mrs. Plavsic -- and NATO -- may lose their gamble.
Because Dr. Karadzic is protected by his paramilitary policemen, his arrest is the hardest challenge for the peacekeeping force. It is also the most important -- and not just because it would make the author of so much evil face justice.
If Radovan Karadzic is at large, Dayton will be at risk: That is the short of it. He has a corrupt economic empire, profiting from control of gasoline and cigarette imports. He controls a mafia. He keeps alive the extreme nationalist dream that led to so much horror in Bosnia.
We speak of a NATO decision on whether to move on Dr. Karadzic. But it is really President Clinton's decision, and it is one of the toughest he has faced. The Pentagon has been planning a possible operation, but hardly with enthusiasm. If the operation goes wrong, military figures will no doubt leak the word that they advised against it.
But a failure to act would exact a heavy price, probably including in time a renewal of the Bosnian war. We have to stay the course, and that means strong action under American leadership. The Economist of London said last month: "If there is a lesson of the past five years, it is that half-hearted, or timorous, Western intervention in Bosnia achieves little."

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting;
Strutting Vintage Stuff And Selling It, Too

BYLINE: By KEITH MARTIN 

DATELINE: MONTEREY, Calif.

 BODY:
One weekend each August, this beautiful coastal area can lay claim to some of the most desirable and expensive automobiles in the world. Like a three-day summer camp for car fanatics, the Monterey Historic Weekend, held Aug. 15-17 this year, encompasses many types of classic-car activities, from vintage racing at the Laguna Seca race track to wallet racing at the auctions put on by Christie's auction house and the Rick Cole Auction Company.
"I come to Monterey each year because it has a little bit of everything," said Bruce Russell, a resource coordinator for the Vancouver, Wash., school district and a collector of Italian cars. "I sold some old Ferrari parts on Friday at Concours Italiano, watched the Cobras race on Saturday, tried to buy a Ferrari Testarossa at the Cole auction Saturday night, drooled over the hot rods at Pebble Beach on Sunday morning and eyeballed a couple of cars on Sunday at Christie's." 
 The oldest event of the weekend is the Concours d'Elegance held at the Lodge at Pebble Beach in nearby Carmel. An automotive concours is a beauty pageant for cars; the prize-winners' cars have usually been completely disassembled, made perfect, then painstakingly reassembled to a condition far better than when they were originally built. The Concours d'Elegance, founded in 1951, is acknowledged as one of the world's premier events of its kind.
It is not unusual to see judges wearing white cotton gloves, running their hands along the inside of an engine compartment looking for grime. (Better not try that on your 10-year-old Toyota Camry.) The car judged Best of Show was a 1937 Talbot-Lago T150C Figone et Falaschi Coupe, owned by William E. Connor 2d, of Kowloon, Hong Kong. New this year was a category called Historic Hot Rods: the winner was a classic Ford Highboy roadster built by Doane Spencer in the late 1940's. It is owned by Bruce Meyer of Beverly Hills.
The cars of Carroll Shelby were featured at the 24th annual Monterey Historic Races. Shelby, the former race driver who gained his car-manufacturing fame by putting large, high-output American engines into English chassis and calling the resultant hybrid a Cobra, was there to autograph souvenir programs, hats, tires, dashboards -- nearly anything with a flat surface.
While the daytime competition is on the track, at night the collectors wage war with checkbooks. Rick Cole's annual Monterey Auction of Sports and Classic Cars gave evidence that consumer confidence in the collector-car market is returning. Cole sold 120 of the 163 cars he offered for a rate of nearly 74 percent, for a total take of $5.13 million.
Christie's auction house did even better. Of the 66 cars Christie's offered, 56 sold, or 84 percent, and sales totaled $8.8 million. At both the Cole and Christie's auctions, the cars that captured attention weren't shiny, tarted-up vehicles. Rather, each auction featured an unrestored, original racing car from the 50's.
The Cole auction offered a 1956 Ferrari 500 TR sports racer, discovered by Cole in a suburban Los Angeles garage. Despite its faded paint, crooked grille and dents and dings, the crowd broke into spontaneous applause when the four-cylinder engine was coaxed to life after nearly 40 years in storage. It sold for $455,800 to an American collector.
At Christie's, an unrestored racing 1956 D-Type Jaguar captured the attention of the audience. Purchased by Paul Ketty, of Kent, Conn., in 1967 for $6,500, it had not run for 16 years. The Jaguar's engine bay still had broken hazelnut shells in it, evidence that the local squirrels had taken a liking to this high-performance English racing car. Showing a healthy increase in value since the 1967 purchase, the D-Type brought $1,014,500.
But you didn't have to spend millions to show off your car. I served as master of ceremonies for the Concours Italiano, held at Quail Lodge in Carmel, where anyone could display a beloved Italian car after paying a $25 entry fee. Fantastic $500,000 Ferraris sat side by side with pedestrian $5,000 Fiats.
With more than 450 cars shown, a gate attendance of over 10,000, plus numerous vendor booths selling everything from old car parts to the latest in Italian clothes, Concours Italiano provided the egalitarian moment of the weekend.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Drop as Inflation Fears Revive

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities declined for the second consecutive day yesterday after the release of the minutes of a Federal Reserve meeting in July failed to calm concerns about inflation and the weekly jobless claims report, which still suggested a tight labor market.
The reports did little to ease investors' concerns about inflation and raised fears that the central bank might make a pre-emptory move to raise rates sooner rather than later. In fact, the minutes from last month's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee showed policy makers were slanted toward tightening, said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, a perception that also weighed on prices. 
 The 30-year bond dropped one full point, to 96 29/32, to yield 6.62 percent, up from 6.54 percent at the close of the New York market on Wednesday; the latest yield is the highest in a week. The price decline means bondholders lost $10 for every $1,000 of face value.
"These last two weeks in August tend to be rather slow -- with many people on vacation -- so market moves are often exaggerated by a lack of liquidity," said Stuart Rinschler, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data of Boston. "This is probably why today's price movement was generated on such little volume."
He added that several factors gave investors an excuse to sell, including a threat of a strike against Amtrak and disappointment that the Fed had not made a coupon pass. In a pass, the Fed buys various maturities to add money to the banking system.
"Furthermore," Mr. Chan said, "investors received additional confirmation today that the watershed agreement between United Parcel Service and the teamsters' union was not an aberration but rather the beginning of a trend toward higher wages.
"Investors have to realize," he added, "that even though overall wages haven't flared up yet, the risk moving forward is clearly in favor of higher wages."
The bond market came under great selling pressure in the early afternoon as a rumor circulated about an increase in hiring, which would produce an increase in wages.
Among the data released yesterday were the Philadephia Fed's index of regional business activity, which slipped to a reading of 24.3 this month, from 28.1 in July. But that was higher than the 20.9 that had been forecast, suggesting the economy was still moving at a strong clip. The only thing that has prevented the Fed from raising interest rates thus far has been the absence of inflation. This report may have surprised the markets on the amount of business activity and the lack of wholesale and retail price increases.
The last time the Fed adjusted its monetary base and raised short-term rates was on March 25, when it increased the Federal funds rate, the rate banks charge one another for overnight loans, a quarter point, to 5.50 percent.
The Fed released the minutes of its July 1-2 Federal Open Market Committee meeting yesterday, revealing that although it had not raised interest rates, it would do so if inflation appeared to heat up.
Mr. Chan said, "The minutes kept some investors nervous because they suggest that if the Fed remained nervous in July -- when the economy had just completed a period of slower growth -- it would sure be a lot more nervous and anxious to execute a small dose of insurance if the economy reverted again toward a 3 percent-plus growth path."
In the jobless claims report, released yesterday morning, first-time claims increased 20,000, to 337,000, in the week ended Saturday. It was the third gain in as many weeks, but the increase might have been influenced by claims filed by some of the nearly 200,000 workers then on strike against U.P.S.
 Elsewhere, in when-issued trading of new two-year and five-year notes that will be auctioned next week, dealers were offering the two-year maturity at a price to yield 5.91 percent and the five-year at a price to yield 6.15 percent.

HEADLINE: 62 Are Charged in Violence Linked to Kenya's Politics

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MOMBASA, Kenya, Aug. 21

 BODY:
A Kenyan court charged 62 suspects today with robbery and violence during a raid on a police station that began a week of attacks around this port city that some observers said were politically motivated.
Despite the political turmoil, the International Monetary Fund said it was sending a team to Kenya for talks on resuming aid. "To show our goodwill in this respect, I have asked a mission to leave immediately for Nairobi," the Fund's managing director, Michel Camdessus, told reporters in Washington. He said the decision followed a personal appeal from President Daniel arap Moi. 
 The I.M.F. suspended a $205 million, three-year loan to Kenya on July 31 citing concerns over corruption. The World Bank followed suit and delayed disbursements.
Mr. Moi, 73 and in power since 1978, faces elections later this year for which no date has been set. He had accused the I.M.F. of acting on political grounds.
The 62 suspects in Mombasa court were accused of robbing the police station at Likoni on Aug. 13, killing a policeman, stealing weapons including 40 rifles and damaging property.
They were also charged with arson and taking an unlawful oath binding them to kill if called on to do so. The maximum penalty for robbery with violence is death.
The accused included Amir Hamisi Ali Banda, prayer leader of a mosque south of Mombasa, and Ali Said Chidzondo, chairman of the unregistered National African Democratic Union. All denied the charges and were scheduled to appear again in two weeks.
Security forces beat the opposition leader Raila Odinga and damaged his car today when he tried to visit the Likoni police station with other opposition activists, local journalists said.
"One of them hit me with the butt of his gun on the side of my head," Mr. Odinga told reporters."This confirms our fears that the Government has something to hide."
A police spokesman, Peter Kimanthi, said he was unaware of the incident. But he confirmed that the police had shot and killed a man at Tiwi village south of Mombasa on Wednesday. This took the toll from nine days of violence to 40 dead.
Six policemen and seven civilians including five attackers were killed on Aug. 13 in the well-organized attack on the Likoni police station, just south of Mombasa.
Mr. Kimanthi said the police recovered a rifle today and 50 rounds of ammunition and arrested 101 people, taking the number of arrests since Aug. 13 to at least 410.
President Moi and the opposition have blamed each other for fueling tribal tensions on the coast.
Missions of 10 European countries, the United States and Japan welcomed an agreement in principle by Government and opposition to start talks before elections.
"We urge both sides to enter into dialogue in the spirit of compromise and with the commitment to agree on reforms necessary to ensure free and fair elections," they said in a statement.
The attacks on the coast, the center of Kenya's tourism and its top foreign currency earner, have shaken the industry and tour operators say cancellations have increased.
Tourism earned $465 million in 1996 and is Kenya's top employer. About 60 percent of last year's 770,000 tourists went to beaches to the north and south of Mombasa.
