HEADLINE: U.S. TELLING RUSSIA TO BAR AID TO IRAN BY ARMS EXPERTS

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has been quietly pressing Russia for most of this year to stop Russian scientists and military institutes from helping Iran develop a new ballistic missile that could reach Israel, Saudi Arabia and American troops in the Persian Gulf, senior Administration officials say.
The Russian scientists' assistance has continued, officials said, even though President Clinton raised the matter with President Boris N. Yeltsin in private meetings in June at the Denver economic summit. 
 American officials said they have become increasingly frustrated with Russia's inaction, and they note that Vice President Al Gore complained about the Russians' role in the Iranian project as early as February.
Last month Mr. Clinton assigned Frank G. Wisner to be his special envoy for the problem. Mr. Wisner, who had retired from government service after being Ambassador to India, returned last week from a visit to Russia, Israel, Egypt and Britain.He received new assurances from senior Russian Government officials that "it is not Russian policy to support Iran's development of a ballistic-missile capacity," a senior White House official said.
According to the American officials, the assistance to Iran is being provided by institutes and companies that were an integral part of the state-owned military complex of the Soviet Union, which controlled the design, construction and deployment of all missiles, nuclear or otherwise.
Since the breakup of the Soviet Union and the introduction of Russia's semi-market economy, military spending has plummeted, and many of these institutes have sought private contracts and income.
American officials have long been concerned that Russian scientists would sell their specialized knowledge to countries like Iraq and Iran, and have tried to develop cooperative programs to keep such scientists at work, with salaries.
The fact of assistance by Russian scientists to Iran's missile program has been reported before, but the American officials are only now disclosing how persistently, and unsuccessfully, the United States Government has tried to get Russia to stop it.
Deployment of the kind of mid-range ballistic missile the Americans are concerned about could be between two years and five years or more away, depending on how much help Iran gets from Russia and other countries, like China and North Korea, officials and experts said. One major concern is that Iran is also trying to develop nuclear, biological and chemical weapons that can be carried by such a missile.
Russian officials deny that there is any Government policy or program to help Iran develop a ballistic missile or to transfer missile technology to Teheran. They say the Russian Government has adhered to Mr. Yeltsin's 1994 pledge to avoid any further arms sales to Iran. But the Russians have not responded in detail to the American evidence that Russian scientists and institutes are helping Iran anyway.
The United States, by providing detailed material about what help is coming from which institute, wants Moscow to put an end to the assistance by making sure that contracts are canceled and that scientists with special knowledge do not travel to Iran, the officials said.
The Iran missile program was the single biggest issue in Mr. Clinton's meeting with Mr. Yeltsin in late June, the officials say. Mr. Gore raised the matter with Russian Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin in February, and it was also a major topic between Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and the Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, when they met late last month in Malaysia.
"But despite a range of assurances, the assistance continues," a senior official said. He described it as aid from "a range of institutes and organizations of various types with the necessary expertise," including important help on navigation, guidance and rocket motors dating from the old Russian SS-4 liquid-fuel missile. That missile was developed in the 1950's, deployed in Cuba and finally dismantled under the 1987 American-Soviet treaty banning intermediate-range nuclear missiles.
Mr. Wisner is expected to return to Moscow in a few weeks for further discussions, leading to another Gore-Chernomyrdin meeting in Moscow in late September. Mr. Gore is deeply involved in the issue as the main proponent of cooperation with Russia on space and commercial missile launches.
The Americans have given the Russians detailed intelligence about what help is being provided "to show them the reasons for our concerns," the senior White House official said. "They're digesting it."
"This is undeniably one of the most important issues we face," the official said.
"The Russians understand our concerns and share them and our interest in restraining this development," he said, pointing out that Russia and could itself be a target.
In 1994, with Mr. Chernomyrdin, Mr. Gore helped broker a deal for Russia to cut back on its sale of rocket engines and technology to India and join the Missile Technology Control Regime, which limits missile exports, in return for American help in winning contracts for commercial launches and for American government money and partnership in space.
That help includes the international space station project and some $400 million in American assistance over four years to the Russian Space Agency for training on Mir, the Russian space station. The larger importance of American-Russian cooperation is one reason that Washington has encouraged the trouble-plagued Mir project, American officials acknowledge.
American companies like Lockheed Martin, which is in a joint venture with a Russian company to market Proton rockets for satellite launches, not only benefit from Russian technology but would also be hurt by a cutoff of the partnership, American officials say.
"But if the Russians aren't keeping to their side of the bargain on missile exports, why should we keep ours?" a Congressional staff member said.
The State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, confirming the Wisner trip, said, "We think it's important that the Russians continue to assure us that they are committed to the highest possible nonproliferation standards." He said the talks were "off to a serious start."
Some experts on the issue, like Henry D. Sokolski, executive director of the Nonproliferation Policy Education Center and a former Pentagon official in the Bush Administration, say that given the military background of the institutes and companies providing the help, the Russian Government is being disingenuous about its lack of knowledge.
"The 'I'm O.K., you're O.K.' diplomacy has run its course here," he said. "It makes very little sense to argue that the Russian Government doesn't know what's going on."
But another official said: "Are there Russian officials who probably know more than what they're saying, and who are trying to profit from some of these activities? Probably. But the point is that the Russians have made commitments to us, and in the new Russia the export-control system is not perfect. And sometimes timely interventions can make a difference. So we're trying to ascertain what they know and help them to stop it."
Iran already has some shorter-range missiles like the Scud B and an extended-range Scud, sometimes known as the Scud C. But the issue the Americans are concerned about is a large ballistic missile with a range of between 683 miles and 1,243 miles with a capacity of about 3085 pounds, large enough for a crude nuclear warhead or, a much cheaper alternative, a biological or chemical one. The missile being developed is so inaccurate that it can be aimed only at a large target like a city, the officials say, and so can only serve as a "terror weapon."
Iran is working to develop nuclear weapons, but "there is no need to exaggerate the nuclear threat here," said Anthony H. Cordesman, an Iran expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. "The throwweight is big enough for biological weapons with the same lethality, and it's not clear a nation has to go the most difficult and expensive route."
Israel has pressed the Clinton Administration on the issue since early this year, providing intelligence that American intelligence agencies easily verified and expanded upon, the officials say. The American Israel Public Affairs Committee has also pushed the issue in a Congress already concerned about China's exports of nuclear and missile technology to Pakistan and Iran.
Howard Kohr, executive director of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, said: "This issue, which Aipac has discussed with Congress and the Administration, has an even greater sense of urgency now and requires top-priority U.S. attention."
Congress is debating an amendment to the foreign operations appropriation bill that would cut off all aid to Russia unless the President can certify that Russia has ceased all nuclear and missile cooperation with Iran. Moreover, Russia continues to honor a contract to help Iran finish a German-begun nuclear power plant at Bushehr, despite American pressure to cancel the work, preventing Mr. Clinton from making that certification, officials acknowledge.
The Senate version, passed this month, would not allow the President to waive the cutoff on national-security grounds. The House version, which is scheduled for the floor in September, would let the President continue half the aid. Senior State Department officials say they will continue to argue to Congress that "rigid legislation will not improve this situation," and that "cooperation with Russia will work a lot better than noise, drama and confrontation."
The Iranians are being very sophisticated, the White House official said. "They're trying to work all the problems, including navigation, propulsion and engines," and they are identifying key institutes, scientists and companies that have what they need and might be willing to sell it.

HEADLINE: Cable Reveals a Combative Serb Leader

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Slobodan Milosevic is known in the Balkans for his dismissive manner, and the Serbian leader was in rare form in recent meetings with an American envoy, according to a confidential cable written by a Western diplomat and other accounts of the sessions.
The cable said that Mr. Milosevic showed "absolutely no give" on turning over war-crimes suspects to the international tribunal in The Hague, a key issue for the Clinton Administration. 
 Asked whether he would allow the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe to help keep an eye on elections next month in Serbia, Mr. Milosevic is reported to have replied: "No way. What has the OSCE done for me?"
Mr. Milosevic's dialogue -- held in English with Richard C. Holbrooke, the American architect of the December 1995 Dayton peace accords, and scattered with four-letter words -- gave the impression that he was reverting to his former belligerent stance toward the West, American and other Western officials said. The two major protagonists of the peace accords met for the first time in a year at Mr. Milosevic's ornate villa in Belgrade 10 days ago.
Mr. Holbrooke was dispatched by President Clinton for a four-day tour of Croatia, Bosnia and Serbia to revitalize the sagging accords.
Mr. Holbrooke, who took issue with some of the material in the cable, said that he had won some successes in Bosnia by convincing the authorities there to agree to a common telephone code and by getting them to agree to ambassadors.
Mr. Holbrooke said he was gratified that the Muslim leaders of Bosnia had agreed to an ethnic Serb's being posted to Washington as Bosnia's envoy.
But in Belgrade, Mr. Holbrooke was confronted with an unyielding Mr. Milosevic, who, according to several American officials close to the talks, appeared willing to tough it out.
"He was bidding his price up," said a Clinton Administration official. "He was taking the approach that we need him more than he needs us."
The cable, written after the top American diplomat in Belgrade, Richard C. Miles, briefed Western envoys there, described a one-way atmosphere at the talks, with Mr. Milosevic stonewalling at every turn. The Administration official described the cable as "accurate."
For example, on the subject of Kosovo, the Serbian province where the Clinton Administration has asked Mr. Milosevic to halt abuses against the majority Albanian population, Mr. Milosevic replied, according to the cable: "It is only of interest to a few American Congressmen. We will solve it in our own way."
On the implementation of the peace accords, Mr. Milosevic said the West had to be more "balanced."
Of Biljana Plavsic, the Bosnian Serb leader the Administration is supporting, Mr. Milosevic said, "She is very difficult," and added that she deserved the trouble she was in with other Bosnian Serb officials.
The Administration official said that Serbia's economy is in desperate straits, and that Mr. Milosevic dressed down Mr. Holbrooke over Washington's preventing Serbian access to international financial institutions like the International Monetary Fund.
But Mr. Milosevic, formerly the President of Serbia, who recently engineered for himself the title of President of Yugoslavia, did not feel he was so politically threatened at home by the weak economy that he needed to make any concessions on war criminals, several Washington officials said.
In drawing the line on handing over war criminals to the tribunal, Mr. Milosevic told Mr. Holbrooke that the arrest last month of a Bosnian Serb war-crimes suspect in Bosnia and the killing of another had had "negative consequences," one Washington official said.
One of Mr. Holbrooke's priorities was to find a way to get the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, who has been indicted on war-crimes charges, out of Bosnia and, preferably, to The Hague. Mr. Milosevic has considerable control over Dr. Karadzic, Washington officials believe, and pledged a year ago to insure that he disappeared from public life in the Serbian-governed portion of Bosnia.
Mr. Holbrooke, reached at his vacation home in the Hamptons on Long Island in New York, took issue with the reports of Mr. Milosevic's words, saying, "This is ridiculous stuff." He said that Mr. Miles, the American diplomat in Belgrade who had briefed other envoys, had not been at all the meetings and that he would get Mr. Miles "on the carpet" for the way he conducted the briefing, but he did not single out points for dispute.
The cable writer noted that Mr. Miles was piqued that Mr. Holbrooke had excluded him from some of the talks with Mr. Milosevic, which took place one evening and one morning.
On the question of the war-crimes suspects, Mr. Holbrooke said: "There was a very long discussion. Miles wasn't present."
On the implementation of the Dayton accords, Mr. Holbrooke said Mr. Milosevic's "rhetoric" had been the usual, and that his words were no different than in the past.
On Kosovo, Mr. Holbrooke said the cable writer "got it right" but that Mr. Milosevic "always says that stuff" regarding Kosovo. He said that 90 percent of the discussion about Ms. Plavsic was "out of Miles's hearing."

HEADLINE: Clinton Met Campaign Donor To Discuss a Trade Dispute

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The White House acknowledged today that President Clinton met last summer with the chairman of the Federal Express Corporation, whose company was a major donor to Democrats and Republicans in last year's campaign and who was seeking a far tougher stance against Japan in a long-running trade dispute involving air cargo.
But officials said Mr. Clinton declined the chairman's request for immediate sanctions, which the Administration's economic advisers had decided would be counterproductive in a complex negotiation involving a number of civil aviation issues. 
 The meeting between the President and the executive, Frederick W. Smith, reported in The Washington Post today, occurred at Mr. Smith's request, Administration officials said. He was angry because the Clinton Administration was reluctant to retaliate after several years of inconclusive negotiations.
A year after that meeting, the Administration is still negotiating, and, while it has periodically threatened sanctions, it has never invoked them.
The meeting is likely to draw the scrutiny of Congressional committees investigating campaign finance issues because Mr. Smith's name appears on a list of executives, prepared by the Democratic National Committee in the spring of 1996, whom Mr. Clinton was asked to call seeking donations. Mr. Clinton apparently tried to reach Mr. Smith by telephone in April, four months before the meeting, but did not succeed.
In August, however, Mr. Smith succeeded in arranging a meeting with the President. The meeting occurred despite the fact that Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairman of the National Economic Council, had argued earlier that direct contact between the President and Mr. Smith on the Japan dispute would be a waste of the President's time.
"We all knew that Fred wanted to take his case up with the President directly," Ms. Tyson said in a telephone interview today. "And while we thought he had a legitimate trade complaint, most of us did not agree with the tactics he advocated."
"In the end," Ms. Tyson said, "Fred got his meeting, and the President followed the advice of his policy advisers, not Federal Express." Ms. Tyson said she had not been present at the meeting and had not known of it in advance.
Lanny J. Davis, special White House counsel, said: "We regard the meeting with Mr. Smith as entirely appropriate on an issue that was of longstanding interest and concern to this and prior Administrations. Any suggestion that the President's interest in this issue has anything to do with a campaign contribution is utterly baseless."
Federal Express officials said today that the company's donations to the Democrats last year totaled $506,000. Its donations to the Republican Party, they said, were $540,000. Mr. Smith endorsed President George Bush in the 1992 campaign and was harshly critical of Mr. Clinton then.
A company spokesman, Bill Margaritas, said that Federal Express "makes balanced allocations to Democrats and Republicans" and that it "uses all available channels to make known its views on trade and other subjects."
"But there is no connection between contributions and the meeting," he said.
The issue that prompted the meeting between Mr. Smith and Mr. Clinton dates from 1993 and has been a source of tension and high-level discussions with Tokyo. At issue are the cargo company's rights to fly packages from Japan to other Asian nations, often through the company's relatively new hub at Subic Bay in the Philippines. It is a place Mr. Clinton knows well: just after the election was over in November, the President attended a summit meeting of Asian leaders that was held at Subic Bay, site of a huge American military base that was closed in 1992.
Federal Express argues that under a 1952 aviation agreement with Japan, it has a right to compete in cargo transportation throughout Asia, shipping goods through Japanese airports. Japanese officials have interpreted the treaty differently, and insisted on more landing rights for Japanese passenger flights to the United States and a scrapping of the 1952 accord, reached as Japan was emerging from the shadow of American occupation.
Long before the Presidential campaign geared up, the issue was at the top of Washington's trade agenda. It was one of the first issues that Mr. Clinton raised with Japan's Prime Minister at a 1995 meeting in Halifax, Nova Scotia. At various times over the last three years, including a month before the Oval Office meeting, the Department of Transportation has publicly threatened to retaliate against Japanese airlines unless restrictions on Federal Express are relaxed. But the State Department has opposed such a step -- arguing that there are broader interests in relations with Japan -- and so far its view has prevailed.
Ten weeks ago Japan approved several new routes for Federal Express, but refused to relax the overall restrictions on flights between Tokyo and the rest of Asia. Negotiations are scheduled to resume next week in Washington over further openings in the air market.
But as Mr. Clinton almost certainly knew when he met Mr. Smith in the Oval Office, the issue of how to help Federal Express is a complicated one. If sanctions resulted in countersanctions, the first victims would likely be United Airlines, American Airlines and Northwest Airlines, all of which have passenger routes between the United States and Japan.

HEADLINE: Fed Unanimous on Steady Rates in July

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers were unanimous in holding the overnight bank lending rate steady at their midyear review July 1-2, minutes of the session that were released today showed.
At its latest meeting on Tuesday, the Federal Open Market Committee also refrained from altering monetary policy. Minutes of that session will be released Oct. 2, after the committee's Sept. 30 session. 
 The committee, which sets the Fed's interest rate policy, meets eight times a year. Deliberations are held in secret. Minutes are released several weeks later.
The committee voted 10 to 0 in July to leave the Federal funds target -- what banks can charge each other for overnight loans -- at 5.5 percent, amid signs the economy was cooling after growing rapidly in the first quarter.
The minutes showed that the panel also maintained a bias in favor of raising the interest rate target, if need be, to guard against inflation.
The committee last raised the target a quarter-point on March 25, expressing concern that the economy's rapid growth could translate into accelerated inflation. Since then, the economy has grown at a more subdued pace, while producer prices have fallen for seven consecutive months and consumer prices are rising at the slowest pace in more than a decade.

HEADLINE: In Hospital, Immigrant Gives Views On Brutality

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
His name has been invoked by street protesters and mayoral candidates. He has been the focus of outraged editorials and national news coverage. For many immigrant and minority New Yorkers, he is the latest victim of a criminal-justice system that is too often a foe, not a protector.
But at the center of this storm, Abner Louima's main concerns are more immediate, and more ordinary. When will his body stop hurting, and when can he leave the hospital? When will he be able to go to the bathroom normally? When will his wife stop crying? 
 "When I see my family in pain, I have to stay strong," Mr. Louima said yesterday as he lay with tubes stuck on his side.
Not that Mr. Louima, the 30-year-old Haitian immigrant who prosecutors say was brutalized by police officers from the 70th Precinct in Flatbush, Brooklyn, is unaware of the larger issues his plight has raised.
"What keeps me going is that even if I don't get anything out of this, that my children can grow up in a new society -- a society where no one else is victimized like I was," he said, speaking in Creole. "I believe there are other victims who are either ashamed to come out or did not know how to speak out for themselves."
The nature of the charges -- prosecutors say police officers who arrested Mr. Louima in a scuffle outside a nightclub beat him and then, in the station bathroom, shoved the handle of a toilet plunger into his rectum and his mouth -- has stirred widespread anger. But Mr. Louima's voice, soft and weak, seemed to reflect more pain and weariness than anger.
"The best way to apply anger is to go to the march," Mr. Louima said, referring to a protest planned for Aug. 29 by the Haitian-American Alliance and a coalition of other community organizations. "It will send a strong signal to people in charge that we deplore police brutality. Hopefully that will not happen again."
"It's intolerable," Mr. Louima said quietly. "I think everyone should be an advocate against police brutality."
A quiet and unassuming man, Mr. Louima is an unlikely candidate for political symbolism. He is the oldest of four children who grew up in Port-au-Prince, the Haitian capital, where their father was a tailor. In the early 1980's other family members left Haiti for New York, uprooted by the political trouble of the Caribbean nation.
But Mr. Louima stayed to complete his education, receiving a degree in electrical engineering from the Ecole Nationale des Arts Metiers.
He rejoined his family in Brooklyn in 1990, married in 1994 and settled into a typical immigrant's life: working nights and weekends as a security guard, and helping raise his 1-year-old son, Abner Jr. (His 7-year-old daughter remained in Haiti with her mother when he emigrated.)
Even before the events of recent days, he said, he had also endured an immigrant's hardships. "Haitians have to come to the United States to really appreciate their country," said Mr. Louima, who said he hopes to write a book about his ordeals. "When you come here you have to endure humiliation and other indignities, like people calling you all kind of racist names. In Haiti, with all of the troubles, you are respected as a human being."
Still, he said, the lack of economic opportunities back in Haiti makes it difficult or impossible for most people like him to think of returning.
Mr. Louima spoke in an hourlong interview at his bedside at Brooklyn Hospital Center, where he is protected by two plainclothes officers. A Bible sat on a lamp table surrounded by flowers sent by friends and strangers.
But on the advice of his lawyers and family members, Mr. Louima would not discuss details of the events outside the Rendez-Vous nightclub, where he was arrested after a melee, nor what happened inside the precinct station house.
He did not address some politically charged aspects of the case, including his assertion, stated by his lawyers, that one of his police attackers said, "This is Giuliani time, not Dinkins time" as they assaulted him.
The criminal investigation continues and Mr. Louima's lawyer, Sanford A. Rubinstein, has said he will file a civil lawsuit against the city.
While Mr. Louima said he would forgive the men accused of torturing him, he said he was not so sure what he would tell them if they were to meet. He said he would not ask them why they beat him so savagely or what he did to deserve it. To him, it does not matter.
"It's been done," said Mr. Louima, who has undergone surgery twice for a torn bladder and other injuries and will probably be hospitalized another month or more. "Right now that's not important." Doctors say it is still unclear when or if he will regain normal bowel function.
Mr. Louima, like most Haitian immigrants who came here fleeing political turmoil or economic hardship, said he had always wanted to stay as far away as possible from the police and other authorities. And for more than six years, he had done just that.
But early on Saturday, Aug. 9, Mr. Louima found himself in a swirling crowd outside Club Rendez-Vous on Flatbush Avenue as the police arrived to break up a fight. According to witnesses, Mr. Louima was arrested after a man in the crowd knocked Officer Justin A. Volpe flat in a fistfight in front of other officers; some witnesses said that Mr. Louima had struck Officer Volpe. (The charges against Mr. Louima, including assaulting an officer, were dropped.) Investigators are now looking into the possibility that another man hit Officer Volpe.
Prosecutors have charged two officers with beating Mr. Louima en route to the station, and two others with attacking him in the bathroom.
As the blows rained down, Mr. Louima said, he winced, braced himself for the beating and prayed for it to end. Every hit, every racial slur and every indignity was somehow softened by the hope that at least he would see his wife and son again. And when it was all over, his prayers were answered, Mr. Louima said, because he had survived.
"I kept saying, Please, God, don't let me die," he said yesterday. "I was praying to protect my life because if I died, I did not know who would take care of my children."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Abner Louima, speaking in his hospital bed yesterday, said, "The best way to apply anger is to go to the march." (Garry Pierre-Pierre/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1148 words

HEADLINE: Texas Jail Video Puts Transfer Programs in Doubt

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
It started out a few years ago as an unlikely economic development program: parlaying an excess of jail cells into out-of-state payments. Inmates were sent from states as far away as Hawaii and Massachusetts, and 5,500 of them are now lodged in county jails across Texas.
While the transfer policy was already tangled in numerous court disputes over its constitutionality, it is now the subject of a mushrooming controversy after a videotape became public this week depicting guards in a Houston-area jail kicking inmates from Missouri, coaxing dogs to bite them and shocking at least one prisoner with a stun gun. 
 The nearly year-old videotape, which was originally shot to be part of a training film for jail guards, has led Missouri to cancel its contract to house 415 inmates at the Texas jail.
"As soon as we saw that, our only recourse was to bring them back," John Fougere, a spokesman for the Missouri Department of Corrections, said today in referring to the taped beatings. "We're not going to stand for something like that."
The tape has also prompted the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Houston to announce an inquiry into the possible violations of the inmates' civil rights at the privately run jail, the Brazoria County Detention Center in Angleton.
The incident has grown even more controversial with disclosures that two of the guards who were reported to be involved in the abuse had been hired despite having convictions for beating inmates in their previous jobs as guards in the Texas prison system.
It prompted Gov. George W. Bush of Texas to place a personal call this week to Gov. Mel Carnahan of Missouri in which a spokeswoman for Mr. Bush said the Governor assured his Missouri counterpart that the abuse shown on the videotape was not condoned by Texas officials and would be thoroughly investigated and dealt with.
And the tape has provoked denunciations from many other quarters, including State Representative Ron Wilson of Houston, a Democrat, who said: "If those old boys were acting the way they were on videotape, no telling what they're doing when they're not on tape. That is the scary part. They knew they were on tape."
Many questions raised by disclosure of the videotape -- including whether the guards were provoked or how seriously the inmates were injured -- have yet to be answered because all those involved have declined to respond to inquiries.
Officials in the Brazoria County sheriff's office initially said that they did not think the tape depicted wanton abuse, but they have since declined to make any comment.
The sheriff's office day referred all questions about the tape to Otto Hewitt, a lawyer in Alvin, Tex., who is representing Capital Correctional Resources Inc. of Jackson, Miss., the company that runs the jail.
"This matter is currently in litigation and therefore neither I nor my staff are at liberty to discuss it with you," an assistant to Mr. Hewitt said today, reading from a prepared statement of his. "We expect defendants to be fully vindicated in the court's final judgment; no civil rights violations having occurred or being established."
The videotape apparently came to light in the course of proceedings in a lawsuit by the Missouri inmates and was first reported in The Brazosport Facts, a local newspaper.
While the videotape has become a flashpoint, it is far from the first time that out-of-state inmates have complained about the treatment they have received in Texas jails, or even that out-of-state prison officials have expressed concerns about conditions at the jails.
Several months ago, Oklahoma officials began taking back their inmates from the Limestone County Detention Facility in Groesebeck, Tex., after they were reported to be bothered by how often their prisoners were being controlled with pepper spray.
And just this week, Federal authorities announced an investigation into conditions at a privately run county jail in northwest Texas, which houses hundreds of inmates from Montana and Hawaii. Prisoners there have complained about strip searches and the guards' use of warning shots in giving them orders. And an audit by Montana's Corrections Department concluded that there was inadequate food, medical care and counseling services at the prison.
In addition, a Montana inmate was killed in May in a fight between factions from the two states.
The basic policy of transferring state prisoners to Texas has already provoked legal challenges in the home states of many of the prisoners. The inmates complain that being moved severely limits their ability to have visits from family members, meet with their lawyers or arrange for work and a place to live upon their release.
But a group of inmates from Colorado has already gone one step further, arguing that their transfer violates their constitutional rights because, they say, conditions in Texas jails are much worse than at those in Colorado prisons.
And underlying the whole dispute here is the question of whether there is more abuse or poorer living conditions at the Texas jails than at those of other states. Such a contention is staunchly denied by Texas corrections officials, although they also point out that by definition, jails are typically designed for shorter stays than prisons and thus typically have less in the way of services and recreational offerings.
County officials in Texas, which has far more out-of-state inmates than any other state, have welcomed the prisoners, for whom they receive an average of $40 a day. That has amounted to about $80 million for Texas counties that run their own jails and the private companies that run many jails in Texas.
In general, courts have upheld the constitutionality of the transfer of prisoners to other states, although there have been exceptions, said Jenni Gainsborough, public policy administrator of the National Prison Project of the American Civil Liberties Union. A judge in New Mexico, she said, found that the transfers violated terms of a consent decree between that state and a group of prisoners shipped to Texas, and they were brought home.
A judge hearing the Colorado inmates' claim had clearly expressed sympathy for the inmates' assertions that conditions at a northeast Texas jail fell below state standards. But that case was essentially sent back to square one when the inmates were shipped to other jails in Texas and were required to prove that their new quarters also failed to meet the state standards.
Ms. Gainsborough described the tape from Brazoria County as shocking. "I think there can be no two opinions about that," she said. "It's O.K. now to treat prisoners worse than we treat animals and we find that very disturbing."
At least one Missouri inmate, a convicted burglar, has filed a civil lawsuit seeking $100,000 in damages for being kicked by guards and bitten by a jail dog.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
Charge in Internet Sex Case

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
A 39-year-old unemployed computer engineer from Long Branch was charged yesterday by Federal prosecutors with taking sexually explicit photographs of a 14-year-old girl whom he had met in an Internet chat room in June.
The man, Richard C. Crandon, drove to the girl's home in Coon Rapids, Minn., on Monday to bring her to New Jersey, but left her at a bus stop in State College, Pa., the next day after learning that her mother had reported her missing, said Lieut. Patrick M. Joyce of the Long Branch police. 
 When the police arrested Mr. Crandon at his home Wednesday, they found photographs of the girl partly nude and charged him with endangering the welfare of a minor, Lieutenant Joyce said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Market Volatility Continues With 127-Point Fall in Dow
The Dow industrials again moved by 100 points, but for the first time this week, the direction was downward.
 
 Stocks fell despite a dearth of disappointing financial reports and without indications of a change in the backdrop of moderate growth and low inflation. [Page D3.]
 
One of the big decliners was Wells Fargo, which fell sharply on reports -- erroneous, as it turned out, but drawn from a misunderstood filing with the S.E.C. -- that the company run by Warren Buffett had sold its big holding of Wells Fargo's stock. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [A1.]
 
Like stocks, bond prices fell sharply, as concerns about interest rates and inflation persisted. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.62 percent from 6.54. [D13.]
 
Disappointing Results at Novell
Novell, the troubled provider of computer networking software, reported a sharp decline in revenues as it tried to reduce excess inventory among resellers. That contributed to a substantially bigger quarterly loss than analysts had estimated. [D2.]
 
Amgen Sees Hope for New Drugs
Amgen agreed to pay $48.5 million to Guilford Pharmaceuticals to acquire the rights to a new compounds that could serve as the basis of drugs to treat nervous-system disorders. [D2.]
 
The A.M.A. Changes Its Mind
As expected, the American Medical Association abandoned its plan to endorse health care products made by Sunbeam. [D2.]
 
Saatchi and Bell Atlantic Split Up
Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising agreed to part ways with Bell Atlantic after the agency failed to win the full account of the telecommunications company. The newly expanded Bell Atlantic -- after its merger with Nynex -- wants to work with many agencies. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]
 
Meat Plant to Shut for a While
A Nebraska meat-processing plant owned by Hudson Foods is closing temporarily and expanding its recall of ground beef after investigators found evidence that far more meat might be contaminated by hazardous bacteria than originally suspected. [A1.]
 
Not a Complete Win for Teamsters
The teamsters' agreement with the United Parcel Service, hailed by many as an unqualified breakthrough victory for organized labor, includes a number of unpublicized concessions by the union that will help the company hold down the cost of the five-year contract. [A21.]
 
A U.P.S. competitor, Federal Express, told nearly 90,000 nonunion workers -- the bulk of its work force -- that they would receive special bonuses for their efforts during the strike. The teamsters have mounted a big organizing drive at Federal Express. [A21.]
 
President Clinton acted to postpone for 60 days a possible nationwide strike against Amtrak, invoking the Railway Labor Act, which was not applicable in the U.P.S. strike. [A21.]
 
Venerable Imprint Changes Hands
Basic Books, a bastion of scholarly publishing whose roster of distinctive authors includes Freud, is being sold by HarperCollins to a venture capital firm, Perseus Capital. [D2.]
 
Deal to Create Big Title Insurer
Lawyers Title of Richmond said that it was buying the title insurance companies of Reliance Group Holdings for $478 million in cash and stock. [D2.]
 
Dollar Slips Against Mark
The dollar fell against the mark after the Bundesbank modified its practice on a key money-market rate. [D4.]
 
California Measure Advances
A Federal appeals court reaffirmed California's right to do away with racial and sex-based preferences, clearing a major hurdle for the 1996 ballot measure to end state-run affirmative action programs. [A16.]

CORRECTION-DATE: August 23, 1997, Saturday

HEADLINE: Film Festival Plans Almodovar Premiere

 BODY:
The New York Film Festival, which opens Sept. 26 at Avery Fisher Hall with Ang Lee's "Ice Storm," has announced that it will end its 35th annual presentation on Oct. 12 with the world premiere of Pedro Almodovar's "Live Flesh." A thriller set in Madrid, the film involves the police, a diplomat's daughter and the ghosts of Franco's rule.
The festival, organized by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, will offer 28 films from 18 countries and will have as its centerpiece "The Sweet Hereafter," directed by Atom Egoyan. The film stars Ian Holm as a lawyer investigating a schoolbus crash in British Columbia that results in the death of children. "The Sweet Hereafter" won the Grand Prize at the Cannes International Film Festival in May. It will be shown Oct. 4 and 5 in Alice Tully Hall. 
 In what it calls a "special sidebar event" at Avery Fisher Hall on Sept. 29, the festival will present the world premiere of the Museum of Modern Art's restoration of D. W. Griffith's "Orphans of the Storm," including the original score by William Frederick Peters and Louis F. Gottschalk. The score will be performed by the Brooklyn Philharmonic under Gillian Anderson. "Marcello Mastroianni, I Remember, Yes I Remember," a documentary by Anna Maria Tato, his longtime companion, will be shown at Avery Fisher Hall on Sept. 29. The actor died in December at the age of 72.
Jim Jarmusch's documentary on Neil Young, "Year of the Horse," and Lars von Trier's "Kingdom Part II" will be shown on Oct. 4 and 12, respectively, at the Walter Reade Theater as part of the special-event program.
Among the countries represented by festival offerings are Iran, Egypt, Russia, Mexico, Japan and France. "Taste of Cherry," by the Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami, won the Palme d'Or at Cannes this year and focuses on a man contemplating suicide as he drives around the outskirts of Teheran. From Egypt, "Destiny," directed by Youssef Chahine, takes place in the 12th century and concerns the conflict between intellectual exploration and religious orthodoxy.
Russia's Aleksandr Sokurov paints a picture of abandonment and grief in "Mother and Son." The Mexican entry, "Deep Crimson," directed by Arturo Ripstein, is a psychological drama about a seducer and his victims. In "Hana-Bi," the multi-talented Japanese performer and writer Takeshi Kitano stars in his own film about a former detective who embarks on a wild scheme to make amends for a crippling injury to his partner. Bruno Dumont's "Vie de Jesus," which won the Jean Vigo Prize for best first film, follows the fortunes of unemployed youths in northern France.
The American contingent includes "Telling Lies in America," directed by Gus Ferland, written by Joe Eszterhas and starring Kevin Bacon, Brad Renfro, Maximilian Schell and Calista Flockhart in a story about an immigrant teen-ager learning the ropes from dubious sources in 1960's Cleveland. Paul Thomas Anderson's "Boogie Nights" concerns sexual and other excesses among teen-agers in Southern California during the 1970's and early 80's. Mark Wahlberg stars. "The Apostle," written, directed and financed by Robert Duvall, also stars Mr. Duvall as a preacher on the run from the law. The cast includes Farrah Fawcett, Miranda Richardson and Billy Bob Thornton.
A new adaptation of Henry James's "Washington Square," directed by Agnieszka Holland, stars Albert Finney as the unbending patriarch of James's stifling household and Jennifer Jason Leigh as the daughter whose bleak victory ends the story.
A documentary entry is "Public Housing," Frederick Wiseman's portrait of life in a housing development in Chicago.
The box office for the festival, which is being sponsored for the second year by Grand Marnier, will open on Sept. 7 at noon at Alice Tully Hall. Information: (212) 875-5050.

HEADLINE: New York's Waterways

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Aug. 18 editorial "A Reborn Erie Canal" overlooked Gov. George E. Pataki's strong commitment to New York's waterways as both environmental and economic assets.
In the past two years Mr. Pataki has earmarked more than $150 million for the revitalization of the Erie Canal, a sum that belies your argument that he is unenthusiastic about the project. Additionally, the development of the Hudson River Park, along with Mr. Pataki's $100 million commitment, continues apace, and three miles of bicycle paths are open this summer. 
 Finally, the suggestion that Mr. Pataki revisit the idea of moving the elevated West Side Highway over the old Penn Central railroad yards is aimed in the wrong direction. No one has questioned the desirability of plac ing a park there. What is in question is the extraordinary public expense of relocating the highway. We agree with the Giuliani administration that tearing down a stretch of road that has just been rebuilt at a cost of $70 million is a waste of taxpayers' money at this time.
 
CHARLES A. GARGANO
New York, Aug. 20, 1997
 
Chairman, Empire State
Development Corporation

HEADLINE: British Slice $5 Billion From MCI Bid

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Saying that a gloomier business outlook makes the MCI Communications Corporation worth 22 percent less than it was just nine months ago, British Telecommunications P.L.C. announced yesterday that it had renegotiated its agreement to acquire the American company.
The revised deal is subject to another round of voting by shareholders of each company late this year. And while many analysts said they expected investors to approve the new pact, the support by MCI shareholders will probably be much weaker than the 3-to-1 margin by which they approved the original merger last spring. 
 Several MCI shareholders had already filed suit, contending that MCI's management could have negotiated a better deal. The new, lower price for MCI seems likely to bring even louder complaints from investors.
British Telecom, concerned by eroding profits in MCI's core long-distance telephone business and by mounting losses in MCI's nascent local-service operation, said it would pay about $19 billion for the 80 percent of MCI it did not already own rather than stick with the $24 billion deal the companies announced last November.
"I didn't want to look at the screen today I was so upset," said Salvatore Muoio, an analyst with the financial research firm S. Muoio & Company. "If you own MCI stock, my opinion is this is not a good transaction for you."
The announcement, which came a day after the Federal Communications Commission gave final regulatory approval to the merger, capped weeks of speculation that British Telecom, under pressure from skeptical shareholders, would push MCI to accept a lower price. MCI steadfastly denied that the two companies were renegotiating the deal -- only to issue a terse statement on Wednesday night confirming the talks.
In London yesterday, executives from the two companies said there had been no change in the global strategy behind the purchase by Britain's dominant telecommunications company of the No. 2 American long-distance carrier. But British Telecom executives said MCI's troubles within the United States had forced them to shave about $5 billion from the price.
Most other big telecommunications providers are also lining up international partners these days as they try to offer their customers seamless global service. The Sprint Corporation, for instance, is partly owned by Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom. And the AT&T Corporation has loose ties to more than a dozen overseas telecommunications companies under the rubric of its World Partners alliance.
If the British Telecom-MCI deal is approved by shareholders, it will create a $43 billion giant called Concert with 43 million customers in 72 countries. But Concert would still be smaller than AT&T, which recorded $52.2 billion in worldwide revenue last year.
"There is a global revolution in telecoms which offers a huge opportunity for the merged company," Sir Peter L. Bonfield, the chief executive of British Telecommunications, said at a news conference yesterday in London. "The changes in the United States and the U.K. markets have prompted a new agreement that fairly reflects the current market realities."
Under the new terms, MCI's stock owners would receive 0.375 of a British Telecommunications American depository receipt and $7.75 in cash for each share of MCI.
British Telecom's American depository receipts closed yesterday at $68.1875, up $1.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange, making the deal worth about $33.32 per share of MCI.
Under the deal's previous terms, holders of MCI's stock would have received 0.54 of a British Telecom A.D.R. and $6 in cash for each share of MCI. So, under the old terms the takeover was worth about $42.82 per share of MCI.
MCI's shares lost 62.5 cents yesterday, closing at $29.9375 in Nasdaq trading.
In renegotiating the merger, British Telecom executives not only reduced the total amount their company will pay for MCI. By shifting the proportions of stock and cash in the deal, they also reduced the amount of the new company that will be owned by former MCI shareholders, to about 25 percent from around 34 percent.
That was important to the British company because its stockholders were worried that their stakes would become highly diluted as the company issued millions of new shares.
"From the B.T. shareholders' point of view, the change in the terms is more advantageous than I could have expected," said James Golob, an analyst in London for Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. "And I think that reflects the reality of the market, which is that if the deal fell through B.T. shares would actually have gone up and MCI shares would have dropped."
Even now, though, conservative British investors might have reservations about the deal.
"A lot of U.K. fund managers are skeptical of anything global, which they think leads to dilution," Mr. Golob added. "They don't like acquisitions, and they don't like U.S. acquisitions. They don't like U.S. anything."
The companies said that the merger would lead to lower earnings for this year and next year but that it would add to their profits starting in 1999. They estimated that by the fifth year after the acquisition, Concert would earn $800 million a year more than the two companies would have earned separately.
The general reaction from many analysts in the United States, like Daniel Reingold at Merrill Lynch, was that MCI had done as well for itself as could be expected. But that was probably little solace for the many hedge fund managers who made big bets that the original deal would go through and ended up big losers this week.
"On the economics you'd rather just continue to own the stock," Mr. Muoio said.
The economics have not often been on MCI's side recently. The joint review of MCI's finances that ended in yesterday's announcement began after MCI announced last month that it could lose as much as $800 million this year -- twice the loss the company had previously forecast -- in its unit that is trying to break into the $100 billion local telephone market.
MCI said yesterday that it remained committed to offering local service, but that in the future the company would be "targeting investment on those local markets that we expect will be opening most quickly to true competition." MCI began offering local telephone service in the New York City area earlier this month.
Perhaps even more alarming to British Telecom executives was MCI's disclosure last month that its long-distance business was not growing as quickly as it had. That trend was reflected in the company's financial results for the second quarter, when its profits fell 6 percent from the corresponding 1996 period.
"I'm sure that the erosion of profitability in the core business was of the most concern to B.T.," said William Deatherage, an analyst for Bear, Stearns & Company. "There is no question that over the last year the intensity of competition in the long-distance market has gone to a new level."
After MCI disclosed its weaknesses last month, Mr. Deatherage lowered his estimate for MCI's earnings this year to $1.15 a share, from $1.65.
"I think it was a fair adjustment in the acquisition price, given the reduced earnings forecast for MCI," he said. "Frankly, this is as good as the MCI management can do under the circumstances."

HEADLINE: The Private Sector Life of a Government Lab;
Drumming Up Business to Survive in a World Without Cold War

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company wanted to predict, without weeks of test drives, how its tires would perform under various conditions. So it went to the Energy Department's Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M., for help. "Their computer models show how a nuclear weapon will react to different conditions, so why shouldn't they show how a tire will react?" asked William Sharp, president of Goodyear's global support operations.
A Federal weapons laboratory might seem an unlikely partner for a tire maker, but with the cold war over and military spending shrinking, Sandia is putting out the welcome mat to private industry. And American corporations, which have emerged in this era after downsizing as far more willing to turn to outside sources, are lining up to tap into its technology storehouse. 
 They are using Sandia to develop new manufacturing processes, to run what-if simulations on new products, to solve environmental problems. In the process, they are helping Sandia move beyond its once single-minded focus on the arms race.
For example, a consortium of 17 casting and forging companies, recognizing that few young engineers were joining the industry, asked Sandia to help it simplify software so that employees who were not engineers could create and test new casting equipment. "None of us have the time or money to do this ourselves," said Robert B. Kervick, chief executive of Komtek, a casting company in Worcester, Mass.
And Motorola asked Sandia to run reliability tests on computer chips without using the standard chemical cleaning agents -- the chlorofluorocarbons that destroy the atmosphere's ozone layer. "Customers feel more comfortable buying a product whose reliability is verified by a Government lab," said James F. Landers, a manager in the Space and Systems Technology Group of Motorola.
For Sandia, the money pouring in from its corporate partners helps keep many of its 7,642 employees -- about 800 fewer than two years ago -- gainfully employed. But the real winner, Sandia insists, is the American economy. "National security starts with economic security, and that means helping our industries compete," said C. Paul Robinson, Sandia's president.
Sandia (pronounced san-DEE-uh), which has operations in Livermore, Calif., as well as in Albuquerque, is not the only Energy Department lab sounding that theme. Although documents emerged last week indicating that some of the labs, including Sandia, are still hard at work on new or modified designs for nuclear arms, private-sector projects are nonetheless occupying an ever-larger share of their time.
Los Alamos, Oak Ridge, Lawrence Livermore -- the heart, lungs and brain of the Manhattan Project's atomic bomb and its progeny -- all have been accelerating their industrial endeavors since 1989. That was when Congress removed many of the legal impediments that had kept them from transferring intellectual property or licensing technologies to private industry. Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island, which is grappling with environmental problems caused by the leak of radioactive tritium from a research reactor's storage tank, is looking to commercialize its medical and environmental technologies.
In the last eight years, the labs have written more than 3,000 Cradas -- the acronym for cooperative research and development agreements -- that spell out who pays for what, and how the results can be used. Some call for companies to foot the entire bill in return for proprietary rights to anything that is developed. But more typically, the labs chip in some cash, retain the rights to the resulting technology and give the corporations that contributed several years of free, exclusive use.
The Federal labs, even when shrouded in secrecy, have always intermingled with industry. Many of them have been managed by private corporations -- under contract to the Energy Department and its predecessors -- for several decades. Sandia, for one, was run by AT&T for nearly 44 years and is now managed by Lockheed Martin.
But while all of the labs are devoting more time and resources to projects in the private sector, the effort seems most crucial at Sandia. Unlike Oak Ridge, which has always been a multipurpose energy lab, Sandia's raison d'etre has always been the arms race. And Sandia, which designs the nonnuclear components of nuclear weapons, also is responsible for stockpiling spare parts, and for maintaining the existing supply of nuclear weapons. So, unlike Lawrence Livermore and Los Alamos, which design and develop nuclear warheads, its duties have not lessened much with the end of the cold war.
Even so, Sandia's operating budget is slowly being whittled away. It was down almost $50 million this year, to about $1.28 billion, and Sandia expects it will drop to $1.1 billion in 1999. And a lot of those cuts have come out of the money available for use as matching funds for industrial projects. In 1995, Sandia got about $100 million from the Government for those purposes; it received $56 million last year and $20 million this year. Warren Siemens, Sandia's director of technology partnerships, doubts it will rise above that again.
"Apparently, Congress has said, 'Oops, this is corporate welfare,' " Mr. Siemens said.
So, while most of the laboratories are looking for ways to apply their existing technologies to corporate use, Sandia is the most willing to develop new processes for industry, with the hope that the companies will cover most of the costs.
Right now, for example, Sandia is working with a consortium of electronics companies on a project to miniaturize certain types of semiconductor chips to handle 30 times the functions they typically do now. It is collaborating with numerous manufacturers on ways to cast tools directly from powdered metals. And it is encouraging industry to tap into its supercomputer -- a machine that Sandia says is 300 times as powerful as Deep Blue, I.B.M.'s chess playing champion -- not only to answer questions about products and processes, but also to suggest what questions should be asked.
"We hold the record for speed of computing," Mr. Siemens said. "We have great strength in microelectronics, and these are exactly the areas companies look to for help in making products more reliable."
Progress in persuading industry to chip in has been slow. Five years ago, about $9 million of Sandia's funds came from industry. Last year corporations provided $27 million. But Mr. Siemens thinks private financing will hit $35 million this year, and soar to $100 million by 2000.
And Sandia wants more from industry than simply money. Since it can no longer afford to hire many new researchers, it must rely on industry to keep abreast of new technologies.
Moreover, industrial projects often have implications for the military. "It's a lot cheaper to maintain an air force whose planes need less rebuilding or repairing," said Gernant E. Maurer, vice president of technology for the Special Metals Corporation, a maker of nickel-based superalloys that is part of a consortium working with Sandia to develop defect-free alloys for engine aircraft.
Similarly, weapons and satellites are loaded with semiconductor chips. "Our nation's defense systems rely on semiconductors, and it would not be great if they had to buy all those chips from overseas," said Chris Daverse, manager of national resources for Sematech Inc., a nonprofit research consortium of semiconductor makers and equipment suppliers, which has signed on for numerous projects to develop lower-cost production methods and contamination-free chips.
Sandia's new reliance on industry comes at an opportune time. Companies have grown more comfortable with the idea of outsourcing all kinds of tasks, so letting outsiders work on their research is not as radical as it would have been in the do-it-yourself 80's. Moreover, many have formed strategic alliances with suppliers and competitors, making companies less averse to sharing their technologies with others.
"The thinking is, it is better to get half the rights to a product that is first to market, than all the rights to one that comes in late," said Mary L. Good, a former Under Secretary of Commerce who helped set up a project among the auto industry and several national laboratories to develop a fuel-efficient car.
If repeat business is a sign of satisfaction, the corporations that have tried it clearly believe they have received their money's worth. Goodyear, which has completed four cooperative projects in which it used computer modeling to predict how different tread designs and materials would perform, just signed on for its fifth Sandia project. It is aimed at analyzing and improving rubber processing technology.
A deal between Delphi Saginaw Steering Systems, an arm of the General Motors Corporation, and Sandia to develop better finishing processes for auto parts has metamorphosed into a Detroit-wide project to develop electronic controls for industrial heating and hardening processes.
"We'll save tens of millions just by eliminating destructive testing," said James M. Farago, Delphi's supervisor of controls engineering. "And we're going to get better insights into the materials we use."

Many of the country's national laboratories were set up during or just after World War II as part of the nuclear weapons program. Fifty years later, the labs are still involved in weapons research, but many are also teaming up with companies in the private sector to do research with direct commercial applications. Chart lists various labs, their location, date founded, and what they are currently working on. (pg. 35)
 
"The Cost of Cutting-Edge Research"
The Federal Government spends billions of dollars a year on the national laboratories. With the cold war over, though, some of the labs have lost support, while others have managed to justify increased spending.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 635 words

HEADLINE: Colleges Beyond Reach

 BODY:
A forthcoming report from two university economists asserts that students from affluent families are attending public colleges and universities in ever larger numbers. The report has already commanded considerable media attention and has raised fears that wealthier students may be grabbing places in lower-cost institutions that would normally be occupied by poorer students. It has also inspired some interest in the notion of means-testing public education -- charging higher fees for wealthier students.
Means-testing is a misplaced idea that would discard the venerable principle of equal access to public facilities and possibly undermine taxpayer support for public education. But the report underscores some underlying realities of modern higher education. Chief among these is the fact that rising tuitions at private universities have increased the competition for spaces in public institutions. The report's findings also suggest that educators need to do some imaginative thinking about how to keep those same institutions accessible for bright, low-income students. 
 In their forthcoming book, Michael McPherson of Macalaster College in St. Paul and Morton Schapiro of the University of Southern California estimate that 38 percent of college freshmen from families earning more than $200,000 a year enrolled in public universities in 1994, compared with 31 percent in 1980 -- a slow but steady increase. This has not, so far, greatly altered the demographic balance in public institutions. Though more wealthy students may be attending public colleges, they are still a fraction of the enrollment. In 1995, less than 2 percent of entrants to public four-year colleges came from families earning $200,000 or more.
Nevertheless, as private school tuitions skyrocket and wealthier families decide that the qualitative differences between an Ivy League school and a state university are not worth the huge price differential, the pressures on public institutions are sure to grow -- raising costs and tuitions to a point where they may well be out of reach for many low-income families. Even now, many poorer students are not even applying to public four-year colleges.
Increased demand also raises the academic bar for admission. Applicants for elite public schools like the University of Michigan come equipped with ever higher S.A.T. scores and higher grade point averages. Since those measures are closely tied to family income, low-income students find themselves increasingly disadvantaged.
The broad demographics are also daunting. The fact that a college education, now more than ever, is seen as the ticket to higher paying jobs has elevated enrollment rates of 18- to 24-year-olds from 26.7 percent in 1980 to 34.3 percent in 1995.
An overall drop in the college-age population during that time made the numbers manageable. That is sure to change during the next 15 years, when demographers predict a 20 percent increase in the college-age population.
The central policy question, therefore, is how to keep low-income families from being squeezed out. There are innovative ideas buzzing about. New York's Tuition Assistance Program, for example, gives grants to students based on a sliding income scale. Thomas Kane, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government and Politics, proposes that loans to students from low-income families might be forgiven unless they later join the ranks of the affluent.
Another possibility is to focus the Federal Pell grant program on the first two years of college -- a period when many poor students drop out because they decide they cannot make it financially or academically. The states and the Federal Government need to explore these and other ideas. The old dream of broadly affordable public education keeps receding.

HEADLINE: U.S. Envoy to Kenya Warns Both Sides to Restore Peace

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 22

 BODY:
In a hard-hitting speech aimed at slowing the spiraling violence here, the United States Ambassador to Kenya strongly criticized both the Government and opposition leaders today for heading down a path toward more confrontation and suggested that Kenya's foreign aid may hang in the balance if peace is not restored.
The Ambassador, Prudence Bushnell, also made it clear that the Government led by President Daniel arap Moi must push through several political reforms if it expects the world to judge elections to be held later this year as free and fair. 
 "We hear commitments to free and fair elections, but the political playing field remains decidedly uneven," Ms. Bushnell said.
Her comments appeared intended to break a deadly political stalemate between Mr. Moi's ruling party and opposition politicians seeking to revamp what they see as an unfair electoral system. Thirteen protesters and two police officers have been killed in riots this summer.
A loose coalition of opposition leaders, clergy and civil rights advocates has been staging the protests to persuade Mr. Moi's Government to change the electoral rules and repeal several laws giving him the power to control the media, jail opponents and break up political rallies. Opposition politicians have vowed to boycott and disrupt the elections if their demands are not met.
To appease his critics at home and abroad, Mr. Moi, who is 73 and has been in office since 1978, has proposed his own slate of watered-down reforms in the Parliament, which his party controls. So far, however, he has refused to negotiate with the protest organizers and has maintained there is not enough time to rewrite the Constitution before elections are held.
Ms. Bushnell's words carry weight in Kenya, where the United States has wielded considerable influence since the East African nation gained independence from Britain in 1963. During the cold war, Mr. Moi was a staunch American ally and received millions in Western aid in return.
In the early 1990's, however, the United States Ambassador at the time, Smith Hempstone, became one of Mr. Moi's most vocal critics. He led an international charge that eventually forced Kenya to liberalize its economy and move from a one-party system to open elections.
Last week, Kenya's political crisis took a nastier turn. Beginning Aug. 13, well-organized gangs of thugs drawn from coastal tribes began mounting raids along the Indian Ocean coast around Mombasa, lynching people from inland tribes and razing their homes and kiosks. At least 42 people, including 9 police officers, have been killed.
Mr. Moi has blamed the violence on the opposition, saying leaders had stirred up tribal hatreds. The opposition has charged Mr. Moi's aides with orchestrating the attacks to provide an excuse for forestalling political reforms.
In her speech to the Law Society of Kenya, which has joined the pro-reform coalition, Ms. Bushnell strongly implied -- without naming names -- that both sides bore some responsibility for the violence. She said the United States "does not condone violence as a tool of political change, whatever the objective, whoever the perpetrator."
The Ambassador also delivered a veiled threat to the Moi administration.
"Some leaders in Kenya may anticipate that the current state of affairs, however unhealthy, is only temporary," she said. "Once the Government is back in power, they may believe, political tension will die down and Kenya will return to the fold of multilateral lending institutions with new commitments to old promises."
"It may not necessarily work that way," she went on. "Many within and outside Kenya could decide that, in the words of a popular American expression, they have 'been there, done that,' and don't want to do it again."
Referring to opposition politicians, Ms. Bushnell was equally critical, saying their plans to disrupt the elections "could lead to tragedy."
"Violence and unrest are easy to provoke," she said. "But they are extraordinarily difficult to stop."
Other diplomats, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said there is a growing fear that Mr. Moi will push his less extensive version of political reforms through Parliament and then call the elections immediately for mid-October or early November.
That would set the Government on a collision course with opposition leaders, who have threatened to interfere with the polling if their reforms are scrapped. Since most of the opposition parties are tribally based and each has a youth wing, the result could be bloodshed.
But Kenya's Foreign Minister, Stephen Kalonzo Musyoka, said that giving in to the opposition demands before the polls would lead to tribal clashes. He said some of the electoral changes the opposition leaders are seeking -- a rule requiring a President to win a majority of votes cast, for instance -- would divide the country along tribal lines, giving more voting power to the large tribes and taking away protections now enjoyed by smaller ethnic groups.

HEADLINE: New Model and New Ads As Saab Aims for Revival

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Think of it as a midlife crisis. At age 50, Saab finds itself at a crossroads: After years of struggling, it has a new management team, a new advertising agency and perhaps most important, a new car on the way.
Next month, in the most visible of all the internal shifts at the company, Saab embarks on a new advertising campaign as it struggles to jettison its murky image. 
 "For them, image is going to be critical," said Christopher W. Cedergren, managing director of Nextrend, an auto research group in Thousand Oaks, Calif. "Because the Saab image is so nebulous right now, it is really going to be difficult for them to compete against Mercedes and BMW."
Saab has a plan. The campaign, created by Saab's new advertising agency, the Martin Agency of Richmond, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, aims to reposition the cars as safe, high-performance autos that are fun to drive.
"We're presenting Saab as a car that offers the safety of a Volvo without the boredom, and the performance of a BMW without the pretense," John B. Adams Jr., Martin's chairman and chief executive, said.
The campaign consists of four print advertisements that will appear in the October issues of magazines like Forbes, Food and Wine and Vanity Fair and two 30-second television ads that will be shown, starting Sept. 8, on shows like "Seinfeld," "Tonight" and "20/20."
The print ads have dark backgrounds with quirky, diagonal photographs of the car to convey a sense of motion. One carries a headline reading, "Safety marries performance. They elope." The text describes how driving a Saab feels safe because of the car's turbocharged engine and tight handling. A television ad shows a couple riding down the highway in a convertible as an ominous shadow cast by the setting sun nearly overtakes the car. The driver accelerates, sending the car speeding into the sunshine on the road ahead.
While the new ads showcase the Saab 900, the smaller of Saab's two models, Mr. Adams said the advertisements would reposition the whole Saab brand, which has been struggling. Saab doubled its annual ad budget in 1996 to $62 million, according to Competitive Media Reporting, which tracks advertising spending. With the new ad campaign and the new car, Saab plans to increase its ad spending next year to about $70 million.
Saab's larger car, the 9000 model, will be replaced in April with a sedan called the 9-5, followed with a station wagon in late 1998.
Saab executives have pinned their hopes on the new sedan because it has been so long since the company has introduced a new model. The Saab 9000 has changed little since its debut in 1986. Even the Saab 900 has been around since 1978, although it was substantially redesigned in 1993.
Saab's popularity reached its peak in the mid-1980's, but sales then began to slide, bottoming out in 1993. Profits fell, too. In this decade, Saab has lost money every year except 1994 and 1995. Executives have said they expect Saab to return to profitability in 1999.
For all those years, Saab's owners have been bailing it out while wondering whether they were throwing good money after bad. Saab Automobile A.B. is a joint venture between Investor A.B., an investment group controlled by the Wallenberg family of Sweden, and the General Motors Corporation.
Last summer, Investor seemed to lose patience. It reached a deal with G.M. that gives Investor the right to force G.M. to take an additional 25 percent stake in the company in 2000 and gives G.M. the option of buying Investor's entire stake then. Saab executives have said they hope to improve the company enough by then to make it worth arguing over.
The next 12 to 18 months are "the most important in the last decade" for Saab, said David M. Garrity, an analyst at Smith Barney. "The clock is ticking between now and the year 2000."
Fixing Saab has been harder than executives thought, with sales goals slipping again and again, only to be reset at lower levels. In 1990, when Saab sold 93,224 cars worldwide, its goal was to sell 180,000 by the year 2000. By last year, when it sold 98,036 worldwide, it hoped to sell 150,000 cars by 2000, with 40,000 of them in the United States. This year, it expects sales in this country to top 30,000.
As G.M. has increased its investment in Saab, it has devoted more management attention to it. Last summer, it named Robert W. Hendry, 51, a G.M. executive close to John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman, as chief executive of Saab. It also brought two executives from G.M.'s highly regarded Saturn division to Saab's American arm.
John J. Orth, a former Saturn executive who serves as Saab Cars USA Inc.'s vice president for sales and marketing, said Saab planned to improve its sales and customer service while quietly taking advantage of economies of scale available through its link to G.M.
Since 62 percent of Saab's sales are in the Northeast, Mr. Orth wants to persuade buyers in other parts of the country to choose Saabs. In addition, he is bringing to Saab dealers some lessons learned at Saturn, which has a reputation for strong customer relations.
A handful of Saab dealers are likely to sign up soon to try the no-haggle pricing used by Saturn dealers, and Mr. Orth said he hoped more would try it.
While Saab plans to continue to keep its distance from G.M. when it comes to designing cars, Mr. Orth said the ties to the giant company had already helped it keep costs down.
For instance, the Saab 9-5 shares its underpinnings with G.M.'s Opel cars in Europe, cutting development costs. Also, by using G.M.'s corporate might, Saab was able to get more bang for its buck in advertising. "We've basically gotten 25 to 30 percent more ads than we would have gotten if we'd run the campaigns by ourselves," he said.
But all the changes ride on the shoulders of the Saab 9-5. "Saab is going to put a full-court press on" with the new advertising, Mr. Cedergren, the auto consultant, said. "They really view that car as being the primary catalyst for the rebirth."

Saab's car sales in the United States and worldwide have rebounded from a trough in 1993, but have not returned to the levels of the late 1980's. (Source: Saab)
