HEADLINE: FILM;
A Grim Reality Check In Russia

BYLINE: By NANCY RAMSEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
"OF ALL THE ARTS, THE most important for us is the cinema," Lenin reportedly said not long after the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917. With a population that outside the cities was largely made up of people who couldn't read, cinema would become a "powerful media of enlightenment for the masses," he said. But today Russian film directors hesitate to tell people their profession.
"There's no prestige; it means you're very poor," says Aleksandr Baranov. 
 "People either think I'm sleeping with someone powerful or that I'm a bandita, a criminal," says Natalya Pyankova.
Six years after the collapse of the Soviet Union, filmmakers in Russia and the former republics are in crisis, much like their counterparts in Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary. The once powerful Mosfilm and Lenfilm Studios, which regularly produced more than 60 films a year during the Soviet era, today turn out no more than a handful. A distribution system that insured that films would play across the Soviet Union has been undermined by videotapes (many pirated), rundown theaters, audiences' inability to afford theater tickets and the popularity of Grade B American action movies.
Gone are the good old days of censors and state subsidies, when filmmakers used an Aesopian language to tell their stories, when irony, indirection, satire, humor, metaphorical language and surrealism were the esthetic. Gone too are the heady days of perestroika, when state censorship was lifted yet there was still a strong ideology to resist.
All of this is a serious jolt both to artists and to an industry that once held an exalted position, giving the world Sergei Eisenstein ("Potemkin") and Vsevolod Pudovkin ("Mother") as far back as the 1920's and, more recently, Andrei Tarkovsky ("Andrei Rublev") and Nikita Mikhalkov ("Burnt by the Sun"). The problems faced by filmmakers all over Eastern Europe are writ large in Russia, a vast, chaotic land with little tradition of democracy or market economy but a great one of holding its artists in special regard.
"In Russia, artists were always considered to be prophets," said Naum Kleiman, the director of Moscow's Film Museum. "Now artists no longer have a function in society. For us, cinema was a liberating language; we had very good and honest artists trying to bring us the truth. We had people who used to go to the cinema 40, 50 times a year. Now that audience is destroyed."
In a country where a long talk in a cramped kitchen -- over vodka, salty fish and dark bread -- would once have brought on rambling discourses on the Russian soul, talk with filmmakers today, over Turkish coffee, is about markets, distribution. Audiences were once a given, after a film was approved by censors; now, who the audience is for a particular film is open to question. And this uncertainty is affecting story lines and esthetics in general.
"For the last several years, filmmakers in Russia have been making films not for their audiences but for international festivals, boards of five to seven people," said Daniil Dondurey, editor of Film Art. "And what are those seven people expecting? They want to see that Russia is a horrible country, that a killer will never be punished, that there are no happy endings, that moral values will never win. And the director wants to show that he is a courageous boy who shows this to the world."
Such dark themes are not new. During perestroika, when it became permissible to criticize the system directly, most filmmakers found it hard to resist doing anything else. Chernukha, or blackness, became the order of the day. Vasily Pichul's "Little Vera" (1988), for instance, showed the life of a provincial working class teen-age girl in all its loneliness and uncertainty. Chernukha still holds many in its sway: Aleksei Balabanov's new film, "Brother," is about a rootless young soldier who returns to civilian life and becomes a professional killer (acclaimed at festivals, the film has yet to find a distributor in Russia).
But stories that portray the motherland as a safe house for criminals are ones that Russian audiences no longer want to see, and that filmmakers are moving away from telling.
"I got tired of so many killers and prostitutes," Mr. Baranov said of his most recent film, "Shanghai." Named after a neighborhood in Alma-Ata, Kazakhstan, the film follows seven days in the lives of several people, including a boy and his grandfather, an artist and a couple who talk of moving to Moscow. "I looked around to see how we live now," continued Mr. Baranov. "People came up to me after they saw it and said, 'It's been a long time since we've seen something that was about our own lives.' "
LAST MONTH, "SHANGHAI" was one of more than two dozen films from Russia and the former republics shown as part of the 20th Moscow International Film Festival, a biennial event. Once a grand celebration, the festival was plagued throughout its 11-day run this year by questions of whether it was appropriate to spend a reported $6 million on a festival when the industry here is near collapse. The film director Aleksandr Sokurov held up permission to allow his "Mother and Son," a meditative film with little dialogue, to be Russia's entry in the international competition, until he felt assured that the $6 million could not have been redirected to filmmaking itself. ("Mother and Son," which attracted much acclaim when it had its premiere at the Berlin festival earlier this year, will be included in the New York Film Festival, which starts next month.)
Foreign visitors viewing the Moscow festival's Russian film series at Dom Kino, the filmmakers' union headquarters, were often asked -- by Russian critics, and even promoters -- why they were not going to see the films in the international competition instead. Adding insult to injury, Dom Kino is not open to the public, and the native films scheduled to run in commercial theaters as a sideline to the festival were often canceled. One evening, at a newly renovated theater minutes from Red Square, advance tickets to one failed to sell, so a French thriller was substituted.
Nevertheless, audiences say they want to see more Russian films, or at least that's how they answered a market survey recently conducted by the new head of Gorky Studios, Sergei Livnev. Production will start next month on an ambitious project that many believe is the best hope to revive Russian film. Gorky will release 12 movies a year, filmed for approximately $200,000 apiece, with private and public financing: comedy, romance, thrillers, horrors, mysteries, all with happy endings. In a strategy to beat pirates at their own game, these movies will be released on video immediately; the best films will have a simultaneous theatrical release. "We want to create a new old habit," said Mr. Livnev. "Each month, when you leave work on, say, the 15th, you pick up the latest video in your local metro station kiosk."
Mr. Livnev, also a screenwriter and director, is new to producing; the son of a well-known documentary maker, Marina Goldovskaya, he is only 33 years old and is therefore someone who is not linked to the old state-subsidies system. His most recent film, "Hammer and Sickle," is set in 1937 and centers on a fictional sex change; it is a surrealistic, metaphorical journey into the heart of Stalinism.
Unfortunately, "Hammer and Sickle" was not on the schedule at Dom Kino, because it was held up in litigation. On the calendar were films with an assortment of themes: war, death, first love, loss of innocence, preserving one's humanity against historical currents. Few of these films lived up to the standards set by Russian cinema of years past; all were worth watching, however, for how they reflected current society.
"Cinema is a medium between myth and social reality," said Sergei Dobrotvorsky, a critic who headed the festival's jury for Russian films. "We lost our reality, the symbols of everyday being. In a Soviet film, you had recognizable symbols: a Soviet apartment, specific books, a portrait of a Russian poet and one of Ernest Hemingway on the wall. That reality is now gone, and we are waiting for a new one."
If Mr. Livnev, as a producer, is trying to create a new audience for Russian films, filmmakers are searching for that point where myth and social reality meet on the screen. The dominant esthetic that worked during Soviet days, with metaphor and irony, is no longer viable, and critics agree that a new one has yet to be created. But that does not mean that filmmakers are not working energetically in a world they did not anticipate. Aside from bringing to light wounds both old (pogroms) and new (ethnic conflict, on which "The Graveyard of Daydreams," by the Georgian director Georgi Khaindrava, stood out), here are four directions suggested by filmmakers who had movies at the festival:
* Make films with, for and about your friends. This is a deeply rooted Russian tradition: you could not count on the state, but you could count on your friends. Ms. Pyankova's "Strange Times" focuses on the lives and loves of three characters in Moscow. Critics immediately understood its title and enjoyed its playfulness as men and women couple and uncouple.
* Focus on chernukha's antithesis: svetlukha, or lightness. "I want people to laugh when they see my film," said Murad Ibragimbekov, the director of "A Man for a Younger Woman." This film is based on a story by Mr. Ibragimbekov's father, a well-known Azerbaijani writer: A middle-aged businessman visits an alchemist for a youth potion so that the young actress he's in love with will not leave him. He's sent to scrape off bits of a rhinoceros's horn, which lands him in jail. The moral? Accept your fate.
* Stick to the tried and true, but give it more form. "Form is important, content is not," said Abai Kharpikov, director of the stylized thriller "The More Tender One." Mr. Kharpikov, along with Baranov, is one of several filmmakers who came to be known as the Kazakh New Wave in the late 1980's. They hailed from Kazakhstan, a republic settled by Khrushchev, which had in effect lost its history and gained a Soviet one. And they reveled in making "easterns," taking their lead from American westerns, French New Wave and the directors' own sense of filmmaking as a game. Set in the vast open spaces of their beautiful and desolate native land, the films offered a metaphor for the vacuum left when the walls of the state collapsed.
* Be experimental and don't apologize for it. (Grants from the West are easier to come by if you call yourself experimental.)
One sideline to the festival was a program run by the Parallel Cinema group, who began life in the Leningrad underground in the 1980's. (This work was intended to run parallel to, or coexist with, official state cinema.) Their films and videos included older work by the Necrorealists, who substituted metaphors for a dying society for the socialist realism canon; one critic described their work as "a harsh tragicomic vision suffused with traces of black humor, surrealism, slapstick and a punk industrial style."
GLEB ALEINIKOV IS ONE of the more talented of the Parallel Cinema group. Mr. Aleinikov, along with his brother Igor, made "Tractors" in 1987, satirizing and eroticizing that most sacred of socialist realist symbols. After Igor died in a 1994 Aeroflot crash, Gleb ceased being productive for a while, but he recently began working again and just completed a road movie begun in 1990.
"We got used to the new," said Mr. Aleinikov of both his generation and the last 10 years in Russian society. "During perestroika, there was always something new. Then after the putsch, until 1995, people were waiting for something to happen. Now we know what our situation is, and that we have to act within this new world."
Russia has always had an uneasy relationship with the present. "It's an old Russian tradition, going back to Peter the Great," said Mr. Kleiman of Moscow's Film Museum. "We're in a constant war with the past, we're looking ahead with hope to the future, and we don't pay attention to the present. But the situation today is completely new. Imagine being asleep for 70 years, waking up, and the first place you're standing is on the edge of a roof. It's a little hard to keep your balance."

HEADLINE: Sales-Tax Waiver Leads to a Debate

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER County sales-tax revenue is pouring in at record rates, making some officials eager to eliminate the sales tax permanently on some clothing purchases, and others nervous that such an exemption will create a large hole in the budget.
Last week, the Board of Legislators voted to take part in a state program that waives the collection of sales tax on clothing purchases of less than $100 during the week of Sept. 1. Under state enabling legislation, local governments that collect sales taxes may permanently eliminate the sales tax on those clothing purchases beginning in 1999. 
 Westchester levies a 1.5 to 2 percent tax on sales, with some of the funds shared with local school districts. In addition, the state collects a 4 percent tax, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority a 0.25 percent tax and White Plains, Yonkers, Mount Vernon and New Rochelle impose their own sales taxes.
Joseph E. Phelan, the county's Budget Director, estimated that the county government would lose about $500,000 just from the one-week moratorium and about $20 million a year from a permanent exemption, although he said precise figures could not be provided.
The decision by the Board of Legislators to take part in the one-week exemption was unanimous. "Eliminating the sales tax on clothing will give an added boost to Westchester's economy, and everyone will benefit," said Paul J. Noto, a Republican from Mamaroneck, in a news release before the vote. "I am hopeful that this trial period will pave the way to the eventual elimination of the sales tax on clothing."
But a fellow Legislator, Richard G. Wishnie, a Democrat from Briarcliff, said he was concerned about the county's making the exemption permanent. "When you talk about losing $20 million from the revenue stream, you have to understand that that is equal to about a 5.7 percent increase in property taxes," he said. "Who's going to pay? People should understand that what the government gives with one hand, it takes away with the other."
Mr. Wishnie said he was resigned to the fact that for competitive reasons Westchester would have to join in the permanent-exemption program in 1999 if New York City and Nassau did. But he said he hoped to persuade his colleagues to ask the State Legislature to eliminate the exemption entirely. Mr. Phelan of the Budget Office said sales tax revenue is flowing in at a record rate. From 1992 through 1995, it grew an average 3.6 percent a year, but in 1995 and 1996 the growth was 8.5 percent each year, or $15.6 million more than the year before.
He said 1997 collections were also going strong, with the county already at least $3 million ahead of a projected $204 million for 1997. He attributed this to a good economy, the soaring stock market and the 1995 opening of The Westchester mall.
The total state, M.T.A., county and local sales tax collected in Westchester is 6.75 percent in towns, villages and the cities of Rye and Peekskill; 7.75 percent in White Plains, and 8.25 percent in Mount Vernon, Yonkers and New Rochelle.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Economy Prods Hotel Construction

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WITH a strengthening economy business and leisure travelers have taken to the road, pushing up hotel occupancy and room rates and, in turn, prompting developers to bring new rooms to the market across New Jersey.
Evidence of that is in the number of lodgings recently opened, under way or planned in the state, including some in the Secaucus Meadowlands, Princeton and along the Hudson River in Jersey City. 
 All told, the projects could produce more than 2,000 new rooms to add to the state's current supply of 94,000, according to the New Jersey Hotel and Motel Association in Trenton.
Joseph A. Simonetta, the group's executive vice president, said that there was "more than enough demand to fill whatever supply is coming on board."
Tourism, the second largest industry in the state after the pharmaceutical industry, generated $24.6 billion in 1996, up $1 billion from 1995, according to the latest figures from New Jersey's Division of Travel and Tourism.
As of the first half of this year Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage, reported the vacancy rate for the 11-county northern New Jersey office market at 15.1 percent, down from 17.9 percent the same time last year. Moreover, speculative office construction is under way for the first time in a decade in some of the state's tightest markets.
John A. Fox, senior vice president of PKF, a hotel and real estate consulting firm based in Manhattan, said areas of the state close to New York City were benefiting from a spillover from the city's strong hotel market.
In the first six months of this year New Jersey's hotel occupancy rate was 67.5 percent, up from 66.5 percent the same time in 1996, according to Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn., which reports on the market for hotel companies nationwide. The national rate was 64.9 percent. And average room rates in New Jersey hotels rose 6.5 percent to $82.35; in the nation it rose 6.6 percent to $74.50.
"The numbers are improving to the point to justify new construction," said Mr. Fox, noting that activity was expected to continue through the end of the decade.
Hotel construction, and planning for new hotels, are being stoked by the availability of financing, analysts said. For the first six months of this year 59 permits were issued or updated for all types of lodgings, most of them hotels -- up from 38 the same time last year, according to state figures.
In New Jersey, as in the nation, most of the new hotels are moderate-priced, limited service and all-suite. Typically, they lack the abundance of meeting rooms, large restaurants and shops found in traditional full-service hotels.
Their appeal to developers is plain: They are smaller, easier and less expensive to build and, in turn, easier to finance, said Mark V. Lommanno, executive vice president of Smith Travel Research.
LENDERS still require 20 to 25 percent equity participation from builders, which will help keep supply in balance with demand, added Patrick Ford Sr., president of National Hotel Realty, a research firm in Portsmouth, N.H. Developers say New Jersey's long approval process, strict zoning and high land costs will also temper the pace of construction.
The key market for limited-service and all-suite hotels is the corporate traveler. "What that means," said Mr. Ford, "is that they are going up in developed areas and into and around office developments."
Indicative of that is the cluster of hotels that recently opened or are planned in Morris County, among the more active office markets in the state.
Summerfield Hotel Corporation of Wichita, Kan., has opened two hotels in the same Morris County town. One is a 136-suite hotel on Route 10 in Hanover on that town's side of the 1.5-million-square foot Prudential Business Campus, which straddles the Parsippany border. The other is a 133-suite hotel on Columbia Turnpike on the Hanover/Morristown line.
"There may be some overlap, but generally speaking the office market in the county can support both because it is so large," said Dennis S. Meikleham, vice president of real estate and development at Summerfield.
Others agree. G. Holdings Corporation of Manhattan is seeking approvals to build a 150-room Courtyard by Marriott on a site in the Morristown Airport complex, also in Hanover. It is one of five Marriott Courtyard hotels planned or under way in the state.
The other four hotels -- in South Brunswick, West Orange, Princeton and East Rutherford, totaling 550 rooms -- are to open by the fall of 1998, said Geary Campbell, a spokesman for the chain, a division of Marriott International Corporation in Bethesda, Md.
As for the Hanover site, Ronnie Gross, executive vice president of development at G. Holdings, said that beyond the area's office buildings "business travelers use the airport and as the last site inside the airport it is suited, and zoned, for a hotel." He added that "demand is high and there is room for expansion."
Farther west in the county a 141-room Wyndham Garden Hotel opened last June at the International Trade Center in Mount Olive. It the first hotel in the 670-acre business park off Exit 25 of Interstate 80 and among the few new full-service hotels to go up in the state. The business park is home to companies with 6,000 employees.
THE hotel was built by the center's developers -- The Rockefeller Center Development Corporation, part of the Rockefeller Group, and Leslie E. Smith Jr., a builder and the center's executive director. It is being managed by Wyndham Hotels & Resorts in Dallas. The corporate room rate is $105 a night.
Mr. Meikleham said Summerfield was "very positive about New Jersey because it has a tremendous number of areas with a concentration of offices." To that end it is also building a 128-suite hotel on Route 22 in Bridgewater in Somerset County, another active office market. And in Piscataway, not far from Rutgers University, it will start construction on a 113-room Sierra Suite, the company's more moderate-priced product.
Mr. Meikleham would not disclose room rates at Summerfield's four new hotels but said they would be higher than the average nightly corporate rate for its chain nationwide, which is $116. He added that the average for Sierra Suite hotels was about $55. Mr. Meikleham said his company hoped to build four to six more hotels in the state.
Prime Hospitality Corporation of Fairfield is building two AmerSuites hotels near office hubs. One, with 124 rooms, is in Princeton along the Route 1 business corridor. The other, with 159 rooms, is in the more than 2-million-square foot Harmon Meadow mixed-used development in the Secaucus Meadowlands. The average room rate is $80 at the Princeton hotel and $90 for the one in the Meadowlands.
David Simon, president of Prime, said the fundamentals of the New Jersey hotel market supported new ventures, but "they need to be hotels that fit the right product to the right market niche." He said Prime was "bullish" on areas near strong office and retail centers and intended to open up to eight more hotels in the state in the next three years.
IN Jersey City ground was broken last June for a 13-story, 200-room Club Hotel by Doubletree one block from the Hudson River waterfront, where 8.6 million square feet of offices line the river's edge. It will be the first hotel in the city in decades and the only one on its riverfront.
"Jersey City is already an important business center, now that there is a hotel to accommodate that community," said Emanuel Stern, president of the real estate division of Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus. Hartz is developing the hotel with the local Garden State Development Inc. It is expected to open in the summer of 1998. The average room rate will be $120, said Mr. Stern.
In Atlantic City, the 502-room Sheraton Atlantic City Convention Center Hotel is scheduled to open in November next to the $318-million new Atlantic City Convention Center. While it will not have a casino, it will have a skywalk to the exhibit hall level of the convention center.
By the end of 1999, the number of casino hotel rooms in Atlantic City will triple from the present number to more than 27,000, according to the Atlantic City Convention and Visitors Authority.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
A Waterfront Awash in Reclamation Projects

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: GLEN COVE

 BODY:
THE 214-acre area bordering both sides of Glen Cove Creek and fronting on Hempstead Harbor has some of this North Shore Nassau community's most spectacular water views. It also contains some of its worst blight.
A smokestack towers over decayed buildings that cover a 26-acre tract once occupied by Li Tungsten, a metal smelting and refining company. A 1.9-acre section once housed the Mattiace petrochemical plant. Both properties are federally designated Superfund sites now undergoing a $20 million cleanup by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. The cleanup is expected to take to the end of the century to complete. 
 Along Garvies Point Road, a 23-acre meadow of wildflowers blooms deceptively. It covers a former city landfill that has been designated a hazardous-waste area by New York State. Over it loom the skeletons of apartment buildings that were never completed because of the contaminated ground.
A junkyard, an asphalt plant and the former city incinerator, now a garbage transfer station, are other neighborhood eyesores. "We have 10 miles of waterfront, of which nine miles are beautiful and one mile is environmentally blighted," said Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi. But if a five-year waterfront revitalization plan that he is spearheading materializes, all that would change, he said.
The proposal outlined in a master plan prepared by Jambhekar Strauss, architects and land planners in Manhattan, divides the 214-acre area into seven distinct sectors. It calls on private owners and investors to work with the city in building a bustling maritime center containing, among other things, hotel and conference facilities, restaurants, marine-related stores and a museum.
Glen Cove is not alone in working to revitalize its waterfront. Encouraged by the availability of state and Federal funds for such projects, Port Jefferson, Greenport, Patchogue and Long Beach, among others, are also implementing plans to reclaim dormant and often blighted waterfront.
But Glen Cove's proposal, needing an estimated $280 million investment over five years, is the most ambitious.
"Our objective is to transform the 214 acres into a regional tourist attraction that would capitalize on the city's Gold Coast history and on the natural beauty of the area," Mayor Suozzi said, adding that he envisions creating a destination point equal in appeal to Newport, R.I., and Mystic Seaport in Connecticut.
Upgrading three existing marinas, adding more boatyards, a fish market, and a ferry terminal with high-speed commuter service to Manhattan and conventional ferry service to Connecticut and Westchester are also envisioned.
To help create jobs, the development of offices and light industry would be encouraged to supplement the existing small industrial operations.
Pedestrian walks and bikeways would link the various attractions and businesses. A new access road would bring Glen Cove's downtown within easier reach and hikers would be given better access to the adjoining 68-acre Garvies Point Preserve, owned by Nassau County.
Some pieces of the plan other than the Superfund cleanup are already falling into place. The Army Corps of Engineers has dredged one-third of the mile-long Glen Cove Creek. And the city has received more than $1 million in New York State grants, including a $570,000 Department of Transportation grant for the restoration of Mill Pond at the head of the creek.
An agreement has been worked out under which the city, with the aid of state funds, will clean up the 23-acre Garvies Point Road site, which the Maryland Deposit Insurance Fund in Baltimore took over as receiver of assets belonging to the failed Old Court Savings & Loan of Baltimore and its subsidiary, Village Green Realty at Garvies Point.
Bids on the property, which is valued at around $16 million, are now being solicited by the receiver. In return for the cleanup, the insurance fund has agreed to pay the state up to 12 percent of the net proceeds from the sale. Glen Cove will either receive a portion of the property or a payment equal to 25 percent of net proceeds.
Some of the area's property owners are already making investments based on expectations of a better future.
"I see this plan as a great opportunity," said Joseph Weiser, owner of the 180-slip Jude Thaddeus Glen Cove Marina. He said he had invested $1 million in new bulkheading and also intended to invest $5.5 million in building a 250-seat restaurant, a 24-unit boatel, retail outlets, and other facilities on the 17-acre site and to expand the number of boat slips to 240.
In Port Jefferson, voters will be asked in an October referendum to approve a proposed $1.7 million acquisition by the village of a 5.1-acre waterfront site on East Broadway owned by the Mobil Corporation. The property, once used for oil storage, and an eyesore for years, would become the only village-owned parcel on the waterfront.
UNDER a plan developed for the village by Martin R. Cantor of Melville, a planning consultant, and Cashin Associates, a Hauppauge engineering and architectural firm, the site would become a park with a bandshell, a marina, and a museum focusing on the village's maritime history.
"This would take a very important piece of Port Jefferson, and make it a focal point as you come in by water, as well as a tourist attraction," said Robert L. Strong, the village's mayor.
A similar plan is being developed by the Village of Greenport, which last September acquired a 3.1-acre parcel on Front Street for $1.2 million.
Dilapidated buildings have been cleared for a complex that will include an enclosure for the village-owned carousel, a berth for the Regina Maris, a 100-year-old sailing ship, and a village green. A pedestrian walkway along the waterfront will lead to the Long Island Rail Road train station.
Largely as a result of village ownership of the property, a trial weekend high-speed ferry run from Manhattan was begun by New York Fast Ferry Services of Staten Island on Aug. 15. If the demand warrants, it will resumenext summer. Dock space was provided by the village.
"We have made an investment in ourselves by turning around a site that economically and physically has been a problem for the last 20 years," said Mayor David E. Kapell. "And by doing so we have sent a message to the outside world that Greenport is an interesting place to be."
The Village of Patchogue is also moving forward with plans to redevelop land along the Patchogue River as a tourist area with a new Fire Island ferry terminal. A startup awaits completion of a sewer extension and a possible land swap with the Federal Government.
And in Long Beach, the city has issued requests for proposals, due Saturday, for hotel and retail development on a six-acre oceanfront site between Long Beach and Riverside Boulevards. The property has several private owners, but the city intends to acquire it "through condemnation if need be," said City Manager Edwin L. Eaton.
The request for proposals developed for the city by Hospitality Consulting Services, of Mineola, calls for a $35 million project that would include a 150-suite, extended-stay hotel with conference and banquet facilities and a 125-seat restaurant.
"Right now there is no hotel in Long Beach and we are the only waterfront community on Long Island with no waterfront restaurant," Mr. Eaton said. "This would give a completeness to the revitalization efforts that have been going on here for 15 years."
State financing for waterfront revitalization projects is being made available through, among other sources, the $1.75-billion Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act approved by voters last November, and from the Environmental Protection Fund created in 1993, which provides $100 million annually statewide in grants to environmental projects.
"We are trying to help local governments to understand the importance and value of their waterfronts and to articulate a vision of what they would like their waterfronts to be," said George R. Stafford, director of the coastal resources division at the New York State Department of State, which serves as the liaison with local governments.
Municipalities will have a chance to discuss state grant opportunties with officials of several state agencies at a meeting to be held at the State University of New York at Stony Brook on Sept. 15.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 5; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: The Taming Of the 'Wild West'

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
IMPROBABLE as it sounds, the sun may finally be rising in the west -- that is, the farthest western reaches of mid-Manhattan. A combination of forces could induce some of the development in the West 30's and 40's that has been anticipated, with little result, since the foundations were laid 16 years ago for the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.
A necklace of economic activity now rings the district, with the boom in Times Square, residential construction in Clinton, major property transactions in the Garment Center and the growing vibrancy of Chelsea. One would expect that development must inevitably spill over. 
 Of course, that has been expected before. Yet the area, where the sky stretches high and wide, still has a touch of frontier to it. The newest local landmark is a covered wagon at the Gold Rush Bar and Grill on 10th Avenue. Hooves clip-clop along 11th Avenue, where horse-drawn carriages are stabled. There is even an occasional shoot-'em-up, as when Federal agents and drug dealers traded gunfire in broad daylight at 10th Avenue and 34th Street earlier this month.
But the "wild west" days may be nearing an end.
More than $175 million in public financing has been cobbled together toward the $315 million cost of creating a new Penn Station in the neo-classical shell of the General Post Office, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.
For rivergoing commuters, N.Y. Waterway is proposing to build a glass-walled West Midtown Union Ferry Terminal, at a cost of $8 million to $10 million, at the foot of 39th Street.
The Javits Center is to spend $12 million to $15 million on a renovation that will carry it through the near term, while it lays out long-term plans for a major expansion northward.
Four blocks north, Silverstein Properties and the Equitable Life Assurance Society are prepared to begin a $190 million, 40-story, 921-apartment tower at 42d Street and 12th Avenue, to be followed by a near-twin on 11th Avenue.
"The neighborhood is a lot better than the image people had," said Mortimer B. Zuckerman, chairman and co-publisher of The Daily News, who faced "a lot of nervousness" among employees two years ago when he moved the newspaper to 450 West 33d Street. But it worked out "very, very well," he said -- so well that he has just leased another 100,000 square feet in the building -- a giant, sloping-sided structure that spans the rail yards for two blocks along 10th Avenue. There Mr. Zuckerman will move the business staff of U.S. News & World Report, from Washington, and the headquarters of Applied Graphics Technologies, a digital prepress service company now at 28 West 23d Street.
Three years ago, 450 West 33d Street stood almost half empty and prospective tenants were leery, said Richard G. Karson, senior managing director of the Insignia/ Edward S. Gordon Company, which manages the building. (It is owned by the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.) "The biggest problem we had to overcome was fear," Mr. Karson said. "We were in the 'wild west.' Now we're almost in the core of what's being redeveloped."
Standing on the roof with Mr. Karson, it is not hard to understand his view of geography. To the west are the Long Island Rail Road's John D. Caemmerer yards, where a new Yankee Stadium has been envisioned.
To the east is the James A. Farley Building, which serves as the General Post Office. Within this structure is a 36,000-square-foot courtyard that would be covered with a glass roof to serve as the Amtrak concourse, reclaiming for intercity railroad passengers some of the grandeur that was lost when the first Penn Station was demolished in the early 1960's. Both buildings were designed by McKim, Mead & White.
Most of the underground train platforms extend as far west as the Farley building, meaning that they would be directly under foot and easily reachable. Passengers and visitors would enter at sidewalk level from 31st or 33d Streets -- no need to lug suitcases up that imposing flight of steps.
IN the last two months alone, the Penn Station project has secured commitments of $35 million from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, $25 million from the New York City Economic Development Corporation, $20 million in the New York State budget and $14 million from the Federal Railroad Administration.
"It's become real," said Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, which manages the project through a subsidiary, the Pennsylvania Station Redevelopment Corporation.
Across from the Farley Building, at Ninth Avenue and 33d Street, is the site of an office building proposed in the 1980's and designed by Gwathmey Siegel & Associates, whose office is nearby. The tower was to have had 32 stories and 1 million square feet of space but it foundered with the rest of the market.
Plans are now being dusted off by Harvey Schulweis of Schulweis Realty, who controls the property. A tenant whom he declined to identify is interested in a new headquarters. "They feel that the location has come of age," Mr. Schulweis said. "In addition, it's one of the few sites around that has all the necessary approvals to proceed."
Intriguing as all the talk is, however, for the moment it is only that. Shovels have yet to turn over a spadeful of earth.
"Believe me, if it was viable to build there, we'd be the first people in," said Jeffrey Katz of Sherwood Equities, who owns eight properties along West 34th Street and 10th Avenue.
Mr. Katz said the area had the advantage of being contiguous to the commercial core of midtown while requiring relatively little displacement. But he does not think the Penn Station and Javits Center projects alone will spark redevelopment. That will not happen, Mr. Katz said, until Times Square is more fully built out and the real estate market is expanding; certainly not in the next two years or in this cycle.
Barry Gosin, vice chairman and chief executive of Newmark & Company Real Estate, added another necessary ingredient: "It will have to be gentrified first. You've got to get residential. You've got to get retail. You've got to get a life."
Enter Larry A. Silverstein, who thinks the time is right for two apartment towers on a full-block site between 11th and 12th Avenues, 41st and 42d Streets. "What makes it feasible now is a very attractive rental market where the demand is clearly in excess of supply," he said.
The first tower, River Place 1, will include a 34,000-square-foot sports club with a pool and tennis and basketball courts; a 30,000-square-foot restaurant; 10,000 square feet of convenience shops and 200 parking spaces for tenants. A half-acre park will run through the middle of the block. Mr. Silverstein said he expected to begin construction this year. Lehrer McGovern Bovis is the general contractor.
Most apartments will be studio or one-bedroom units, for single tenants, young couples and roommates pooling rent. "My sense is that the people who will work in and around Times Square will be the people who will be renting from us," Mr. Silverstein said. "It's the walk-to-work group.
Once this tower is substantially rented, Mr. Silverstein said, work will begin on River Place 2, a virtual twin. There will also be 500 transient parking spaces.
River Place was designed by Costas Kondylis & Associates in an undulating form to take advantage of the many vistas. Each floor is an unbroken ribbon of glass.
Eighty percent of the apartments will be rented at market rates, currently about $1,350 a month for a studio, and 20 percent will be subsidized and made available to tenants whose income is less than half the median income for New York City.
As an "80-20" project, River Place will be financed in part through the sale of $138 million in bonds by the New York State Housing Finance Agency. An "80-20" project is also eligible for 20 years of real-estate tax abatements.
What is not known yet is whether the Silverstein towers will prove to be unmovable objects in the face of the irresistible force known as the Javits Center.
The center has embarked on an interim renovation, designed by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, to freshen and brighten the Galleria, River Pavilion, meeting rooms, conference rooms and restrooms.
But even 6,000 yards of carpet cannot obscure the larger issue. The Javits Center has 760,000 square feet of exhibition space, putting it behind Chicago, Las Vegas and Atlanta. Bookings at Javits increased 19 percent in the last year, as measured by square footage for each show. And a report by the consulting firm of Coopers & Lybrand said trade shows -- by far the largest users -- would keep expanding. "Numerous events currently require or will soon require additional space," the report said.
The Javits Center "could achieve maximum occupancy" by doubling its exhibition space to 1.5 million square feet, Coopers & Lybrand concluded. Gerald T. McQueen, president of the center, said last month that the likeliest expansion route would involve the three blocks from 39th to 42d Street.
Were the center to expand north, the first property it would encounter would be the former Yale Express System truck garage on 12th Avenue, between 39th and 40th Streets. This is owned by Mr. Silverstein, who said he would entertain the idea of swapping it for development rights on the 11th Avenue end of the block -- a perfect spot for a convention-related hotel.
The developer believes his 42d Street site is protected by an intermediate property: the M.T.A.'s West Side Bus Depot, between 40th and 41st Streets. This structure, with its drum-like facade, was built by Greyhound and refurbished by the authority at a cost of more than $35 million. "It serves as a major impediment to any convention center expansion," Mr. Silverstein said.
And Jo Ann Macy, co-chairwoman of the Clinton land-use and zoning committee of Community Board 4, said that while neighbors expect the Javits Center to grow, "their concern is having a megastructure that isn't sensitive to people's access to and views of the waterfront."
BUT Mr. Gargano, a board member of the Convention Center Development Corporation, said the first phase of the expansion would stop short of the depot, "and then we would look at alternatives."
Whatever happens at the depot, the area's complex infrastructure of roads, rails and piers will play a major role in shaping its future. "Anything that would encourage any new use or development would have to be looked at in terms of transportation," said Joseph B. Rose, director of the City Planning Department, which is now preparing a transportation study of the area.
The most ambitious of the transportation projects involves the creation of a new Penn Station, taking as much as half of the 1.4 million-square-foot Farley Building. As envisioned by state officials, the new station would have 200,000 square feet of retail space, 200,000 square feet of public space, up to 200,000 square feet of office space and 75,000 square feet for Amtrak operations.
"It will be almost like a shopping mall combined with a transportation facility," Mr. Gargano said. "Retail is a necessary part of this project, to create the revenue stream that we need to support it."
Speaking of the city's recent $25 million contribution, Charles Millard, president of the Economic Development Corporation, said the project was closely allied with efforts to retain and attract companies.
"If you think of Penn Station as a hassle-filled, gray, dirty, grimy place," Mr. Millard said, "you might think you can do business just as well in Jersey City."
The city, state and Federal governments are expected to cover $200 million of the total cost, with a private developer providing the other $115 million, 20 percent of which would be eligible for a historic preservation tax credit. Each level of government has two representatives on the board of the redevelopment corporation. The president is Alexandros E. Washburn, an architect who was formerly public works adviser to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.
The next step is to negotiate with the Postal Service, Mr. Gargano said. Once it is known how much space Penn Station will occupy, a request for design proposals can be issued, perhaps by the end of the year. And once the design is completed, a request for development proposals will follow.
On the nearer horizon is N.Y. Waterway's plan for a 40,000-square-foot ferry terminal, replacing a city-owned garage on Pier 79. The company now serves 9,100 passengers a day at Pier 78. It expects daily ridership to reach 21,000 in the next six years.
The new terminal, designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, would have six slips, for use by N.Y. Waterway and other operators. There would be small strips of convenience shops on the north and south ends. On the waterfront side, the structure would be girdled by a 37-foot-wide mezzanine walkway.
"It is intended not only to enhance mass transportation options but to hasten redevelopment and facilitate enjoyment of waterfront," said Arthur E. Imperatore Jr., president of both N.Y. Waterway and Arcorp Properties.
Mr. Millard agreed that the terminal had such potential. "It is the kind of transportation service that does open new areas to development," he said.
Even as they pursue one plan on the west side, the Imperatores are abandoning another one: a multi-use complex along 11th Avenue, from 36th to 38th Streets, that was to have included a 34-story apartment building, 17-story hotel and 6-story garage.
The site is for sale, Mr. Imperatore said, because it no longer fits the corporate strategy, which is concentrated on planning and developing property in New Jersey and on the burgeoning ferry business.
On a smaller scale, residential redevelopment is tentatively planned for the former Hobb Electric Supply Company building, a six-story, Romanesque structure at 541 West 34th Street. Ron Cohen, senior managing director of Insignia/Edward S. Gordon, who represents the owners, said a buyer would convert the 74,000-square-building to loft apartments and might even build an addition. "That will be a pioneer for the neighborhood," Mr. Cohen said.
It is worth recalling that other pioneers have perished in this terrain. Thirty years ago, Lazard Freres bought the air rights over the railroad tracks west of Penn Station, planning a high-rise apartment complex called Chelsea Place, designed by Philip Johnson, and a distribution center for the garment industry called Westyard.
Nothing came of the housing, although the Westyard Building, now 450 West 33d Street, was finished in 1970 to designs by Davis, Brody & Associates (now Davis Brody Bond). "A confident giant standing astride a broad valley," as The Architectural Record put it, this 1.6 million-square-foot behemoth spans the 220-foot-wide railroad cut.
Today, tenants include the Chase Manhattan Bank, Lerner New York, the New York City Financial Information Services Agency and the Daily News, with Mr. Zuckerman's other companies to arrive this fall.
"It's certainly not as convenient as East 42d Street," Mr. Zuckerman conceded. "But my theory is that reporters should be out of the building anyhow. The same thing is true of advertising people."
The most noteworthy space for rent is the 16th floor, which used to be Sky Rink skating arena. Its centerpiece is a column-free space, 200 by 100 feet. The room is 22 feet high and lined by clerestory windows.
Fred C. Trump 3d, director of the Gordon Property Group, played hockey at Sky Rink in his youth. Running his shoe over the dry bed in which the rink sat, he said, "I joke that this is the best the ice surface has ever been." Now he is showing the space to foreign banks for use as a trading floor.
THE expansive floors and high ceilings at 450 West 33d Street have also attracted the attention of Channel 13/ WNET, which is exploring the possibility of moving to new quarters. Mr. Millard said there is a "surprising amount of interest" generally in television or movie studio space in the area.
The neighborhood is already home to the studios of major architects and designers. There is an entire colony of them in the former Hill Building, 475 10th Avenue, at 36th Street: Gwathmey Siegel & Associates, Richard Meier & Partners, Vignelli Associates and Buttrick White & Burtis.
One of the few architectural gems in the area, 475 10th Avenue is a gleaming white 14-story structure, built in 1914 to designs by Starrett & Van Vleck. It originally housed the Hill Publishing Company, at a time when the competing McGraw Publishing Company was at 239 West 39th Street. After the two merged, McGraw moved into the Hill Building, where it remained until 1931.
At the initiative of Robert Siegel, the Gwathmey Siegel firm moved to the building 15 years ago. "We're very happy," said his partner, Charles Gwathmey. As well they might be, paying $7.50 a square foot for space with 14-foot ceilings that is minutes from Penn Station, the Port Authority Bus Terminal and the Lincoln Tunnel.
Surveying the surroundings, Mr. Gwathmey said: "Slowly, the housing fabric is being renovated. The adjacent loft buildings have been upgraded. And you get a sense that there's more density, more people."
"I didn't realize how residential this neighborhood is," said Keith Liles, one of the managers of the Gold Rush, which opened last month at 10th Avenue and 38th Street. Designed by RAM Innovations of Manhattan, it was aimed at the crowd coming and going from Javits. But many other patrons have materialized.
"We have a lot of neighborhood people," Ms. Liles said. "And we get a late-night hit from the buggy drivers. They all drink here from 2 A.M. to 4 A.M. every night."
Perhaps there's some frontier spirit yet.

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 2; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1048 words

HEADLINE: The View From: Redding;
Fields of Flowers for Everyone to Pick

BYLINE: By ANDREA ZIMMERMANN 

 BODY:
IF you have the urge to snip a snapdragon or sniff sweet Annie, your instincts might very well lead you to Warrups Farm in Redding, one of the few in the state that grows flowers as a pick-your-own crop. There you can create a bouquet from an acre of annuals, a dozen different types, cultivated in tidy rows.
Bill Hill, crop manager, also cultivates four acres each of sweet corn, pumpkins, and vegetables. Warrups is a certified organic farm. Although flowers are not a crop included under the certification, they share a field with the vegetables and are cultivated using the same ecological methods. 
 Being a farmer these days can be pretty dicey, says Mr. Hill, a fifth-generation farmer. "That's why you've got to be diverse."
Each year the farmer plows up the field, starts the flowers in the greenhouse from seed, and transplants the seedlings when appropriate. He tries to rotate the flowers within the section; crop rotation being one of the basic practices of organic farming.
Although he cultivates some herbs, Mr. Hill steers clear of most perennials because they are trickier to grow and need more weeding. "I don't use herbicides, so weeds can be a major problem," he explains.
Warrups' pick-your-own flowers include zinnias, cosmos, sunflowers, snapdragons, black-eyed Susans, amaranth, celosia, sweet Annie, calendula, strawflowers and asters. These, like all flowers, are considered high-value crops because new stems will continue to emerge throughout the season. They will, that is, if patrons do not cut the plant at its base.
"Cut 12 inches down on the stem. And choose flowers just starting to open so they last longer," suggests Mr. Hill. "When you get home, clip them again and put them in warm water. Change the water every day or two and the flowers will last a week, sometimes longer."
Customers are encouraged to supply their own clippers and flower container. Water is provided; look for the hose behind the stand.
In many respects, Bill Hill is an old-fashioned farmer. "There is a pull that the land has on you," he says. "I grew up here; I know every field."
The farmer intensively cultivates 15 of the family's 300-acre parcel which was originally a dairy. Successive generations shifted focus over the years.
"My great-great-grandfather built the house in 1840 and the barns," Mr. Hill said. "He had a dairy farm. His son sold it in 1900 and then my grandfather bought it back in the late 20's. It had been actively farmed until the 20's, when it was gradually abandoned as a farm. My parents raised beef cattle here from the mid-70's to 1982. I saw vegetables as a way of making the farm more economically viable, so in 1980 I moved to vegetables. And I've been cultivating flowers for the past 12 years." He does not want his farm to become "too commercial" and so he ceased advertising years ago. "Enough people know about it so I just put a sign at the end of the road," he said. That's John Read Road, a dirt thoroughfare in Redding.
To preserve the open land he and his family have donated the farm's development rights to the Redding Land Trust.
Hayrides are offered in the fall. Mr. Hill admits it is a commercial draw, but also believes it provides people with a rare experience from another era. "There is a big interest in seeing what a farm looks like," he says. "During pumpkin season -- one month -- a couple of thousand people come through here."
As testament to this, he recites the list of places his customers come from: Norwalk, Bridgeport, Wilton, Weston, Danbury, Bethel, Ridgefield and New York state. Some people have come to cut flowers for their own weddings.
Mr. Hill is also a philosopher. He considers how many of the rocks in his field did not emanate from native bedrock; the ones carried hundreds of miles by glaciers and deposited in Redding.
He refers to himself as a nature mystic, willing to try new things to preserve the natural interplay of the environment -- bugs and all. "I love to observe and be a part of the natural world and be a part of the process," he explains.
Mr. Hill is moving into bio-dynamic farming, which follows the philosophy of Rudolf Steiner. "It precedes the organic movement," he says. Although complex in theory, Mr. Hill says the practice is "like homeopathy applied to farming. You apply an organic preparation to the soil in very small quantities and it increases the life of the soil somehow."
Mr. Hill finds great satisfaction in the diversity of his work, the challenge of repairing equipment and figuring out what the weather will do. Most of all, he enjoys being outside.
"I was always interested in gardening and studied botany in school, so it followed naturally to do something like this. Plus I wanted to keep the place in one piece as a farm," he says. "It's fun for me. But it is very labor intensive."
Over the years, his brother, Bob Hill, has helped him manage the farm and bring in the hay. His wife, Laura Selleck, designed brochures about the farm, and their 6-year-old son, Lincoln, often is found hanging out at the farm stand. Three or four other people also work full-time during the summer.
Mr. Hill is a member of Connecticut Farm Bureau, and serves on the certification committee of the nonprofit Northeast Organic Farm Association of Connecticut. When a farm is certified organic, it means the farmer has subscribed to the association's standards, submitted an affidavit detailing farming practices and the history of the farm and has been visited by an inspector from the certification program. The certification committee also examines soil tests before it decides whether to award certification to a farm.
The pick-your-own flower season at Warrups Farm runs until frost, and the field is open Tuesday through Sunday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Visitors can pick their own pumpkins and have a hayride on weekends throughout October. The first three weekends in March, the Warrups host maple syrup making demonstrations.
"I get the most pleasure out of seeing school groups; showing the kids where broccoli comes from," says Mr. Hill. "Nature is infinitely amazing. Just contemplate a flower for a while. There's an order and symmetry to everything that doesn't always seem apparent in the everyday chaos."

HEADLINE: A Premium Crop From the Shade

BYLINE: By JAY AXELBANK 

 BODY:
WHAT do the jungles of Sumatra have in common with the Connecticut countryside? Not much -- unless you're talking about growing tobacco for cigars. It all began in the late 1800's when Connecticut tobacco farmers faced stiff competition from Southeast Asian imports. Researchers and farmers came up with an ingenious idea: Why not grow tobacco here under cotton netting to approximate Sumatran conditions, meaning perpetual cloud cover and high heat and humidity.
Thus was born "Connecticut shade tobacco," with its cured leaf with its kid glove smooth texture and distinctive taste is used worldwide to wrap expensive, hand-made premium cigars. 
 Connecticut shade is a hot player in the new cigar boom that is sweeping America. And this week under the miles of long, white tents (now made of polymer netting) in north-central Connecticut, thousands of farm workers are swiftly -- but gently -- plucking and hanging the last of the tobacco leaves to cure. It looked for awhile as if the 1997 crop would set a 10-year record. But an attack of blue mold, a fungal disease that appears every few years, may keep the yield at 1996 levels despite increased tobacco acreage.
Growers like Emil Mulnite, who farms 160 acres in East Windsor, say they have been hit pretty hard. Elsewhere in the Connecticut River Valley, blue mold infestation is scattered with varying severity.
Jim LaMondia, plant pathologist at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment station in Windsor, reckons as much as 20 percent of the value of the crop could be lost -- about the same as in the last major blue mold attack in 1979. Recent heavy rains, Dr. LaMondia says, have only added to the problem.
The precise size and quality of the 1997 crop, however, will only become known in the months to come -- or, in some cases, a year or two -- after curing, processing, sorting and aging.
State officials and growers had estimated that this year's crop would reach 2 million pounds (before curing), worth $52 million or more. Now it is felt that the 1997 harvest probably will not get much above $38 million, about the same amount that last year's harvest pumped into the state's economy. The acreage boost -- to 1,200 acres from 1,000 last year -- as well as higher tobacco prices will help. And these dollar figures don't include an additional $10 million or so that comes from broadleaf tobacco, which is used primarily for lesser-grade cigar binder and filler.
Whatever the outcome, 1997 will still be a good harvest, according to most growers. In a year or two, it will be wrapping cigars in the $3 to $5 range.
"We just can't keep up with demand," says Austin T. McNamara, president of the General Cigar Company, the largest grower of Connecticut shade with 300 acres. General Cigar, headquartered in Bloomfield, manufactures the Macanudo, the largest-selling premium cigar in America, which is wrapped only with Connecticut shade. Mr. McNamara says the firm has doubled production of all its premium cigars this year.
Despite its prominence here, tobacco draws a blank from many Connecticut citizens. Including shade and broadleaf, it ranks No. 6 on a list of 23 in the value of the state's farm output while occupying just 3,000 acres out of the approximately 400,000 acres devoted to agriculture in the state. Shade tobacco is centered in a narrow belt on both sides of the Connecticut River from Hartford to the Massachusetts line.
"Most people are surprised when they find out what we grow under these tents," says Kathi Martin standing under the white netting that shades the nine-foot plants and increases the temperature underneath 5 to 10 degrees, as well as the humidity. She helps manage her family's 120-acre farm, called H. F. Brown, in Windsor.
"People equate tobacco with Southern states," she continues. "Even many of our cigar-smoking customers dont know how unique shade tobacco grown in Connecticut really is."
Farmers have tried to grow wrapper tobacco under the same tent- shade conditions in other parts of the United States and in the tropics, where labor is much cheaper and land far more plentiful. But without success. Traveling through Tobacco Valley, one keeps hearing references to Connecticut's mysterious mix of soil, climate, growing conditions.
Tom Rathier, soil scientist at the Windsor experiment station who specializes in tobacco cultivation, explains that the Connecticut River Valley is blessed with sandy loam with lower levels of silt and clay -- and optimum drainage. "The key is drainage," he says. "Whether water comes from irrigation or rain, tobacco doesn't like to sit in water."
And Connecticut shade has had something else going for it since the 1920's: the Windsor experiment station. It has helped perfect the crop through better cultivation, including crossbreeding of strains for quality, size of leaf and pest resistance. General Cigar and other growers keep seeds -- tinier than grains of sand -- going back decades for crossing tobacco varieties.
"Tobacco quality comparable to ours may be found in other places like Cuba or Sumatra where our seed originally came from," says Angel Daniel Nunez, a senior vice president of General Cigar. "But you cannot duplicate our taste anywhere else."
He points out that the wrapper is only about 5 percent of the weight of a cigar, "But it accounts for most of the taste. A Connecticut wrapper cigar smokes cooler, longer, more evenly and with a delicate taste."
Connecticut shade, according to Ms. Martin, is now cultivated, for example, in Ecuador and marketed as "Connecticut seed" leaf. "But one puff and a smoker knows it is not the real thing," she says.
Don't just take Connecticut's word for it. Gordon Mott, managing editor of Cigar Aficionado magazine, says: "Connecticut shade is considered, simply, the finest wrapper tobacco in the world with its high degree of suppleness, consistent golden brown color and flavor that's not overpowering."
Shade tobacco is one of the most labor intensive, complex, delicate, risky, expensive -- and lucrative -- crops in the world. If Mother Nature is very kind, tobacco growers can turn a profit of $5,000 or more an acre. In a golden year -- no hail, wind or disease to harm delicate leaves -- farmers could realize double that amount.
But growers are skittish about divulging details of acreage, crop sizes and profits. "Even we have trouble getting statistics," says Rick Macsuga, marketing and inspection supervisor at the Connecticut Department of Agriculture in Hartford. "You can't blame them because the tobacco business is so risky and competitive. Besides, a lot of growers over the years have been on a roller coaster."
Connecticut growers claim their shade-wrapped product is every bit the equal of cigars from Cuba -- which contributed some seeds to the Connecticut pedigree decades ago. Today, the growers point out, the economically hard-hit Cubans don't have the resources to adequately fertilize or to age their tobacco as they used to in their heyday. "A Cuban cigar is still a great smoke," says Mr. McNamara. "Comparing Connecticut and Cuban cigars is like comparing two great French wines. But the fact is Cubans are not pampering their tobacco like we are."
And pampering is an understatement. In April, growers plant seedlings in greenhouses. In May, they painstakingly transplant them to the tented fields, using both men and machines.
The tents are designed to filter out about 25 percent of the sunlight. The space between plants and rows is calculated down to the inch -- as is the distance between rows of leaves in curing sheds.
Around July 1 the harvesting begins. Approximately three leaves per plant are harvested every week until the plants' 18 or 20 leaves -- dark green, silky and slightly sticky -- are stripped off the stalks by the end of August.
Everything about tobacco growing and processing is carried out with the precision of a military campaign. "Do you hear that snapping sound?" asks Mr. Nunez as workers pluck leaves. "Two or three days ago you would not have heard it. The tobacco would not have been ready to be picked -- it wasn't talking to you."
Workers are trained to deftly snap off the leaves at the very base of the stem with thumb and forefinger. The leaves are so easily bruised that too much finger pressure is enough to reduce a leaf to interior binder material rather than the top-grade wrapper. Even the tiny pink flowers that bloom atop a plant can damage a leaf simply by falling on it and resting there until it causes a fatal blemish.
A leaf is also immediately disqualified for top-of-the-line wrapper if it is accidentally torn or punctured. "A cigar smoker demands a clean, even colored wrapper," says Jean-Marc Bade, co-manager of the Windsor Shade Tobacco Company, a co-op representing eight growers.
The curing takes place in hundreds of darkened well-ventilated sheds, where the leaves are carefully strung together on long white cords, then hung to dry and cure for about six weeks.
The 30-foot-high sheds are checked daily for temperature and moisture. "The tobacco has to have a moisture content of between 12 and 24 percent," says Mr. Nunez.
At the end of the six weeks, the now-brittle leaves are humidified to make them pliable enough to ship out to warehouses without damage. The next stage, several months long, begins: fermentation and sorting out the leaves by size, color and quality.
Finally the tobacco is aged for a year, two years or longer -- depending on the standards of the cigar maker -- before making a final appearance as a wrapper on a fine cigar.
Connecticut shade tobacco tends to be environmentally friendly, growers proudly claim. Organic fertilizer is generally used because the plants thrive on it and pesticide spraying -- except for use against blue mold -- is kept to a minimum. "Pesticides could spoil the taste," says Mr. Nunez.
While growers luxuriate in the current cigar boom, they well remember the ups and downs over the decades. Perhaps nobody recalls better than Mr. Mulnite, who has spent all of his 90 years among tobacco leaves in East Windsor.
"Back in the 1920's," he says, "it was the peak for all tobacco -- shade and broadleaf. We're told the state had about 30,000 acres -- 4,000 of them in shade. But in the late 40's, we went up to about 8,000 acres in shade alone. The white tents were everywhere. We were famous by then."
But the sky began to fall, starting in the 1950's, with competition from a synthetic wrapper leaf made from homogenized particles of tobacco. Cigar smoking itself began drifting out of vogue. By 1975, according to the State Department of Agriculture, shade acreage had shrunk to 3,000 acres. The nadir was in 1992 when only 720 acres were planted.
"We thought Connecticut tobacco growing was doomed," says Edgar M. Cullman, chairman of the Culbro Corporation, parent of General Cigar. Connecticut farmers switched to pumpkins, strawberries or nursery items. But then came the cigar mania and tobacco growers galloped back from the brink.
Still, growers keep a wary eye on potential competition, from Cuba if relations are normalized, and on the controversy swirling around tobacco and health issues.
Thus far, they have not been targeted by anti-tobacco activists, nor were they named in the suit that the state has filed against tobacco firms.
"Nor has any other state acted against cigar tobacco," added Richard Blumenthal, the state's Attorney General. "I admit that cigar smoking has the potential to cause cancer and other diseases. But cigars are only a small proportion of the overall tobacco market and don't involve the same kind of marketing and advertising aimed at children as cigarettes."
Even the anti-tobacco crusader State Representative Robert Farr of West Hartford says, "Cigar smoking does not have the same addiction problem."

HEADLINE: Cancellation Sinks Pricey Audience Test

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

DATELINE: ELMSFORD

 BODY:
THE first Gold Star Event at the Westchester Broadway Theater here, "An Evening with Jackie Mason" on Aug. 12, was an unqualified nonevent. "Insufficient promotion" and "scheduling conflicts" were the reasons given by Allan Gruet, the theater's press and public relations director, before the cancellation of Mr. Mason's one-night stand, which was to have been a pricey test case for audiences on Mondays and Tuesdays, the nights the musicals of the moment give way to solo performances by singers, comedians or big bands. The question was whether audiences accustomed to paying $51 plus tax for Jackie (The Joke Man) Martling or $53 plus tax for Jerry Vale (with a guest comedian, John Pizzi) would go for the Mason tariff: $125 plus tax, which totals $133.44.
The answer must wait until after Oct. 20 -- Mr. Mason's rescheduled date -- or after Nov. 17, the appearance of Connie Francis, the second scheduled Gold Star Event for which $100 and $125 tickets are on sale. No other relatively upscale performers have been signed, but the management's wish list, in response to customers who have reportedly requested bigger names, includes Paul Anka, George Carlin, Don Rickles, Harry Belafonte and Joan Rivers. 
 A question of entertainment has become, like virtually everything else, a problem in economics. Is one Connie Francis, say, worth two Al Martinos? Such engagements will invariably steepen fees, at least of those performers teetering between A and B lists (we are not talking megastars here). Tickets for Mr. Vale's on Oct. 7 have escalated to $67.25, tax included, no comedian.
For such performers as Mr. Martino and Mr. Vale, Westchester is a small-change stopover on the way home to California after an Atlantic City booking. Recent Monday or Tuesday "special nights" have included the Guy Lombardo Orchestra, Frank Patterson, the Irish tenor, with singers and dancers, and Johnny Maestro and the Brooklyn Bridge in rock-and-roll songs from the 50's and 60's, with the comedian Pete Michaels. Next up: the Irish Rovers on Oct. 6.
The musical of the moment through next Saturday is "South Pacific" in a pedestrian staging, unlighted by essential romantic leads. Yet, the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical has been faring better than "Carousel," a superior musical with a far superior cast, which played here from January through April.
The box office success of the musicals at the Westchester Broadway Theater depends on the recognition factor, and that keeps changing. "We cannot do obscure shows, however," Mr. Gruet said. " 'Sayonara,' which was a new musical, bombed."
"Fiddler on the Roof," the most recent production, remains a perennial. Business exceeded 85 percent of capacity, the figure necessary to stay in business. "South Pacific" has topped it. "Carousel" and "Damn Yankees" did not break even.
"Phantom" was a hit the first time around, but not the second. Ditto "Dreamgirls."
"But why 'South Pacific' drew crowds and 'Carousel' didn't, I cannot figure out," Mr. Gruet said.
Or as Hammerstein put it:
"Who can explain it? Who can tell you why? Fools give you reasons -- Wise men never try."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBOORHOOD REPORT: TRIBECA;
Candy, Nuts and a Bite of History Move On

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
The moving trucks will be coming downtown this week. And as they take the last nut and chocolate processing machines from A. L. Bazzini Company on Greenwich Street, a little bit of New York history will be going with them.
"We were the last food manufacturer in TriBeCa," said Rocco Damato, owner of the company. "Without us, there's no one left." 
 Indeed, in a neighborhood that once was home to the city's wholesale produce and dairy businesses, Bazzini's departure leaves one butter and egg warehouse and a couple of upscale retail bakeries.
According to Madeleine Wils, the wife of the owner, the dairy business -- Harry Wils & Company -- is also planning to move, and for the same reason: TriBeCa has become too fancy, and its real estate too expensive for them to stay.
Founded by Anthony Bazzini in 1886, Bazzini processes fruits as well as nuts, and makes chocolates and other candies. It supplies Yankee and Shea Stadiums and stores like Balducci's and Zabar's.
It has been in TriBeCa since 1968, driven there from Park Place by urban renewal programs that swept many of its competitors to the Hunts Point market in the Bronx or out of the city entirely.
Nevertheless, when Mr. Damato and his late brother-in-law, Jim Strong, bought the business from Mr. Bazzini's heirs in 1983, there were plenty of other food businesses around, including Hotel Bar Butter and Martinson Coffee.
But while Bazzini stayed, the others soon left; the Martinson building is now Robert DeNiro's TriBeCa Film Center.
Mr. Damato was never completely immune to the gentrification around him. His wife, Electra, opened a high-end food store on Bazzini's ground floor in the late 1980's, and a few years later he sold some of his space to condominium developers, shifting part of Bazzini's production to North Carolina. Then last year he decided to move it all away.
"It doesn't pay to stay here anymore," Mr. Damato said. "Real-estate taxes are too high, and energy costs are, too."
Although wooed by North Carolina, New Jersey and others, Mr. Damato found the best deal in Hunts Point. In fact, he is bringing much of the North Carolina production back north, and is happy that he won't have to dislocate his 50 employees.
Bazzini's food store will expand to five times its present size, Mr. Damato said. And the rest of the building? It's being converted to condominiums, of course. BERNARD STAMLER
