LENGTH: 1178 words

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
For Many Small Businesses, The Labor Pool Is Shallow

BYLINE: By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

 BODY:
DICK BELCHER, a bank president in a small Indiana town, cannot recall when the economy was better. At his bank, delinquencies are virtually nonexistent and business is steady.
While a strong economy brings many good things to small businesses like his, it also creates a problem: Where do you find enough qualified employees? 
 The national unemployment rate of 4.8 percent in July was the lowest in almost 24 years. And small businesses, particularly in rural communities with smaller labor pools, are finding that their biggest challenge these days isn't bringing in work orders and jobs. It is finding someone to do the work.
Mr. Belcher employs nearly 100 people at five branches of the First Federal Savings Bank, with about half the jobs in Rochester, Ind., a town of 7,000 about a two-hour drive north of Indianapolis. Over the last 36 months, Mr. Belcher said, he has found it difficult to fill all the positions in his branches. He now has three job openings.
"It's a market for the employees," Mr. Belcher said. "We have had to raise salaries and talk more about our benefits."
Several years ago he started a profit-sharing plan, which he sweetened this year, and he has also offered a 401(k) -- an inducement provided by few small employers in the past.
Employment at small businesses has a broad effect on the economy. About 53 percent of the nation's workers are employed by companies with fewer than 500 workers. And despite competition for workers at businesses large and small, most economists say wages and prices are not rising sharply -- and thus, with the threat of inflation abated, interest rates have stayed unchanged, meaning a period of unusually good news for the economy.
Yet small-business owners say the competition for workers has caused them to raise salaries in some cases and benefits in others. The owners have also become more flexible with work schedules and advertised the jobs over a much wider areas.
The employment problem for small business "has been skyrocketing in the last year and a half," said William Dunkelberg, an economics professor at Temple University in Philadelphia and chief economist for the National Federation of Independent Business in Washington. The group represents 600,000 member companies, 80 percent of which employ fewer than 40 people each.
In July, 29 percent of the 2,000 employers responding to the federation's monthly survey said they were having trouble filling at least one job. That is the highest percentage in 25 years, Professor Dunkelberg said. Often in the early 1980's, less than 6 percent of employers said finding workers was a problem.
When asked to list the biggest problems facing their companies, the managers put the availability of skilled employees right after taxes and government regulations, Professor Dunkelberg said. In the past, inflation and interest rates were larger concerns.
The December 1996 survey showed that 32 percent of the respondents had recently raised compensation for employees, a figure that Professor Dunkelberg interprets as another sign of increasing demand for workers. The federation's surveys also showed that 10 percent of the business owners had unfilled openings for unskilled laborers.
"We've generated so many jobs," Professor Dunkelberg said. The problem is compounded in a smaller town, he said, where "you don't have as big a pool of workers."
At the Ana-Lab Corporation in Kilgore, Tex., Charles Whiteside, the owner, said he had been unable to fill three positions. The company, which does environmental testing and operates water systems, employs 60 people in the town of 11,000 residents. Ana-Lab offers health insurance, sick leave, retirement and education benefits, Mr. Whiteside said, but he has still gone two months with openings.
"We've had a lot of economic development and new industry here," he said. "There's not enough good employees for the demand. We pay a lot of overtime here because we don't have enough people."
In Indiana, Mr. Belcher recently hired a woman in her 30's from another local business. She was making a higher hourly wage at the other job, he said, but needed the benefits that his bank offered: "She told me, 'I'm at the age where I need to be concerned about retirement.' "
Sarah Wilson, publisher of The Rochester Sentinel, the local newspaper, said the lack of a 401(k) plan had cost her workers. Indeed, one former employee returned after the newspaper instituted such a plan this year.
"Applicants in their 20's are asking about that," she said.
Employers like Mr. Belcher and Ms. Wilson have usually been able to rely on local networking and newspaper advertising to find employees. But increasingly, small-business owners are finding they have to branch out.
By using trade journals and college placement services, Ms. Wilson recently found candidates for an advertising manager's job that had been open for several months. Mr. Belcher has used temporary employment agencies.
Both employers say they accept the fact that small-town life will attract some candidates and discourage others. "It's definitely a life-style change," Ms. Wilson said. "It's not New York."
They also know that for some workers a small-town business is a springboard to a larger market and that a certain amount of turnover is inevitable.
"That's something small business has always faced," said Bruce D. Phillips, director of the Small Business Administration's office of economic research in Washington. But the wage disparity between large and small businesses has shrunk. On average, according to Mr. Phillips, pay at small companies -- defined as those with fewer than 500 employees -- is 93 percent of that at large companies. In rural areas, employees also find that their living expenses are lower.
Ms. Wilson said two former employees had returned to the newspaper. One had tried another business and the other had left to join a larger company. But both found that they preferred the work and benefits at The Sentinel.
Flexibility has become another selling point for small businesses. Mr. Belcher said letting working mothers adjust their schedules so they could pick up their children after school -- or see a Little League baseball game -- had helped make his company a more attractive place to work.
"We have picked up employees that way," he said. "If you have to go to the doctor, we don't dock you."
In Redfield, S.D., a town of 2,800, Dale Haiar runs two shifts totaling 65 workers as plant manager for Dakotah Inc., which makes insulated throws and blankets. His previous employer, a plant in Aberdeen, S.D., was beginning to have problems finding skilled workers, he said, but Dakotah has had several applications from workers who were let go in government cutbacks at a state school. The company has also pulled in workers with its benefits: health insurance, paid vacation and sick days. About 80 percent of his employees are wives of farmers, he said.
"The benefits package is the big thing," Mr. Haiar said. "Dad can farm and Mom can provide the insurance."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Ana-Lab Corporation, an environmental testing company in Kilgore, Tex., has improved its compensation package but still cannot find enough qualified employees. (Melinda W. Bigelow for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Help Wanted"
A sign in the window cannot be counted on the fill jobs at small businesses in the current economy. William Dunkelberg, an economics professor at Temple University, offers these suggestions to employers.
 
Use university and community college placement offices
"You have a great captive labor pool," he said. Use students part-time while they are in school and you "get a chance to look them over."
 
Start an internship program
Many students are underemployed. Interns will often stay on in a full-time job after graduation and they have already had your training. Set up a relationship with an area college placement office so that the placement officer knows when you have openings and steers good people to your company.
 
Call trade organizations
Many have computer job banks.
 
Talk to regional Chambers of Commerce
Some of them post job openings or have programs to help locate new employees.
 
Use trade journals
In addition to local advertising, ads in trade journals can attract applicants for higher-paying jobs for which relocation would be worthwhile.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Digging for Treasure in Their Own Backyards

BYLINE: By ANNE TERGESEN 

 BODY:
INVESTORS already face a dizzying array of funds that use all kinds of arcane strategies to invest in every corner of the globe. Perhaps that helps explain why more people are choosing funds with the straightforward approach of focusing on companies in their own backyards.
But as the number of regional funds grows, so does the debate over their value. 
 The funds' managers argue that investing locally gives them an advantage, because they can really get to know the companies whose stocks they own. Critics, however, contend that a regional focus is just a marketing gimmick. And as one might expect, the performance of the funds has been mixed.
There are now more than 20 funds with a regional emphasis, selling Northwestern companies to Oregonians, Silicon Valley stocks to Californians and the industrial heartland to Midwesterners. Though outsiders -- residents of other areas -- can usually buy regional funds, they often appeal mainly to local pride.
The appeal seems to be working. In five of the last six years, regional funds have grown faster than the average for equity funds, and now total about $3.1 billion of assets, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund trackers in Chicago.
This year, the amount of money in regional funds soared 30.4 percent through July, compared with an average increase of 22.5 percent for all funds, Morningstar said. And the investment style has proved hot enough to attract at least two newcomers, focusing on Michigan and New York State, since May.
Fund managers in Seattle; Columbus, Ohio, and East Lansing, Mich., say they can keep better track of a regional portfolio because they socialize with employees of the portfolio companies, keep abreast of local news, drive by parking lots to see which businesses are busy, and stop in to test customer service.
Conrad Herrmann, senior manager of the Franklin California Growth fund, went to a hockey game with a friend who worked for one of the fund's holdings, Bay Networks. The friend had so much work to do that he rushed back to the office at 10 that night, Mr. Herrmann said, "reaffirming to us that our position was solid." Later, the fund, which has some of the best returns of any regional fund, sold the stock at a profit, he added.
Similarly, Norm Klopp, who runs Fairport Midwest Growth, said his knowledge about hundreds of executives in the eight states bordering the Great Lakes had helped him predict several successful turnarounds. For example, after following the career of John P. Reilly for years, Mr. Klopp didn't hesitate to buy shares in Figgie International after it named Mr. Reilly chief executive in 1995. Since then, the stock has appreciated almost 100 percent, Mr. Klopp said, helping the fund gain an average of 21 percent a year.
In the age of air travel and instantaneous information, the backyard advantage may be disputed. "The communications and technology revolution has brought investors much closer to firms than may have been the case 20 or 30 years ago," said Gerald Perritt, editor of The Mutual Fund Letter.
Even some managers who like the philosophy have hesitated to adopt it formally. Daniel Perkins, whose Perkins Opportunity fund invests about half its $84 million in assets in the upper Midwest, said he avoids the regional label because he does not want to be boxed in by securities regulations that require those professing a geographic allegiance to invest at least 65 percent of their assets there.
And critics argue that it is unwise to invest in a fund that ties its hands. If companies in another state are hot, managers who cling to laggards at home restrict returns, said John Markese, president of the American Association of Individual Investors in Chicago. He said investors also expose themselves to increased risk by tying portfolios to the fortunes of their local economies, which may already influence the security of their jobs and the value of their homes.
Portfolio managers note, however, that they take steps to reduce the risk of geographical concentration. Aquila Cascadia Equity, which focuses on seven Western states, roughly replicates the industry weightings of the Standard & Poor's Mid-Cap 400 index, said George W. Hosfield, a portfolio manager of the fund. Because the Northwest lacks oil and natural-gas companies, Cascadia compensates by buying such stocks with the portion of the fund that is invested outside its region.
James P. Foster, who runs STI Classic Sunbelt Equity, has an unwritten policy to start selling a position once it accounts for more than 3 percent of the fund's assets. STI invests in a 12-state area from Virginia to Texas.
Some critics suggest that the recent spate of new regional funds has less to do with investing principles and more to do with a need to stand out in a crowded field. The growing popularity of regional investing "is consistent with the amount of additional marketing that has gone on in this industry in the last couple of years," said Brian Mattes, a principal at the Vanguard Group, which does not offer regional funds.
Even some of these funds' managers cite marketing as one rationale for their offerings.
"We needed to differentiate ourselves as a new fund," said Patrick Dooley, the managing director of the New York State Opportunity Funds, the first of which had its debut in May.
WHEN there is the matter of returns. As a group, regional funds have trailed the average domestic equity fund, whether for the first seven months of 1997, the past 12 months or the last five years, Morningstar said.
"There's no good reason to own one of these funds if it can't compete with diversified equity funds," said Laura Lallos, a senior Morningstar analyst.
A few of the funds have compiled standout records. Franklin California Growth I, with a heavy emphasis on technology, has among the best three- and five-year records of any growth fund, despite trailing badly this year. And Composite Northwest, which emphasizes companies in Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Montana and Alaska, has zoomed 55.7 percent in the last 12 months, a hot performance for any fund.
But lagging returns and portfolio limitations have caused at least one fund to drop a regional slant. Shareholders of One Group Gulf South Growth voted recently to eliminate the portfolio's concentration on the states bordering the Gulf of Mexico and to instead invest in small companies around the country. The fund is up only 10 percent or so this year and has not burned up the track in previous years. Rick Jandrain, managing director of equities for the fund's new parent, Banc One Investment Advisors, said One Group should be free to pursue "the best companies without worrying about what states they are in."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBOORHOOD REPORT: JACKSON HEIGHTS;
In School for Deaf, America's Promise to Immigrants Is Kept

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

 BODY:
For deaf immigrants, especially those from third world countries, the United States is a place rich beyond imagining, offering a cornucopia of services: schools with the most up-to-date pedagogic techniques, electronic and telecommunication devices that ease communication, civil rights protections and an organized advocacy community.
Many of these advantages are not available to illegal immigrants, like the deaf Mexicans smuggled here to peddle trinkets and held in conditions approaching bondage in two Queens apartments. They were forced into the underground economy because current law prohibits their employment of any illegal immigrant, disabled or not. 
 But for deaf immigrants who are eligible for green cards or citizenship, the United States is the land of opportunity. The Lexington Center and School for the Deaf, a 135-year-old academic and social service agency at 30th Avenue and 75th Street in Jackson Heights, not far from the apartments where the trinket peddlers lived, is one of many institutions that provide unusual training to the disabled.
Lexington, like many other American schools for the deaf, has shifted over time from the so-called oralism that dominated schooling for the deaf for decades. The old system emphasized time-consuming and often unsuccessful efforts at speech, and the newer system stresses mastery of sign language. In Mexico, by contrast, only the biggest cities even have schools for the deaf, and their focus is on the old-fashioned oral methods.
Lexington also has access to the latest aids: telephones that allow the deaf to send messages by teletype, devices that flash when a doorbell rings or a baby cries, dogs trained to alert their masters to sounds the human ear cannot hear. In underdeveloped countries, such help is generally unavailable or unaffordable.
These educational and technological services are staples at schools like Lexington, which is private but financed with public money. But tides of immigration have brought curricular changes.
The school has developed a tri lingual approach to teach deaf children in their home language (be it Urdu, Russian, Spanish or Cantonese), the school language (English) and American sign Language, a visual communication system with its own syntax, vocabulary and grammar. Lexington's student body is now nearly 60 percent foreign-born, from families that speak 28 different languages.
Some immigrant children arrive able to speak their native language but with varying degrees of impairment. Some can read a bit. Some are familiar with the sign language used in their home country, which is different from American sign language in vocabulary but similar in grammar and syntax.
Others arrive illiterate in all three languages, with no communication skills other than an idiosyncratic form of sign that deaf people commonly develop when not taught a formal version.
Developing language skills under such circumstances is a complicated process with, say, a deaf teacher fluent in Spanish and sign aided by a Russian or Chinese translator. While the first instructor presents the lesson, the children with other languages read the lips of native translators. Hands are flying, multiple languages are spoken, multiple sets of lips are read, until the children master English and American sign language.
Lexington's vocational center has also developed programs to deal with the crush of new immigrants, who are often ignorant of their legal status under America's changing immigration laws.
To guide clients through the process, the center assigns sign language interpreters to accompany the deaf to immigration hearings, explain the law and translate documents. But despite all these advantages and innovations, an illegal immigrant educated or trained at Lexington and other places like it eventually runs into a brick wall when the time comes to find a job: Federal immigration laws.
Graduates of vocational programs who lack legal status cannot be offered job placement services.
"They cannot access the system," said Dr. Kevin Keane, who is Lexington's assistant superintendent. "So we are training them to do what? Eventually, they will have to enter the underground economy." JANE GROSS

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Why German Auto Makers Are Humming

BYLINE: By LARRY DIGNAN 

 BODY:
AUTO industry analysts are abuzz over the new models that German manufacturers are bringing forth this fall, like the Mercedes-Benz sport utility vehicle and a modified Volkswagen Beetle. But high as expectations are, the analysts say other aspects of the companies' business may be equally important in making them good long-term investments.
The German companies are cutting production costs, just as their American counterparts did in the 1980's, and demand for their products is growing in Europe. And with uncertainty over Europe's planned common currency, the euro, the dollar has soared against the German mark to levels unseen in six years, making these vehicles less expensive for Americans. United States sales contribute anywhere from 6 percent to 50 percent of these companies' revenues. 
 American investors can get in directly on this action with Volkswagen and Daimler-Benz, parent of Mercedes-Benz, through the companies' American depository receipts.
The two companies are very different. Daimler derives only about two-thirds of its income from auto and truck sales; its various other ventures include a stake in Airbus Industrie, the European airplane consortium. And while the company's cars are synonymous with luxury, its new models, like the sport utility vehicle and a compact car set to have its debut in Europe this fall, will carry more modest prices.
Volkswagen is purely an auto company. Its current goal is to expand its presence in the higher-priced market, using its Audi subsidiary to take on BMW and even enhancing some Volkswagen models, like the new Passat, to duel with Mercedes.
But Daimler and Volkswagen have something in common: their stocks are doing well, particularly Volkswagen's, even though both have pulled back a bit recently because of concerns over Germany's economy and possible changes in monetary policy. Both stocks have enough fuel for a longer run, many analysts say.
True, if Germany raises interest rates, the mark's value will climb against the dollar, increasing the cars' prices here. And the new models may fail, despite the industry's excitement. Nevertheless, analysts say, the two companies look good.
DAIMLER has already sold off about one-third of its businesses, mostly unprofitable ones like Fokker, the Dutch aircraft company, said Paul Korngiebel, a senior analyst at Brandes Investment Partners in San Diego. It has also streamlined its organization and struck favorable labor pacts.
The payoff so far: Daimler's first-half profits were 1.8 billion marks, more than double those of the corresponding period a year earlier.
Daimler is also saving money by simplifying its engineering. It is using modular assembly techniques, partly by outsourcing various tasks, said Rich Lazarchic, manager of the American Express IDS Global Growth fund, which owns Daimler shares. For example, suppliers now give Daimler whole doors rather than just door components.
Of course, Daimler's challenge is to maintain its famous engineering excellence as it trims costs. "Quality is the main reason people buy a Mercedes," Mr. Lazarchic said. "They can mix and match parts, but the cars still have to appear as if they were individually done."
Still, Daimler has strengths beyond the Mercedes name. Its truck business is the world's largest, and it is in a good position to benefit from the weak mark. Because most of its plants are in Germany -- some other car makers' facilities are more spread out -- its costs have fallen far in dollar terms.
For its part, Volkswagen has been in the forefront of the movement to simplify production techniques. "They have cut a great deal in costs by reducing suppliers and creating economies of scale," said Loretta Morris, a senior international portfolio manager for Nicholas-Applegate Capital Management in San Diego, which owns shares in Volkswagen and other German auto makers.
"The restructuring has given them good operating margins and return on equity," Ms. Morris said.
As for Volkswagen's new models, the Beetle has garnered the most attention. Many analysts say the retooled Bug -- the original is still made in small volume in Mexico -- will catch on because nostalgic baby boomers will be happy to pay the price -- about $15,500.
However, Volkswagen's long-term bottom line will be more affected by the new Golf, said Robert Sigler, an analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York. And he is hopeful because the new Golf will be cheaper than its old version yet produce higher margins because of manufacturing efficiencies.
Another big factor in Volkswagen's fortunes is its success in China and Latin America, and Mr. Sigler is optimistic on that front, too.
"They have a foothold in the key growth markets," he said. In Brazil, for example, where Volkswagen has 36 percent of the market, car sales are up 24 percent this year.
Mr. Sigler projects that Volkswagen's earnings will grow 20 percent to 30 percent within 18 months.
Ms. Morris also expects to see further gains in Volkswagen's stock, which she called cheap despite its run-up. The stock is at the low end of the European auto makers' group, selling at about 20 times 1997 earnings and 14 times projected 1998 earnings, less than Daimler's respective multiples of 24 and 22.
Some analysts, however, say such comparisons are misleading because Volkswagen is just a car company while Daimler is more diversified.

HEADLINE: Cuban Culture Avoids Political Tensions

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your article on the growing popularity of Cuban art in the United States (Arts pages, Aug. 21) says a "loophole" in the Helms-Burton Act is responsible for the surge in Cuban music sales. In fact, the Berman amendment to the embargo, passed in the late 1980's, exempted cultural activities from the restrictions imposed on trade between the United States and Cuba. 
 Since United States law prohibits sale of a Cuban product only if the earnings end up in Cuban Government coffers, the Castro regime has allowed its artists to keep their fees from performances and sales overseas. Also, regulations requiring performers to permanently reside in Cuba have been relaxed and artists are allowed to settle abroad, provided they do not break with the regime.
Before the Berman amendment, Cuban artists like Pablo Milanes and Gonzalo Rubalcaba were denied visas to perform in the United States. Today, United States record companies enjoy the benefits of the new cultural-exchange system.
President Castro winks at the thawing of cultural relations, but at the same time he is keeping political tensions with Washington as high as possible.
 
RODOLFO A. WINDHAUSEN
New York, Aug. 21, 1997

HEADLINE: Tito Mahones: A Life On the Edge

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
TITO MAHONES woke up in his Bedford-Stuyvesant apartment last Tuesday feeling better than he had in weeks. He may have only had a few dollars in his pocket, but the 40-year-old handyman, street hawker and jack-of-all trades was expecting a few renovation jobs to come his way. For once, he thought, good luck was on his side.
After tinkering with some broken television sets and making breakfast for his father, he got on a Manhattan-bound J train, lugging an armload of scavenged merchandise -- clothing, books and refurbished electronics -- that he could peddle on the streets. He made his way to the East Village, where, on a shady patch of sidewalk at Ninth Street and First Avenue, he made an easy $80 in sales. God must have been looking out for him, he thought, because the police didn't even harass him once. Feeling as if he didn't have a care in the world, Tito returned home that evening with enough groceries to fill his empty refrigerator. 
 "Things is looking up," he told his father as he mopped the kitchen floor and cleared out a week's worth of dirty dishes from the sink. But just as he started to vacuum his grimy carpet, the power died. So did the lights. He looked out the window, saw the Con Ed crew in the street and knew that his unpaid electric bills had finally caught up with him. Defeated by the dark, he sat on his bed and cried. Later that night, he pawned his tools for $20, bought a few 40-ounce bottles of Colt .45 and sat in his bedroom as the crack heads began gathering below his window on De Kalb Avenue. "Seems I just can't get ahead," he said, his face lit by the glow of a Newport. "I must be cursed 'cause bad luck follows me wherever I go."
Bad luck. Bad circumstance. Bad judgment. Tito Mahones has them all. On his own since he was 15, Tito survived on street smarts, petty larceny and big-time drug deals. He has been in and out of prison a dozen times. He has been homeless twice. His body is a three-dimensional canvas of thick scars, remnants of the beatings, shootings and stabbings from his days as a teen-age gang member. At night, his dreams are so full of mayhem he can only sleep a few hours at a time. "I've almost used up all of my nine lives," he said with a half-grin last week, surrounded by the candles that illuminated his kitchen. "But I don't go down easy. I think God wants me to survive for a reason. He wants me to do something with my life."
Tito doesn't know much about bull markets and mutual funds, but he can smell the city's booming economy, the prosperity and the opportunities. He just can't figure out how to make the system work for him. Tito is stuck on the margins, just getting by, living hand to mouth. "On bad days, I'm lucky if I can buy me a slice of pizza," he said. "On good days, I hand out dollar bills to the addicts who hang on my stoop." If only he could get a steady job he swears he would save money, open a bank account, get a phone, buy a used van and start up the contracting business he has long dreamed of owning. Maybe then he could start giving money to his six children. Maybe he could afford to move away from his rundown apartment, the random violence and a neighborhood he believes is holding him back.
Tito doesn't have a resume and never made it past fifth grade, but when he has money in his pocket, he can talk big about his prospects, his get-rich schemes. "I feel like I'm about to break through," he said the other day, showing off $50 he made fixing the roof of a neighborhood church -- money that bought him back his pawned tools. "If I keep busy working, I can blank out my problems. When I'm not, I get myself into trouble."
His youthful brawn has long since given way to a soft belly, but if provoked, Tito can still put up a fierce fight. And while middle age has mellowed his fury, a quick temper is never far from the surface. "Everywhere I go, people think I'm a tough guy because the way I walk," he said. "They look in my eyes and they think I'm a killer. If they gave me a chance, they'd see I'm a nice guy."
Since his last brush with the law -- a six-month jail term for drug possession in 1991 -- Tito has been trying to forge a new life built on hard work and clean living. He has, he says, "found God," and his friends and family agree that the hard-drinking hell-raiser has become something of a pussycat. "Tito is so honest, you could drop a wallet and he wouldn't even look at it," said his brother Leon. "His biggest problem these days is that he's too good to people who give him nothing in return. He's very sensitive, so when folks disappoint him, he beats himself up."
It doesn't take much to set Tito back. A fight with one of his brothers, a junkie's insult or losing a game of dice will foul up his head and send him into a dark hole. Things are like that for Tito. Some weeks are good; some weeks are real bad. The first two weeks of August were worse than usual. It all started with the death of his brother Paco, after a long battle with AIDS. When he heard the news, Tito stopped working and took solace in a six-pack of beer. Nearly a hundred people gathered at the wake, including all of Tito's six surviving brothers. Only a sister, lost to drugs and mental illness, didn't show up.
As a boom box filled the San Juan Funeral Home with samba, children -- a half-dozen of them Paco's -- ran around the crowded chapel. Others practiced crossing themselves in front of the pewter casket. An iridescent Last Supper, rendered in felt, hung opposite a mural of puffy clouds floating over turquoise skies. Paco's oldest daughter brought a custom-made floral arrangement shaped like a bongo drum, her father's passion before heroin destroyed his life. Few tears were shed among the mourners, most of whom saw Paco's death as a release from suffering. After viewing the body, people spilled onto the sidewalk, chatting in a mix of Spanish and English and sipping drinks from bottles wrapped in brown paper bags.
Tony Escobar, one of the few brothers to make it out of Brooklyn, came all the way from Florida, where he works installing utility ducts. Even though they hadn't met in years, Tito was nervous because he owed Tony $150. Tony didn't bring it up, but Tito still felt ashamed. "It's bad enough that I didn't have enough money to buy a suit," he said, tugging at his black shirt.
Like Paco, Tony had a different father than Tito -- a man he never knew. His mother, Fanny Mahones, an immigrant from Puerto Rico, fed her eight children on welfare checks. Until he learned Spanish a few years ago, Tito and his mother could barely communicate. "We don't have much of a relationship," he said. "She hates me. I think it's because I remind her of my father."
 
A Cruel Childhood That Ended at Age 9
Growing up, the children spent most of their time in the streets. But in the kitchen, Fanny Mahones ruled with an iron fist, her son recalled. "We never got enough to eat," said Tito, describing how his mother kept the refrigerator chained with a heavy padlock. When drunk, she could be cruel. "If we wet our bed, Mom would put our naked bottoms on the hot radiator so we wouldn't do it again," he said.
The family moved every few years, from East New York to Brownsville to the Lower East Side to Bedford-Stuyvesant. The brothers had to fight wherever they went. "There were so many of us, and our skins were all different shades, people assumed we were a gang," Tony said. "We were tough. We never backed down from a brawl."
It was Tony who got Tito involved in raising pigeons, a popular hobby in Brooklyn during the 1970's. But what started as a peaceful pursuit turned into a cat-and-mouse game of pigeon theft from neighboring rooftops. Once, when a competitor stole some of the brothers' birds, Tony and Tito set his coop ablaze.
By age 9, Tito had stopped going to school. He spent his days on the streets tagging his older brothers, all of them members of the Tomahawks, one of central Brooklyn's most fearsome gangs. His first arrest came at 9, for shoplifting. At 12, he was arrested for driving a stolen Chevy Impala given to him by his brother Carlos. When a police officer called his mother, asking her to pick him up at the station house, Tito recalls her saying, "You take him." A judge sent him to a juvenile detention center upstate, where he stayed for the next three years. "I was so busted up, I cried for a week," he said. His mother never answered his letters. No one ever visited.
The day he turned 15, he was transferred to a home for troubled youths in the Bronx. After a few weeks, he slipped away and went back home. When his mother refused to open the door, he ended up on the Lower East Side, sleeping in Tompkins Square Park. "Mama," a well-known heroin dealer on East Sixth Street, took him in, looking after Tito and other runaways. In exchange, they worked as drug runners or helped out in her busy shooting gallery, injecting customers in parts of their bodies -- buttocks, legs and the back of the neck -- that would hide the track marks.
By the time he was in his early 20's, Tito was running his own dealership on De Kalb Avenue, just north of the elevated subway line on Broadway. Those were crazy days in Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick. Crack was hot, and at night the streets became a battleground for rival dealers. "Every day, someone would get knocked off," Tito said. "I've seen too many people die, a few of them in my arms."
His good fortune came to an end one spring night in 1992, when a competitor tossed a Molotov cocktail through Tito's apartment window. To escape the flames, he jumped out a fourth-floor window, landing on a mound of garbage that filled the roofless building next door. More than three hours passed before firefighters found his unconscious body.
After he left the hospital, his right hand permanently damaged, Tito ended up at the Atlantic Avenue men's shelter. "I had nowhere to go," he said. "No one wanted me." One evening, he sneaked into his mother's apartment and barricaded himself in the bathroom, he said, "with a 40-ouncer in one hand and a .38 in the other." The last time he had tried suicide by drinking a bottle of iodine from his mother's medicine chest. It was a miserable attempt and after his stomach was pumped, he had to face the world with a mouth that stayed purple for weeks.
He didn't pull the trigger that night and passed out drunk on the floor. When he woke up a few hours later, he vowed to clean up his act. He remembered his friend Pepe, an ex-crack addict who had gone straight with the help of a church in East New York. Pepe introduced him to Pastor Lydia Grenade, who ran Faithful Mission on Pennsylvania Avenue. The pastor gave him food and a bed and showed him how to live an honest life.
At Faithful Mission, Tito met June Weatherly, a soft-spoken schoolteacher from Trinidad who was getting back on her feet after an abusive relationship and a bout of homelessness. Tito and June seemed to have a lot in common: they both craved stability, a tight family. He was impressed by her kindness, her education. She was moved by his frank way of speaking, his earnestness and the fact that he taught himself to read and write at 28, watching "Sesame Street" while in prison. Five months after they began dating, June became pregnant.
 
A Broken Relationship, And a Bond With His Son
Tito is the father of five other children, by two other women, but Jonathan's birth was the only one he actually showed up for. "Mine were the first hands they put him in after he was born," he said proudly. After his son's birth, however, Tito started gambling again and June grew weary of the lies and his inability to bring home a steady income. After a year together, she got an apartment in a housing project in Coney Island and moved out with Jonathan.
A few days after Paco was buried, Tito took refuge at June's place, looking after Jonathan and trying to regain his footing. He was broke, but time away from De Kalb Avenue would do him good. There's not much action on Surf Avenue; no numbers joints, no one tempting him to party. The only lure is the pinball arcade, where Tito sometimes goes to ease his boredom. Seagulls squawk overhead and when the wind blows from the east, you can hear the crashing waves. The people on Surf Avenue are mostly working-class, the projects clean and graffiti-free. Compared to his dingy apartment, which has no locks on the doors, June's home is like a palace. "It's real quiet here, almost too quiet," he said.
They are no longer a couple, but Tito tries his best to stay involved in Jonathan's life. "My other kids, well they don't know me too well," he said. "I want this one to think of me as his daddy." When he woke up on Wednesday, the heaviness in his gut had eased. He stepped onto the balcony and looked out over the Atlantic, watching freighters and cruise ships disappear in the haze. On the boardwalk below, he could see people jogging. Inspired, he went down to the beach and did a set of pushups. They left him short of breath. "First time in six years I exercised," he said. "At Rikers, I worked out all the time. I used to be the champion arm wrestler. I gotta get back in shape."
When June came home that afternoon from her job as a teacher's aide, Tito's good spirits quickly faded. Sally Jesse Raphael was on the television. The theme: "I Was Rich but I Lost Everything." Tito shook his head and said, "That's the story of my life." June let out a laugh and Tito muttered something under his breath. Later they took Jonathan to the beach. Tito was dressed in a full set of fatigues, leftovers from the days when he volunteered for the Army Explorers, leading troops of city kids on field trips.
By the time they reached the boardwalk, they were already arguing. June said that Tito never gave her any money for Jonathan's upbringing. Tito's hands waved angrily, beer splashing out of the can he was holding. He was almost snarling. "Why you have to disrespect me?" he asked. "I don't need you to respect me, just stop disrespecting me." June kept quiet, knowing that anything she said would stoke his temper. When he went off to a relieve himself against a wall, she talked about her frustrations, describing the day Tito gambled away $900, money they had planned to use for a crib, a carriage and baby clothing. Then there was the time he sold her furniture and dishes after she had moved out. "Tito would go straight from the check cashing place to the numbers parlor," she said. "Sometimes we wouldn't have a dime."
When Tito came back, he was calm. As he gazed at Jonathan playing in the sand, he made a quiet confession. "I know I messed up," he said, his eyes tearing. "I guess I wasn't the man you thought I was."
June is moving on with her life. Right now she is focused on completing a masters degree in education at Medgar Evers College. She has forgiven Tito for the past but holds out little hope for reconciliation. The way she sees it, Tito's accumulated trauma is too much for him to bear. "Tito can't get away from the streets," she said. "It's in his blood. The street is where he gets his sense of belonging, his respect, but these people always betray him and then he comes here and takes it out on me."
Once, after she paid off a gambling debt, Tito agreed to go to a Gamblers Anonymous meeting. "He showed up drunk, and then walked out, saying he didn't have that kind of problem," she recalled. "Tito is a good person, but I don't think he can sort out his life until he gets help."
 
A New Haircut And a Ray of Hope
A few days later, when Tito turned up at his usual peddling spot on First Avenue, his hair and mustache were gone, shaved off by his brother Leon. "Time for a change," he said, rubbing his shiny head like an awkward schoolboy. "New look for a new life." There was something jaunty in Tito's walk, more strut, less swagger. A big renovation job on Pacific Street had come through and Con Ed had turned the power back on, agreeing to look into his claim that someone in the building was illegally tapping his line (the utility acted after a reporter inquired about the shutoff). More than a month had passed since he had fed the one-armed bandit that sits, illegally, between the Pampers and pet food at the back of his corner bodega. "Things is looking good for me," he said. "I'm feeling happy."
As long as it is not raining, Tito can be found bopping around the East Village, "a place you won't get killed if you wander off your block," he said. In Brooklyn, a guy can get shot walking into the wrong neighborhood. To him, the East Village is freedom. "Here, everyone's all mixed up: black, white, Puerto Rican," he said. "The worst I get over here is dirty looks." His dream is to find an apartment on a quiet street, but he knows he couldn't afford East Village rents.
Tito hadn't come by to join the peddlers that day. "I'm on to bigger and better things," he said, showing off the Swanson watches he had bought that morning from a wholesale place on 28th Street. With a loan from a friend, he was able to buy 20 watches at $5 apiece. In neighborhoods like East New York, he knows he can get $10 a watch. He lined his wares up inside a vinyl display case and headed east toward Avenue C, "where the Dominicans and Puerto Ricans buy 'em like hot cakes." He hit every bodega, botanica and sidewalk domino game on the way, yelling "barato, barato, barato" in Spanish ("cheap, cheap, cheap") or "Got them watches, got 'em cheap," in English. He carried a paper coffee cup filled with water and a submerged watch. "This way they know you're not lying when you say they waterproof," he explained.
By the end of the day, he had sold all but five and went back to buy another batch. "I gotta sink the money right into more merchandise, otherwise I'll spend it," he said over a slice of pizza. "If I go home at night, I'm bound to get in an argument with someone. Then I'll get upset and my mind will switch channels. When that happens, I start drinking and gambling." Finished eating, he excused himself and went back on to the street. Avenue C was buzzing. The sun was sinking. There were deals to be made.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBOORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Ground Broken for Pathmark but Concerns Remain

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
Two years after leaders in East Harlem grudgingly accepted a deal brokered by Mayor Giuliani that would give the community a stake in the controversial Pathmark project, construction is finally set to begin.
But as politicians and community leaders gather tomorrow on the empty lot on 125th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues for the groundbreaking ceremony, bitterness lingers among East Harlem's leaders. 
 For supporters of the project, including Mayor Giuliani, the event is a milestone in the community's effort to revitalize the greater Harlem area. With rooftop parking and a Chase Manhattan Bank branch that will open seven days a week, the $15 million, 50,000-square-foot store will create 200 mostly part-time union jobs with health benefits, with 75 percent of the slots to be filled by community residents.
Darren Walker, the spokesman for the developer -- the East Harlem Abyssinian Triangle -- called the project "an extraordinary event" for Harlem. "After decades of no significant growth, we now are beginning to reverse the trend," he said, adding that residents throughout Harlem support the development.
The East Harlem Abyssinian Triangle is a partnership between the Community Association of East Harlem Triangle and the Abyssinian Development Corporation, an arm of the Abyssinian Baptist Church.
But the heads of several local job training and development agencies say the project is falling short. They say most of the jobs created by the store will pay $5.25 an hour, not enough to support a family.
Jose Pagan, the vice chairman of Community Board 11 in East Harlem and the chairman of the board's economic development committee, said the Community Association has not lived up to its promise to work with the board to hire workers for 25 percent of the construction jobs.
"With construction weeks away, they have not hired anybody," Mr. Pagan said.
Concerns have also been raised in recent weeks by Raul Rodriguez, the executive director of the East Harlem Council for Community Improvement, which is to make job referrals to Pathmark, and Harry Rodriguez, chairman of Community Board 11.
Freddy Brown, who is president of the Community Association, said hiring decisions have not been made because the project's closing did not become final until Thursday night. He said he was planning a meeting with the contractor, James A. Smith, this week to discuss job opportunities. JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT/MUTUAL FUNDS -- THE MARKETS: Navigating Choppy Waters;
Value and Growth: More Than a Distinction

BYLINE: By ANNE TERGESEN 

 BODY:
IF the stocks of small companies are finally waking up, as some analysts said during the market's recent storminess, it may be a good time to remember that not all such stocks are alike.
There are growth stocks and there are value stocks in the small-capitalization world, and the common belief that small caps have been doing poorly must be revised when this distinction is made. The growth stocks -- those with above-average earnings prospects -- had total annual returns of just under 12 percent this year through Thursday. But the return on the value stocks -- those that are inexpensive relative to the company's earnings -- was 19.8 percent. 
 "Value is having a phenomenal year," said Claudia E. Mott, director of small-cap research at Prudential Securities.
Such starkly differing results between the two sets of stocks -- measured by looking at the growth and value components of the Russell 2000, the benchmark small-cap index -- are hardly unusual. Last year, for example, the value small caps had a total return of 21.4 percent, nearly as much as the 22.9 percent return of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. In the same period, the growth stocks had a tepid gain of 11 percent. But in 1995, the growth stocks outperformed the value stocks, 31 percent to 25.8 percent.
The pace of the economy and many other factors determine which type of small cap excels. But generally, value stocks outdo the growth variety when the total small-cap market is cool, and growth beats value in a hot market. Thus, in the cool small-cap market of 1993, value small caps had returns that were nearly double those of the growth types. But in the hot market of 1991, growth stocks outpaced value stocks by about 10 percentage points.
With value stocks ascendant these days, what are some favorites of the managers who run successful small-cap value funds?
William J. Nasgovitz, who manages the Heartland Value Plus fund, likes the Continental Homes Holding Corporation of Scottsdale, Ariz., which builds single-family homes in the South and West.
"We are making a bet here on interest rates," said Mr. Nasgovitz, whose fund has risen 36.9 percent over the last 12 months, through Thursday. "Our call is that rates are going lower," which would spur home buying.
But in case he is wrong about lower rates, Mr. Nasgovitz has a safety net. At $22.1875, Continental's stock is cheap, he said. While the stocks of home builders generally trade at an average of 10 times earnings, Continental's sells for a multiple of just 5.2, meaning that the stock will have to rise about 90 percent just to catch up to the industry average. The stock also trades at slightly below its book value of $23 a share.
True, "they probably will have a down quarter, and that's a caveat," Mr. Nasgovitz said of the company, which has annual revenues of $726 million. But Heartland remains bullish on Continental, saying it is diversifying from the weak geographic markets that have deflated its new orders and its stock price, and is venturing into the growing retirement-housing market, which may benefit from new tax laws.
Quanex, a Houston steel and aluminum mini-mill that makes, among other things, air-bag canisters, is another good bet, said Frank Reichel, whose Stratton Small-Cap Yield fund has gained about 43 percent in the last 12 months.
With Government mandates requiring that both front seats be equipped with air bags by the 1998 model year, and with many new cars now featuring back-seat and side bags as well, Quanex's canister business should grow by 50 percent over the next three years, he estimated.
Quanex stock is also cheap, Mr. Reichel said. At $31.75, it trades at 13.5 times its earnings per share, compared with an average multiple of 24.9 for the Russell 2000 at the end of July. And the company, which has annual sales of $896 million, is paring its debt and expanding market share.
All told, the stock may rise to $45 within 12 months, Mr. Reichel said, although he added that if aluminum prices rose, Quanex's fat profit margins might be reduced.
Both Mr. Reichel and Mr. Nasgovitz look for bargain-price stocks that pay dividends. Gary Haubold, who has steered the PBHG Small Cap Value fund to a just under 21 percent return since its start in May 1997, is a value investor who, on occasion, also buys growth stocks. He says a great value stock is a cement maker, Lone Star Industries of Stamford, Conn.
Lone Star stock is trading at $52.25, or about 10.2 times its estimated earnings per share next year. While that price level is consistent with companies that have "mediocre growth prospects," Mr. Haubold said, the outlook for cement is positive. With the economy growing, demand is strong. And cement prices are due for a lift, he added, because of the industry's longtime underinvestment in new capacity.
Moreover, he said, some foreign companies are in the market for American cement makers. If Lone Star, whose $368 million in sales make it the country's ninth-largest such concern, is acquired, its share price could rise above the $65 that he foresees within 12 months.
As with Continental Homes, however, Lone Star stock may suffer if the Federal Reserve raises interest rates and building is curbed.
OF course, inexpensive small caps will not outshine growth stocks forever. Indeed, Satya Pradhuman, the manager of domestic quantitative analysis at Merrill Lynch, expects growth stocks to lead small caps back to health this year. As the gains in blue-chip earnings slow, investors in search of high-earning stocks may turn to growth small caps instead, he said. Their mediocre performance since 1995 has made them cheap, he added.
Ms. Mott forecasts a growth-stocks revival for late in the year, but sees scant evidence of one now. With traditional value strongholds like financial services and basic industries doing well, "value still has some strength to it," she said.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 900 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT/MUTUAL FUNDS -- THE MARKETS: Navigating Choppy Waters;
Some Stocks That Even The Bears Would Buy

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
WHEN they look at stocks these days, they use words like "mania," "ridiculous" and "crazy."
They are bears, and some have been predicting a blowoff in stock prices for years. But if you ask them politely, most will acknowledge that there are companies and sectors that are not obscenely overvalued. And for investors worried about the market's recent drops, what better havens than those picked by pessimists? 
 Following are the stock selections of four notable bears:
 
Energy and Health Care
James B. Stack, president of Investech Research in Whitefish, Mont., is quick to say he is not a "gloom and doomer." Still, for the last year and a half the $30 million he manages has been 70 percent to 80 percent in cash.
"The greatest danger is not valuation," he said. "The greatest danger is that we have a psychology that this is a correctionless market, which has eliminated the fear of risk." Without saying how much the market should fall, he said he would feel more "comfortable" if stock prices declined by 15 percent.
The stocks that Mr. Stack does own are in sectors that do better at the end of bull cycles and, often, have high dividends. Energy, drugs and health care and utilities are three examples.
"We are holding stocks like Royal Dutch Petroleum, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Citizens Utilities, which pays a 6 percent stock dividend and is selling at a very low historic valuation level," Mr. Stack said.
He is also watching Japan. "If we see any strength in the Japanese economy, including a rise in interest rates, we will be moving into their stock market," he said.
 
Cable and Private Prisons
Steve Leuthold, chairman of Leuthold/ Weeden Research in Minneapolis, manages about $120 million. He says it will take more than rising inflation or interest rates to bring on a steep correction.
"Those things will upset the professionals, but not Main Street, and that is what is driving this market," he said.
But even though he is awaiting "something that shakes the confidence of Mr. and Mrs. Main Street," he bowed to the reality of the bull market earlier this summer.
"In June we increased our equity exposure to about 47 percent, from 17 percent," Mr. Leuthold said. "We are short-term bullish and long-term scared as hell."
His newly bought stocks are in life insurers like SunAmerica, the Provident Companies and the Equitable Companies. Insurers have good growth prospects, Mr. Leuthold said, yet many of their stocks trade at prices that are low relative to earnings.
Because he sees privatization and incarceration as growth fields, Mr. Leuthold also likes what he calls the "crime stopper" group, companies like the Corrections Corporation of America, the Wackenhut Corporation and the Pittway Corporation.
And even though Bill Gates's deal in which Microsoft bought 11.5 percent of Comcast has made cable stocks pricier, a bear like Mr. Leuthold still considers them cheap enough, given their growth potential. His picks include Comcast, Adelphia Communications and Cablevision Systems.
 
Insurers and a Cafeteria Chain
Charles Allmon, who said in August 1987 that the market was due for a fall, has been predicting the next one almost ever since.
"My guess, and I think it is a reasonable one, is a drop in the Dow of 40 percent to 60 percent by the year 2000, give or take one year from the high the Dow reaches in this cycle," said Mr. Allmon, who believes valuations are crazily high.
The editor and publisher of Growth Stock Outlook, in Bethesda, Md., Mr. Allmon also manages about $140 million. Those accounts are now 80 percent in cash, he said, "more cash than I was holding in 1987."
Still, there are some stocks he likes, including Luby's Cafeterias, which has its outlets in shopping malls across the South, and two insurers, Jefferson-Pilot and Aflac.
Because of the 4.5 percent yield for Luby's, the insurers' growth prospects and other factors, "I am willing to hold these stocks even if they decline 30 to 40 percent," he said.
Mr. Allmon also likes the prospects of Mity-Lite, a manufacturer of folding tables and chairs. "They have no balance-sheet problems and a ton of cash," he said.
And he said he would love to buy some technology stocks -- he particularly likes software stocks -- but they cost too much. "I have about 12 to 15 technology stocks on my list, but they would have to decline 40 percent or more in value before I would consider them," he said.
 
I'll Pass, Thanks
Unlike the other members of the group, William A. Fleckenstein has all four paws squarely on the ground.
"If you believe we are in a new era and the business cycle has been conquered, you can make an argument that securities are pretty expensive, but not bordering on the ridiculous," said Mr. Fleckenstein, whose Seattle money-management firm, Fleckenstein Capital, specializes in short-selling. "If you believe the business cycle has not been conquered, and there are still problems, the equity market is almost ridiculously priced. I am in the latter camp."
Mr. Fleckenstein owns one silver stock, which he declined to identify. He did own some technology stocks but sold them when their prices fell.
"Things are so uniformly out of whack it is hard to find anything I would feel comfortable owning," he growled. "I don't see anything that is compelling. It is far easier to find things that are ludicrous."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT/MUTUAL FUNDS -- THE MARKETS: Navigating Choppy Waters;
Laggards Become Leaders As Small Stocks Revive

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
THE stock market's recent slump -- and its wild volatility last week -- are shuffling the leader boards for stocks and mutual funds.
The well-known multinational stocks that pulled the market higher all year, like General Electric and Exxon, have been outpaced by smaller companies from Ethan Allan furniture to Pool Energy Services. And the once-popular consumer stocks like Coca-Cola, Gillette and Procter & Gamble have lagged badly, even as stocks that tend to track the overall economy, the ones like Caterpillar and Alcoa that Wall Street calls cyclicals, have more than held their own. 
 The pattern continued even as the market fell sharply on Thursday and on Friday morning, before rallying at 3:30 on Friday afternoon. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day off six points but up 2.5 percent for the week.
While it is too soon to say whether the shifts in stock leadership will persist, market gurus say the changes to date have been driven by more than just fears that many stock prices are too high -- which by many measures they are. Corporate earnings, the underpinning of the bull market in stocks, have come under pressure at some big multinational companies, and that has made many investors worry about the outlook for that sector.
The turnabout in stocks has brought to the fore some diversified domestic mutual funds that spent the year through July in the small-stocks backwater. In particular, funds that invest in the very smallest stocks, known as micro-caps, have prospered in August, including Bridgeway Ultra Small and Oberweis Micro Cap, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund trackers in Chicago.
The laggards have been diversified funds that concentrate on bigger companies, especially those in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which had been the best performers until August. One of the worst performers this month, Rydex Nova, was one of the leaders through July. The fund uses futures and options to produce better returns than the S.& P. 500 when it is rising, but that also results in larger declines when the index is falling.
Things have been more stable for specialized mutual funds. Technology funds consolidated their top spot; Merrill Lynch Technology D posted the biggest gain among all American equity funds in the month through last Thursday, followed by Seligman Communications and Information and Fidelity Select Electronics.
Chief among the losers were funds that invest in financial services like banking, insurance and brokerage firms. These funds fell in part because of rising interest rates. Funds that specialize in health care were pulled down as drug stocks took a much bigger hit than the broad market. Adding to the selloff were worries about the expiration of patents in the years ahead and downgrading by some large brokerage firms.
Whether small stocks, cyclicals and technology stocks will continue to dominate the market, and investors' hearts, is unclear. Looking at the entire year, multinational stocks are still fighting with the cyclicals for No. 2 billing, behind technology issues.
And small-company stocks performed the worst this year, even though the Russell 2000 index of small-company stocks has risen 22.5 percent since April 11, when the market hit bottom after a monthlong plunge this spring. That is not a bad performance, until one compares it with the gains of technology stocks. The Pacific Stock Exchange Technology index soared 38.3 percent in the same period.
"There is a change in the leadership that is evolving," said Eric Miller, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. So far it seems to be favoring the stocks of small companies, he added, but "it is not decisive."
Several analysts argue that small-company stocks could move up if multinationals continue to disappoint investors as Coke and Gillette did recently with their earnings projections. "As we go longer into this cycle and see some of these larger companies stumble, people begin to look elsewhere," said Edwin Miska, co-manager of the Evergreen Limited Market fund, one of August's top performers, which specializes in very small companies that have solid earnings records but that investors have largely overlooked.
The key will be whether big companies can maintain their profitability, said Claudia E. Mott, director of small-cap research at Prudential Securities. "So much depends on third-quarter earnings," she said. "Will the dollar hurt the larger companies? Will big names say things will be slower?"
She is not yet convinced that market leadership is broadening from the big names. So far, she noted, the outperformance of the Russell index in August has consisted of losing less than the other indexes. The recent jump in the flow of money into small-cap mutual funds could improve this performance. According to AMG Data Services, $1.3 billion went into small-cap funds in the week that ended on Wednesday, and the four-week average flow into the funds is $562 million, the highest since the end of January.
Bryon R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, is expecting many large multinational companies to have earnings problems, because their revenues have been growing slowly.
For example, in the second quarter, operating earnings of the 50 multinationals in the Morgan Stanley index of such companies rose 15 percent while revenues climbed just 7.7 percent.
This means that to increase their earnings, these companies have to depend on cost-cutting, which, he said, is getting harder and harder.
The best performance, he predicts, will come from cyclical stocks, including companies dealing in technology, basic materials, machinery and capital equipment, as well as retailers and automobile companies. "The economy is stronger than people thought it was," he said. "And in a stronger economy, economically sensitive stocks look better."
But Mr. Wien warns that a shift in investor sentiment in favor of cyclicals and away from the multinational consumer stocks will not come quickly. "The belief was so deep," he said, "that it will take a while to break."
