PUB-DATE: August 24, 1997

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3526 words

HEADLINE: 10 Years After, Lessons of an Earlier Market Peak

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
IT was a glorious summer on Wall Street. Stock prices rocketed to a series of new highs as investors poured record amounts of money into mutual funds. The last recession was a distant memory, and, although interest rates were perking up a bit, inflation appeared under control. With Labor Day approaching, few saw any reason for the market run-up to end anytime soon.
Sound familiar? The description fits today, but the same events transpired in the summer of 1987, at the end of one of the greatest bull runs in Wall Street history. On Aug. 25, 1987 -- 10 years ago tomorrow -- the Dow Jones industrial average peaked at 2,722.42, culminating a spectacular advance of more than 40 percent in just eight months. 
 Who on Wall Street that day could have known that less than two months later, those gains would evaporate in a frenzy of selling, the memory of which still produces knots in the stomachs of many market longtimers?
To some who lived through it, the crash of Oct. 19, 1987 -- when the market plummeted 22.6 percent in a single session, a percentage decline nearly twice as large as the 1929 debacle that ushered in the Great Depression and more than seven times the 3.1 percent plunge that rattled Wall Street nine days ago -- seemed like a bolt from the blue.
But even as the first crocus poked its head out of the still-thawing ground that spring, signs of trouble were sprouting on the economic landscape. By late August, they were everywhere, and a few nervous investors were beginning to sniff a disaster. Before the market opened on that Black Monday in October, stock prices had already fallen more than 17 percent from their peak.
With the parallels between the market exuberance of 1987 and 1997 so stark, the question naturally arises: Are there also parallels between economic conditions then and now that forebode another market meltdown?
A review of the developments that led to Black Monday makes it obvious that the United States economy is in much sounder shape now than it was then.
In addition, policy makers have clearly learned the lessons of that era and are not likely to make the same mistakes.
But the same historical retrospective shows that even as events that bring down a market unfold, their capacity for damage often goes unrecognized. And that raises a troubling question for investors in 1997: Now that the economic generals know how to fight the last war, will they recognize the warning signs of the next one?
So many economic and political episodes -- from the recent currency crisis in Southeast Asia to last month's balanced-budget accord in the United States -- hold the potential for disruptive consequences that even the savviest policy maker cannot know exactly how to respond to them. And market downturns have a habit of catching people by surprise. Indeed, the big guessing game on Wall Street these days is whether a correction or worse is under way at this very moment.
That said, many analysts are much more comfortable with the resilience of the American economy today than they were a decade ago. "From my perspective, 1997 and 1987 are very dissimilar," said Wayne D. Angell, a Bear, Stearns economist who 10 years ago was a member of the Federal Reserve Board. "At that time, you had a deterioration of the economic policy environment, which meant stocks were not going to work as the market had priced them.
"The economic condition was worsening from October 1986 through October 1987," he added. Today, by contrast, it is not. "My major responsibility is to blow the whistle of alarm if economic policy starts to deteriorate," Mr. Angell said. "I do not see any signs of that occurring. I continue to expect that the bull market goes on and on and on, interrupted only by some corrections."
 
Letting the Good Times Roll
Probably the most striking similarity between 1987 and today is the investor euphoria that in both periods helped fuel the market to ever loftier peaks -- peaks that, then as now, economic killjoys were warning were unrealistic by traditional measures. The good times, it seemed, would never end.
"I would say that things today are maybe 70 percent similar to 1987" in that regard, said Robert Farrell, a senior investment adviser at Merrill Lynch who in 1987 was the firm's chief market strategist. "On an economic basis, the two periods are different. But we have a period of overvaluations, with high public participation in the market and a high level of complacency in bullish sentiment."
For example, Mr. Farrell recalls, analysts considered the market to be highly valued in March 1987 -- and it shot up another 20 percent over the next five months as $3 billion a month flowed into mutual funds, foreigners scrambled to invest in American stocks and the total supply of stock shrank from all the leveraged buyouts and other deals that were taking place.
Market players who recount their astonishment at the 1987 gainssound remarkably like people today marveling over the Dow's climb from one millennial post to the next.
Barton M. Biggs, chairman of asset management at Morgan Stanley, spent part of August 1987 climbing Mount Kilimanjaro in Africa.
"I had been out of touch for a week, and when I came back down from the mountain I got a copy of The International Herald Tribune," Mr. Biggs recalled. "I remember looking at the prices of stocks and just being stunned by the gains that had occurred in just a week."
Peter Lynch, then the manager of the Fidelity Magellan fund, the country's largest mutual fund, also spent a lot of his time shaking his head in wonder.
"What sticks in my head is that in the four years from August 1982 to September 1986, the Dow went up 1,000 points," Mr. Lynch said. "In the next 11 months, it went up another 1,000 points. That's an unbelievable acceleration."
Like many investors in 1987, though, Mr. Lynch saw no reason to fear a market crash. Indeed, he went on a mid-October trip to Ireland, the first vacation he had taken since the beginning of the bull market in 1982.
He acknowledges having some misgivings as the market headed lower in early October, but, he said, "I'm not going to cancel what was to be my first vacation in five years, based on something that might never happen."
Of course, historical analogies are never exact, and the mood of the 80's differed in some important ways from today's.
In contrast to the more circumspect 1990's, investors and corporations had a weakness back then for extravagant borrowing and flamboyant gestures like the Digital Equipment Corporation's decision to have a $20 million party aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2 in Boston Harbor to announce a new product offering.
Even so, Mr. Biggs said, investors were probably a bit more squeamish 10 years ago than they are now.
"I see much the same environment today that I saw in 1987 as far as the momentum of the market, and the enthusiasm in stocks that are going up, making their own magic," he said. "But I think there was less exuberance then than there is today. Any time you get a market making a big move, people tend to ignore valuation measures. And there's always the argument that it is different this time and this is a new era. But in 1987, I don't think people were making that argument to the same extent that they are now."
Mr. Farrell of Merrill Lynch agrees about the climate of a decade ago.
"Nobody was talking about the economy being in a sweet spot, with just enough strength and no inflation," he said. "At that time, people were concerned about the economy. And while there were people talking about a new era, that was not as prevalent as it is today."
But if the mood was ebullient back then, the forces driving the economies of 1987 and 1997 were pushing in very different directions.
 
The Clouds Gather
Then, as now, the most potent force was the cost of credit. The higher the interest rates people and businesses must pay for loans, the heavier the drag on the economy; the lower the interest rates, the more powerful the impetus.
For those who were asked to compare the two eras, one of the sharpest discrepancies was the sudden uptick in interest rates in the summer of 1987, even without any explicit action by the Federal Reserve Board.
That reversed what had been an extended period of rate declines that unwound the high interest rates engineered in the early 1980's by the Fed chairman, Paul A. Volcker, to squelch rampant inflation.
From January through July 1986, the Fed made three cuts in the discount rate, the rate at which member banks borrow money from the Fed. As short-term rates fell, so did Long-term rates, to about 7.5 percent from 10.5 percent a year earlier. As rates came down, so did commodity prices; in July 1986, at the time of the third rate cut, the price of a barrel of crude oil stood at $9.74.
In August 1986, the Fed took a final step to cut short-term borrowing costs, trimming half a percentage point from the discount rate, to 5.5 percent. Mr. Angell, the former Fed board member, now says that was a mistake. "Paul Volcker and I both agreed afterwards that was the one we shouldn't have made," he said. Soon, the prices of precious metals started to rise, followed by the prices of other commodities later in the year.
Those price gains were largely ignored by Fed watchers, who, drawing on their experience of the early 1980's, saw monetary aggregates -- M1, M2 and other money supply statistics -- as the most important indicators of economic direction. By the time Federal Reserve policy makers agreed that inflation was picking up again, "we were behind the curve," Mr. Angell said.
Had the Fed bumped rates up closer to 7 percent in the first quarter of 1987, it might have orchestrated a soft landing of the economy and avoided the market turmoil to come, he said. Instead, its inaction was compounded by a a surprise move in early June by the Reagan White House: the decision not to reappoint Mr. Volcker as Fed chairman and to name Mr. Greenspan -- the former chief economic adviser to President Gerald R. Ford but mostly an unknown quantity as a monetary policy maker -- to the post instead.
Mr. Greenspan took office in mid-August and the Fed finally raised rates on Sept. 4, but by then world markets had lost confidence in its resolve. "I think there was a question about the Federal Reserve's credibility," Mr. Angell said. "The 30-year bond would not have been able to rise well above 10 percent without some people making pretty heavy bets that monetary policy would not be able to bring inflation down."
Stock prices had already started to slip further in early October, as the Federal funds rate -- the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans -- rose a quarter-point and the yield on long-term Treasuries rose above 10 percent for the first time in two years. The mood of the stock and bond markets was not helped when Salomon Brothers announced its intention to close its municipal bond department and lay off 10 percent of its staff, setting the tone for retrenchments around Wall Street.
Today, the monetary picture could not be more different. Mr. Greenspan, confirmed to a third four-year term last year by an adulatory Senate, reigns as the inflation-slaying idol of the financial markets. While some people worry that he is not keeping the credit reins quite tight enough, most people expect him to work them with just the right finesse.
The discount rate is at 5 percent, the same as it was a year ago, while in the same period short-term Treasury bills have hovered at just over 5 percent and 30-year bonds have eased to 6.65 percent from 6.79 percent. And nobody pays attention to M1 or M2 anymore.
"I'm not suggesting that the Federal Reserve is that much smarter today than in 1987," Mr. Angell said. "But I feel confident that the Federal Reserve has a lot of credibility. As a result, there is little likelihood that the Fed will have to raise interest rates a whole bunch or make a whole series of increases." He expects the Federal funds rate, now at 5.5 percent, to end the year at 5.75 percent.
 
Disunity at the Top
The confusion surrounding American monetary policy in 1987 was not limited to interest rates. Nobody could quite figure out the Federal Government's stance toward the dollar.
The dollar's strength, or weakness, exerts a huge influence over the American economy. A strong dollar makes American goods more expensive overseas, weakening demand and thus widening the country's chronic trade deficit. A weak dollar, on the other hand, makes imports more expensive, and thus can be inflationary. One of the main tools for modifying the dollar's value is raising or lowering interest rates, which makes dollar-denominated securities more, or less, appealing to investors.
In early 1987, the Reagan Administration switched its policy from one favoring a weaker dollar to one that was officially neutral and finally, in mid-April, modified it further with a declaration by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d that further declines would be "counterproductive." But it was reluctant to implement the higher interest rates and narrower budget deficits that would make that goal a reality.
Worries about the dollar's continued slide had started to push interest rates higher in mid-March, catching many bond traders and Wall Street firms by surprise. In the second quarter, Wall Street firms lost $1 billion because of higher long-term rates.
Financial markets were also caught in the intricate crossfire among the industrial powers over whether the best way to stabilize the dollar was for Washington to do more to tighten fiscal policy or whether Germany and Japan should do more to stimulate domestic spending. September also brought into the open the conflict between the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve, with Mr. Greenspan apparently determined to demonstrate his independence from the Administration on coordinating international economic policy.
Today, by contrast to 1987, the dollar is stable and relatively strong. In the last year, it has risen about 22 percent against the Japanese yen and 26 percent against the German mark, with the recent budget accord between President Clinton and the Republican Congress providing another bulwark.
More important, there is no lack of cooperation between the Federal Reserve and the Treasury, now led by Robert E. Rubin and his Deputy Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers. "It would appear that Alan Greenspan and Bob Rubin have regular weekly meetings, and they appear clearly in sync," Mr. Angell said. "You don't have any statements coming from Larry Summers or Bob Rubin that would cause you to say, 'Does this make sense in regard to what the Fed is doing?' "
 
Other Economic Worries
Aside from all the confusion emanating from lawmakers and policy gurus 10 years ago, serious economic dislocations were developing at home and abroad.
By late August 1987, oil prices had climbed above $20 a barrel because of uncertainty in the Persian Gulf, where foreign oil tankers were flying American flags and sailing under American escort.
Moreover, the trade deficit was still ballooning despite the lower dollar, which was just beginning to help make American goods more competitive in world markets.
The banking system was in serious straits. Congress approved a $10.8 billion infusion into the beleaguered Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which insured deposits in savings and loan associations, many of which already were suffering the ill effects of real estate loans gone sour. But everyone close to the situation knew that the money was grossly inadequate and that the Reagan Administration wanted to put off dealing with the problem until after the 1988 election.
Simultaneously, Brazil threatened the big American money-center banks with a refusal to repay its debts. In the second quarter, the 15 largest United States banks added more than $10 billion to their reserves for possible loan losses, the largest such move since the Great Depression and one that significantly cut the pool of money available for loan to American corporations.
Today, all those problems have receded into memory. World oil production is rising, and many analysts expect prices to decline from the current $20 to $21 a barrel to $18 or less in the next few months -- though American dependence on imported oil has grown, auguring potential problems for the economy if there is ever an abrupt cutoff of supplies. The trade deficit is down substantially as a percentage of gross national product. And the banking system is healthy.
 
Then Again, You Never Know
For all the differences between 1997 and 1987, the economy wasn't all that bad back then. Indeed, after the October crash led to an easing of Fed policy, the economy continued to grow for nearly three years. In the view of some analysts, the market collapse that fateful fall day was not as bad as it seemed.
Mr. Lynch, the former Magellan fund manager, noted that in 1986-87 the market first went up 1,000 points in 11 months and then went down 1,000 points in two months. "If the market had instead gone sideways for a year, people wouldn't have been worried at all," he said. "In fact, nothing really happened. Companies were doing well. Corporate profits were O.K.. The crash was one of those funny things that happen in time.
"There is a big misconception that everyone lost money in 1987," he added. "But the market was up for the year. Everyone did not put money in the market in August and take it all out in October."
And if the economy was not as bad then as many people now assume, it is also not necessarily as invulnerable now as some would like to think. After all, Murphy's Law -- if something can go wrong, it will -- often strikes when people are reveling most loudly in their good fortune.
For example, said Mr. Farrell of Merrill Lynch, it not yet clear how the market will react to last month's budget agreement. "It is hard to read right now, but it is going to affect the market in some way," he said.
Mr. Lynch finds great reassurance in the small talk he indulges in with strangers on airplanes. "I don't have people recommending stocks to me these days," he said. "That's usually the final sign of the speculative boom: People recommend stocks to me, and those stocks go up. There are four phases of reactions people have when I meet them on an airplane and they ask what I do and I say I manage money. In the first phase, they say, 'Oh,' and they go on to the next subject. In the second phase, they ask, 'What do you like?' In the third phase, they might then recommend you take a look at something. But in the fourth phase, they recommend a stock to you and you take a look at it and you notice that it goes up substantially. We don't seem to have entered that phase yet."
 
The Downward Spiral
After the market peak on Aug. 25, 1987, it was a short trip to the market meltdown. In its first meeting after Mr. Greenspan took charge, the Fed finally made its move, raising the discount rate by half a percentage point, to 6 percent, on Sept. 4. But the market sensed that further tightening was in the offing. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had already slid 5 percent from its peak, continued to drift down, as investors weighed signs of higher inflation. Then, in quick succession, the index of leading indicators registered its sixth consecutive increase, signaling a strong economy that might have to be reined in; foreigners appeared to be steady sellers of Treasury bonds, indicating that rates would have to go up to attract enough future buyers; and, in mid-September, the Government reported that industry operated at 81 percent of capacity in August, the highest level since late 1984, another sign that the credit noose would have to be tightened.
By early October, investors had learned that the unemployment rate had fallen to 5.8 percent the previous month, its lowest rate in eight years, and money-center banks moved independently of the Federal Reserve to raise their lending rates, lifting the prime rate half a percentage point, to 9.25 percent.
On Wednesday, Oct. 14, the Dow suffered its largest single-day point drop: 95 points, or 3.8 percent. The next day, Chemical Bank led its peers in raising the prime rate by another half-point, to 9.75 percent. The Dow, helped along by a furious rate of futures-related trading as institutions sought to lock in the year's still-impressive portfolio gains, fell another 57 points, to 2,355.
Before the week ground to a halt, however, stock prices collapsed in a broad selloff on Friday, Oct. 16, again spurred by a heavy bout of futures-related program, or computer-driven, trading. Capping the stock market's worst week since the week in 1940 when France fell to the Germans, the Dow recorded its first daily loss of more than 100 points and finished the week down 9.5 percent. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was the heaviest ever, at 338.5 million shares. At the end of the day, the bellwether market index stood at 2,246, or 17.5 percent below its August peak.
And the worst was yet to come.

"The Pride Before the Fall"
The remarkable stock market run-up in the first eight months of 1987 masked an accumulation of events that, in retrospect, offered early warnings of the tubmle -- and then the collapse -- that would follow in September and October. Incipient inflation, a dispute over the strength of the dollar, ballooning trade deficits, tightening credit and a rise in private lending rates -- well ahead of any action by the Federal Reserve -- all helped turn Wall Street's euphoria into an avalanche of sell orders.
 
April 1987 -- Bond prices drop sharply because of fear that a falling dollar will revive inflation. Government bond investors lose about $20 billion.
 
June 15 -- Crude oil price rises above $20 a barrel for first time in 17 months, up from $10 a year earlier.
 
July 17 -- Dow Jones industrial average closes above 2,500 for the first time, for a gain of 32 percent so far in 1987.
 
Aug. 25 -- Dow industrials gain 25 points to close at 2,722.42, a record.
 
Sept. 1 -- Long-term bond yields rise to 9.27 percent after the sixth consecutive monthly increase in the index of leading indicators. Dow falls 52 points, or 2 percent.
 
Oct. 16, Friday -- Dow suffers first daily loss of more than 100 points, on heaviest New York Stock Exchange volume yet recorded: 338.5 million shares. Treasury bill rates plunge.
 
Oct. 19 -- Black Monday. The Dow loses 508 points, falling 22.6 percent.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:

THE FED
Inflation? What Inflation?
The Federal Reserve, continuing a remarkable economic experiment in which it has kept interest rates low despite shrinking unemployment and unusually strong economic growth, left interest rates unchanged, with the key Federal funds rate at 5.50 percent. That is because inflation remains at the lowest level since the early 1960's, below an annual rate of 2 percent in the first half of the year. Providing evidence of the strong economy, the nation's trade deficit narrowed, to $8.2 billion in June from $9.54 billion in May, as exports rebounded to a new record and imports subsided for the first time this year. Housing construction was steady in July at a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 1.45 million.
 
THE MARKETS
It Climbs! It Dives!
What could be more fun in the dog days of August than a roller-coaster ride? One can only hope investors have retained a 12-year-old's enthusiasm for thrills and chills. The Dow industrials, surging back from a 247-point tumble on Aug. 15, , chalked up three consecutive gains of more than 100 points -- a first for the blue-chip average. Then, on Thursday, investors took profits with a vengeance, apparently worried that interest rates could rise and spoil everyone's fun. The Dow lost 127.28 points, and the pummeling continued on Friday, with the average losing XXX.TK points to close at 7,XTK.TK. With leading technology companies like Microsoft, Intel and Dell joining the retreat, the Nasdaq composite index also skidded, closing at 1,5TK.TK, down TK.TK for the week.
 
U.P.S. STRIKE ENDS
The Brown Trucks Are Rolling
After more than 80 hours of intense negotiations, 185,000 striking teamsters began returning to work at United Parcel Service. Company executives said fears of mounting losses forced them to settle the 15-day strike. The union won most of its demands, like keeping control of pensions and limiting the use of part-time workers. Hourly wages for full-time workers over the five-year contract are set to rise by $3.10, to a top rate of $23, and for part-time workers by $4.10, to a top rate of $15. Ron Carey, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, asserted that the settlement would be as much a boon to labor as the failed air traffic controllers' strike of 1981 was a bust. And most Americans -- even Wall Street analysts, who normally see wage inflation where labor sees a living wage -- were cheered. But four days after the settlement, Mr. Carey was handed a setback. After an eight-month investigation into allegations of fund-raising abuses by Mr. Carey's campaign, a Federal official threw out his narrow re-election victory over James P. Hoffa and ordered new balloting.
 
TOBACCO SUITS
Is the Marlboro Man Wheezing?
About 100,000 Americans "might have" died from smoking-related diseases, conceded Geoffrey Bible, the chairman and chief executive of Philip Morris, during pretrial questioning by a lawyer representing the State of Florida. The state is suing the major tobacco companies, seeking $12.3 billion for the public cost of smoking-related illnesses. Separately, the attorneys general of 20 states asked the White House to support an exemption of the Liggett Group from the financial terms of the proposed $368.5 billion settlement with the tobacco industry because of its earlier deal with their states and the company's "valuable role" in bringing the other tobacco companies to the bargaining table.
 
THE A.M.A. DEAL
What the Doctor Ordered?
Stung by widespread criticism of its planned endorsement of Sunbeam health care products, the American Medical Association sought to abandon its marketing alliance with the company. "The A.M.A. apologizes for creating a public doubt about our motives," said Dr. P. John Seward, the organization's executive vice president. Instead of a royalty deal that was expected to bring in millions of dollars, the A.M.A. wants to package informational brochures with health care products, charging companies fees to cover its costs. Sunbeam's reaction was stormy. Its chairman and chief executive, Albert J. Dunlap, said, "We have a contract with the A.M.A., which we are prepared to honor, and we expect them to honor it as well."
 
VALUJET CRASH
F.A.A. and Airline Faulted
Supervisory failures by both Valujet Airlines and the F.A.A. were responsible for the Everglades crash 15 months ago that killed all 110 people aboard, the National Transportation Safety Board said. James E. Hall, the board chairman, said, "The Valujet accident resulted from failures all up and down the line, from Federal regulators to airline executives in the board room to workers on the shop room floor." The plane crashed because of a fire started by oxygen generators from other planes that were improperly packed by a contractor and loaded into the jet's cargo hold.
 
'MIDLIST AUTHORS'
You're Not John Grisham
These are humbling times for seasoned writers known as "midlist authors," those whose sales are too mediocre to crack the best-seller lists. The book market is gloomy, and publishers say multimillion-dollar advances paid to top-tier writers have soaked up financial resources. In the 1960's, many writers whose books sold fewer than 15,000 copies believed publishers had a social contract with writers, but publishers today feel the need to satisfy stockholders, said Albert N. Greco, a Fordham professor. Still, Ann Birstein, a retired Barnard professor who had eight books published before receiving 10 rejection letters on her latest literary novel, keeps trying. And Barry Beckham, a novelist and writer of college guides, was turned down on a work about Chase Manhattan Bank. Now he is serializing it on the Internet.
 
BREAST IMPLANTS
Dow Chemical Loses in Court
In a major courtroom setback for one of the nation's largest chemical producers, a Louisiana state jury in New Orleans found that Dow Chemical had knowingly deceived women by hiding information about the health risks of silicone used in breast implants and had failed to test silicone adequately before it was used in the human body. The decision in a class-action lawsuit potentially involves the claims of 1,800 women who received breast implants. What compensation, if any, eight representative women should receive will be decided in the trial's second phase, expected to start in late September.
 
THE MERGER FRONT
British to Pay Less for MCI
MCI Communications won F.C.C. approval for its $23.4 billion merger with British Telecommunications. But MCI stunned Wall Street with an ominous disclosure that financial terms of the deal might be revised. Indeed, British Telecom said Friday that it would pay as much as 22 percent less than originally agreed. In other merger developments, Texaco, seeking to increase its oil reserves in California, agreed to acquire Monterey Resources, the oil assets of the former Santa Fe Railroad, in a stock transaction valued at $1.12 billion. Comverse Technology, a leading maker of telephone voice mail systems, agreed to pay $843 million in stock to acquire a rival, Boston Technology.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1548 words

HEADLINE: Spoils of Peace;
A New Credo: Make Money, Not War

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
HAS there ever been a moment quite like this? In the United States, high-yield retirement accounts are making near-millionaires of thousands of salaried workers and hourly wage earners. In India, resort towns are crammed not with foreign tourists but with newly affluent Indians, more than a few of them village people in chartered buses who come to enjoy wonders once reserved for the rich and powerful. All over Asia, and in eastern Europe, Russia and Latin America, the emerging middle classes are buying designer clothes and computers and taking foreign vacations. Even in struggling but newly hopeful Africa, leaders are urging aid donors to prod investors and provide advice on how to fire up the private sector.
As a whole, the world economy has been growing at about 3 percent annually in recent years, a rate of expansion that will exceed that of the 1980's, the United Nations predicts. It's easy to fret, as many do, over blips and glitches -- and neither Wall Street nor the tiger currencies of Southeast Asia have been without them lately. But that misses the larger point: never before in modern history, arguably, has so much of the world savored economic growth, however rough around the edges. Much of this is thanks to peace. 

 
 
Freed Spirit

Economists call the surge in human productivity the real peace dividend -- it is not simply reductions in military spending. And though they may disagree about how wisely this windfall is or is not being reinvested in one place or another, they pretty much agree that a world battered by a century of devastating wars now faces a future with unparalleled opportunity.
No major international wars are being fought. The world has its ugly regional conflicts -- its Bosnias, its Rwandas -- but no Stalin, no Hitler, no Mao visits the cruel whims and devices of totalitarianism on vast numbers of its people. No military alliances are faced off in a global arms race. Democracies flourish. The end of the cold war has removed ideological chains and with them distortions of economies rooted in big-power rivalries. India, for example, lost its cozy relationship with Moscow and was forced to sink or swim with economic reform, jettisoning an accretion of Soviet-inspired practices. In Central America, a number of nations, not the least of them El Salvador, lost the automatic cold-war patronage of the United States and are now learning to build civilian economies largely on their own resources and with new partners, including some major Asian ones.
Since ancient times, people have required the breathing space of peace to plant crops, develop crafts, build industries and engage in barter -- to release the enormous human energies that quickly turn to economic activity. In the 1990's, there are new factors at work spreading such vigor worldwide -- not least technology. One of the most technologically sophisticated nations, the United States, has emerged as both a military giant and economic powerhouse, a situation few predicted a decade ago when it was fashionable to argue that America's leadership would not survive the century.
Gavin Wright, an economic historian at Stanford University, says that analysts have been comparing this era to the Pax Britannica of the last century and early this century, "when the British had domination of the seas and certainly were not afraid of being attacked in Britain." Such a situation, he added, "was a very positive thing for long-term investment in new technologies and skills." As this century ends, the United States is in roughly the same position and, released from the cold war fears of giving away knowledge to the enemy, is more willing to share and sell American know-how.
"You could say that we wouldn't be having this globalization unless it were basically an era of peace," Mr. Wright said. "People are relaxed about the transmission of technology across borders."
 
A Foundation
 But many historians and analysts of world trends caution that peace on its own is never enough for sustained economic strength. Peace provides only a positive environment for development and growth. Social, political, cultural and sometimes geographic factors take over from there, they say, and they point to short-term problems in healthy countries and some long-term weaknesses elsewhere -- in many African nations, in North Korea and in pockets of the former Soviet bloc. Also, in an age of economic globalization, the policies of disparate nations and regions need a certain amount of mesh. The collapse of Communism and the discrediting of centralized economic policies have fostered integration. But the next stage is crucial.
"If peace is defined as the absence of conflict, that may or may not mean that you have what you need to get economic growth going," said Paul Goble, a former adviser to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on Soviet nationalities and the Baltics who is now a director at Radio Free Europe in Washington. Mr. Goble sees many false hopes for what peace could bring in Central Asia, Afghanistan and Pakistan.
"The Chevron oil company has obviously seen the movie 'Field of Dreams' one too many times," he said. " 'If you drill it you can get it out.' You can drill it, but whether you can get it out is a big question. Central Asia is potentially one of the wealthier places in the world except that its located in the middle of a huge land mass and you can't export things easily. If you have the infrastructure and geography right, then peace may let economic development break out. If you don't, then it doesn't."
James Chace, a Latin American expert who teaches international Relations at Bard College and edits the World Policy Journal, agrees that "the danger is to try to make too easy a connection between peace and prosperity." But he tempers his doubts. "It's true that in peace you are more likely to have prosperity. Generally businessmen don't like war. The merchants of death may, but that's an exception. For the average businessman, the banker, it spells turmoil, uncertainty -- so why would you do it? Interstate conflict is less and less likely now."
The looming problem is translating worldwide growth into equity for all, he said, and that applies to the United States as much as to the third world.
"In times of war, you rally people around the flag," he said. "But if there's no trouble abroad, it's very hard to distract them. If you strip people of the benefits they have come to expect, if too many people are left out of the economic boom, particularly in the middle class, then you can have internal turmoil. Turmoil at home and peace abroad -- I think that is the most likely danger, unless you begin to have an economy that avoids social dislocation."
Mr. Chace looks back to the 1890's, when the United States was at peace and in an economic boom, but there was unrest because organized labor was suppressed and not a lot of wealth was trickling down. A century later, the growing phenomenon of small civil conflicts, coupled with widening gaps between rich and poor in many nations -- and the existence of hundreds of millions of people in absolute poverty worldwide -- gives policymakers plenty to work on in peacetime.
"Peace is not only the absence of conflict," said Juan Somavia, Chile's representative at the United Nations. "It is the presence of human security -- at the individual level, the family, the community. Peace is also positive things happening within a society. The two peaces are necessary. The problem today is that, yes, you have less major conflict, but you also have more human insecurity worldwide. The real security threat of the future is that people feel insecure in their own societies."
And it isn't hard to see why they would view economic globalization not as an unparalleled opportunity to attract investment and modernizing skills to their countries but as a new form of economic imperialism.
With external threats fading, the policies of nations are now on the line, with no place to hide, most economic historians and social scientists agree. Amartya Sen, professor of economics and philosophy at Harvard, says one challenge is to sustain research when there are no foreign threats, for the betterment of lives. Another is to change the thinking that posits war as a source of human creativity.
 
Domestic Upheavals
 Claudia Goldin, an economic historian at Harvard, agrees. "Periods of war are periods of tremendous disruption," she said, and sometimes the negative effects are great even when the war is not fought on one's own soil. Case in point: the domestic upheaval caused in the United States by the Vietnam War. Calling wars the mother of invention is wrong, says Ms. Goldin.
"Out of World War II came antibiotics, aluminum, jet planes, the atomic bomb," she said. "We had everything that American ingenuity was forced through long hours and hard labor to invent in the briefest period of time.
"It was an enormous triumph but it was not because of the war. We had it in us all the time. We would have had a jet engine. Antibiotics would have been invented. Aluminum would have been produced. We had synthetic rubber, we just had no reason to use it. Most great inventions do not come when you have a gun to your head."

HEADLINE: Movie Crews, Milk Crates ...;
Damage to Mt. Morris Bank Could Be Developers' Bonus

 BODY:

To the Editor:
For many years the city has been trying to auction the Mount Morris Bank building but with no takers ("Fire Is a New Blow for an Old Bank," Aug. 10). The millions needed to make it usable made no economic sense. Now that the top floors have been removed the building is a huge bucket that will trap water and snow. 
 After the bricks start falling again, an "emergency" order will be issued and the building will be leveled. Since the land use review process has been concluded the vacant land will then be sold to developers for many millions.
 
SID MILLER
Mount Morris Park

HEADLINE: The World;
France's Allegiance: To Things French, Like Hypocrisy

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
CHARLES de GAULLE, who knew his people well, once said: "Every Frenchman wants to benefit from one or several privileges. It is his way of affirming his passion for equality."
It was the general's way of gently capturing an essential French duplicity. Perhaps in no other country are form and substance so divergent. Formal discourse is full of grand principles: equality, solidarity or, more recently, the iniquities of American-driven globalization. But the substance may have more to do with the defense of privilege or the concealment of pragmatic acts in the robes of idealism. 
 A French politician's art thus lies in offering splendid ideals while insuring the people get fed. Francois Mitterrand, the late President, was a master of the art. After a brief and calamitous experiment with textbook socialism, he opted to defend only principles lofty enough that they would never affect the franc's strength. Goodbye, Albania; hello, the bourse. By the end of his second term in 1995, he had elevated the riddle to the heart of his governance.
All this may be worth remembering at a time when France is taken very much at its word. During the cold war, French posturing was an irritant, but seldom more, to the United States. In its aftermath, a very public French stand against the harsh capitalism of America's boom and the dangers of a world driven by the American quest for profit has given a new edge to the allies' old sparring. At times, as at the summit of major industrialized nations last month in Denver, it has looked like real rivalry.
France has become America's favorite European basket case. With its socialist government trying to create state-sector jobs by the hundreds of thousands, its record unemployment, its diatribes against globalization, its quaint plans for 32-hour work weeks and its defense of an apparently unaffordable welfare state, France has taken over Britain's role as the faintly risible archetype of the failed European economy. It is the Titanic-with-piano-still-tinkling adrift on a sea of global competition.
There is, of course, much substance to this vision of France. Fewer and fewer businesses want to hire because it costs too much to do so, and many of the 3.6 million unemployed have settled into a way of life based on perennial state financial assistance combined with odd jobs on the black market. Initiative is quashed and dependence encouraged. Disillusionment spreads.
But the French reality is rather more complex. It has to do with the fact that change, adaptation and modernization must be masked because they have little to do with the country's self-image.
That image is attached to notions of equality, a strongly centralized Jacobin state and change, if it all, through revolution alone. Evolution is a kind of anathema in the land of 1789 and 1968. As Pierre Birnbaum, a sociologist, said, "We have not found the way to modernize while preserving our imagined community."
So modernization takes place on the quiet. Thus, in the past decade alone, France has turned a currency that was a laughing stock into one virtually as strong as the German mark. It has freed capital movements, an idea once unthinkable in the home-par-excellence of the secret Swiss bank account.
It has sold off great swaths of state industry, including the automaker Renault, the oil company Elf Aquitaine, the chemicals giant Rhone-Poulenc and the manufacturer of Gauloise cigarettes, Seita.
 
Creeping Retail
 It has littered the countryside with Americana: more than 600 McDonald's restaurants, Toys "R" Us in countless malls, Haagen-Dazs on fashionable Paris streets. It has adopted American habits, cutting way back on the leisurely lunch and banning smoking in the Metro. It has allowed St. Germain-des-Pres, sanctuary of the Left Bank intellectual, to turn into a glitzy -- and depressing -- home to international fashion.
Its national airline, Groupe Air France, no longer flies to even major cities where it cannot make a profit. The profit motive, pure and simple, has also driven numerous private companies -- including Michelin, L'Oreal, Carrefour and the luxury-goods conglomerate LVMH -- to adapt and remain highly competitive throughout the world. These have contributed to the country's huge trade surpluses, and to the fact that France is the world's fourth-largest exporter.
Drive out of Paris in the direction of Rambouillet, and you will soon find the town of Coignieres. A decade ago there were wheat fields there; today it is a hymn to the American way of life. A busy highway cuts through a landscape dominated by McDonald's and other hamburger restaurants, Pier 1 Imports, warehouse-stores selling bathroom fittings, and advertisements full of words like "light" and "cool." Coignieres is globalization incarnate.
 
Nothing to Be Done
 "I suppose all this is inevitable," said Jacques Eperon, who runs a small choucroute tavern opposite the Coignieres McDonald's. "I don't like it much, but in the end you have to accept it."
So change is accepted and not much liked. And more than ever, politics becomes the art of concealing change behind anti-American slogans and the like.
Lionel Jospin, the new socialist Prime Minister, seems to be aware of this. The Government talks a lot about the 32-hour week and jobs in the state sector and American economic arrogance while it gets on with preparing new privatizations and the austerity measures needed to qualify for the planned adoption of a single European currency, the euro, at the end of next year.
Mr. Jospin knows that the French still want to dream of "du pain et des roses" -- "bread and roses," or a salary and poetry. In this he has proved more adept than President Jacques Chirac, who sometimes seems insufficiently shrewd for the divided French heart.
A lot is heard today about French roses. The country wants to offer some poetry and compassion to a globalized world where it often seems the rich get richer and the poor poorer. That can be an irritant to America. But it should not be forgotten that France also has an eye on its bread.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Defining Disadvantage Up to Preserve Preferences

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHO'S left?
That's the question that follows the Clinton Administration's recent announcement that it is considering a proposal to make it easier for whites to qualify for contracting preferences that had been reserved almost exclusively for racial and ethnic minorities. The proposal is part of a trend in which supporters of affirmative action seeking to widen the policy's political base, pushed by a 1995 Supreme Court ruling that made it difficult to operate programs based solely on race, have steadily broadened the definition of oppressed groups whose members qualify for special help. 
 Conceived as a policy to help blacks, many affirmative action programs have, over the years, been stretched to cover Hispanic people, Asians, Native Americans, Hawaiian Polynesians and women of any color or creed. Now, the Administration is contemplating rule changes that would open the affirmative action door to more whites, including white men.
While arguably legally necessary, the proposed change raises a number of uncomfortable questions. At what point have the benefits of affirmative action been scattered so broadly that they actually diminish rather than enhance opportunities for blacks, the group the policy was originally designed for? What is the justification for recent immigrants, who came to the United States voluntarily and may or may not have suffered from discrimination, to share the fruits of a policy meant to help the descendants of slaves who were forcibly brought here? At what point does "socially disadvantaged" become defined so broadly that the only ones not included are Donald Trump and Bill Gates?
"We have reached the point where Hasidic Jews are eligible, immigrants from India are eligible, white women are eligible," said Gerald Reynolds, president of the Center for New Black Leadership and a fervent opponent of affirmative action for anyone. "We've gone so far from the original idea that I believe it's time to reassess the whole approach."
 
A Different Purpose
 As the beneficiaries of affirmative action have increased, its moral rationale has changed. Supporters now speak as much of achieving diversity in a work force or on a college campus as they do of making up for past racism or preventing current discrimination. But while diversity may be a noble goal, it does not necessarily mesh with the original idea of affirmative action: helping to overcome the vestiges of slavery and Jim Crow.
"The concern that I have about the rhetoric of diversity is that it doesn't have any moral bite to it," said Glen C. Loury, a professor of economics at Boston University. "You end up with a kind of touchy-feely policy where you've lost the thread of why you were looking to treat people specially in the first place."
The latest step in the trend toward affirmative action catholicism came Aug. 14, when the Small Business Administration proposed changes in requirements for companies to qualify as "small disadvantaged" businesses. The new rules would cover companies that want to be enrolled in special programs that provide technical help and eligibility for certain Federal contracts set aside for them. The rules also cover companies that, if signed up as subcontractors, give larger prime contractors bonus points when they bid on Federal contracts.
Under the proposal, the owner of a small company would be considered economically disadvantaged if he or she had a personal net worth of less than $250,000, excluding equity in a home -- a criterion that more than 90 percent of Americans could meet. Applicants would also have to show that they were socially disadvantaged, meaning that they have been the victims of some kind of chronic discrimination. Blacks, Hispanic people, Asians and members of other racial minorities are presumed to meet this criterion, while whites, both men and women, would have to make a showing of past bias.
While the proposed new rules would make it generally easier for whites to make a case, Federal officials say white men will still have difficulty establishing that they have suffered from discrimination. "This is not opening the floodgates for people who might not qualify," said Aida Alvarez, the S.B.A. administrator.
Perhaps not yet. But the Federal courts could very well toss some banana peels on what is already a slippery slope. Last month, Federal District Judge John L. Kane Jr. in Denver ruled that the white owner of a construction company had been the victim of bias -- and therefore was socially disadvantaged -- because he lost out on a government contract as a result of an affirmative action program that the Supreme Court later ruled unconstitutional. The ruling is not binding beyond Colorado, but it lays down a new legal principle: whites who could prove they have been unfairly treated by affirmative action programs would be eligible to apply for affirmative action programs.
"Judge Kane's ruling draws a circle around this program and puts everyone inside," said William Perry Pendley, the Denver lawyer who represented the white contractor.
The question of widening eligibility is vexing to black supporters of affirmative action. More beneficiaries could mean more support for a policy that is under growing attack in the courts and in the political arena. But more beneficiaries also means diluted benefits. In 1987, when they were first included in a Department of Transportation program that set aside contracts for "disadvantaged" businesses, companies owned by women earned 20.4 percent of dollars in the program. By 1996, the percentage had climbed to 41.4 percent.
"That's why it's such a dilemma," said Anthony W. Robinson, president of the Minority Business Enterprise Legal Defense and Education Fund. "You do need that kind of political support to try to preserve the policy. But sometimes you wonder whether you're cutting your own throat at the same time."

HEADLINE: Speaking Volumes;
You Can't Read Books Fast Enough

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
SO many titles, so little time. So why do publishers produce enough new books daily to overpopulate a small library wing?
On any given day, the nation's latest literary choices amount to feast or frenzy -- roughly 166 new titles ranging from "Biggest Elvis" (promoted as "a witty novel that turns a trio of Elvis impersonators working clubs on the Pacific Rim into a powerful evocation of America") to "Letters From a Nut" ("Dear Greyhound Bus People: I will be dressed like a stick of butter. Can I get approval for this?"). 
 With more than 58,000 trade titles published last year, not even a voracious reader can keep up, a fact that some publishers of serious nonfiction and popular novels are starting to absorb in a bleak time of declining hardcover sales.
"You have to realize that your obligation as publisher is not to sign every book available in the marketplace," said Jo Kiener, the chief operating officer for HarperCollins, which angered many writers and their agents when it decided in June to cancel more than 100 contracted books.
"Your obligation is to the business," Mr. Kiener said, "and we choose to publish so that we can do the best damn job we can with publicity, marketing and promotions."
 
Information Overload
 Media conglomerates are not the only ones questioning the steady widget-like production of popular books. Small publishers, who are trying desperately to gain their share of attention for literary fiction and serious nonfiction, also have doubts.
"Everybody has come to the conclusion that the number of titles is not the same thing as the number of readers," said Peter Osnos, a former Random House executive who started a new Public Affairs imprint to publish serious nonfiction.
"We don't believe anymore that the publishing of books is Immaculate Conception," he said. "You have to find the audience because there's an awful lot of competition for people's time."
It's a truism in New York City, the hub of American publishing, that readers are slicing up their time, shifting from the written page to the flickering computer screen and web sites. But, in fact, books are still holding their own in the competition for attention. While people have been devoting less time to reading newspapers and magazines over the last decade, they have actually increased the time they spend on books -- dedicating about 100 hours a year to that pursuit, according to various recent surveys. And although many of them are logging on to the Internet and its many on-line services, that time amounts to only eight hours a year.
So why then are publishers having such a difficult year selling books? Albert N. Greco, an associate business professor at Fordham University who has studied the consumer book market, says that a critical part of the answer is a simple issue of supply and demand.
"What I think you have is a tremendous amount of titles," he said. "There are too many titles being published and too many in the wrong market. You're looking at an aircraft carrier in the Atlantic Ocean and you can't turn that around on a dime. They have contracts for books that won't be delivered until the year 2000 and there is a massive commitment to books in the pipeline."
The tide of titles actually reached its crest in 1995 with 62,039 new titles, a 20 percent increase from the year before, which was the highest output of American books since the Puritans brought the first press to the Massachusetts Bay colony in 1638.
 
Wrong Theme, Wrong Time
 But this growth did not generate an increase in sales. It also didn't guarantee contracts and fat advances to every author seeking to write the great American novel; many were laboring over manuscripts lacking the popular appeal that publishers want.
"You picked the wrong theme in the wrong time," observed Mr. Greco of literary authors hoping to rise with the tide. "There's a very limited market for midlist authors and that limited market is not going to grow."
It was in the midst of this wave that Jonathan Karp, a senior editor at Random House, shared a lunch with a colleague from sales who idly mentioned a notion that would haunt the editor for days to come.
"You know," the salesman confided in Mr. Karp, "I'd be perfectly happy if we didn't publish any new novels for a year or two. Our books would sell a lot better if there were a moratorium on fiction."
That conversation prompted Mr. Karp to raise the issue at an editorial meeting with 15 colleagues. He wondered aloud if there was any real demand for the novels that they publish. The first response was silence, he recalled in an article he wrote for a publishing journal. Then came the brave consensus: it's a publisher's job to build demand.
In the last few weeks -- since canceling books and trimming its publishing list -- HarperCollins has been making the case that it is going to build demand for its books by promoting and focusing on a smaller number of titles. "Everyone understands that there are signs of diminishing returns with an ever-increasing number of books," said Mr. Kiener, who estimated that his company's list of titles published annually will drop to 1,000 from 1,600.
 
The Yale Method
 Perhaps publishers should seek some guidance from librarians and curators who have already faced the issue of book inflation and finite shelf space.
Patricia C. Willis, the curator of the Yale Collection of American Literature in New Haven, subscribes to the "cone theory" -- in which the book production expands outward in girth with more books published each year. As the cone widens, she said there is simply too much for her collection to absorb.
"There are so many being published that it is time to trim the list," said Ms. Willis, who described the Yale library as an "intelligent vacuum cleaner."
But unlike publishers, Ms. Willis is free to make her choices based on literary distinction. She follows no particular rule except she considers the staying power of contemporary authors and monitors whether rare book collectors consider the works valuable enough to keep for years to come.
Asked if Tom Clancy novels are stocked on her shelves, Ms. Willis swiftly replied, "I have Tom Wolfe, who is a graduate."
 
Graph: "Too Many Books Published and Not Enough Readers"

It also shows a breakdown of 1995 book purchases, by book category. And, it tracks the number of hours spent per person using various forms of mass media each year in the U.S., from 1986 through 1996. HEADLINE: G.I.'s Slaying in '92 Entangled in Panama's Politics

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
On the eve of a visit here by President George Bush in June 1992, an American soldier was shot and killed as he drove an Army Humvee near the Panama Canal. Based on the accounts of witnesses, an arrest warrant was quickly issued for the son of a powerful anti-American politician who is the president of the party that now governs this country.
Five years later, the man arrested, Pedro Miguel Gonzalez, has still not been tried for the slaying of Sgt. Zak A. Hernandez. The police official who led the investigation that resulted in Mr. Gonzalez's arrest has been forced to resign, his life has been threatened and he now faces prison on charges that he and human rights groups say are fabrications. 
 "In this country, those who have power define the truth, so I suppose I should not be surprised by what is happening," the former police official, Jaime Abad Espinosa, said in an interview. "In Panama, politics is often mixed in with the administration of justice, but this case is extraordinary by any standard."
From the start, the killing of Sergeant Hernandez and the wounding of another American soldier at the same time have taken one odd turn after another. Mr. Gonzalez was named as the chief suspect in the slaying almost immediately and a $100,000 reward for his capture was offered. But for more than two years he evaded capture and was said by the police to have fled to Cuba.
Early in 1995, Mr. Gonzalez gave himself up. But instead of going to the police, he surrendered to President Ernesto Perez Balladares at the National Palace, with his father, Gerardo Gonzalez, and Mr. Abad's replacement as chief of police at his side. The proceedings were shown on national television.
Gerardo Gonzalez, a member of Congress, said he had sought that unusual arrangement "to avoid an attempt on the kid's life." Once Mr. Perez Balladares came to power in September 1994, he said, "the proper conditions for my son's personal security finally existed, so that he could defend himself and not be killed in jail." Under the previous Government, Mr. Gonzalez maintained, "there was only a campaign of judicial terrorism and persecution against" his son.
But Arcadio Hernandez, the father of the slain American soldier, thinks the surrender in the palace sent a different message. "What it really said was that both the father and the President of Panama were going to give him aid and support, that he had all the resources of the Government at his disposal," Mr. Hernandez said in a telephone interview from his home in Puerto Rico.
These days, Pedro Miguel Gonzalez is confined to an air-conditioned jail cell equipped with television, cell phone, fax and computer. Prosecutors have repeatedly indicated his trial is imminent, only to delay it further at the last minute.
The postponements have come as Panama is beginning negotiations that would permit as many as 4,000 American troops to remain here as part of an antidrug effort after the Panama Canal is handed over to Panama on Dec. 31, 1999.
Under the canal treaties, American troops stationed in the former Canal Zone are supposed to leave here by that date, and all American bases are to be handed over. But President Perez Balladares has floated the idea of a drug interdiction center as the linchpin of an effort to attract foreign investment and tourism to the so-called "reverted areas."
A banker and economist, Mr. Perez Balladares represents the pragmatic, business-dominated wing of the Revolutionary Democratic Party. In contrast, Gerardo Gonzalez heads a populist, anti-American faction of the party, which Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega controlled during the 1980's and used as a tool of military dictatorship until Mr. Bush sent 20,000 American troops to depose him in December 1989.
"Gerardo Gonzalez hates the Americans and wants them gone," said a Latin American diplomat here. "But with his son in jail, he must be careful not to offend the President, who knows perfectly well he has a trump card and has used it to keep Gonzalez in line. So it has been in the Government's interest, and perhaps Washington's too, to drag this case out as long as possible."
Gerardo Gonzalez is expected to be elected president of the Panamanian Congress in September. He said in an interview that he would insist his son's trial take place as soon as possible. "We're tired of waiting," he said. "The boy is innocent, and there is no proof against him."
Neither Raul Montenegro, Minister of Government and Justice, nor his deputy, Martin Torrijos, responded to requests to discuss the charges against Mr. Gonzalez or Mr. Abad.
American officials here and in Washington also declined to comment publicly on the case. But a local lawyer, Diego Velazquez, has been hired by the United States Embassy to represent the Hernandez family's interests and assist the prosecution.
The chief prosecutor in the case was said by colleagues to be on vacation, but in an interview, Mr. Velazquez said he had no doubt that Pedro Miguel Gonzalez and two accomplices, who have been arrested, were responsible for the killing. Three witnesses put them at the scene, he said, and others saw them in the stolen car from which the shots were fired. The car was later found on one of Gerardo Gonzalez's farms.
Ballistic tests ordered by Mr. Abad also implicated Pedro Miguel Gonzalez in the killing. But Gerardo Gonzalez then accused Mr. Abad of suppressing other ballistic tests that he said exonerated his son. This led to Mr. Abad's arrest and trial.
No verdict in that case has been announced. But Mr. Abad has strenously denied any wrongdoing, and said the charges had been fabricated to weaken the case against Pedro Miguel Gonzalez. "There are only two alternatives," he said. "Either I stole evidence, or he is a terrorist and an assassin who is using the influence and protection of his father to make me a scapegoat and derail the prosecution of this case. And I will tell you this: I am no thief."
Human rights groups here have strongly criticized the Government's treatment of Mr. Abad. The Panamanian Center for the Investigation of Human Rights and Judicial Assistance said the charges against him had been subject to "manipulation" and handled with "unaccustomed dispatch," whose "clear purpose is that its result influence the result of the other case."
Mr. Abad said that on the day of his trial, he was approached in the courtroom by Gerardo Gonzalez, who said to him, "You're a C.I.A. dog, and I'm going to see you go to jail."
Asked for his account of the confrontation, Mr. Gonzalez said that it was "absolutely a lie" to say he accused Mr. Abad of working for the C.I.A. "I said that he was working for the American Embassy, that he was a puppet who allowed himself to be manipulated," Mr. Gonzalez said.
Arcadio Hernandez said such incidents would not dissuade him from attending the trial of the man accused of killing his son. But he is concerned about the outcome.
"They've threatened witnesses and thrown out judges and acted with no respect for the rule of law," he said. "So far, it's been nothing but a show, and I worry that what comes next is going to be even worse."

HEADLINE: Credit Lures College Students Down Path to Onerous Debt

BYLINE: By HALIMAH ABDULLAH 

 BODY:
LaToya Dailey's credit troubles began with a T-shirt giveaway. They spiraled into a credit-card debt of more than $8,000 by her sophomore year in college.
"I was a freshman and there was this guy giving out free T-shirts, so I went over," said Ms. Dailey, who just completed her junior year at the University of Alabama at Tuscaloosa. " 'Want a free T-shirt, just sign up here for a Discover card.' So I did. And I've been signing and paying ever since." 
 Richard Matson, an aspiring filmmaker who attends Columbia College in Chicago, said he figured he would have no problem getting through college debt-free. His parents had saved an $80,000 college fund. But today, $65,000 and three colleges later, Mr. Matson is running through the remaining money with a monthly credit-card payment of $900. He used his credit cards to satisfy his needs, often splurging on his wants: books, trips to New York, film supplies and beer.
"It's stupid, I know; sometimes I blow my money on silly things," he said. "I've gotten a lot of other offers from credit-card companies and so far I've turned them down. But now I'm thinking about getting every one I can find."
Scenes of credit-card representatives offering items like Frisbees, T-shirts and candy as "premiums" to sign up for various credit-card offers have become commonplace on American college and university campuses, experts say. This aggressive marketing has led more and more students to subsidize their education and their life styles with credit cards. The debts come on top of record amounts of student loans, and students around the country say they feel overwhelmed by the consequences of their credit-card use.
College students teeter under a load of missed payments, high interest rates and default accounts, said Robert McKinley of RAM Research Group, a credit-card industry research company in Frederick, Md.
Freshmen and students strapped for cash are especially enticed by the credit-card marketing, said Debbie Conrad, manager of community education at the Michigan division of Credit Counseling Service, a nonprofit organization that counsels people with debt problems.
"We're running into students who feel they had neither the income nor maturity to handle a credit card," she said.
Mr. Matson is transferring to Columbia University in New York next year and now realizes that debt is inevitable. "I have about $15,000 left in my savings account," he said. "It's not going to be enough to cover tuition at Columbia. I'm just going to have to take out a loan."
Spokeswomen for some of the nation's largest credit-card companies contend that students have no more problems with credit-card debt than anyone else, although they decline to give numbers.
Maria Mendler of Citibank, said of the students, "Sometimes they're a better credit risk."
But consumer debt specialists say they are seeing more students in trouble. It is a result of the increased marketing of credit cards to college students in the late 1980's and early 1990's as part of an industry effort to revive the then-sluggish credit-card market, Mr. McKinley said.
Patricia Scherschel, a spokeswoman for the USA Group, a nonprofit group that provides student loan services, said that it was easy for student debt to snowball because many students are taking on larger student loans just to get by.
"Clearly students are borrowing more to finance their college education," she said. "Investing in a college degree is worthwhile even if it means the student needs to borrow."
The rise in student loans can be attributed to several factors, said Tom Kane, associate professor of public policy at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government. Since 1993, when the Government raised loan limits and made getting loans easier, loans have tended to supplant outright grants, Mr. Kane said. As private colleges limit institutional aid, he said, "the share of the cost paid by families and students in tuition has been rising."
At Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, students are learning a lesson in debt management. Its students graduate with, on average, $26,031 in debt, according to U.S. News & World Report's annual ranking of colleges.
Students are advised about their debt load upon entering and graduating, said Donald Chenelle, director of financial aid at Case Western. He said students "have to budget and manage their money well."
Across town in the corporate offices of Cleveland Scholarship Programs Inc., students are learning to do just that. More than 90,000 students have been served by Cleveland Scholarships, the nation's oldest college-access program, helping inner-city youngsters get and pay for a college education. The program advises and coordinates financial aid for more than 500 students every year.

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeks Elbow Room To Develop Trade Deals

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 23

 BODY:
President Clinton called on Congress today to give him greater freedom to negotiate free trade agreements with other countries, getting a jump on one of the toughest legislative challenges that await him when he returns from his Martha's Vineyard vacation.
In his weekly radio address, Mr. Clinton made a detailed defense of his economic strategy, which he said hinged on opening more markets abroad with "tough new trade agreements." 
 "To keep our economy growing and to create these good jobs," he said, "we must keep tearing down foreign barriers to American goods and services."
Mr. Clinton is seeking so-called fast-track authority, which would give the Administration greater flexibility in seeking several new trade accords around the world, including a long-promised extension of free trade privileges to Chile.
The fast-track legislation would allow the Administration to negotiate trade accords that Congress could approve or disapprove, but not amend. The theory is that if Congress could change the contents, negotiations would never stop. The last fast-track authority lapsed three years ago.
But the President faces stiff opposition within his own party, in a debate that is likely to figure prominently in the next Presidential race. With the backing of labor unions, Representative Dick Gephardt, the House minority leader and a likely rival of Vice President Al Gore for the Democratic nomination in 2000, opposes the legislation.
Opponents say the North American Free Trade Agreement has cost America jobs, depressed wages and damaged the environment along the border, assertions the Clinton Administration disputes.
Trying today to blunt the main objections to his trade policy, Mr. Clinton said he would "continue to promote worker rights and responsible environmental policies with our trading partners."
The Clinton Administration had considered pushing for the trade legislation last spring, but concluded that it would interfere with negotiations on a balanced-budget agreement. The Administration is now counting on passage of the legislation this fall, since it probably could not win Congressional approval in 1998, an election year. Mr. Clinton plans to submit the legislation in the second week of September, aides said.
"It'll be a tough fight, no question," said Barry Toiv, a White House spokesman. The President, he added, "wants to take every opportunity to remind the American people of the benefits of free trade."
While his proposed first step is to negotiate a free trade accord with Chile, Mr. Clinton has more ambitious plans. Fast-track authority would let him pursue the "Free Trade Area of the Americas," which he promised at the Latin American summit meeting in Miami in 1994.
But despite Mr. Clinton's efforts, the United States is seen internationally as retreating from its vigorous free trade policy. Canada and Mexico, the two other Nafta signers, are thus striking their own deals in Latin America, saying they cannot wait for the United States to act.
Mr. Clinton warned today that the United States risked being left behind. "If we don't seize these new opportunities," he said, "our competitors surely will. Already since 1992, in Latin America and Asia alone, our competitors have negotiated 20 trade agreements that do not include the United States."
Noting that "95 percent of the world's consumers live beyond our borders," Mr. Clinton said more than one-quarter of the country's economic growth over the last four years had come from trade abroad.
In the Republicans' weekly radio address, Senator Bob Bennett of Utah charged that John Huang, a former deputy assistant secretary at the Commerce Department and later a fund raiser for the Democratic National Committe, had used his Commerce post to pass sensitive information to his former employer, the Lippo Group of Indonesia. Mr. Huang has denied the accusation.
