HEADLINE: As U.S. Urges Delicacy on Swiss Gold, New York City Hints at a Bold Stroke

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
As it tries to persuade Switzerland to pay greater restitution to victims of the Holocaust, the United States has been engaged in a delicate dance with the increasingly testy Swiss public. But now New York, taking a far more confrontational approach with Swiss companies, may be about to upset that effort.
Ever since May, when the United States issued a report harshly critical of how Swiss banks aided the Nazis and impeded the efforts of Holocaust survivors to recover their family fortunes, the Clinton Administration has sought to calm the ensuing political storm. It has repeatedly praised the Swiss for confronting the past, and steered clear of any hints that it might consider sanctions against the banks. 
 Now New York's Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, whose family included Holocaust victims, is starting to drop those hints.
Mr. Hevesi has been dogging Swiss companies for months now, noting that New York's pension funds are big investors in Swiss companies and asking for details about how much the companies have contributed to a special fund set up to aid aging Holocaust survivors. Most of the companies have said they are contributing -- but have decided to keep the amount secret.
In an interview, Mr. Hevesi declared that he was "deeply disappointed" with the actions of Switzerland's largest private bank, the Union Bank of Switzerland, which still declines to disclose details about Holocaust-era documents it was caught destroying in January.
Mr. Hevesi, who is running for re-election in November, said he had asked his staff to "begin an internal review of the city's options" in dealing with Union Bank, which earned fees in excess of $1.25 million last year for performing a variety of banking services for the city. Through a New York spokesman, the bank said on Friday that it was "surprised by Mr. Hevesi's comments" and that it had been "responsive to all his requests."
Mr. Hevesi stopped short of actually threatening to cut off business with the bank, and even if the city did that, the economic impact would be minimal. But Clinton Administration officials say they are worried that his actions, along with a newsletter titled "Swiss Monitor" that Mr. Hevesi has begun circulating to financial officers of other states and cities, could hamper delicate, behind-the-scenes negotiations with the Swiss.
Stuart E. Eizenstat, the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said in an interview broadcast on Swiss television on Friday that the Clinton Administration "feels very strongly that any sanctions at any level -- Federal, state or local -- are counterproductive."
Mr. Eizenstat has spent much of the last three months trying to manage the backlash in Switzerland over the publication of the historical report. .
The report concluded that Switzerland's banks tilted the country's traditional neutrality toward Nazi Germany, hiding gold and other assets the Nazis looted throughout Europe, even long after Germany's surrender. It determined that Swiss banks knowingly violated a 1946 accord to turn over half of those assets to the Allies for the resettlement of refugees.
The report also concluded that the banks had systematically hampered efforts by Holocaust survivors and their heirs to recover assets placed in Switzerland for safekeeping. Last month, more than a half century after the war's end, the banks reluctantly published a list of long-dormant accounts that were opened by non-Swiss citizens before Germany's surrender in 1945.
Even before the report was published, three major Swiss banks all said they would contribute to a Special Fund for Needy Victims of the Holocaust, and other Swiss firms have made donations. The Swiss central bank also promised a significant donation, but the required parliamentary approval has been delayed until at least the fall. A much larger humanitarian fund proposed by the Swiss Government, not primarily intended for victims of the Nazis, must be approved in a national referendum that the Government has yet to schedule. Polls show that it may be defeated.
Washington's diplomatic strategy in dealing with Switzerland on all these issues has been to accentuate the positive. It has never publicly discussed, for example, forcing Switzerland to live up to the 1946 accord, which would require the banks to disgorge billions of dollars in profits they made trafficking in gold and other assets that the Nazis looted in Europe.
"My feeling is that sanctions are neither justified by the objective steps that Switzerland has taken," Mr. Eizenstat said in the interview, "nor are they productive when the Swiss Parliament has yet to approve its own contributions to the special fund."
Noting that "Swiss public opinion is very fragile at this time," he cautioned that even the hint of imposing penalties on Swiss firms "creates an atmosphere of Swiss-bashing that is not justified."
New York's approach, however, seems less interested in diplomatic niceties than in concrete answers.
Last month Mr. Hevesi wrote to the chief executives of Swiss companies in which New York's $70 billion pension funds have invested. "We have found that a company's public image is one of its most valuable assets," he wrote in the letters. "Similarly we have found that contingent liabilities -- such as potential boycotts or even the expense of lobbying against such boycotts -- are often undervalued. As investors in many Swiss companies, we do not want to see their values diminished."
He asked the firms to let him know if they were contributing to the Holocaust funds, and if so, how much. At the same time he began publishing the newsletter to keep financial officers up to date on the actions of Swiss firms. "We must seek to make restitution to the survivors and victims' heirs who are the rightful owners of assets held by Swiss banks since before World War II," Mr. Hevesi wrote in the first issue of his newsletter.
So far a dozen firms have confirmed that they are making contributions, but only one has disclosed how much. "As to your question with respect to the size of our contribution," wrote Fritz Gerber, the chairman and chief executive of Roche, one of Switzerland's larger companies, "I hope you can understand that we have agreed not to disclose individual figures in order to avoid internal discussions." Another executive wrote of "an agreement between the participating companies not to publish the amount of the individual donations."
In Switzerland, some executives and politicians have already said that they feel as if they are being shaken down for contributions. More than a few, including a former President of Switzerland, have said they suspect the United States is engaged in a conspiracy to undercut Switzerland's role as a world financial center -- and thus a competitor to New York.
So far the Swiss institution that has plunged itself deepest into the controversy is the Union Bank of Switzerland. After a guard at the bank, Christoph Meili, discovered carts full of old ledgers awaiting shredding and slipped some of the information to a Swiss Jewish group, he was dismissed. He has since moved his family to the United States, where Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican, pressed Congress to grant them permanent residency. Last month President Clinton signed a bill that does so.
The bank remains unapologetic about Mr. Meili's treatment, however, even after it admitted that some of the documents dealt with the forced sale of German properties belonging to Jews before the war.
It has also said little in public about comments by Robert Holzach, its honorary president, who told the New Yorker this spring that Jews are excluded from top posts in most Swiss banks and that he suspected a Jewish conspiracy lay behind the recent disclosures about the banks.

HEADLINE: Face Time for Federal Express

 BODY:
When a big corporate political donor is invited to press his company's case at the White House before the President, he is probably going to expect results. But the attempt by Federal Express to buy influence with the Clinton Administration over an economic dispute with Japan, which was disclosed last week, has not helped anyone.
Instead of advancing his company's interests, Frederick Smith, the Federal Express chairman, has probably set them back. Thanks to the now well-documented tendency in this White House to mix policy-making with insatiable political fund-raising, a sensible objective for the United States has been tainted and the 1996 Democratic fund-raising effort has been revealed once again as structurally corrupt. 
 President Clinton says he is proud of the fund-raising he and his party carried out in recent years, and that there were no direct quid pro quos for donors. But the episode involving Federal Express, first reported in The Washington Post, provides a case study in why the system he embraces not only has polluted American politics but has actually damaged American interests abroad.
At issue is a long-running demand by Federal Express to fly cargo through Japan to its new hub at Subic Bay, the former American naval base in the Philippines. A 45-year-old aviation agreement between the United States and Japan clearly requires Tokyo to grant access to Federal Express, as this page argued two years ago. Both the Bush and Clinton Administrations have supported the company's cause, but Federal Express wanted sterner action. Mr. Smith used his meeting with Mr. Clinton to press for sanctions against Japan. Federal Express also ponied up $506,000 in campaign contributions to the Democrats last year, along with $540,000 to the Republicans.
Federal Express has been a major success story in the competitive global economy, and is worthy of American support. Its gamble in setting up a hub at Subic Bay has revitalized the area around the old naval base. It makes sense in the new age of commercial diplomacy for the United States to help American companies in their attempts to win contracts and market access. But such an approach is simply undercut in the eyes of the world when it looks like nothing more than a payoff for a large political donation.
In addition, the United States needs to be sensitive to the risks of favoring one company's interests over another's, however plausible that company's case. The appearance of evenhandedness was undermined by Mr. Clinton's ill-advised meeting with Mr. Smith. Until now, the United States has refrained from the tougher approach of the sanctions demanded by Federal Express. Though sanctions might well be justified and certainly would be legal, there was good reason to hesitate. Sanctions could well invite Japanese retaliation, which, in turn, would almost certainly damage other American companies doing business in Japan. In negotiating with Tokyo, the United States has to weigh the interests of everyone, not just Federal Express.
The point is that the United States' bargaining position with Japan has been weakened because of Mr. Smith's clumsy intervention and the Administration's willingness to peddle White House meetings. Even among those in the White House who opposed the idea of sanctions, there was agreement that Mr. Smith had a legitimate complaint. It will be understandable now if Japan takes less seriously an American demand that looks so obviously like a favor to a political contributor.
Other airlines have reason to fear that Federal Express will gain an upper hand over them. The way to remove such suspicions is obvious. Enacting legislation banning open-ended contributions by individuals and corporations is the only way to restore integrity to the process in Washington.

HEADLINE: 1997 U.S. OPEN;
Ho Returns In Time To Say Farewell

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY 

 BODY:
Yesterday was the first day of freshman orientation at Rice University, and Tommy Ho played hooky.
He also played tennis, and when he had finished his final-round qualifying match and watched his taller, healthier opponent, Dick Norman of Belgium, give his racquet a final disgusted kick, Ho was in the main draw of the United States Open for the first time since 1994 with a 6-3, 6-4 victory. 
 This is an odd sort of comeback in that it also appears to be a farewell. Ho has enrolled at Rice, where he plans to pursue a degree in economics and volunteer as an assistant coach with the men's tennis team.
He is only 24, but for much of the last two years, his lower back has felt considerably older than that. He took four months off in 1995, eight in 1996 and another three so far in 1997.
"The basic problem is that I've had two herniated disks; I'll spare you all the ugly details," he said. "Basically, my back is a career-ending injury. There are times when I can't tie my shoes for two or three days. So stiff. So painful. Other days, it can be all right, even good. The weather has a lot to do with it. When it's sunny like this, it is certainly better."
If it is better, it is also because Ho decided to get an injection earlier this month to help break up scar tissue in his back. It might seem like a Faustian bargain, but Ho is making the best of his borrowed time.
The week before arriving here, Ho reached the quarterfinals at the ATP Tour event in Indianapolis. Now, after three consecutive straight-set victories in qualifying, he will face Martin Damm of the Czech Republic in the Open's first round today.
 "Maybe it's fate, but right now I'm playing my best tennis," said Ho, one of nine men to qualify for the Open yesterday.
Ho, who was born in Winter Haven, Fla., was once considered a potential champion. In 1988, he won the national 18-and-under championship at age 15, and then he became the youngest man to play a match at the United States Open, losing to Johan Kriek in straight sets in the first round. But precocity did not evolve into stardom -- his highest career ranking is 85th -- and now he is searching for some graceful form of punctuation.
Oddly enough, Ho was the first person to win a professional match in the revamped national tennis center. It happened at the challenger event held last month when he won his first-rounder, 6-0, 6-0.
"Sometimes, I'm just thinking, 'God, I'm going to miss all this,' " he said. "But I look around this stadium, and I realize it's a new era, a new Open. This is what it will be the next 20, 30, 50 years. And at least I got a chance to play in the new facility."
The other American who, on the final day of qualifying, earned a chance to play in the Open was no nostalgic former teen-age phenom. He was Geoff Grant, a late-blooming Boston resident who, with his curly, long red locks, exuberance and sartorial excesses, looks a bit like the soccer star Alexi Lalas minus the goatee.
Grant, a 27-year-old Duke graduate, can tell you horror stories from satellite tournaments in Guatemala and challengers in Uzbekistan. He hits with two hands off both wings and now, after quitting the sport for 10 months, he is brimming with passion.
"When I quit, I was jealous of people getting ahead of me in the business world and moving ahead with their normal lives," said Grant, who defeated Dirk Dier of Germany, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday. "But I realized eventually that I really hadn't given tennis everything I could."
No longer jealous, Grant showed up at the Open qualifying in 1995 wearing a suit after a half-hearted interview for a radio sales job in Manhattan and proceeded to lose in the final round. "Obviously, the sales interview went terribly," he said with a grin.
Grant wasn't grinning quite so widely when he heard about his first-round draw: he will play Gustavo Kuerten, the French Open champion.
Then again, it could be worse. He could be Todd Larkham, a 203d-ranked Australian qualifier who drew Pete Sampras and will get to play the world No. 1 and two-time defending Open champion on tonight in the new Arthur Ashe Stadium in front of thousands of utterly unobjective Americans.
"I've watched him on the telly 101 times, and I'll bet he's never even heard of me," Larkham said. "Maybe he'll break an ankle or something."

LENGTH: 1764 words

HEADLINE: Rescuing a Big Phone Deal From Oblivion;
British Telecom's Chairman Makes Fateful Trans-Atlantic Pledge to MCI

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
Sometimes the most tortuous negotiations can be teased along with a grand gesture by a single person.
Sir Iain Vallance, the chairman of British Telecommunications, made such a gesture last week during a pivotal moment in the talks to salvage his company's acquisition of the MCI Communications Corporation. MCI had agreed to accept a 22 percent reduction in the value of the deal. But the company's directors wanted a guarantee that the transaction would finally close without further snags, according to people with knowledge of the talks. 
 Sir Iain's bold stroke? If British Telecom's shareholders did not ratify the deal, now worth $19 billion, he would resign, he promised MCI directors in Washington, speaking to them on a video hookup from London.
People familiar with the matter said his pledge gave MCI's board the confidence to accept the revised deal. And it ended a bizarre trans-Atlantic corporate melodrama. "It was extremely difficult," said Gerald H. Taylor, chief executive of MCI, referring to the three days of talks that led to the new terms announced on Friday. "But when we looked at what MCI would be like by itself, it wasn't as good as what we have now."
What MCI has now, though, is the subject of spirited debate among shareholders and analysts. Did the company preserve a powerful alliance that will set the agenda for the global communications industry of the future? Or did it simply patch up a relationship that will slip back into chaos the next time MCI or British Telecom hits a rough spot?
"Given what's happened over the last few weeks, I'm assuming there are some bruised egos there," said Scott Wright of Argus Research in New York. "Behind the shoulder-to-shoulder unity, there are dark undercurrents at those companies."
The contretemps between MCI and British Telecom has implications for the rest of the telecommunications industry, which is consolidating into a handful of vast alliances. Global partnerships like that of MCI and British Telecom are clearly more challenging than domestic mergers.
But even deals between next-door neighbors, like the recent combination of Bell Atlantic and Nynex, are prone to internal strife and culture clashes. And it was bad personal chemistry between top executives that helped derail tentative merger talks earlier this summer between AT&T and a regional Bell company, SBC Communications.
Taken together, such pairings indicate that even in telecommunications -- where all companies are basically in the same business -- manners and management may be what matter most.
For British Telecom and MCI, the pressure to smooth over their differences is especially acute because the companies must still persuade their respective shareholders that the revised deal is worth supporting. Earlier this year, investors in both companies had voted their support for the original deal, although some MCI shareholders had filed suits contending that its terms were insufficiently generous.
MCI and British Telecom now both plan to resubmit the deal to shareholder votes by November or early December, with a goal of closing at the end of the year. But some analysts are already predicting additional lawsuits from MCI shareholders.
Based on the value of the deal when it was announced last November, MCI shareholders will receive $2.02 a share less for the company under the new terms. They will also be deprived of a one-time British Telecom dividend worth $1.21 a share. Moreover, MCI shareholders will wind up with 25 percent of the combined company, versus 34 percent under the old agreement.
The prolonged dispute over the terms laid bare the stark differences between the two companies and two sets of shareholders. From British Telecom's perspective, the dispute was a cut-and-dried case of renegotiating an acquisition to account for the deterioration in MCI's financial results. That deterioration had been made clear on July 10, when MCI warned Wall Street that it was running unexpectedly large losses from its entry into the local phone business. The company said those losses could reach $800 million in 1997.
British Telecom responded by pushing to reduce the price of the deal to mollify its institutional shareholders, who were used to the steady earnings of a regulated utility and who reacted to MCI's warning with fury. At British Telecom's annual meeting in July, one investor told Sir Iain he was an "English muffin," who had allowed MCI "to eat him for breakfast."
For its part, MCI could not understand what all the fuss was about. As the No. 2 company in the intensely competitive American long-distance business, it was accustomed to making bold bets and weathering losses to break into new markets.
And so, when Sir Iain and other British Telecom executives investigated MCI's business and then demanded that the deal be revised, it plunged MCI into a searing internal debate, according to several executives with knowledge of the company. After three decades of refusing to back down from conflict with a monolith like AT&T, some insiders resisted the idea of MCI's now capitulating to its monolithic British partner.
"There was a lot of emotion and a lot of different perceptions," said an adviser to B.T., who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "The American perceptions and the U.K. perceptions weren't the same."
MCI's first response to British Telecom was to argue that B.T. had no legal grounds to change the deal. Lawyers for British Telecom had pointed to a clause in the original agreement that allowed either company to terminate it if there was a "material adverse change" in the business of the other. But a separate document carved out some businesses from that category. Among those, MCI's lawyers insisted, was local phone service.
MCI's law firm, Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, prepared an analysis of the company's legal options. The firm thought MCI had a good chance of beating British Telecom in court. But besides the unseemliness of suing to complete the combination, MCI's lawyers also knew that the case would drag on for years, cost millions of dollars and distract MCI from its business.
"Litigation isn't really a business plan," a legal adviser to MCI said, also speaking on condition of anonymity.
As for MCI's actual business plan, several analysts said the company would have been severely handicapped by losing British Telecom's war chest when it was mounting an assault on the local telephone-service monopoly. And although all the world's other big phone carriers had not yet paired off, MCI might never have found a partner of the scale and with the resources of British Telecom.
"This was a choice between economic reality and emotional independence," said Michael Price, a managing director at Lazard Freres & Company, who advised MCI on the original deal and its revision.
After considering these issues, MCI's chairman, Bert C. Roberts Jr., decided to make a deal with British Telecom. But in accepting a lower purchase price, he still had to convince his colleagues and MCI's directors, some of whom were fiercely opposed.
MCI's board met for six and a half hours on Wednesday and several hours more on Thursday to hash out its options. Even on Thursday night -- hours before the revised deal was announced in London -- board members were raising concerns about whether even the new pact would survive a B.T. shareholder vote.
To assuage those concerns, Sir Iain and Sir Colin Marshall, who is the deputy chairman of British Telecom and the chairman of British Airways, addressed MCI's board by video. In addition to Sir Iain's pledge to resign, British Telecom agreed to pay MCI a fee of $750 million if the deal fell apart. And the amended agreement does not contain any loopholes about "material adverse changes." Shortly before 9 P.M. on Thursday, MCI's board felt secure enough to vote approval of the revised terms.
The following morning, British Telecom and MCI executives tried to put a good public face on the whole episode. They reiterated the strengths of the combined company, which, despite the discord, will carry the harmonious name of Concert: 43 million business and residential customers in 70 countries with revenue of $43 billion, or 6 percent of the $670 billion global telecommunications market.
Even though the changed deal is intended to compensate British Telecom, the executives argued that it would benefit MCI's shareholders, as well. That is because British Telecom now plans to issue fewer shares and more cash to acquire MCI. By reducing the projected number of outstanding shares by 10 percent, Concert will have higher per-share earnings, which will be good for MCI shareholders who will become shareholders of Concert.
"This is a win-win scenario," said Yves Istel, an investment banker at Rothschild, who advised British Telecom. "When everybody became persuaded of that, the pieces fell into place."
B.T. also tried to squash persistent rumors that it would set off on a housecleaning at MCI's Washington headquarters. The company said it did not plan to order 5,000 layoffs at MCI, as The Financial Times had reported on Thursday, although it did not rule out some layoffs. And British Telecom said it did not plan to remove any senior MCI executives.
It declared that it would support MCI's efforts to break into the local phone market and that it would not put pressure on MCI to scale back its investments -- and projected losses -- in that business. Privately, though, MCI officials said the company would become more selective about which new local markets to vie for, in an effort to keep those losses below $800 million.
Despite the sting MCI may feel in having to accept cheaper terms, some analysts argue that it is getting off easy. In addition to its costly local initiatives, the company has suffered an erosion in its core long-distance business. Together, those negative developments could in fact account for a 35 to 45 percent reduction in MCI's value since the original pact, according to Daniel Reingold, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.
"MCI did very well for itself, in light of the challenges ahead in the United States, both in long distance and local," he said.
At MCI's headquarters, though, the mood is one of acceptance rather than triumph. The company's bruising encounter with British Telecom demonstrated that for all its entrepreneurial zest, MCI is destined to remain very much the junior partner.
Or, as Sir Iain put it on Friday, "it could well be in the interest of MCI shareholders to have a smaller slice of a greater cake."

HEADLINE: Forecasters Begin to See Who Will Feel Effects of El Nino

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
AS the latest version of the powerful weather-maker known as El Nino develops into a giant of its breed in the tropical Pacific, forecasters are beginning to get a clearer idea of how and where its impact will be felt globally in the weeks and months ahead.
For openers, there may be good news: El Nino has called into serious question earlier forecasts of an unusually active Atlantic hurricane season. The warming Pacific waters that define El Nino spawn wide-ranging atmospheric conditions that carry over into the Atlantic and tend to abort developing hurricanes. And as the 1997 hurricane season enters what should be its busiest period, the tropical regions that give rise to the big storms are almost eerily quiet. 
 "We're seeing a dead Atlantic at the moment; there's nothing going on out there" and El Nino is surely the reason why, said Vernon Kousky, an expert at the Climate Prediction Center of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in Camp Springs, Md.
But come winter, El Nino may not be so benign. If the forecasters are right, it will bring abnormally high rainfall to California and virtually the entire southern tier of the United States. The last time El Nino appeared with strength comparable to this year's, in 1982-83, California and much of the southern tier were drenched again and again, causing floods, mud slides and general climatic havoc. Worldwide that year, El Nino caused more than 1,000 deaths and exacted staggering economic costs.
Already, early signs of El Nino's work are appearing in some parts of the world. Indonesia is drier than normal, for example, and the forecasters expect this situation to widen into a drought affecting the entire region, including Australia. That is characteristic of El Nino. So are the heavy rains that have recently fallen in Chile, giving that country a year's supply of precipitation in two drenching downpours. The weak monsoon and dry conditions now being experienced in Pakistan and northwestern India, the breadbasket of the Indian subcontinent, are also characteristic of El Nino disturbances.
El Nino is a vast pool of abnormally warm water that is brought about from time to time by naturally occurring oscillations in atmospheric pressure and ocean movements in the equatorial Pacific. Until recently, this pool materialized every two to seven years, but in the 1990's the warm El Nino waters have been in place most of the time. Why this is so is not clear; some scientists suspect that it may be somehow related to global warming, but others disagree.
In any case, the warmer ocean pumps more energy and moisture into the atmosphere, and this in turn alters wind and rainfall patterns around the world. The nature and severity of the resulting disturbances is directly related to how warm the equatorial water gets.
Just now, equatorial water off South America is about 9 degrees Fahrenheit above normal, according to the Climate Prediction Center, and it is expected to warm further in the months ahead, reaching a peak from February to April, when the equatorial waters would normally be warmest. This year, the water is already as warm as it was in the winter of 1982-83, when El Nino's bite was its sharpest of the 20th Century.
The forecasters are confident that California and the southern tier will experience abnormally heavy rainfall this winter and next spring, said Mr. Kousky, because that has been the invariable result when El Nino is at its strongest. But whether the abnormal precipitation will actually translate into the havoc of 1982-83, he said, depends on how the atmospheric circulation patterns that transport storms from the Pacific to the West Coast and across the continent develop.
El Nino, when it materializes, presents forecasters with an especially good predictor of weather trends months in advance; without it, they are hard pressed to make long-range predictions. With El Nino's aid, the Climate Prediction Center has just issued a forecast for January through March of next year.
The forecast calls for higher-than-normal precipitation for most of California, New Mexico, Arizona, most of Texas, the Gulf Coast, Florida and eastern Georgia, South Carolina and North Carolina. Below-normal precipitation is predicted for the Ohio Valley, the Midwest east of the Mississippi and Montana. Elsewhere, including the Northeast, normal rain, snow, ice and sleet are forecast.
The prediction says that warmer-than-normal temperatures will prevail on the West Coast and most of the northern tier of the country as far east as the Great Lakes, but it is expected to be colder than normal in much of the Southeast.
While the forecasters cannot be sure until this fall's atmospheric circulation patterns become established, they say the Northeastern United States may be in for a relatively mild winter. One reason for iffiness about the Northeast is that atmospheric circulation over eastern North America is influenced by sea-surface temperatures in the North Atlantic as well as by El Nino, and forecasts for Atlantic temperatures for this winter are uncertain. Even if the Northeastern winter does turn out to be mild, said Mr. Kousky, that does not rule out some snowstorms.
A more immediate uncertainty for the Eastern United States has to do with the Atlantic hurricanes. El Nino generates strong west-to-east winds that blow into the hurricane cradle of the tropical Atlantic. These winds tend to shear tropical disturbances apart before they can develop into hurricanes.
In June, forecasters at Colorado State University in Fort Collins predicted that this year's hurricane season would be more active than normal for the third consecutive year. In an early August update, the Colorado group revised its forecast downward somewhat but still predicted an above-average year. The prediction calls for a total of six Atlantic hurricanes, two of them major ones, and five other lesser tropical storms strong enough to be assigned names. So far there have been four named storms, including one minimal hurricane. All occurred in July.
Dr. William M. Gray, the chief author of the Colorado forecast, said his group agonized over the revised August prediction. El Nino aside, he said, a wide range of conditions, including warm sea-surface temperatures in the Atlantic, favor hurricane development. "This is the hardest forecast I've ever made, with El Nino breathing down our throats like this," said Dr. Gray, whose predictions have been generally accurate.
Mr. Kousky said even the revised prediction was too pessimistic. "My feeling is that we'll get fewer hurricanes than what he's forecasting," he said.
Dr. Gray conceded: "Vern could be right. I don't know what's going to happen. Nobody knows. We gave it our best shot, and we'll go with the forecast."
A word of caution: Even if Mr. Kousky is right and there are fewer hurricanes than expected, it takes only one to cause a disaster; 1992 was a year of infrequent hurricanes and tropical storms, yet the big one that did develop that year was Hurricane Andrew, the most destructive storm in American history.

GRAPHIC: Maps: "El Nino Returns, Bringing With It The Threat of Climactic Distruption"
The climate disruptor known as El Nino appears when sea-surface temperatures in the eastern tropical Pacific rise above normal. The heat sets off atmospheric chain reactions affecting weather around the globe. As of last month, the temperatures had already risen to levels recorded in the winter of 1982-83, when the most powerful edition of El Nino so far in the 20th century raised climatic havoc in many parts of the world. Forecasters expect the seas to warm further in the months ahead, and based on that they have issued long-range temperature and precipitation forecasts for the coming winter in the United States. Maps show these forecasts. (Source: N.O.A.A. Climate Prediction Center)

HEADLINE: Looking For Laughs? Call a Harvard Grad;
As Writers and Producers, Young Alumni Find They Can Make a Lot of Money Fast

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Richard Appel was a Harvard man for the 1980's. He graduated with a degree in history and literature in 1985, went directly to Harvard Law School, like many of his classmates, and later joined the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan, a conventional step in a high-flying career.
And today? Mr. Appel is a Harvard man for the 1990's: he writes for "The Simpsons." 
 Welcome to the other Hollywood. Without doubt, the movie industry continues to be the most visible and glamorous side of the entertainment field. But head over to the second most fashionable tables at the city's must-see lunch spots, or peek inside some of the biggest houses in Los Angeles's toniest neighborhoods, and you will find the frequently better-paid and at times better-educated writers and producers of television shows.
Prime-time television may be reviled in intellectual circles for its supposedly lowbrow sensibilities, but many people in the medium regard this as a second golden era, both in terms of money and the quality of writing. Few things demonstrate the growing attractiveness of the field more than the presence of dozens of Harvard graduates (as well as many other Ivy Leaguers), particularly in the realm of comedy. Writing staffs of shows like "The Simpsons," "King of the Hill," "Saturday Night Live" and "Late Show With Dave Letterman" have come to look like Harvard alumni clubs.
Many other shows, including "Party of Five," "Cracker," "News Radio," "Third Rock From the Sun," "Seinfeld," "Veronica's Closet," "The Larry Sanders Show," "Suddenly Susan," "Murphy Brown" and "The Naked Truth," have or have had Harvard writers and producers and even a few Harvard-educated actors.
It is a career path that, as many of these people admitted, at one time seemed declasse by Harvard standards, but has gained considerable cachet with the soaring salaries and numbers of graduates heading out here.
"It's like there's a conveyor belt of people now coming out here," said Mr. Appel, who added that many of them, like himself, had worked at The Harvard Lampoon, long a launching pad for television comedy writers. ("The Lampoon has been the end of many a promising career in cancer research," said David Sacks, class of '84 and a co-executive producer of "Third Rock From the Sun.")
These people are, of course, endowed with varying degrees of talent. But, more important, they tend to be exceptionally ambitious, and the world of television now has credibility as a place that bright young Ivy Leaguers can go to show off their skills, something they were far less likely to do a generation ago.
Jonathan Aibel, class of '91 and a writer at "King of the Hill," said he recently went to a reunion and spent time with two classmates who are currently law clerks to United States Supreme Court justices. He said he had feared some subtle sense of rejection but was pleasantly surprised.
 
Shift in the Focus Of Money and Power
 "They said they enjoy the show," he said. "It was really good to hear that."
It is a business that pays huge sums even to very young people and is rising in prestige because of heavy media coverage. It requires not bursts of output and solitary efforts, as in writing screenplays or novels, but an ability to churn out consistently snappy scripts in collaboration with other writers, week in and week out.
"It's the same thing motivating these people that motivated graduates in the past, just in a new area," said Carolyn Strauss, class of '85 and a vice president for original programming at HBO. "The focus of money and power just shifted in a way."
At a show like "The Simpsons," fairly typical for sitcoms, a story editor, who holds one of the most junior positions, earns about $110,000 in a 22-episode year. (Payment is made by the episode.) The job of supervising producer, a mid-level writing position often reached after a few seasons, pays roughly $550,000 a year, and the top writing job, that of executive producer, $700,000 to as much as $3 million a year.
By contrast, the top salary for a first-year associate at a major New York law firm is roughly $86,000 a year, a figure that rises to about $170,000 in the fifth year, according to the National Association for Law Placement.
"I think we'd all be doing this even if it paid $16,000 a year," insisted Bill Oakley, class of '88 and a consulting producer of "The Simpsons." "But it does help that you can make as much after a few seasons as someone who's been at a law firm for 40 years."
Steven Peterman, class of '72 and an executive producer of "Suddenly Susan," said, "This has become a fast-track place where a smart person can make a lot of money in a hurry."
It helps, too, many said, that television shows are run by writers rather than deal makers. This produces a work environment that many regard as more intellectual and more in touch with the craft than film, which some writers complain is an endless series of pointless meetings.
"In television you work for other writers," said Jonathan Collier, class of '83 and a consulting producer on "King of the Hill," which was created in part by another Harvard alumnus, Greg Daniels, class of '85. "In film you work for people who want to have lunch with you."
Indeed, there is a sort of reverse snobbery now, with many television writers looking down on film as generally less interesting than good television.
John Romano, an executive producer and co-creator of "Michael Hayes," a one-hour drama series that will make its debut this fall, was an English professor at Columbia University before coming to Hollywood. He said he had been drawn here in part because he felt that the literature of the medium was more interesting than movies, or even many of today's novels.
"Television dramas are genuinely intelligent and interesting in the complexity of the situations in which you can put your characters," said Mr. Romano, who attended Yale, not Harvard. "Television in that sense is rich in character and complexity, even in a way film generally is not. There are many writers who find film language poor. And the novel has really turned inward."
Heavy news coverage of the television industry has also added sex appeal to the business. "In the 1980's investment banking got the same media play that Jamie Tarses gets today," Ms. Strauss said, referring to the embattled young president of ABC Entertainment.
And one should not underestimate the draw of the relaxed character of the television writing business, in which a pressed shirt is as welcome as a tie-dyed T-shirt and dreadlocks in a corporate boardroom.
"There's a tremendous amount of work, a tremendous amount of competition, tremendous job insecurity," Mr. Sacks said. "There are lots of periods of unemployment. Nevertheless, just the opportunity to show up and work in jeans and a T-shirt is a huge electromagnet to young people."
 
A Bit Defensive About Their Jobs
 Which is not to say there is not a knee-jerk defensiveness among these Harvard graduates.
"Yeah, I have had encounters with people recently who thought not only that television writing was for morons, but have said things like, 'Don't you of all people wish you wrote for something more positive?' " Mr. Appel said.
Mr. Appel, who is married to the novelist Mona Simpson, said he never felt a need to apologize for his work in her literary circles but added, "I guess you can't help but be a little defensive."
Irene Ng, a Harvard pre-med student who stars in a Nickelodeon show, "The Mystery Files of Shelby Woo," said there was still some division among students in their views on television.
"One group is fascinated by television and impressed and happy for you," Ms. Ng said. "They think it is really just great. The other group is like, well, one friend said: 'Acting on TV, it doesn't help people. It's so self-promoting.' I do get a sense that some people think working in TV's not socially responsible."
William Wright-Swadel, head of Harvard's career services office, said that the largest number of Harvard's 1,600 or so graduates each year still went into what he called "the big four": law, business consulting, medicine and investment banking. Nevertheless, he said that a media fair, the first ever, was set up last November to introduce students to jobs in the entertainment business. It drew nearly 800 students in a half-day.
"The thing that was important was that the whole thing was student-generated," he said.
Lucy Fisher, class of '71 and the vice chairman of Sony Pictures Entertainment, said that for a number of years she had hired her assistants from Harvard. She said she no longer did so but that she was receiving a growing volume of inquiries from undergraduates.
"If I opened those floodgates, I know about a zillion Harvard people would come out here," she said. "There's a lot of interest."
Some Harvard graduates said they had had to conceal their alma mater because of anti-intellectual attitudes just below the surface among some people in Hollywood.
Nestor Carbonell, class of '90 and an actor who plays Luis, the passionate Latin photographer, in "Suddenly Susan," said he had hid his Harvard background at times because some directors thought he could play only highbrow parts, not street toughs.
 
What a Diploma Can Accomplish
 But the name and the network can clearly help. Christopher Keyser, class of '82 (and class of '85, Harvard Law School), is the co-creator and executive producer of the drama "Party of Five." He said he had never obtained a job because of his Harvard connections, but he admitted that they could help get a young writer a second look, which can make a big difference. "The world is an unfair place like that," he said.
But, he insisted, "there is not a secret handshake."
All this still leaves open the question of whether these well-educated writers are raising the quality of prime-time television or trying to appeal to what some critics describe as the lowest common denominator. GQ magazine raised the issue several years ago in an article titled "Smart People, Dumb TV."
For their part, the writers tend to regard their work as lifting the quality of television, citing the popularity of their shows as evidence.
"For me it's the perfect synthesis of high and low," said Mr. Sacks of "Third Rock From the Sun." "You can make a great insight into the human condition and then have a guy tumble down a flight of stairs."
Well, let the reader judge. Mr. Sacks cited a "Third Rock" parody of the show "E.R.," in which the characters in his show, aliens in human form, had insinuated themselves into a hospital, pretending to be physicians.
"When's our next shift?" Sally asks.
"Hard to say," Harry replies. "We're not doctors."
"I can't wait to go back to that place," Tommy says. "It's like Disneyland. Only with a really high fatality rate."
In another episode, which is to appear on Halloween, Tommy and Sally buy costumes at a shop and dress up as Sonny and Cher. Dick, the group's leader, asks who they are supposed to be.
"Julius and Ethel Rosenberg," Tommy replies. "But I think the guy at the store made a mistake."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances Against Yen As Flat Japan Rates Are Seen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the yen yesterday as sluggish consumer spending in Japan bolstered expectations that interest rates there would not rise soon, while the United States currency was little changed against the mark on concern German rates might head higher.
In late trading in New York, the dollar settled at 118.79 yen, up from 118.31 yen on Friday; the dollar edged up to 1.8205 marks from 1.8168 marks. The pound slipped to $1.6051 from $1.6093. Volume was thin yesterday, as there was no trading in London, the world's largest currency market, because of a bank holiday. 
 The dollar received a lift against the yen after Japanese reports showed that an April tax increase stifled sales at department stores, supermarkets and electronics retailers in July for the fourth consecutive month.
The sales reports touched off a rally in Japanese bonds, as traders bet record low interest rates would not be raised soon. Higher rates would buoy the yen by luring global investors to some yen assets.
"Any talk of Japanese interest rates headed higher seems to be premature," said Jack Griffin, manager of foreign exchange sales at Fuji Bank. "If you're an investor looking at the situation, you wouldn't put your money in Japan."
Also weighing on the Japanese currency was fragility in Southeast Asian currencies. Countries in that region are among Japan's largest trading partners.
"Asian currencies are still showing weakness," said Thomas Lapinski, chief currency trader at MTB Bank. "There's concern more of them will need bailout packages and that Japan will need to assist."
The dollar was little changed against the mark after a higher-than-expected rise in consumer prices fueled speculation the German central bank could soon raise interest rates.
"There's fear that inflation is kicking up in Germany," said Thomas Lapinski, chief currency trader at MTB Bank. "A lot of traders are a bit nervous the Bundesbank might raise rates."
West German consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in the month ended mid-August, and 2 percent from the comparable period a year earlier.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Fall a Bit Pending Economic Reports

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities slipped yesterday as investors grew cautious prior to this week's economic reports and Government note auctions.
The 30-year bond fell 7/32, to 96 9/32, with the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rising to 6.66 percent from 6.65. 
 Analysts said this week's reports might show signs of economic strength, raising fears of inflation, which erodes the value of bonds. In addition, the Government auctions could cause dealers to try to raise the yields in advance to make the securities easier to distribute to investors.
Today, the Treasury will auction $15.5 billion in new two-year notes and tomorrow, it will sell $11.5 billion in new five-year notes. Steven Landis, director of fixed-income investments at Bull and Bear Advisers Inc., said that with dealers raising yields in preparation for the sales, there could be "a distribution rally coming out of the auctions."
In when-issued trading, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.98 percent, while the five-year was offered at a price to yield 6.24 percent. Rates at yesterday's bill auction were up moderately and in line with expectations. The three-month bill came in at 5.12 percent, up from 5.08 percent the previous week, while the six-month rate was 5.14 percent, up from 5.12 percent.
While the approach of the Treasury auctions might be contributing to the rise in yields, traders said that the recent volatility of the market had been exacerbated by other factors, including the thinness of trading. Yesterday, volume was among the lightest levels of the year; many market participants have left for vacations.
Mr. Landis also cited international factors for the recent volatility, including the currency crisis in Southeast Asia and the weakness of the Japanese economy. Also, the continuing sluggishness in Germany -- and the threat of an increase in interest rates, which Mr. Landis said would only compound the problem -- has further left investors scratching their heads.
All this should be making the United States market more attractive, because foreign investors have few other options. As a result, Mr. Landis said, the market was now only going through a technical adjustment and that it was still cheap by comparison.
While there was little economic news of note yesterday, Doug Burtnick, managing analyst with Technical Data of Boston, said the rest of the week "does carry a few tidbits worth watching, starting with tomorrow's two-year auction."
On the surface, he said, it looked as though the auction should go fine. Yields on the two-year note have risen by about a quarter of a percentage point over the last few weeks, and Wall Street expects the Federal Reserve to enter the market this week. "But with the summer doldrums comes a lack of liquidity," he said. "That should force dealers to try backing the market up even further on Tuesday morning," raising yields again.

HEADLINE: Colombia In Disarray, But Leader Prospers

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 25

 BODY:
The Letters to the Editor column in El Tiempo one recent day read like the script for a movie that could be called "Country on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown."
The first note was from a woman to her husband who had been kidnapped months ago, urging him not to lose hope. Another reader exploded over the "swindlers, juvenile delinquents, phony civil servants; peddlers selling umbrellas, videos, books, dogs, taffy, knives, kites; predators, murderers just out of jail" who besiege him the moment he leaves home each morning. 
 A third brought up a promise President Ernesto Samper made, that his last year in office would be a "striptease," unveiling great works. With interest rates on savings accounts falling short of inflation, the pledge rang true in a way, the reader said. "We've been completely fleeced."
Three years into his four-year term, President Samper has proved himself a far shrewder, more audacious politician than his opponents in Washington or here at home imagined in the adrenaline-filled days when the clamor for his resignation echoed from streets to boardrooms.
Mr. Samper has won the battle over the drug corruption charges against him. Nobody here expects him to leave office before his term expires next August. And yet his victory is dubious. By virtually any measure, Colombia is in its worst shape in decades, demoralized, angry and broke.
"He's a political genius," said Francisco Mejia, an economic consultant who was one of those calling for Mr. Samper to step down. "But it doesn't matter. He doesn't have credibility, nobody trusts him, and without that, you can't really run a country."
Pardoned by Congress on charges that drug dealers from the southern city of Cali pumped $6 million into his election campaign, the President has used control of jobs, pork-barrel projects and the airwaves to avoid resigning.
Supportive members of Congress have been rewarded with cash for enormous, often unnecessary projects in their districts, devastating the country's once enviable economy. Economists like Mr. Mejia estimate that the district of Heyne Mogollon, who came under severe criticism for playing down the case against Mr. Samper when he chaired the Congressional Committee of Accusations, has received an estimated $20 million in assorted contracts.
"Most of the upper classes live off the state, and the President has tremendous pull," said Hernan Echeverria, who stood at the forefront of the drive among business leaders to remove the President, only to watch their commitment dissipate as time passed. "He has so many contracts, so many jobs, to give out."
Economic growth, which had been running upwards of 5 percent a year before Mr. Samper took office, is down to an expected 1.5 percent this year, while the major international investment houses are advising their clients to look elsewhere. Revenues gained from privatization have gone largely to pay salaries rather than to build public works necessary for future growth. The unemployment rate, once at 6 percent, has more than doubled.
With the Government soaking up domestic sources of finance, Colombian companies have increasingly turned to foreign banks. During Mr. Samper's term, foreign debt has soared to $32 billion from $17 billion. And Government spending as a share of the gross domestic product has swollen to 33 percent from 20 percent, said Mr. Mejia.
In social and political terms, the situation is hardly more optimistic. About 70 percent of all the kidnappings in the world occur here. More people died violent deaths in the first nine months of 1996 than all of last year in the United States, which has nearly eight times the population. Jose Miguel Caballero and John Murphy, two gung-ho entrepreneurs who make bulletproof fashion wear, are busy outfitting all the candidates for next year's presidential elections.
In order to prevail over his enemies, Mr. Samper has had to curry favor with power bases that are frequently at odds, much as he has tried to satisfy the Rodriguez Orejuela brothers, the Cali traffickers who allegedly financed his election, as well as officials in Washington, who criticize him for protecting the interests of the drug lords.
A perfect example has been a bill to reinstate extradition, which the President launched as Washington prepared its annual report card on Colombia's cooperation in fighting drug exports. The United States, which would like to be able to try the Colombian drug lords in its own courts, is eager to have an extradition treaty with Colombia, and Mr. Samper's proposal has effectively muted Washington's criticism. But the law would not apply to drug dealers who turn themselves in, like the Rodriguez Orejuelas. And a twist in the bill announced last week means that passage of a second law, under the next President's administration, will be necessary.
Such weak leadership has been a boon to the right-wing paramilitary groups and the leftist guerrillas, who together control more than half the country's territory.
In the atmosphere of lawlessness beyond any sense of proportion or shame, some crimes veer into the surreal. Last week, a legislator reported that a 32-foot-wide metal bridge weighing 40 tons had disappeared from his district. Residents of San Agustin, in Neiva state, said they neither saw nor heard anything.

HEADLINE: Stocks Drift Aimlessly as Dow Drops 28.34

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
After a week of disorienting volatility, the stock market turned less volatile yesterday, but no less disorienting.
Blue-chip stocks showed little direction for much of the day, drifting in and out of negative territory, before finally succumbing to modest losses. Smaller stocks performed better. 
 Analysts said that the market's seeming aimlessness was caused in part by the thinness of trading as many investors were away on vacation. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was near its lowest level of the year, with just 392 million shares changing hands.
"The light volume is the main culprit today," said Edward Collins, a trader at Daiwa Securities. "I can't make a trend of much of anything."
Though the Dow Jones industrial average fell at the opening bell, it soon turned higher, gaining 56 points, before drifting lower through much of the afternoon.
At the closing bell, the Dow was off 28.34 points to close at 7,859.57. It was the third consecutive loss for the Dow, which has been sluggish all month long.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also slumped, losing 3.39 points, to 920.16. But the Nasdaq composite index, which is laden with technology issues, rose 2.88 points, to 1,601.57.
Among the major measures, the Russell 2000 index of smaller company stocks was the day's best performer, up 2.36 points, or 0.57 percent, to 418.09.
While rising interest rates in the bond market and nervousness over the state of the economy seem to have reduced some investor enthusiasm in the last month, smaller issues have quietly come to life.
Not only has the Russell been steadier than the Dow and the S.& P. 500, but midsize companies, as represented by the S.& P. mid-cap index, have also fared well. The S.& P. midcap index rose 1.47, to 313.21 yesterday, and is now up 22.5 percent for the year, outpacing the Dow, which is up 21.9 percent.
And while blue-chip technology issues were only a trifle higher yesterday, smaller technology stocks soared. The Russell 2000 Technology Index rose 1.26 percent, and the S.& P. small-cap technology index gained 1.55 percent. Among other stocks that did well were tobacco issues, which rose after the companies agreed to pay $11.3 billion to settle a smoking-related lawsuit in Florida.
Because the market was so strong in July, some analysts say it was inevitable that it would weaken in August, tempering a run that saw the Dow gain nearly 2,000 points, or 29 percent, between mid-April and early August.
But Gail Dudack, the chief investment strategist at UBS Securities, said that the strike at United Parcel Service, weakness in the dollar and heightened activity in derivative securities had contributed to the downdraft.
"The key thing is the market's been overvalued, and there's also an extensive use of derivative strategies," she said. Besides, "August is a vacation month, and a thin market is often a more volatile market because it doesn't take as many buyers or sellers to move the market."
Indeed, last week -- on weaker- than-average volume -- the Dow had four consecutive 100-point moves, and on Friday plunged 177 points before rallying sharply in the final hour of trading to close down 6.04.
Analysts said that because of high valuations and jitters over interest rates and the economy, the market was taking a break after a spectacular run, with bulls and bears battling for the upper hand.
"This is like a prize fight that's gone well past 15 rounds; both fighters are exhausted," said Jon Olesky, the head trader at Morgan Stanley.
Among the hardest hit this summer have been the bluest of the blue chips, companies like Coca-Cola, General Electric, Gillette and Procter & Gamble -- two of which recently warned of earnings slowdowns. G.E. -- which fell 3/4, to 64 1/8 yesterday -- is down 24 percent from its recent high. And Coke, which fell 1, to 59 11/16, is down 14 percent in a month.
Gillette fell 1 7/16, to 85 1/4 yesterday, and Procter & Gamble, the Dow's worst performer, fell 2 1/4, to 136 1/4.

HEADLINE: In Suffolk, Bok Choy and Good Wine

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: CALVERTON, N.Y.

 BODY:
With the push of a button, Jack Van de Wetering, the largest producer of greenhouse plants in the New York metropolitan region, can rotate his entire crop of 10 million plants in just one hour.
"At the height of the season, we've got about 20 acres inside our greenhouses," Mr. Van de Wetering said. "We move them inside and out on a mechanized system of wheels and trolleys, enabling us to produce three to four times more than in the old traditional greenhouses." 
 Mr. Van de Wetering, whose father, a Dutch seed grower, came to the United States after World War II, has become a leader in the agricultural revolution on Long Island, enabling Suffolk County to expand its role as the largest producer of agricultural products, based on wholesale value, of any county in New York State.
His sprawling Ivy Acres farm here on the rural North Fork of Long Island, just north of the end of the Long Island Expressway, includes 40 acres of greenhouses and research buildings and produces 65 million plants a year.
While Long Island was once known primarily for its potatoes and ducks, it now produces a variety of products, from wines and specialty foods to bok choy (Chinese cabbage) and other Asian vegetables sought by the region's growing Asian population.
"There is no county in New York State, or possibly in the United States, where agriculture is more diversified than Suffolk County," said William Sanok, an agent with the Suffolk-Cornell University Cooperative Extension Association. "It's not just potatoes and Long Island duckling anymore, but a competitive world in which farmers have been forced to produce a wide variety of high-return crops employing innovative technology."
He said that all this innovation was taking place on the eastern two-thirds of Long Island.
Despite the pressure to turn yet more of the rural East End into vacation and year-round housing, the state's agricultural census indicates that Suffolk continues to increase its agricultural output. The total value of production rose from $93 million in 1982 to well over $160 million in 1995, when the last such census was taken. The census being taken this year is expected to show even more growth, officials said.
Suffolk's farm industry generates 8,000 jobs and contributes a quarter of a billion dollars to the local economy, county officials said.
The 1995 cash receipts for crops alone totaled $146.4 million, including $17.7 million for vegetables, $3.8 million for fruit, $110.5 million for nursery and greenhouse plants and $14.8 million for field crops. Livestock and poultry receipts totaled $13.6 million, according to the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.
While potato acreage has dropped from 19,000 acres in 1982 to around 6,000, vegetable production has remained steady at around 8,000 acres. Vineyards, rare in 1982, have grown to nearly 2,000 acres. And while total farm acreage, measured at 50,000 in 1982, has dropped to around 30,000, productivity and the wholesale return per acre has increased, Mr. Sanok said.
Over the last three decades, farmers have been pressured by higher costs for land, labor, taxes and energy. They have also been affected by new laws intended to protect Long Island's environment and underground supply of drinking water. Many duck farmers chose to close down rather than install expensive sewage treatment equipment to process duck waste to reduce the pollution of nearby bays.
To beat the high cost of energy, Mr. Van de Wetering joined forces with Richard Harrison, a former engineer at Brookhaven National Laboratory in nearby Upton, to reinvent the greenhouse.
They designed a lightweight aluminum grid on wheels that moved all the plants in and out of the greenhouse at will, and robots to plant the seedlings. These and other innovations enable them to produce three times as much as the traditional greenhouse.
Dr. Andrew M. Novakovic, professor of agricultural economics at the Cornell University School of Agriculture and Life Sciences, said, "What's going on on Long Island is really just kind of an acute case of what's happening elsewhere in New York, the Northeast and the rest of the country."
The success of Suffolk farmers in finding their own niche in a changing marketplace, combined with a growing appreciation among county officials of the value of maintaining the East End's rural character, led to the adoption in 1974 of Suffolk's Farmland Preservation Plan.
Since then, the county has placed approximately 10,000 acres into permanent open space agricultural land, said George Proios, assistant Suffolk County executive for environmental affairs. The plan's ultimate goal is 20,000 acres of protected farmland.
The preservation program was among the first in the United States and has become a source of pride among agriculture officials on Long Island and in Albany.
"We see Suffolk County as a terrific role model for any community that is trying to preserve and protect is agriculture industry," said Pete Gregg, spokesman for the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.
"The fact that Suffolk has been able to do so well, despite pressures from development and other sources, says a great deal about its farm friendly attitude and actions," he said.
The Island's tourism industry has also found that it is good business to be friendly to farmers, said Dr. Pearl Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, the Island's largest business organization.
"Tourism wouldn't be as strong on the East End if you didn't have agriculture here," Dr. Kamer said. "It creates an ambiance that tourists expect. They come because they want to spend their time in a less hurried rural atmosphere."
The wine industry, which began in 1973, has brought the most significant change in agriculture to Long Island in recent years, Mr. Sanok said. It now produces about 3.5 million bottles a year, valued at more than $30 million.
The Lenz Winery in Peconic says that the North Fork is a perfect place to grow grapes for wine.
"It's the sunniest place in the Northeast and has just the right amount of breeze to ventilate the vines," said Thomas Morgan, marketing manager for Lenz. "So far this year, growing conditions have been ideal, and if we don't get any more rain until September, we'll be very happy."
While most other crops on the Island depend on some form of irrigation, the wineries would rather live without it.
"Irrigation encourages surface roots," Mr. Morgan said. "We prefer deep roots that seek out the minerals and other ingredients that make for good wine."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
As SFX Deal Is Announced, More Mergers Are Expected

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
While stepping up the rapid pace of consolidation in radio broadcasting, Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst's acquisition of SFX Broadcasting is hardly giving the industry a pause.
News of the $1.2 billion deal, which was announced yesterday, propelled the stocks of many radio companies, including those of Emmis Broadcasting, which has repeatedly declared that it is not for sale, and of Clear Channel Communications, an aggressive acquirer of stations. 
 Indeed, there is a clear sense on Wall Street that more deals are on the way in an industry that has been awash in mergers and acquisitions for more than a year. About 20 percent of the nation's 10,300 commercial radio stations are now owned by seven major companies, including Hicks, Muse, the Dallas buyout firm.
"It's no surprise whatsoever that they're up," said Bishop Sheen, a fixed-income analyst with First Union Capital Markets, said of radio stocks. "The real question is, will we get to Labor Day without another $2 billion announcement."
Hicks, Muse said it would acquire SFX's 71 radio stations, making it the leading operator of radio stations in the country, in terms of the number of stations owned, eclipsing the CBS Radio unit of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. Hicks, Muse, which already owns 241 radio stations through its various subsidiaries, including the Capstar Broadcasting Corporation, is assuming about $920 million in debt.
Shares of SFX surged $6.25, or 9.2 percent, to $74.125. Class A shares of Emmis rose $2.1875, or 5 percent, to $46.0625, while Clear Channel shares gained $1.75, or 2.8 percent, to $63.75.
Once the struggling orphan of the media industry, radio companies have become a hot commodity. Regulators in recent years have allowed owners to acquire a larger share of local radio markets, which in turn helped the companies increase their advertising revenues. All of the biggest companies in radio, including Westinghouse, Jacor Communications and the American Radio Systems Corporation, pursued SFX, which is based in New York, in the hope of strengthening their grips on mid-market cities.
A buyer until a few weeks ago, American Radio, the fourth-largest radio broadcaster, with 69 stations, has suddenly decided to switch sides and become a seller. Analysts said that the company had found it hard to compete with the larger players given its debt and the rapidly escalating cost of acquisitions.
On Wednesday, American Radio said it had hired Credit Suisse First Boston to assess its strategic alternatives, which, as one analyst said, was "code for: We're for sale." Within hours American Radio's stock soared 17 percent, to $45.625. Jacor and Westinghouse are now mentioned as possible suitors, and the stock closed unchanged yesterday at $48 a share.
"They're not aligned with one of the massive groups and they don't have the capital to pay for an acquisition," Victor B. Miller 4th, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company, said of American. "I think they decided it's time to go. The best combination for American is Clear Channel. They have no overlapping markets and they're both in the broadcast tower business."
Analysts said that Emmis Broadcasting might also follow suit and become a candidate for a takeover.
No one has embraced the consolidation trend with more enthusiasm than Hicks, Muse. Earlier this year, the buyout firm and the Evergreen Media Corporation agreed to form the nation's largest independent radio broadcaster. The combined company, the Chancellor Media Corporation, is in the process of buying 10 radio stations owned by Viacom Inc.
Much of the consolidation so far has taken place in the country's large and midsized cities. The merger and acquisition craze will now "trickle down" to smaller markets, analysts said.
Since the Federal Communications Commission eliminated many regulations governing station ownership last year, more than 2,100 of the 10,300 commercial radio stations in the nation have changed owners in deals worth an estimated $15 billion.
But the industry had been poised for a drastic change since 1991, when a recession drove down radio advertising revenues for the first time in 30 years, even as the number of stations increased. The F.C.C. raised local and national ownership limits in 1992, allowing a company to own as many as two AM and two FM stations in the same market.
Prior to that move, advertisers had regarded radio as a less effective way than newspapers or television to reach consumers. But with deregulation, companies could accumulate multiple stations in a single market and, presumably, deliver a greater audience to advertisers. At the same time, it made sense for once-tiny radio companies either to sell or to buy stations in other markets to gain size and heft.
"It's metamorphosized from a survival technique to a device that allows radio to compete more effectively with local television and newspapers," said Mr. Miller of Bear, Stearns. "Now you're seeing a hell of a lot of competition. These are not lightweight, dinky radio groups anymore."

HEADLINE: Doctors Win Pact to Run City Hospitals

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration has reached an agreement to let a private group of doctors operate a major hospital network in the Bronx, the first time that a large public teaching hospital in New York City would not be run by a private hospital or medical school.
Under the unusual arrangement, worked out in principle on Friday, the city will pay a group of about 375 doctors $253 million over three years to operate Jacobi Medical Center and North Central Bronx Hospital, which together are known as the North Bronx Health Care Network. To handle the hospital's business matters, like billing and writing checks, the doctors will use a private management company that performs the same function at the city's Coney Island Hospital in Brooklyn. 
 Most of the doctors in the group have worked for years at the two hospitals, which have been operated until recently by the private Montefiore Medical Center, and before that by the Albert Einstein School of Medicine of Yeshiva University. In June, however, the city terminated Montefiore's contract to run the two hospitals, citing poor performance, and at that point the doctors decided to form their own corporation and make a bid to run the hospitals themselves.
The contract with the doctors is the latest illustration of the increasing competitiveness in the region's health care system. The city established affiliation agreements with large private hospitals decades ago because it feared that high-quality doctors could not otherwise be attracted to its public hospitals. Both sides agreed that a contract like this one would probably not have been possible before managed care and reduced insurance reimbursements put greater economic pressure on doctors and hospitals.
In fact, one of the main reasons the city said it canceled Montefiore's contract was that the private hospital had been siphoning patients and income away from the public hospital, a growing practice in the city's hospitals, said Dr. Luis R. Marcos, president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation. That will not happen under the new arrangement, Dr. Marcos said, because the doctors will no longer be working for a private hospital.
"This has a lot of advantages for us," Dr. Marcos said in an interview yesterday. "Not only does it save us a lot of money, but it removes the incentive on the part of doctors to send patients somewhere else. And because it's the same doctors, there's a continuity of care that's important to our patients."
The agreement must be approved by the board of the city hospitals agency, which is expected.
Dr. Paul Gennis, the leader of the Jacobi/ North Central Bronx Physicians Alliance, as the doctors' group is known, said many doctors at city hospitals have long chafed under the traditional affiliation agreements with private hospitals.
"Many of us have felt for a long time that these affiliation contracts never made sense," said Dr. Gennis, chief of the emergency room at Jacobi. "When Jacobi or any H.H.C. hospital contracts with an outside entity, there's no incentive for that entity to improve the operations and business of the hospital. They just meet the letter of the contract but go no further. But the doctors in the hospital have a stake in its success, because this is where we live and work."
It will be the first time that the alliance and the private management company, University Group Medical Associates, have run a network of this size, although University Group has run Coney Island's business operations for about 20 years. Dr. Gennis said he believed that in combination with University Group, the doctors had sufficient experience to run the two hospitals, which have a total of 782 beds. Coney Island has 450 beds.
The hospitals will maintain their academic affiliation with Albert Einstein College, which will supply them with medical students and residents. The college will have no role in operating the hospitals, however, having pulled out two years ago after complaining about the city's stringent new productivity requirements.
Those requirements, which demand an increasing level of productivity from each hospital, will be in force under the new contract. The doctor's alliance can be fined if it does not meet goals in each medical department, and it will be expected to maintain the same level of care each year, although the city payments will decline each year. This fiscal year the city will pay $89.5 million; next year $83.9 million, and the following year $79.5 million. The city paid Montefiore $101 million to run the hospitals last year.
This is not the first time that the city has contracted with private groups of doctors, which already operate two smaller hospitals in Brooklyn, Coney Island Hospital and Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center. But by agreeing to such a contract at Jacobi -- which, along with Bellevue Hospital Center, is one of the two academic bulwarks of the city hospital system -- the city sent a clear message to all of its large affiliates that times have changed.
"In the past, we needed the affiliation agreements to attract good doctors, but that is not the case anymore," Dr. Marcos said. "Now, with patients at a premium, we can attract first-rate physicians on our own. And a contract like this gives us more control over the hospital, because the doctors' corporation depends on H.H.C."
The agreement is a further embarrassment to Montefiore, which has lost hundreds of millions of dollars in city affiliation fees -- and possibly lucrative referrals -- even as the city chose to hire the same doctors who have long worked at Jacobi and North Central Bronx. Montefiore officials issued a terse statement yesterday saying they planned to work with the doctors' alliance to achieve an orderly transition.
