HEADLINE: City Gets Higher Profit on Tennis Than on Baseball

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is refusing to appear at the new $254 million National Tennis Center because of a lease provision that would force the city to pay fines if jets from nearby La Guardia Airport pass over the site during United States Open tennis matches.
But when his anger recedes, Mr. Giuliani may discover that David N. Dinkins, his tennis-loving predecessor, produced a better financial deal for the city than those it has in stadium leases with the Yankees and the Mets. 
 The main difference is that while the city is ultimately responsible for maintenance costs on the two baseball stadiums, its deal for the tennis center puts those costs squarely on the United States Tennis Association.
Last year, for its two-week tournament, the tennis association paid $1.1 million in rent to the city. That nearly equaled the $1.2 million the city netted from the Yankees for the seven-month baseball season: the Yankees paid $5.1 million, but $3.9 million in maintenance costs were deducted from that sum. The city's net profit from the Mets last year was $400,000: $3.8 million in rent, offset by $3.4 million in maintenance costs.
In 1995, the tennis association paid $1 million, but the city lost $300,000 on Yankee Stadium. That year, the Mets' rent of $3.4 million exceeded the maintenance costs by just $100,000.
With the new tennis center, including Arthur Ashe Stadium, operating, the tennis association's payment is expected to rise to $1.5 million this year.
"The U.S.T.A. deal is an excellent deal for the city," Alan G. Hevesi, the City Comptroller, said. "And, for two weeks, we're getting a lot of rich folks spending a lot of money at the tennis center and filling up our hotels."
But Colleen Roche, the Mayor's press secretary, said, "That's not the issue."
The relative financial merits of the three leases are "irrelevant to the Mayor's opposition to the United States Tennis Association contract," which is based on the jet noise provision, Ms. Roche said.
The provision, which has never been invoked, would fine the city up to $325,000 if too many jets fly over the center during Open tennis matches, although flyovers necessary for safety are exempted.
The Federal Aviation Administration, not the city, controls air traffic, but the city agreed to lobby the F.A.A. to keep diverting planes over other parts of Queens during the tournament, as it has done since 1990. The Mayor has questioned the safety and fairness of the diversions.
"He cannot and will not look beyond that issue," Ms. Roche said.
The tennis association's lease calls for a $400,000 base payment, plus 1 percent of tennis center revenues over $25 million. And the tennis association pays all maintenance costs, while the city maintains Shea Stadium and reimburses the Yankees to keep up Yankee Stadium.
From 1986 to 1996, the city's Department of Parks and Recreation said, the tennis association has paid $4.4 million in rent, with no maintenance costs to offset the city's profit.
In that period, the Mets produced a $1.2 million surplus of rent over maintenance for the city; the Yankees, a $500,000 net loss.
The Yankees' payments might have been higher if not for the way the team accounts for its cable television revenues. The team divides its 12-year, $500 million cable deal with the MSG Network into several contracts, and then uses a portion of the annual MSG payment of more than $40 million, along with percentages of ticket sales, concessions and parking, to figure its city rent.
Parks Department figures show the cable portion of the Mets' and Yankees' rent payments were identical in 1994, 1995 and 1996, even though the Yankees' deal is about four times larger.
The Yankees' lease, in particular, nettles city auditors. Each year, the Yankees submit maintenance bills, which the Comptroller's Office routinely pares by several hundred thousand dollars. Some of those audits have dragged on for years.
Although the city does not maintain the tennis center, it invested $11 million to improve ramps and roads that lead to the renovated facility.
"For that, we're getting an $8 million community payment from the U.S.T.A. and access to 40-plus courts in the rest of the year," Mr. Hevesi said.
Mr. Hevesi's office calculated that the Open's direct economic impact on the city this year -- including tickets, concessions, television rights, sponsorships, hotel, retail and restaurant spending -- will be $161.3 million, slightly less than the $166 million projected for the Yankees.
Another aspect of the tennis association's deal with the city was how it financed the tennis center.
The city issued $150 million in tax-exempt industrial revenue bonds, at a rate the tennis association could not get on its own. But the city is protected from making any debt payments, which the tennis association must pay.
Mr. Hevesi said it was "not too likely" that the Yankees and Mets, which are both seeking new ball parks, would pay for their stadiums without city and state financial aid. "That would be an ideal world," he said.
So, the city will incur no debt from the tennis center, unlike the 1974-75 renovation of Yankee Stadium, for which the city must pay $1.1 million each year through 2004. No debt remains to be paid on Shea Stadium.

HEADLINE: Trying to Make Labor Work;
Can New Secretary Revive a Beleaguered Department?

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Once the teamsters strike at United Parcel Service of America was settled last week, it was hard to find Alexis M. Herman. After the initial round of triumphant news conferences on the night of Aug. 18, Ms. Herman, the new Labor Secretary who played a widely praised role in keeping the talks going when both sides seemed ready to quit, just wanted to go on vacation.
She agreed only reluctantly to her public relations chief's pleas to appear on television interview programs the morning after the settlement. She then virtually disappeared for two days last week to relax with friends and family in her hometown of Mobile, Ala., seldom checking in with her staff in Washington. 
 But even as Ms. Herman has refused to preen in the afterglow of the strike, her newfound celebrity is providing her an opportunity to advance a more progressive agenda affecting business and workers that as in the case of the Labor Department itself has languished for years in Washington's liberal backwaters. The question is whether Ms. Herman can build on her enhanced visibility and stature or whether the settlement will turn out to be the high-water mark of her career.
So what does Ms. Herman want to do with her hard-won credibility?
"I hope it will help spotlight the issues that we care about -- whether it is lifelong learning or the challenge of moving people from welfare to work or retirement security for young women and girls," the earnest Ms. Herman said in a telephone interview.
She noted how the dispute between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the company over investing U.P.S. pension funds opened a window on a wider debate. "I hope these things will get more attention because of this," she added. "Look at the attention pensions got during the strike."
But turning those lofty goals into actual accomplishments will not be easy. Ms. Herman, 50, hopes to complete the consolidation of dozens of Government worker training programs into a single system that provides vouchers that workers can use to create an individualized job education plan. She also wants to pass legislation that would simplify the creation of retirement plans for small business. And her agency is studying major new workplace safety regulations that are bound to produce conflicts between business and labor.
Whether or not Ms. Herman can turn her momentary advantage into long-term policy gains, it has been a remarkable turnaround for a woman who just a few weeks ago was engaged in an uphill battle simply to win confirmation as Labor Secretary. She was repeatedly dogged by questions about her past business associations and her political fund-raising activities in the White House.
Today, however, she is a virtual candidate for canonization, gracing the front pages of the nation's big newspapers and managing to place herself at the center of the issue of the long-term erosion of the wages and security of average American workers in a city with a notoriously short attention span.
It is far from certain that Ms. Herman's intervention in the U.P.S. battle was decisive. Forces larger than the Labor Department and the White House were driving the two sides to find a quick resolution to their costly dispute, which could have done far more damage if it had lasted much beyond its 15 days.
But, as President Lyndon B. Johnson used to say, "If they're going to blame me for the rain, I'm sure as hell going to take credit for the sunshine."
President Clinton nominated Ms. Herman, a longtime Democratic activist, to the Labor post last December. But she quickly became embroiled in the campaign finance scandal because of her contacts with donors as head of the White House's Office of Public Liaison during Mr. Clinton's first term.
Her private business dealings in the 1980's as a consultant to corporations on affirmative action, also raised questions about what some in Congress characterized as sweetheart investment deals that she may have gotten because of her political connections.
But after months of inconclusive investigation, Ms. Herman was confirmed by the Senate on April 29 and sworn in 10 days later.
Her first weeks in office were relatively quiet, as she recovered from the bruises of the confirmation fight and learned her way around the Labor Department, where she last worked in the Carter Administration as head of the Women's Bureau.
Then came the U.P.S. strike and the significant increase in Ms. Herman's public profile.
The coincidence of forces that has brought Ms. Herman to prominence this month provides her with a belated opportunity to advance the Administration's labor agenda, which has met much resistance in the Republican Congress and the business community.
Ms. Herman is crossing the country this week to highlight her priorities. She is on a five-city tour with each stop designed to showcase one of her chief agenda items.
Today she is in Seattle to speak with former welfare recipients who now have jobs about the Administration's welfare-to-work initiative.
On Tuesday, she is scheduled to tour the El Paso Job Corps program to talk about retraining workers for jobs in the information economy. On Wednesday, she is to address the problems of balancing work and family life at Honeywell Inc. in Minneapolis.
On Thursday, it is supposed to be Nashville and a meeting with workers, employers and a Girl Scout troop to talk about pension security and the importance of early retirement planning.
And she is to close the blurry week with a visit to a mine near Morgantown, W. Va., where the Labor Secretary will talk about workers' health and safety.
The priorities are little changed from President Clinton's first term. While they seem on the surface to stir only marginal controversy, former Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said he was stymied in trying to advance his ambitious agenda, particularly after the Republicans won control of Congress in 1994.
"I'm proud of what we accomplished, but there's obviously much more to be done," Mr. Reich said. "We had some advantages in 1993 that are not present today. It was relatively easy to get the school-to-work apprenticeship law enacted, as well as the first round of pension reform."
But American workers will need considerably more help in adapting to the new economy, Mr. Reich said. Persuading Congress or corporations to finance training programs will be one of the most important tasks Ms. Herman faces.
"The budget is far more constrained, the Republican dominance is more entrenched," Mr. Reich said. "On the other hand, the unions are more aggressive and possibly more popular, if the U.P.S. strike is any indication."
Mr. Reich's recent book "Locked in the Cabinet" was challenged by several critics as failing to accurately reconstruct events he witnessed. But there is little question that it captured Mr. Reich's own frustrations in dealing with Congress, the bureaucracy and even with his close friend, the President. "Alexis is perfectly positioned," he acknowledged, with some envy, "to achieve some important accomplishments."
Still, Ms. Herman could end up just as frustrated as Mr. Reich was. Among the Labor Department initiatives that Ms. Herman hopes will survive the Washington buzz saw is a new Occupational Health and Safety Administration standard on repetitive stress injuries, a rapidly growing form of workplace disability arising from computer keyboarding, lifting heavy packages and other repeated actions.
OSHA is also developing new rules on indoor air quality, including protection from secondhand smoke, that business interests complain would add to their costs. The agency has already received 115,000 public comments on the air-quality proposal, thousands more than it has ever received on a potential regulation.
Jeffrey H. Joseph, vice president for domestic policy at the United States Chamber of Commerce, said that Ms. Herman's current glow was not going to change the lineup of forces in the age-old war between business and Government.
"No matter who's there," Mr. Joseph said, "the bureaucracy carries on."
He said that Ms. Herman ingratiated herself with the teamsters and other unions by helping to settle the U.P.S. dispute in terms generally seen as favorable to the union.
"But having said that, the Department of Labor is not the department of organized labor," Mr. Joseph said. "The Secretary shouldn't be that close to unions. Remember, 90 percent of American workers don't belong to unions, and that number is rising." (Over all, about 15 percent of American workers are union members; roughly 10 percent of workers in the private sector belong to labor unions.)
Paradoxically, Ms. Herman is accused of trying to ingratiate herself with organized labor even though the A.F.L.-C.I.O. originally opposed her nomination to head the department because she was seen as insufficiently grounded in union politics and policies.
Ms. Herman's own business background and her close relationships with corporate executives and political donors at the White House also caused labor to look on her with some suspicion.
But she appears to have redeemed herself with union leaders through her forceful role in the U.P.S. strike.
Richard L. Trumka, secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the former head of the United Mine Workers, noted that unions originally supported former Senator Harris Wofford of Pennsylvania for the Labor Department job. He said that many in the labor movement were skeptical that Ms. Herman could be an effective advocate for their issues.
"Absolutely, she helped herself," Mr. Trumka said. "She showed tremendous skill and a commitment to the institution of collective bargaining. That has to make her job of helping workers a little easier."
The Labor Secretary traditionally delivers a broad-gauged assessment of the state of the American work force on Labor Day, often at a big union-sponsored event in a traditional labor bastion like Boston, New York or Detroit.
Ms. Herman chose Washington's National Cathedral as the site for her coming Labor Day speech, in a reflection of her religious upbringing and as a way to emphasize the sanctity of work, she said.
She will speak from the pulpit of the Gothic-style structure next Sunday.
"I will speak about the moral value of work, first of all," Ms. Herman said. "I was raised to believe that next to family and faith, the most important thing in our lives is the work that we do."
She added, as an aside, that she had been around Washington too long to expect the current adulation to last.
"I can only say I'm going to stay firmly focused on the future," she said. "I'm going to treat every day in this job as if it were my first day."

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
THEY tell a story in Bordeaux about Jean de Rauzan, an 18th-century owner of what is now Chateau Rauzan-Segla in Margaux, France. At some point the Marquis de Rauzan became convinced that the Bordeaux shippers were underpaying him for his wine. So he chartered a vessel, filled it with his best vintages and crossed the English Channel to London to sell directly from the ship.
Finding no takers, he announced he would toss his wine into the Thames until buyers stepped forward. He dumped a cask over the side; then another, then two more. Finally, unable to bear the waste of good wine, the crowd began to buy and, it is reported, at the Marquis's price. Over the next two centuries that sort of initiative was rare at Rauzan, although Thomas Jefferson was impressed enough during his 1787 visit to order 10 dozen bottles. 
 Most wine fans are aware that winemakers, including the great chateaus of Bordeaux, are vulnerable to weather and economic crises. But the chateaus are also hostages to the vagaries of successive owners. There is no better example of this than Rauzan-Segla. The modern renaissance of Rauzan began just two years ago, when the chateau was purchased by the Wertheimer Group, best known as the owners of Chanel, the fashion and perfume house in Paris.
At one point, it appeared that the Wertheimers were front runners in the bidding for Chateau Latour in Pauillac, one of the five first growths, which had been in British hands since 1962. But at the last moment, in June 1993, Latour went to Francois Pinault, a French industrialist, for about $130 million.
Apparently determined to buy a Bordeaux chateau, the Wertheimers -- Alain, who lives in New York; Gerard, his brother in Geneva, and Charles Heilbronn, their half-brother, also of New York -- turned to Rauzan-Segla. They bought it, almost a year later, for somewhere between $28 million and $50 million, depending on the source of the information. The sale price was not made public. Rauzan-Segla had been for sale for years, following the financial collapse of its owner, George Walker, a British investor, who bought the estate in 1988.
One of the Wertheimers' first moves was to hire David Orr as chairman of Rauzan-Segla and John Kolasa as director. Both had held similar posts at Latour and had been replaced by Mr. Pinault. Their next step was to change the spelling back. It had become at some point Rausan-Segla. When Jefferson bought the wine he called it, simply Rozan. The chateau was then owned by a Madame de Rauzan, who occasionally spelled her name Rozan.
Around the French Revolution, the estate was divided in two, when a Mlle. de Rauzan, probably a daughter of Madame Rauzan -- or Rozan -- married Pierre Louis de Segla. Another daughter married a certain Seigneur de Gassies, and their portion of the estate became Chateau Rauzan-Gassies. When the "s" appeared is unclear, but it will live on if only in the inscription over the stone archway leading to the chateau.
In the famous Bordeaux classification of 1855, Rauzan-Segla was placed just below Chateau Mouton-Rothschild, which had been designated the best of the second growths. When Mouton-Rothschild was elevated to first-growth status in 1973, the only time the classification has ever been changed, Rauzan-Segla became the first of the seconds.
The Cruse family, once-powerful Bordeaux wine shippers, owned the property from 1903 to 1956 and erected the present chateau on the foundations of two previous buildings. Over the years, a few improvements were made to the cellars and vineyards, but through most of the 20th century, Rauzan-Segla rarely lived up to its 1855 ranking. Managed for a time by Echenhauer, another Bordeaux shipper, the chateau turned out good wines in 1986 and 1988.
The rise of the so-called "super seconds" in the 1980's, chateaus like Leoville-las-Cases, Pichon Lalande and Cos d'Estournel, bypassed Rauzan-Segla, where grapes were crushed by foot and the bottling line was outside the cellar, subject to the unpredictable Bordeaux weather.
Under the Wertheimers, the vineyards have been replanted; drainage has been improved; a new press, fermentation tanks and storage cellar have been installed, and the first- and second-year aging cellars, where the wine is kept in barrels until ready for bottling, have been rebuilt. The results of this effort have shown up in the wines. Critics' ratings of the three vintages since the Wertheimer takeover -- 1994, 1995 and 1996 -- have been uniformly high.
The impact of new plantings is well in the future, but the first of the new-owner vintages have profited from rigorous selection. In previous vintages at Rauzan-Segla just about all the wine from each harvest was bottled under the chateau's label. The procedure since the chateau changed hands has been to use only the top 45 percent of the harvest for the first wine and the second 45 percent for Segla, which is the chateau's second label. The lowest 10 percent is sold off for inexpensive blends. Only financially strong properties can afford this kind of selection.
Of Rauzan-Segla's 163 acres, about 120 are planted with vines. The mix is about 65 percent cabernet sauvignon, 30 percent merlot and 5 percent cabernet franc. Having been the 19th-century equivalent of a super second, Rauzan-Segla would like to be one again. There is more at stake here than prestige. The super seconds like Pichon Lalande and Ducru-Beaucaillou can command prices as much as 20 percent higher than their less honored second-growth colleagues. There is no reason to believe that it won't happen at Rauzan-Segla with a little patience and the Wertheimers' money.
The old Marquis de Rauzan would be happy about that.

TASTINGS
Pine Ridge Winery Cabernet Sauvignon, Rutherford, Calif., 1994. About $22.
 
Pine Ridge is a member of that distinguished small group of wineries that call the Stag's Leap section of the Napa Valley home. But this cabernet, which includes 11 percent cabernet franc and 6 percent merlot, comes from Pine Ridge vineyards a little farther west in the equally famous Rutherford Bench part of the valley. Pressed, I would say that Rutherford is the St. Julien of the valley, and Stag's Leap is the Pauillac. But that can change from winery to winery and from year to year. This 1994 is a beautifully structured wine with a nice touch of wood in the nose and the taste. It spent at least 16 months in French oak and is very drinkable now. And yes, it will almost certainly age elegantly.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Mobsters and Grand Opera (Sound Familiar?)

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
Try as he might to be a likable heroic type, Laurence Fishburne has always conveyed the icy gloom of a man who has gazed into the abyss and come away with a withering sense of disgust. Mr. Fishburne's cold, lidless stare and the hard curl of his lips suggest that while contemplating the void, he whiffed a stench so foul it left him permanently on the brink of nausea.
In "Hoodlum," Bill Duke's hugely ambitious but unsatisfying gangster film about organized crime in Harlem in the 1930's, Mr. Fishburne has a role that suits his aura of implacable pessimism. As Ellsworth "Bumpy" Johnson, an ex-convict who takes over the Harlem numbers racket and fiercely defends his turf against a rival mobster, Dutch Schultz (Tim Roth), Mr. Fishburne is as coolly ruthless as Al Pacino's Michael Corleone in "The Godfather." 
 The comparison is not frivolous. With a running time of nearly two and a half hours and a sprawling cast of characters, "Hoodlum" aspires to be an urban American epic on the order of Francis Ford Coppola's masterpiece. Its vision of crime and upward social mobility is similar, as is its portrayal of government officials on the take and loyal mob lieutenants sacrificed along the way. As in "The Godfather Part III," the bloodiest shootout is staged with a grand operatic flourish (to the strains of an aria from "Tosca," no less).
But "Hoodlum" fails to evoke the tragic realism that gave the first two installments of "The Godfather" the force of social history writ in stone. Though set in New York City, it was filmed in Chicago, and you feel the discrepancy. Several key performances are also shaky. And while Mr. Duke's direction has visual panache, the movie is unevenly paced. Chris Brancato's pulpy, melodramatic screenplay laboriously underlines each dramatic turning point.
"Hoodlum" begins as Johnson is released from Sing Sing and returns to Harlem, where he becomes an assistant and bodyguard to Stephanie St. Clair (Cicely Tyson), the elegant French-speaking queen of the numbers racket. Her business is so lucrative that Dutch Schultz, a ruthless mobster and beer baron who operates under the watchful eye of the Mafia superboss, Lucky Luciano (Andy Garcia), decides to move in on her territory.
When Schultz connives with Thomas E. Dewey (William Atherton), New York City's special prosecutor against organized crime, to have her arrested and jailed, Johnson takes charge of her business, It isn't long before he is butting heads with Schultz and winning most of the skirmishes. "Hoodlum" portrays Johnson as much the lesser of two evils. Where Schultz is a psychopath who relishes humiliating his black underlings with racist epithets, Johnson sees himself as a Robin Hood protecting an enterprise that despite its illegality is a crucial economic mainstay for Depression-era Harlem.
His intentions seem honorable enough for him to be able to persuade Francine Hughes (Vanessa Williams), a beautiful, pious charity worker, to marry him. The marriage closely parallels that of Michael and Kay Corleone, as the body count of Johnson's enemies steadily rises and Francine becomes increasingly horrified by her husband's profession.
The scenes of Johnson's courtship and marriage are awkwardly shoehorned into the narrative, and Ms. Williams gives a characteristically flat, passionless performance as a wife who eventually flees a marriage that has brought her piles of jewelry. Mr. Garcia's Lucky Luciano is another weak link. The actor is too relaxed and jocular to convey the kingly pride or the tension and insecurity of being an underworld monarch. And Mr. Atherton as the corrupt special prosecutor gives one of his typically over-the-top, snake-hissing performances.
But Mr. Roth's Schultz is a compelling enigma. Wearing a fatuous half-smile and gazing through blank, hooded eyes, the actor plays Schultz as a sadistic, poker-faced madman who remains unreadable until the second he reacts, which is usually with a grinning spasm of violence. In the film's most gruesome moment, Schultz arrives at a meeting and casually deposits the severed testicles of a slain enemy on the table.
Ms. Tyson is also memorable as the self-appointed (and self-deluded) crime queen, whose fondness for tossing off French phrases and attending the opera are played as pretentious affectations. Chi McBride and Clarence Williams 3d are effective in their roles of loyal lieutenants (on opposite sides of a war), each of whom grows to loathe his boss.
As Mr. Fishburne stalks grimly through the film, you feel his character's cynicism and disbelief more palpably than any noble intentions. With Michael Corleone, at least you felt a moral choice was being made and saw its chilling consequences. When at the beginning of "Hoodlum" a prison warden releasing Johnson from Sing Sing asks him if he has read the Bible, Mr. Fishburne mutters bitterly, "It's a good book." You know he's already chosen the wrong path.
 "Hoodlum" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has scenes of extreme violence and gore and one of torture.

HOODLUM

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Edge Up, Ending Four-Session Slump

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended slightly higher yesterday, recovering from early weakness as an auction of new two-year notes was well received. But trading was thin again yesterday, exaggerating the price movements.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 8/32, to 96 17/32, ending a four-session slump. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.64 percent, from 6.66 percent on Monday. 
 Yesterday's gains came despite strong economic reports. While the Commerce Department reported yesterday that orders for durable goods fell six-tenths of 1 percent in July, orders actually rose three-tenths of 1 percent when excluding transportation goods.
Other reports also showed signs of economic strength. Existing-home sales rose 2.2 percent in July, to an annual rate of 4.24 million units, pointing to continued robust demand in housing. And the Conference Board's consumer confidence index jumped to 129.1 in August from 126.3 in July, a demonstration of buoyant consumer mood and outlook.
The signs of strength provoked some hesitation at first in the bond market, as investors worried that such strength could herald a pickup in inflation and a response from the Federal Reserve. But analysts saw little in the data to change their view that inflation remained contained.
"The economy continues to advance at a healthy clip with few signs of sustainable inflationary pressures," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst with Chase Asset Management. "Durable goods appear to be on a moderate, sustainable upward path, a clear indication of the economy's forward momentum."
The next significant economic report, Mr. Fine said, will be the revised gross domestic product report for the second quarter, which is due out tomorrow.
"The Fed appear to be in no rush to move to a less accommodative monetary policy stance, although it is clearly remaining vigilant by maintaining a bias toward tightening," Mr. Fine said. "But the bond market recently has been slowly inching from a neutral Fed stance to one that encompasses the possibility that the next Fed move could well be a tightening."
In other words, the market is pricing in a rate increase by the Fed.
With the Treasury selling $15.5 billion of new two-year notes at auction yesterday, the market was vulnerable to supply pressures as dealers positioned themselves ahead of the auction. Dealers often cause rates to rise ahead of an auction to make the issue more attractive to investors and insure its quick distribution.
But Treasury securities edged higher into the afternoon after the two-year note auction, which saw the new issue awarded at the high yield of 5.998 percent.
Today, the Treasury will auction $11.5 billion of new five-year notes. Ahead of the auction, dealers were offering the new notes at a price to yield 6.23 percent, which is the yield traders expect will be awarded at auction.
Short-covering by investors betting against the market also helped sustain the gains. Short-covering rallies occur when when some market participants sell borrowed securities, hoping to buy them back later at lower prices, thereby pocketing the difference. But if prices begin to rise instead of fall, these participants have to buy back securities to limit their losses.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Against Mark On Concerns on Rising Rates

BYLINE: By Bridge News 

 BODY:
The dollar plummeted to a five-week low against the mark yesterday because of continued concerns that the German central bank will raise interest rates soon despite opting not to do so yesterday.
The dollar weakened against the yen because of concerns about increased trade tension as a key United States trade official visits Japan. 
 The dollar initially rose after the German central bank, the Bundesbank, said that it would keep the securities repurchase rate at 3 percent, but soon reversed course with currency traders selling in waves. Higher interest rates typically lift a nation's currency because a rise in rates increases the value of some assets in that country. Investors were concerned that even though the Bundesbank left rates steady, it might raise them soon because of a report yesterday that German inflation was running at a higher-than-expected rate.
"The market had generally expected a relief rally after the Bundesbank announcement, but players took it as an opportunity to sell," said John Rothfield, an international economist at Nationsbanc-CRT.
The dollar was quoted in late New York trading at 1.7953 marks, down from 1.8205 late Monday. It was the lowest level since July 21 and left the dollar down 5 percent from a nearly eight-year high of 1.8832 on Aug. 5. The dollar settled at 118.18 yen in New York, down from 118.79.
The dollar weakened against the yen on concerns that trade friction between the United States and Japan, driven by Japan's rising trade surplus, could flare anew. That belief was fanned by news that Wendy Cutler, the assistant United States trade representative, was in Japan for talks. Ms. Cutler said she would discuss "the entire range of our trade agenda" with the Japanese, though she declined to comment on whether she would express disappointment with attempts by Japan to deregulate its auto parts market, an area of particular disagreement.
Increasing trade tensions with Japan typically cause currency traders to sell the dollar against the yen because they believe that the United States may alter its policy of supporting a strong dollar if Japan continues to run a large trade surplus with the United States.

HEADLINE: Janet Good, 73; Advocated the Right to Die

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
Janet Good, a longtime civil rights worker who cooperated with Dr. Jack Kevorkian to help terminally ill people die, ended her own life yesterday in her home in suburban Detroit. She was 73.
Mrs. Good had suffered from pancreatic cancer and said she hoped not to die as her mother had, slowly and in great pain. As it was, Mrs. Good confounded her doctors, who had expected her illness to take her life by early 1996. 
 "My time, obviously, is not quite here," she said in an interview late last year. Yesterday, she decided it was, said a person familiar with her decision and who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
At a news conference in Southfield, Mich., Dr. Kevorkian's lawyer, Geoffrey Fieger, asked the authorities not to pry into the circumstances of Mrs. Good's death.
And while Mr. Fieger declined to confirm that Dr. Kevorkian was present when she died, he said, "Janet Good is no more the victim of a homicide than anyone else who has died in association and in the presence of Dr. Kevorkian."
In recent years, Dr. Kevorkian has become well known for assisting in dozens of suicides. He has been tried but acquitted several times, and Mrs. Good became his top assistant, helping him screen those seeking help to die and consoling their survivors.
She said she was proud to have been indicted in late 1996 on charges of assisting in a suicide. "I was almost offended when I wasn't charged last time," she said. The indictment was later dropped because of her deteriorating health.
Dr. Kevorkian's name was hardly known in 1989, when Mrs. Good started the right to die movement in Michigan by founding a chapter of the Hemlock Society in her living room. The chapter now has several hundred members.
In June 1990, Dr. Kevorkian asked her if he could use her house for the very first assisted suicide.
Although she agreed at first, she later declined after conferring with her husband, Ray, a retired Detroit police commander who thought the deed might be illegal.
"The doctor called me every name in the book," Mrs. Good recalled later.
But they mended their differences, and in May 1996, after her husband had changed his mind, she allowed Dr. Kevorkian to use her home to help end a life.
After her own illness was diagnosed, she said her belief in a right to die had come naturally, in part because of her mother's suffering. "I have worked for civil rights and women's rights and human rights for many years, and this seemed to me just another right we should have," she said.
A native of Detroit, Mrs. Good worked for the State of Michigan, processing unemployment claims.
In the 1970's, she led a successful drive to make sexual harassment illegal in the state, a triumph that won her election to the Michigan Women's Hall of Fame.
She was also honored by the Log Cabin Society, a gay Republican group, for consoling AIDS patients and their families.
Survivors include her husband of 55 years; a son, Michael, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; a daughter, Marjorie Helmling, and a sister, Margaret Moran, both of Detroit; six grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. Her oldest daughter, Donna Ungar, died in 1995.

HEADLINE: Show Them The Money;
New York's Financial District Is a Must-See Tourist Destination

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
Wall Street is booming, and tourists are flocking to New York in record numbers. Until recently, one apparently had nothing to do with the other.
Yet lower Manhattan is now swarming with camera-carrying tourists, whose brightly colored T-shirts and shorts contrast vividly with the suits and stripes that otherwise abound downtown. That is because increasingly, these tourists are in town to visit the financial district. 
 They are making reservations weeks in advance to see the $140 billion in gold ingots stacked in the Federal Reserve Bank of New York's vault, posing for pictures in front of the big bronze bull on Broadway and lining up weekdays as early as 8 A.M. to snag one of the 3,000 tickets given away to see the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.
To meet the rising demand, the Federal Reserve opened a $750,000 visitors' gallery last month. The New York Exchange is finishing a $2 million remodeling of its decades-old tourist center and has extended its hours so that 700,000 people a year can pass through. The American Stock Exchange, which sacrificed its visitors' mezzanine years ago to make way for a new trading floor, is studying ways to build a new one. Even the obscure New York Mercantile Exchange spent $1 million for an exhibit hall and two public viewing galleries at its new waterside headquarters in Battery Park City.
At the Museum of American Financial History, a small, 10-year-old institution whose exhibits run to 200-year-old bonds and 19th-century stock certificates, a surge in attendance led to a move in April from the space around back where it had paid no rent to the front of the old Standard Oil Building at 26 Broadway.
And Heritage Trails New York, a nonprofit group that gives walking tours of lower Manhattan historic sites, added a weekly World of Finance tour this summer and quickly sold out through Labor Day. The tour, on Wednesday mornings, has been extended indefinitely, said Alexia Lalli, the executive director. It includes a stop outside Delmonico's, which the guide describes as the 19th-century birthplace of the power lunch.
Recently, Mike and Jane Strojny, accountants and financial planners from Biloxi, Miss., devoted a full day to their pilgrimage, stopping at the New York Exchange with their daughter, Jennifer, after seeing the gold vault beneath the Federal Reserve. Mr. Strojny said that staring down at the trading floor was as exciting as going to the Statue of Liberty.
"It actually is a place," Ms. Strojny marveled after watching the tumult. "It's not telephoned in, it's not computered in. It's sort of like watching history happen."
The financial institutions say they are getting into the tourism business not to make money but to burnish their image. "The merchandise we sell is there because people want something to take home," said Robert Zito, a spokesman for the New York Exchange, which has a gift shop that sells everything from women's scarves with the exchange's logo to bull-and-bear paperweights. "It's not a profit center by any means."
Tourism and financial officials tick off several explanations for the bull market in bull-market tourism, including the heightened attention the media pays to the Dow Jones industrial average and the popularity of the Stock Market Game, a nationwide stock-picking simulation in which 650,000 schoolchildren now participate. But basically, they say, it derives from the same phenomenon driving the expansion of the stock market itself: the tens of millions of Americans who have recently begun investing through mutual funds or through Individual Retirement Accounts, pensions and 401(k) plans.
"With the market going as well as it has, and people in the 90's putting their money in a lot of different financial vehicles, they're coming to New York and going downtown to see either where their money is going or where it's coming from," said Stephen J. Morello, president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. He added that the trend was particularly interesting because none of the financial institutions has done much promotion at all.
On the blocklong line outside the New York Exchange the other day Sam Harold, 12, a sixth grader from San Pablo, Calif., said he was in New York to check on his first investment. He bought shares in Hasbro, the toy maker, six months ago, he said, and when he flew to New Jersey to visit his grandmother he asked her to take him to New York so he could watch his money at work.
"I just want to see it, to see the stuff that happens on the floor," he said.
Behind Sam and his grandmother were Jake and Jeanne Rosen, evangelical ministers from Creve Coeur, Mo., with their children, Aliza, 11, and Josiah, 13. The Rosens have invested in a college fund for their children, but it was at Josiah's urging that they were visiting the market. "I want to be a stockbroker," he said. "I think it'd be fun."
If authenticity is what tourists want, the new attractions downtown may be lacking, or at least one-sided. Nowhere in the New York Stock Exchange's visitor center, for example, does the word "crash" appear. The terms "robber baron" and "monopoly" are used only in passing at the Financial History Museum's exhibit on the financing of the nation's railroad empires. And the Federal Reserve's exhibits, which portray inflation as a flame-breathing dragon, tend to provide only one answer for every economic quandary: Tighten monetary policy.
Yet reality does present itself, in the form of the gravel-voiced floor traders sucking on cigarettes on the sidewalk next to the line of visitors, and the middle-aged man on the Mercantile Exchange floor who "busted out" as a speculator, according to the guide, and now looks dejected in his lowly role as a clerk.
Young Sam Harold, emerging from the New York Exchange on a day when the Dow average dropped, conceded that his shares of Hasbro had dipped a dollar since he bought them.
But the 12-year-old said he planned to be a long-term investor, so he couldn't worry too much. Besides, he was having too much fun.

HEADLINE: Chicago Hails District As Symbol of Gay Life

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Whether their families came to America buoyed by hopes or bound by shackles, chasing a fortune or a factory job, or just searching for a place to worship in peace, Chicagoans remember their roots. And they stick together.
While not as ethnically segregated as it was even a decade ago, Chicago is still a big city of many little nations. A drive along Halsted Street, for example, seems like a leap across continents: the maps of Ireland on the faces in Canaryville, the joyous sounds of Mexico on the sidewalks of Pilsen, the grit and fire of the spirit of Africa in the churches and dance halls of Englewood. 
 Cultural identity is considered such a treasure in Chicago, in fact, that city planners in recent years have used ethnic pride as a key element in a billion-dollar project to beautify and revitalize old neighborhoods, posting signs and banners to proclaim local heritage in such places as Greektown and Chinatown.
The latest neighborhood to be celebrated, a vibrant commercial strip along North Halsted Street, will have its own special symbol: towers ringed with the universal colors of the gay pride rainbow.
Civic recognition of a largely homosexual neighborhood, coming in a tradition-minded place like Chicago, a city that customarily reflects a more conservative, Midwestern view on social mores, is a profound example of the growing acknowledgment of gay life as part of the American cultural fabric.
"This is a first in the country," said Mark Johnson, a spokesman for the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force in Washington, saying that no other city had formally promoted a neighborhood for its homosexual culture.
The move follows the passage of a domestic-partner law in Chicago earlier this year, endorsed by Mayor Richard M. Daley, which extended certain benefits to the same-sex companions of city workers.
"You would expect this in San Francisco or New York, but not Chicago," said Mary Lake, a 40-year-old lesbian who manages the Brown Elephant, a nonprofit secondhand store on North Halsted. "What this says is just wonderful. It is a recognition that we, as gays and lesbians, are a culture, a culture that has something to celebrate."
Less than 20 years ago, Chicago police officers were raiding bars frequented by homosexuals, and sometimes beating gay men. And the old Democratic machine, controlled by the legendary Richard J. Daley, was known to conduct whispering campaigns about the rumored homosexuality of political foes.
These days, under the leadership of Mr. Daley's son, the Democratic Party in Chicago routinely endorses political candidates who are openly homosexual. Larry McKeon, the Mayor's former adviser on homosexual issues, was elected to the Illinois Legislature last year with the backing of the Democratic Party.
"The gay issue represents the most striking difference between old Mayor Daley and his son," said Don Rose, a campaign manager who has worked for many liberal Chicago political candidates.
Not only does Mayor Daley have an adviser on matters of concern to homosexuals, a post currently held by Mary Morten; the Police Department, too, has a liaison to the gay community, Lori Cooper, a patrolwoman who is a lesbian. For all the changes, Chicago is hardly a paradise for gay people. Homosexuals are still the targets of physical attacks, and bigots still scream slurs from passing cars in gay neighborhoods.
"When I lived in Seattle, I would never think twice about holding hands with my girlfriend in public," Ms. Lake said. "In Chicago, there are only a couple of neighborhoods where you would feel comfortable doing that."
But cultural openness is making stereotypes more difficult to sustain. The television actress, Ellen Degeneres, showed millions of Americans that a lesbian could be the girl next door.
Here in Chicago, a city that lives and breathes sports, the basketball star Dennis Rodman has surely caused some second thoughts about sex roles. Big and tough, with a blue-collar persona, Mr. Rodman is just the kind of Chicago-style, toughest-cat-on-the-block dude that men here respect. But he likes to wear dresses and feather boas.
"In some of the tough Chicago neighborhoods, Dennis Rodman has done more than anyone to change the image of sexual identity," Mr. Rose said.
In the city's celebration of the North Halsted neighborhood, there is surely some measure of appreciation to the gay community for cleaning up Dodge.
"Before gays started moving in," Ms. Morten said, "this place was a dump."
Sometimes called Boys Town, the neighborhood had been at the center of homosexual life in Chicago for more than a decade, transforming a down-at-the-heels, gang-ridden place into a district so prosperous that many homosexuals can no longer afford to stay.
In the view of many gay and lesbian Chicagoans, North Halsted has become passe, just as the rainbow banners in pink, red, yellow, blue, green and violet will rise to proclaim it the epicenter of homosexual life in the city.
These days, the hottest neighborhood for gay men and women is Andersonville, farther north along Lake Michigan. Andersonville is home to one of Chicago's most cutting-edge restaurants, Tomboy.
In signs and banners along Clark Street, Andersonville promotes itself as a Swedish-American neighborhood. In truth, the vast majority of Scandinavians left before most of the hip, young crowd was born.
The movement of gay people to the Andersonville neighborhood meant one thing to Greg Marvin, 30, a real estate developer.
"When gays start moving in, buy!" said Mr. Marvin, who is heterosexual. "They keep things up. They don't make trouble. What more could you want from a neighborhood?"
Not everybody was thrilled about the city's designation of the Halsted neighborhood. Paul Caprio, the director of Family-PAC, a conservative political action committee, called the comparison of a gay neighborhood to Greektown and Chinatown "an insult to those great communities."
The Rev. Charles Lyons of Armitage Baptist Church accused the city of choosing to "wallow in the slime of moral decadence by celebrating perversity."
But in general, there was little opposition to the move to recognize the gay neighborhood. John Olson, 37, was one of the few homosexuals who expressed cynicism over the city's plan.
"It's all aimed at gay yuppies," said Mr. Olson, who wore a tattered sport coat. "What about the homeless people lying in alleys, gay and straight? This is all about money."
But judging from the views of dozens of homosexual Chicagoans, the city's celebration of a gay neighborhood was nothing short of wonderful.
Bill Amo, a 52-year-old Chicagoan, said it was heartening to see younger homosexuals coming into a world without a sense of shame and guilt.
Two decades ago and more, he noted, most bars that catered to homosexuals did not have windows, or had very small windows, because almost nobody wanted to be seen.
With a smile, he pointed to a nearby bar that had an American flag over its doorway, designed with the colors of gay pride, and great big windows.
"Nowadays, you go into a gay bar and people want to sit in front of the window," he said. "It's a great view out there."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Consumer Optimism Bolsters Growth Outlook
Reports hinted that consumer spending could remain strong for the rest of the year, driving further strong economic growth.
The Conference Board reported that its consumer confidence index rose to 129.1 points this month from 126.3 in July, bouncing back near the 28-year high seen in June. Orders for durable goods eased by six-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Government said, but analysts saw underlying strength in the report. Yet another report showed that sales of existing single-family homes rose in July. [Page D2.] 

Military Contractor to Be Sold
United Defense, a maker of armored military vehicles, is changing hands; its joint-venture owners, FMC and Harsco, accepted an $850 million bid from the Carlyle Group, a leveraged-buyout firm. [D2.]
 
Much at Stake With New Chip
In a top-secret project code-named Merced, Intel and Hewlett-Packard are designing a computer chip that would mark the most significant shift in the history of the immensely popular Intel microprocessor family. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Another Decline for the Dow
Stock prices drifted lower again as blue-chip issues continued to flounder in what has become a stalled bull market. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 77.35 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 7,782.22. [D8.]
 
Treasury prices, however, ended a string of four straight declines, recovering from early weakness as an auction of new two-year notes was well received. The 30-year bond yield fell to 6.64 percent from 6.66. [D6.]
 
The dollar plummeted to a five-week low against the mark because of continued concerns that the German central bank will raise interest rates soon despite opting not to do so yesterday. [D7.]
 
Toyota Pact Lifts Republic Stock
Shares of Republic Industries surged 7.5 percent following the announcement that the company, the nation's largest car dealership owner, had reached an agreement with Toyota. Republic's shares had been in a slump since the spring, when Toyota and Honda began to battle Republic's plan to buy car dealerships nationwide. [D2.]
 
Canadian Insurers Lock Up Deal
Great-West Lifeco, Canada's largest group life and health insurer, said that it had raised its offer to buy London Insurance and that the companies had signed an agreement to prevent other bids, superseding an earlier agreement between London Insurance and the Royal Bank of Canada. [D8.]
 
Battle Over a Memoir
The publishing house of William Morrow is battling with Whitewater prosecutors over an unfinished manuscript for a memoir by the fallen Justice Department official and Clinton confidant, Webster L. Hubbell. [A1.]
 
Union Alliance Expected
The Union of American Physicians and Dentists, one of the few independent doctors' unions, plans to announce that it will join forces with the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. [A18.]
 
Managing Different Risks
Richard L. Huber, the new chief executive of Aetna, is known as a wizard of the corporate comeback. But his turnaround efforts extend beyond his business life: Mr. Huber and his wife, Roberta, live in a troubled Hartford neighborhood that is miles from the lush suburbs where most of the city's business elite have settled. And he has bought almost one-fourth of the buildings on his street, in a crusade to clean things up. [A1.]
 
A Hot Tourist Tip
The stock market has been booming, and tourists are coming to New York in record numbers. Until recently, one trend apparently had nothing to do with the other. But now visitors from Main Street and elsewhere are increasingly flocking to Wall Street. [D23.]
 
Corn and Soybeans Lower
Prices for corn and soybeans fell sharply amid indications that the crops seem headed for bumper harvests. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Israeli Closing of Bethlehem Brings Tensions to a Boil

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG 

DATELINE: BETHLEHEM, West Bank, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Black smoke billowed from burning tires and the crack of rubber bullets echoed through the streets of Bethlehem today as dozens of Palestinian youths hurled stones at Israeli soldiers to protest Israel's military closing of the town, which has now lasted nearly a month.
The clashes reflected rising frustration among Palestinians at Israeli sanctions imposed after the suicide bombing in Jerusalem last month. 
 As the stones and rubber bullets flew, there were fresh disputes between Israeli and Palestinian leaders over whether Yasir Arafat was doing enough to meet Israel's key demand -- that he clamp down on Islamic militants to curb their violence.
Mr. Arafat said today that he had restored security cooperation with the Israelis to an extent that could enable Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright to go ahead with a planned visit that is intended to shore up flagging peace efforts. But his assertion was immediately contested by the Israelis, who accused Mr. Arafat's Palestinian Authority of encouraging the street protests against the closing.
While the Israelis insist that the Palestinians have not done enough on security cooperation, Ms. Albright has not made complete cooperation a condition for starting her first official visit to the Middle East, and such a visit is now expected in the second week in September.
The West Bank and Gaza Strip have been closed off from Israel since the July 30 bombings in the Mahane Yehuda market in Jerusalem, which killed 14 people in addition to the two attackers. The closures have paralyzed the Palestinian economy, preventing tens of thousands of laborers from reaching jobs in Israel and causing heavy losses to Arab businesses.
Although movement between West Bank towns has been restored after initial restrictions, Bethlehem remains under an Israeli blockade, closed off by checkpoints and barriers of dirt and concrete. Israeli military officers say that the measures are part of an effort to track down militants in the area who may be linked to the Jerusalem bombings, and that vital supplies such as food and medicine are being allowed in.
But Bethlehem's Mayor, Hanna Nasser, accused the Israelis of trying to choke off tourism to the town, which is revered by Christians as the birthplace of Jesus. Mr. Nasser said the blockade had already caused losses totaling more than $12 million.
Anger over the protracted closing has boiled over into street protests that began on Saturday and continued today on the outskirts of town near an Israeli outpost at Rachel's Tomb, the traditional burial place of the wife of the biblical patriarch Jacob.
Lieut. Gen. Amnon Shahak, the Israeli Army's Chief of Staff, warned that there was increased potential for a major eruption of violence in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, but not before Ms. Albright's visit.
"I don't think that an explosion is imminent in the next few days," General Shahak said. "I think we're all waiting for the arrival of the Secretary of State.
But undoubtedly there is tension and an accumulation of angers and pressures and a reality that can lead to an explosion."
The frustration was on display in Bethlehem today, where masked youths, some of them using slingshots to fling their stones, charged in waves at Israeli soldiers.
Standing behind coils of barbed wire, the Israelis responded with volleys of tear-gas and rubber bullets. Hospitals reported four people wounded, and a Palestinian policeman was also reported to have been hit. Dozens of schoolgirls were evacuated for treatment when soldiers aiming at stone-throwers fired tear-gas into a schoolyard.
Palestinian police officers made little effort to restrain the rioters, expressing open support for their protest.
"This is a popular response to the siege and starvation," said one officer as he looked on. "When you blow too much air into a balloon, it pops."
Mohammed Fawaghra, a restaurant worker who watched the clashes, said his establishment down the street had no customers because of the closing and the street violence. "Everything's at a standstill," he said. "There's no money, and no work. They're punishing two million people because of a bombing by two people whose identity isn't even known." Israeli officials have yet to establish who the suicide bombers were, where they were from and who sent them.
But in an appearance on Israeli television, the Israeli Cabinet secretary, Danny Naveh, accused Mr. Arafat tonight of failing to combat Palestinian militants and encouraging street riots.
"The Palestinian Authority has yet to do the main thing -- fulfill its obligation to fight the terrorist infrastructure," Mr. Naveh said.
As for the protests in Bethlehem, "it is street violence guided from above by the Palestinian Authority," Mr. Naveh asserted. "This is certainly not what one would call improved security cooperation."
Israeli and American officials have said that improved intelligence sharing by the Palestinians is a condition for further progress in political negotiations.
On a visit to Japan on Monday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that Mr. Arafat had failed to move against Islamic militants, and that his recent public embrace with leaders of Hamas and Islamic Holy War at a gathering of Palestinian factions could be a "kiss of death" to peace efforts. In a statement issued today, Hamas said said it had rejected a call from the Palestinian Authority to suspend attacks.
At the entrance to Bethlehem this afternoon, scores of Palestinian laborers who had skirted an Israeli checkpoint to get to jobs in Jerusalem trekked back from work on dirt paths, bypassing the Israeli roadblock on the way back to town.
They were determined to earn their daily wages, risking arrest and possible beatings by Israeli border police if they were caught in Israel.
"We want to live," said one young man as he walked home.

The isolation was imposed after a suicide bombing in a Jerusalem market last month. (Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SENATE MEASURES WOULD DEAL BLOW TO INDIAN RIGHTS

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Aug. 26

 BODY:
With little debate and no public hearings, a Senate subcommittee last month approved two measures that would knock out some of the oldest principles in how the country's 554 American Indian tribes are governed and deprive them of basic operating money if they do not agree to the changes.
Little noticed in the nation's capital at the time, where they were buried as riders on a spending bill already freighted with the fate of the National Endowment for the Arts and money for new park lands, the proposed changes have caused a furor on the reservations. 
 The tribes say Congress is trying to erode their sovereignty because of a perception that Indian reservations are prospering with casino gambling, disregarding the fact that most of them remain among the poorest places in the nation.
The architect of the two riders, Senator Slade Gorton of Washington, a Republican who has had a running dispute with Indians in his home state for 25 years, says the measures are part of a campaign to force a fundamental change in Indian affairs.
"I find nothing in any Indian treaty that says they must be continuously supported by the Federal taxpayers," Mr. Gorton said in an interview. Mr. Gorton is chairman of the Appropriations Subcommittee on Interior and Related Agencies, which passed a $13 billion spending bill last month that contains the Indian riders and many provisions dear to the Clinton Administration.
Bracing for a showdown, the Clinton Administration has threatened to veto the bill if it contains the Indian measures. Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt called it "one of the most radical and unjust of a stream of recent Congressional proposals" and said it would "overturn almost two centuries of jurisprudence."
One of Mr. Gorton's riders would force tribes to waive sovereign immunity from civil lawsuits or lose up to $767 million, nearly half the budget for daily operations on land that 1.4 million Indians live on or near. Under the other rider, tribes could be denied Federal money if their income was above a certain level.
Without sovereign immunity, the tribes say, they could face bankruptcy by lawsuits and would be unable to operate as governments. And subjecting them to income requirements, or what the government calls means-testing, would be singling them out, they say, because other city and state governments do not have to go through such tests for their share of Federal money.
"If Senator Gorton would ever be willing to come to a reservation, he would see very clearly that most tribal governments are barely getting by as it is," said John Blackhawk, chairman of the Winnebago tribe of Nebraska. "These two riders are outrageous. They are a total departure from the government-to-government relationship the tribes have always had with Washington."
Mr. Babbitt has said he would recommend a veto if the riders are left in the bill, but both items are entwined in a package that contains $100 million to keep the National Endowment for the Arts alive and $700 million for evironmental purchases, like a gold mine that threatens Yellowstone National Park and a huge grove of ancient redwood trees that could be logged in California.
"I'm defending them on the N.E.A. and land acquisition," Mr. Gorton said, "so it would not behoove the Administration to come after me on these issues."
The only Indian in the Senate, Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell, Republican of Colorado, said the measures would only be passed "over my dead body."
Sovereign immunity and basic Federal operating funds are not subject to shifting political winds, Mr. Campbell wrote in a letter to Mr. Gorton, but are "a result of solemn promises made by the United States to tribal governments in exchange for Indian lands."
When the full Senate takes up the Interior spending bill next month, Mr. Gorton and his supporters are counting on the fact that 17 states have no recognized tribes within their boundaries. Also, Mr. Gorton said, it may be time to force a significant change in the longstanding status that tribes have had as nations within a nation.
"The irony is that the very concept of sovereign immunity is descended from English Common law," he said. "And it's an anachronism."
Indian governments, as well as Federal and local agencies, often invoke immunity to guarantee that projects like sewage systems or road construction go ahead without the threat of financially crushing lawsuits. Individual Indians can be sued in Federal court, but the tribes themselves are generally protected.
The tribes say they are under assault by Mr. Gorton and others in Congress because of a perception that they are getting wealthy from casino gambling, which in turn has brought some flexing of newfound political muscle.
"This is straight out an attempt to get rid of tribal governments," said John Dossett, general counsel for the National Congress of American Indians. "In order to do that, Gorton and others are playing off a perception that a whole bunch of tribes are getting rich off gaming. In fact, only a handful are making any money at it."
A report in December by the General Accounting Office found that 10 tribes took in more than 50 percent of the $1.6 billion received by Indian reservations from tribal gambling. About one-third of all American Indian tribes have gambling centers. Unemployment on the reservations is more than three times the national average, and 38 percent of all Indian households with children ages 6 to 11 are below the poverty level, more than twice the national average.
Supporters of Mr. Gorton's measures say they resent the power that Indians have over non-Indians on or near reservations. They say it is difficult for someone who is not an Indian to win redress in tribal courts.
"By being able to claim immunity from suit, tribes are not fully accountable in court for their actions like all the rest of us in America are," said Barbara Lindsey, president of a property rights group in Washington state, in a recent statement sent to Mr. Gorton. "It is simply not fair for us to be denied our constitutional due process rights while the tribes can sue us at will."
The Indians say Mr. Gorton has longstanding animosity toward the tribes that dates to his fight against Indian fishing rights in the Pacific Northwest. As Washington's attorney general in the mid-1970s, Mr. Gorton argued and lost a landmark Supreme Court case, known as the Boldt decision, in which Indians were found to have a right by treaty to take up to 50 percent of all the salmon caught in the waters of the Northwest.
"It's my opinion, shared by many of my colleagues around the country, that Slade Gorton has a vendetta against the tribes," Mr. Blackhawk said.
As Mr. Dossett put it, "Clearly, he's on the most wanted list."
In 1995, Mr. Gorton led an effort to cut $200 million from the $1.7 billion budget for Indian tribes.
"He's an Indian-fighter," said Darrell Hillaire, vice chairman of Washington's Lummi tribe. "This agenda is really just Slade Gorton's agenda. And he's counting on the ignorance of the rest of Congress to get it through."
The Lummi, a small tribe with a salmon-fishing culture, were behind the effort to win fishing rights two decades ago. They have since been singled out by a legislative rider Mr. Gorton inserted on an Interior bill several years ago that would have deprived the Lummi of 50 percent of their Federal operating money if any tribal action had an adverse affect on non-Indians.
This week, the Lummi tribe closed its casino near the Canadian border, saying it was losing too much money.
"Before, he was just going after one or two tribes, but now he's launched a broad attack on all the tribes," Mr. Dossett said. "As a result, Indians have stopped being able to accomplish anything positive in Congress and are just fighting all these defensive battles."
Asked about the tribal accusations of a personal vendetta, Mr. Gorton said he had won more cases in the Supreme Court against Indians than he had lost and did not feel a need to even the score. They are angry at him now, he said, because he is trying to break up an old system that many Indians have grown too comfortable with.
"Crying racism is the last refuge of a group of individuals who can't argue on the merits," Mr. Gorton said.
The tribes are particularly angry that on a matter that could so radically change the nature of Indian governments, there have been no hearings, no debate, no field trips to reservations.
"We see this as an abrogation of treaties," said Debra Doxtator, chairwoman of the Oneida Tribe in Wisconsin. "We gave up vast amounts of land in return for sovereignty and certain obligations by the Federal Government.
"Now they want to throw that out," she said. "It would be devastating to us. Yet, we aren't even consulted."
Mr. Gorton said he thought his riders would prevail when the full Senate takes up the spending bill. But he said that even if they did not pass he would continue to use his position as chairman of the committee that oversees spending for the tribes to overhaul Indian affairs.
"These are matters of principle for me," Mr. Gorton said. "Indians are citizens of the United States. They should be governed by laws of the United States as everyone else is."

HEADLINE: A Very Personal Investment in a Blighted Hartford Street

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Richard L. Huber, the new president and chief executive of Aetna, is a Harvard-educated multimillionaire who owns a stake in a 7,000-acre ranch in the upper Amazon, another in Paraguay, a pied-a-terre on Riverside Drive in Manhattan and a beach house in Stonington, Conn.
Mr. Huber's home, however, is a Hartford neighborhood around the corner from a methadone clinic, a couple of blocks from homeless shelters, down the street from a crime-ridden housing project and miles from the lush suburbs where most of the city's business elite have settled. 
 Imagine George M. Steinbrenner living in a restored brownstone in the South Bronx and you begin to get an idea of what Mr. Huber has done.
But Mr. Huber, 60, a corporate turnaround wizard, not only lives in this struggling neighborhood on the edge of downtown Hartford, he also has bought almost one-fourth of the buildings on his street, Charter Oak Place, and has embarked on a crusade to turn things around.
Neighbors describe Mr. Huber and his wife, Roberta, as a two-person urban renewal team. The Hubers took several rundown buildings and spruced them up. They moved out tenants who appeared to be dealing drugs and recruited new ones with solid professional and blue-collar jobs, not to mention a state trooper who parked his cruiser on the block.
Their commitment, in the minds of some Charter Oak Place residents, helped end a decline in property values that saw condominiums that had sold for as much as $160,000 in the heady 1980's bottoming out at under $40,000 a few years ago.
"If they hadn't moved here, the street would be entirely different," said Jim Wade, a consultant with the State Education Department who rents a $475 one-bedroom apartment across the street. "Whatever you think about them, they saved it."
Mr. Wade said the neighborhood even has a new name: "Huberville."
But not everyone is impressed.
"Living in the neighborhood is not good enough," said Luz Santana, a member of Vecinos Unidos (United Neighbors), a Hispanic community group. "More than him living here, we would like the resources of Aetna to be in the neighborhood. They have a lot more to offer and to give us back."
In the 1950's and 60's, the long-gone group of insurance and bank executives who helped run Hartford with a sense of noblesse oblige were known as "the bishops," and no bishop was more respected than the head of Aetna, perhaps the insurance capital's most venerable company.
But Mr. Huber disputes those who call him a bishop for the 90's.The 1990's are not the 1960's, and the company is unlikely to be the economic and civic presence that it was in the so-called golden days, he said. In those days, Aetna helped initiate projects like the Hartford Civic Center, to which it brought the Whalers, a National Hockey League team. The Whalers left town a few months ago, however.
A self-made man who has been an architect of Aetna's downsizing, Mr. Huber makes no claim of altruism or civic virtue. His reason for living where he does is strikingly personal. Having spent his adult life in some of the world's most sophisticated cities -- Tokyo, Rio de Janeiro, Chicago, Boston and New York -- he said he had no desire to live in the suburbs. Two years ago, when he was recruited to work at Aetna, he could not imagine living anywhere but downtown Hartford, even if it lacked the cosmopolitan airs of his previous homes.
"We're city folk," he said in an interview at his 125-year-old gothic Victorian home, dismissing the idea that he was using his house to make a political statement. "I don't want to overplay this, this was a personal choice. We like to live this way."
The Hubers, who have three grown sons, wanted to be able to walk to Hartford's theaters, restaurants and art museum, and Mr. Huber, who is fluent in Spanish and Portuguese, likes to hear languages other than English. The couple had not owned a car in the 18 years before they moved to Hartford, and Mr. Huber reluctantly bought a 1995 Ford Contour so he could drive to the supermarket a few miles away.
The Hubers' purchase of four properties on a street that runs one-fifth of a mile was "enlightened self-interest," he said, noting that it had never been his plan to become a landlord. Soon after moving in, he saw problems in the neighborhood that could affect his home, ranging from a social service center's plans to take over one building to late-night activity by neighbors that looked like drug dealing.
"The only way you're going to control it is if you own it," he said.
Mr. Huber brushed aside talk of crime, though he made sure the door was locked. ("My wife kills me if I don't," he said.) Only last year, a shooting took place on the corner, and when Mr. Huber moved here two years ago, nearby abandoned buildings were being used as crack dens. While crime has dropped substantially in Hartford during the last year, prostitutes could still be seen on a street corner a block away Monday night.
Mr. Huber said that friends and colleagues were nervous about going to his house when he gave his first parties. "They wondered whether they should come in armored cars," he said with a laugh, adding that they were only reassured when they left and discovered that their tires had not been slashed.
In this city of 125,000, Mr. Huber's decision to live here was seen as an important sign that, like the South Bronx, the city's worst times have passed.
In recent years, Hartford was the fastest-shrinking city in the country, losing a greater percentage of its population than any other major city, and it has repeatedly been ranked among the country's 10 poorest cities. Charter Oak Place, with its Victorian-era gothic and Queen Anne-style homes, has reflected the city's changing fortunes.
In the late 19th century, it was where the city's industrial barons lived (among Mr. Huber's properties is an old mansion owned by Richard Jordan Gatling, who invented the precursor to the machine gun). But by the 1970's the street had fallen into disrepair, its houses subdivided into apartments. With the boom of the 1980's, an effort began to return the block to its previous grandeur and turn it into a historic district, with condominiums for professionals.
The crash of Hartford's real estate market in the late 1980's cut that effort short, and when Mr. Huber came to Hartford in 1995, the street was in a precarious position. The family that had restored the Hubers' home had moved to New York and had taken it off the market after no buyers emerged.
Mr. Huber bought the five-bedroom house for $275,000, already furnished, a fraction of the initial $695,000 asking price in 1988.
The move surprised many.
Paul Shipman, an aide to Mayor Mike Peters, remarked that the city has a lot of boosters who live outside its borders. "It's great to have someone in that position of influence be a city resident," he said. "It sends a message."
A neighbor, Tracy Dalenta, a 24-year-old store manager for Casual Corner, a woman's clothing store, said she moved to Charter Oak Place a few months ago, and calmed her in-laws' concerns about crime by saying, "Don't worry, the guy who runs Aetna lives across the street."
Before going to Hartford, Mr. Huber was a top executive at Citibank, Continental Bank, Chase Manhattan and Wasserstein Perella. Many of his jobs involved overseeing operations and deals in Latin America.
He was not initially interested in working for Aetna. At the time, he said, he did not want to do any more turnaround work, he did not want to work for an insurance company and he did not want to go to an "old mill town on a river."
But upon learning more about the company, Mr. Huber changed his mind, taking the job of vice chairman. Last month he was promoted to chief executive and president. And while he has not exactly become a Hartford booster (he complains that there's no dry cleaner nearby and that it still feels like a small town), he said he has found a good wine shop nearby, and he and his wife have clearly become civic leaders.
Mr. Huber serves on the board of the Mark Twain House and Trinity College, two of the leading institutions in the redevelopment of Hartford, and Mrs. Huber is active at the Wadsworth Atheneum, the city's art museum, and the Greater Hartford Arts Council.
He is an idiosyncratic businessman who would rather go on archeological digs than play golf. He and his wife collect Latin American art from the 17th and 18th centuries.
He is on vacation this week in the remote areas of Argentina and Paraguay looking at the ruins of centuries-old Spanish missions. He does not hesitate to say what he thinks.
And while he declines to pronounce upon some grand vision for Hartford, he readily admitted that he hoped to recoup the investment he had made.
Asked whether he was gentrifying the neighborhood, he answered: "I sure hope so. No city ever came back without attracting a group of middle and upper middle class people to live in the city."
