HEADLINE: Military Contractor Sold to Buyout Firm

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The FMC Corporation and the Harsco Corporation said yesterday that they had agreed to sell United Defense L.P., a joint-venture manufacturer of tanks and other armored vehicles, to the Carlyle Group, a leveraged-buyout firm, in a transaction that seems to have as much to do with politics as economics.
FMC and Harsco, which respectively own 60 percent and 40 percent of United Defense, accepted the Carlyle offer, worth $850 million, even though the companies reportedly received a higher bid worth $1 billion from the General Dynamics Corporation. 
 Analysts said FMC decided not to accept the higher bid after Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania and a member of the Judiciary Committee's antitrust, business rights and competition subcommittee, promised to examine the anticompetitive aspects of a combination of United Defense and General Dynamics.
General Dynamics management "told us their higher bid would not be accepted because FMC would not have the stomach to go through an antitrust fight," said Peter Asiritis, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston.
Pat Brozowski, an FMC spokeswoman, declined to comment on the bidding process, which began in mid-May.
Norine Lyons, a spokeswoman for General Dynamics, which also makes armored vehicles, said the company was "definitely interested" in acquiring United Defense. "We did not think there was an antitrust problem here," she said.
Senator Specter, who had not previously expressed an interest in the continuing consolidation of military industries, acknowledged in a telephone interview that the fate of 1,200 United Defense workers in York, Pa., was much on his mind.
Analysts said it was highly likely that had General Dynamics been successful in acquiring United Defense, it would have phased out the York plant and shifted production to plants in Ohio where it already builds tanks and other armored vehicles.
"With the downsizing of the defense industry and mergers of a lot of defense contractors, we need to keep as much competition out there as we can," Senator Specter said. He added, "I want to keep those jobs in York."
United Defense, which was formed in 1994 by combining FMC's military systems group with Harsco's BMY combat systems division, employs 5,700 people at 10 manufacturing and service sites in the United States and abroad. Last year, the company had sales of $1 billion.
Effectively, General Dynamics, which makes steel armored vehicles, and United Defense, whose products are manufactured principally with aluminum, have maintained a business duopoly. That condition will remain unchanged.
Still, analysts wondered what Carlyle -- which buys and sells businesses, rather than managing them -- would do with United Defense.
"Our objective is to grow the business either through internal growth or acquisitions, and then over time to exit through a private sale or potentially through a public offering," said Alan Holt, a managing director.
Carlyle, whose chairman, Frank C. Carlucci, served as Secretary of Defense in the Reagan Administration, is no stranger to military contracting.
The group, which is based in Washington, owns the Aerostructures Corporation, a maker of wings and tail sections for commercial and military planes that it purchased from Textron; a 51 percent interest in the Howmet Corporation, a big manufacturer of turbine-engine components for jet aircraft and gas-turbine engines, and a 30 percent stake in BDM International, a multinational information technology company that provides computer and technical services to private and Government clients, including the Defense Department.
United Defense is probably best known as the manufacturer of the United States Army's Bradley fighting vehicle and armored personnel carriers.
"United Defense has some very unique products, a strong base of contracts and a fairly solid future for those contracts," Mr. Holt said.
Mr. Aseritis said he had no problem with the price Carlyle was paying for United Defense, or with that company's business prospects. But he did have questions about Carlyle's interest in United Defense.
"They are not a strategic buyer who will integrate it with another business," he said. "They are a financial intermediary. I can't envision who they will sell this to in a year or so. Maybe they will try to resell it to General Dynamics for more than $1 billion."
If that is the case, he added, perhaps Carlyle thinks it could gain leverage in Congress for the approval of such a sale with the help of its prominent connections.
In addition to Mr. Carlucci, former Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Richard G. Darman, a former budget director and Deputy Treasury Secretary, are affiliated with Carlyle.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Rises As Economy Displays Vigor

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Not only does the economy keep bounding ahead this summer, new reports hint that it will not falter for the rest of the year.
The Conference Board reported today that its index of consumer confidence rose to 129.1 points this month from 126.3 in July, bouncing back near the 28-year high seen in June. And the percentage of those considering jobs plentiful, nearly 38 percent, reached a new peak. 
 "Latest readings suggest no danger that the economy will stall during the final quarter of 1997," Lynn Franco, a Conference Board official, said in a statement accompanying the report.
The Government, meanwhile, reported that orders for big-ticket items from jet engines to camcorders eased six-tenths of 1 percent in July, but analysts found that the overall decline masked some underlying strength.
Orders for the key category of nonmilitary capital goods other than aircraft surged 5.3 percent. Gary E. Schlossberg, an economist at Wells Capital Management in San Francisco, called the increase "quite strong." Capital goods are closely watched because they are needed to produce other products; an increase suggests that strong consumer demand is expected.
Such vigor, Mr. Schlossberg contended, is another factor pointing to an eventual tightening of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve. "It certainly increases the risk that the Fed will be moving toward the end of the year to push interest rates up a notch," he said.
Another set of statistics today showed that the housing market revived last month after a June lull, with sales of existing single-family homes advancing 2.2 percent, to an annual rate of 4.24 million. Strength was concentrated on the East and West Coasts, where there have been reports of bidding wars among buyers.
"Many people took advantage of low interest rates and a robust economy to make large purchases, such as a home," said Russell K. Booth, president of the National Association of Realtors, which compiles the report.
Finally, the Government's monthly report breaking down employment conditions by state and metropolitan area confirmed that labor markets are tighter than at any time since the mid-1970's. This tally showed, among other things, that 17 states -- most of them in the Midwest -- had unemployment rates below 4 percent in July, with Nebraska's 2.4 percent the lowest.
The national unemployment rate was 4.8 percent last month.
The Conference Board's report on consumer confidence, based on a sample of 5,000 households, showed that six of the nine geographic regions posted increases, with New England advancing smartly and the mid-Atlantic states, where confidence is lowest by a wide margin, eking out only a small gain. Confidence fell in the Mountain, Pacific and eastern North Central states.
The overall decline in orders for durable goods, those designed to last at least three years, followed an increase of 2.9 percent in June, which was revised from 2.3 percent. The total value of orders in July was $180.5 billion, as expected.
Orders for computers and other electronic equipment and for transportation equipment were lower last month, while industrial machinery and primary metals were higher. The weakness in commercial aircraft surprised some analysts in light of large orders announced by Boeing recently.
Still, Rosanne M. Cahn, an economist at Credit Suisse First Boston, called the latest data highly favorable. "Call it more of the 'just right' economy," she said. "It's not too strong, and it's certainly not too weak."
July's home resales, the realtors' report showed, left 2.13 million on the market, a six-month supply at the latest sales pace, down from 6.8 months as recently as May.
"This is a market that is performing very efficiently but is not overheated" despite the spirited competition for some homes, said Paul Taylor, senior economist for America's Community Bankers, an industry group.
The national median price for home resales was $126,500 last month, 4.1 percent higher than in July 1996, but the Northeast lagged with a gain of just 2.1 percent compared with figures from the previous year.
The July sales gains were 8 percent in the West and 5 percent in the Northeast, with the South showing no change. Sales fell 1.8 percent in the Midwest.

HEADLINE: In South African Beer, Forget Market 'Share';
A 14-Brand Monopoly Takes 98% of Sales

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 26

 BODY:
South Africa is a capitalist country, but it sometimes doesn't act like one. Once a year, for example, an announcement is made that recalls the way Communist states once decreed increases in the price of bread or heating oil. Here, however, it is the annual change in the price of beer.
The dictum does not come from a Government ministry, but from a company, South African Breweries Ltd., that can do so without fear of contradiction because it is virtually a monopoly. It sells about 98 percent of South Africa's beer. It is not uncommon for a bartender, asked what beers he pours, to reply: "All of them." He means all 14 S.A.B. brands, from the local leaders, Castle and Lion, to the Heineken, Guinness, Amstel and Carling Black Label brands that the company brews under license. 
 Valued by the market at $10 billion, S.A.B. is the continent's largest industrial company -- in a category that excludes the huge mining houses and insurers. The company also owns more hotels and retail stores than any other enterprise and dominates the soft-drink and fruit juice market.
But what makes South African Breweries truly noteworthy is how it defies the stereotype that monopolies are sluggish and inefficient. It is considered one of the best-managed South African companies. It is certainly one of the toughest competitors.
The company's beer production costs are the world's lowest. And it keeps price increases below the inflation rate, so the real cost of a beer, before excise taxes, has been halved in 20 years.
Moreover, in a country generally slow to take to affirmative action, S.A.B. has been in the forefront of racial advancement -- though not out of a sense of charity. About 93 percent of its beer customers are black, and in the volatile early 1990's, its trucks venturing into black townships were hijacked and firebombed as a way to strike back at the white-ruled state. So S.A.B. lent dozens of its black drivers the money to buy trucks, trained them in running small businesses and hired them as contractors. The firebombing stopped. Now it has many blacks in middle management, and other companies poach its talent.
South African Breweries understands its market well. On a continent where most people survive on subsistence farming, commercial brewing is the one industrial process that is found in every country -- and survives every calamity. The Primus Beer brewery in Kisangani, Congo, kept working throughout the civil war there. The Mutzig brewery in Kigali, Rwanda, was the first industry rebuilt after the genocidal conflict there. And the Club brewery in Monrovia, Liberia, was guarded by foreign peacekeeping troops throughout Liberia's civil war.
The biggest brands of South African Breweries are pale yellow lagers, not unlike Budweiser or Miller High Life in taste, but with a relatively high 5 percent alcohol content. "Their customers like that bite in the back of the throat," one analyst said. (The taste of darker beers like Samuel Adams and Dos Equis is not particularly popular here and such beers do not play much of a role in the company's portfolio.)
A powerful brand-builder, South African Breweries is the biggest sponsor of soccer, cricket and rugby. It has also spent $15 million supporting schools and clinics. That may be relative peanuts for a company its size, but few South African corporations do anything for the poor.
Flush with cash -- it had a pretax profit of $740 million on sales of $8 billion in its latest fiscal year -- it is expanding aggressively overseas, buying breweries in Tanzania, Zambia, Botswana, Uganda, Poland, Hungary, Romania, Spain and China. It is, by volume, the world's fourth-largest brewing operation after Anheuser-Busch, Heineken and the Miller Brewing unit of the Philip Morris Companies.
In South Africa, which Pepsi-Cola has abandoned, the company bottles both Coca-Cola and Schweppes. It owns both of the top fruit juice brands, bottles spring water and owns 30 percent of the two biggest makers of wine and spirits.
It also owns 64 hotels, including the Holiday Inn and Intercontinental franchises, and 1,500 stores selling groceries, clothing, furniture and appliances, including the Edgar's, Sales House, Jet, OK Bazaars and Hyperama chains, some of the country's biggest. And it makes auto glass, matches, razors, textiles, laminate board and shoes, dominating some of those smaller industries as it does beer.
Its earnings per share have increased with almost boring regularity every year since 1967. Lacking competition, it can essentially decide how much profit to make, and in its annual report, the graphs for its beer business, 70 percent of earnings, never zigzag, but rise in a gentle, steady curve.
Being a monopoly is not exactly an embarrassment, said Graham Mackay, group managing director, but he did confirm what a bartender at the company's amusing beer history museum said: S.A.B. sometimes helps out the local breweries who share the remnants of the market.
"We certainly try not to stomp on them," said Mr. Mackay, who serves as chief executive. "We like having some competitors around -- really just for cover, if nothing else."
South Africa has virtually no antitrust laws, and the present monopoly was created by the merger of two competitors in 1979. Nonetheless, Mr. Mackay said, the company is constantly having to defend itself against "quite spurious allegations that we must have got where we are by illegitimate means." He calls the market "fully contestable," with no legal barriers to entry.
Analysts agree about the legal framework, but say big foreign brewers are simply, and probably sensibly, scared away. Against serious competitors, S.A.B. hits back hard, and it would cost hundreds of millions of dollars to match its computer-controlled breweries, truck fleets and advertising.
Moreover, South Africans have high per-capita consumption and fierce, conservative brand loyalty. "In the mine hostels, where you have 10,000 men, you can't even make a tiny change on the label," said Johannes Letsapa, an owner-driver delivering beer in Soweto. "They say: 'It's different. We don't want it. Give us the old bottle.' "
Pepsi's experience, said Kerry Clarke, an analyst at Fleming Martin, a brokerage house, "was a bit of a lesson." Pepsi just walked away after an expensive attempt to get back into southern Africa. S.A.B.'s Coca-Cola division matched Pepsi's every move, increasing advertising, cutting prices and enlarging its bottles from 1 liter to 1.25.
Both Anheuser-Busch and Miller Brewing have studied the market and stayed out, said Chris Gilmour, an analyst with Smith Borkum Hare, a Merrill Lynch affiliate.
Representives of both American companies confirmed that they sell only tiny amounts of beer here, do not advertise and have no plans to expand. Budweiser and Miller can be found here, but only as novelties in yuppie pubs and liquor stores.
Twenty years ago, Mr. Gilmour said, Whitbread Breweries of Britain took S.A.B. on and "failed miserably." For example, it introduced a beer named Colt 45 after the American malt liquor. S.A.B. promptly came out with Stallion 54, confused the market and grabbed the niche.
No one has accused the company recently of any illegal competition-crushing behavior. But Michael Fridjhon, a lawyer and author of "Conspiracy of Giants," about the beer, wine and liquor industry, said the company "played it incredibly dirty" in the past. Years ago, he said, when the South African currency, the rand, was stronger, local retailers tried importing Carlsberg to sell at a lower price than local brands. Suddenly, Mr. Fridjhon said, the S.A.B. deliveries to those retailers halted as trucks "mysteriously broke down." The store owners got the message and dropped the imports, he said, though no accusations "ever got near a courthouse door."
Mr. Mackay insists such episodes never happened. "It's the kind of urban legend we hear all the time about what the mighty S.A.B. would do if crossed," he said. "It always evaporates on examination." Mindful of its delicate position, the company has a code of conduct, he said, and any depot manager behaving in such a way "would simply be fired."
The company is engaged in a nasty advertising war with next-door Namibia Breweries, which sells Windhoek lager and has a fraction of the top end of the market. Windhoek is made in compliance with 16th-century German brewing laws, using only hops, barley and water, and its makers sneer at S.A.B. for adding corn, sugar, preservatives and foam stabilizers. S.A.B. says its consumers like its beer just fine.
S.A.B. wants to build breweries in Namibia and attack Windhoek at home, but says the company has pressed the Namibian Parliament into raising taxes on imports and forbidding a foreign brewery.
In its expansion plans, South African Breweries is taking the opposite tack from American brewers. It is avoiding well-served markets in Western Europe and Japan, and concentrating on the developing world, which is full of rundown state-owned breweries for sale cheap. It is not trying to sell Castle and Lion overseas, but to buy local brands -- obscurities like Safari, Kilimanjaro, Zambesi, Vultur, Snowflake and Ursus -- make them at lower cost, sell more and collect the revenue better.
S.A.B. insists on having control, on having local partners and on including a financial institution like the World Bank -- not because it needs the financing, Mr. Mackay said, but because the bank's presence helps keep the host government honest.
The company is also working to protect its flanks at home. Robin McGregor, a critic of South African monopolies, admires the company's efficiency but says its beer could be even less expensive. "They always boast about being below the consumer price index," he said. "That's great, but they could be considerably lower."
The Competition Board, which Mr. McGregor recently joined, is about to embark on a 12-month investigation of the liquor industry, which is dominated by a few companies. "We could recommend that they be broken up, like AT&T," he said. "Or say that they mustn't do their own distribution. Or conclude that they are one of the world's most wonderful companies, and we should do nothing -- though I doubt that."
Mr. Mackay rejects the AT&T comparison, pointing out that the phone giant was a regulated monopoly. "We would resist vigorously" any attempts to break up the company, he said.
"I think the days in which that was seen, in simple-minded fashion, as the answer to any economic ills, are way past," he added, perhaps hopefully. "I don't think you'd find a broad consensus for doing that kind of thing even in the States these days."

HEADLINE: Firm Discloses Talks With the S.E.C.

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc. is talking with the Securities and Exchange Commission to resolve the agency's possible legal action over its role in the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., in 1994.
The S.E.C. has "authorized an action" against Rauscher Pierce as well as a current and a former employee over $880 million in Orange County bond offerings, the company said in its quarterly report filed with the S.E.C. 
 The firm, a unit of Interra Financial Inc., said it was seeking a resolution before the agency files an action in the United States District Court of California.
Rauscher Pierce was among a number of securities firms that sold bonds for Orange County, which deposited the proceeds into the county's investment pool. The county declared bankruptcy in December 1994 after losses in the pool mounted when it made wrong-way bets on interest rates.
The filings were first reported today in The Wall Street Journal. The S.E.C. declined to comment.

HEADLINE: DEFECTING ENVOY FROM NORTH KOREA TO GET U.S. ASYLUM

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
The United States announced today that it would grant political asylum to North Korea's Ambassador to Egypt, his brother and their families. Officials said American intelligence agents had spirited them out of Egypt and brought them to this country over the weekend.
The Ambassador, Chang Sung Gil, is the highest-ranking North Korean to seek political asylum in the United States. While the Clinton Administration said little publicly for fear of upsetting delicate negotiations with North Korea, senior officials described the defections as an intelligence bonanza for the United States. 
 As head of the embassy in Cairo, one of the North's most important postings, Mr. Chang was familiar with his Government's dealings in the Middle East, especially its sale of missiles and other arms to Egypt, Syria and Iran, the officials said. The sales to Iran, in particular, have been of concern to the United States and allies in the region, including Israel.
The fact that Mr. Chang defected to the United States -- and not to South Korea, as others have -- means that the Central Intelligence Agency will be the first to interview him, without having to work through the filter of South Korea's intelligence services.
Mr. Chang's brother, Chang Sung Ho, also a diplomat, served most recently as the trade attache at North Korea's mission in France. The Ambassador's wife is an actress who, one official said, had close ties with the leadership in Pyongyang, including North Korea's top leader, Kim Jong Il. Officials declined to disclose her name, citing security concerns. The South Korean press identified her as Choe Hae Ok.
The State Department announced the defections one day before delegates from the United States and North Korea are to meet in New York for a third round of talks about missile proliferation.
In those talks Washington has pressed the North to accept international restraints on exporting missiles and missile technology. American officials say they expect to discover at the talks on Wednesday whether the defections will produce any diplomatic fallout.
[North Korea demanded on Wednesday that Washington hand over the Ambassador and his brother, who it said had defected to avoid punishment for embezzling public funds and leaking state secrets, Reuters reported. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said the brothers had been dismissed in late July and ordered home for investigation.
["Any individual or authority that conceals or protects the criminals will be considered to have been involved in their crimes and will be made to bear due responsibility," the official Korean Central News Agency quoted the spokesman as saying in a report monitored in Tokyo.]
 Just last week the State Department announced that it had imposed new economic sanctions on North Korea for the "missile technology proliferation activities" of two companies. The two companies were accused of exporting components that could be used in missiles. The penalties are only symbolic, though, because the United States has no trade with North Korea.
The State Department's spokesman, James P. Rubin, declined to provide more than the sketchiest details of the defections and the Administration's decision to grant asylum. He would not discuss how the diplomats had left Egypt.
He did say the episode should have little effect on the missile talks in New York or on the "four party" talks that the United States, China and the two Koreas are to resume next month. Those talks are a forum for negotiating a formal peace treaty to end the Korean War.
In recent years, as North Korea's increasingly isolated Government has faced economic collapse and political uncertainty, it has suffered scores of defections to South Korea, most of them through China or other third countries.
Mr. Chang, 48, served as Ambassador in Cairo for three years. He was apparently only a month away from returning home when he appeared at the United States Embassy in Cairo on Friday seeking asylum, American officials said. He previously served in the Foreign Ministry, reaching the rank of Deputy Minister.
The officials said Mr. Chang and his brother, who left Paris with his wife and two children earlier, apparently had coordinated their defections.
The United States has not yet officially granted asylum, but rather a temporary status, known as parole, that is the first step toward asylum. The officials said the Koreans would receive full asylum as soon as necessary legal steps were taken.
The senior official said Mr. Chang might have feared punishment when he returned to Pyongyang, perhaps because he had failed to persuade Egypt to provide more emergency food aid. The Government in Pyongyang has desperately sought aid to cope with starvation brought on by the economic decay and by recent floods, followed now by a drought. In addition, South Korean reports said his son had earlier defected to the West, and presumably he would have faced punishment for that.
Mr. Chang is North Korea's first Ambassador to defect, although lower-ranking diplomats in Africa defected in 1991 and 1996.
The most senior North Korean to defect was Hwang Jang Yop, a former member of Pyongyang's ruling council and an early mentor to Kim Jong Il. He sought asylum in Beijing in February and, after a brief stop in the Philippines, arrived in South Korea in April. He defected after attending a conference in Japan, where he failed to obtain food aid.
Mr. Hwang has since warned that his country is preparing to wage war against the South, but officials in Washington have played down his comments, saying he had not been in a position of power in recent years.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up on Rate Outlook From Germany and Japan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most leading currencies yesterday on expectations that interest rates in Germany and Japan would not rise soon.
The dollar gained against the mark after a member of the German central bank's policy-making council, Hans-Jurgen Kobnick, said there was no immediate need to raise rates. 
 The dollar increased against the yen after a top finance official in Japan expressed concern about the state of the economy there.
"There was a lot of dollar buying on the note that the Japanese economy is still weak and interest rates will stay low," said Jeffrey Yu, senior currency trader at Sanwa Bank. "And with the German economy still very sluggish, I don't think they could justify a rate rise in Germany."
Late in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 118.88 yen, up from 118.18 Tuesday. It traded at 1.8025 marks, up from 1.7953. But it eased against the British pound, which rose to $1.6148 from $1.6147.
In an interview with The Financial Times, Eisuke Sakakibara, Japan's vice finance minister for international affairs, said, "I am more concerned about the economy than I was two months ago." That contrasted with more optimistic assessments by Japanese officials earlier this year.
His remarks suggested that the Japanese economy was not recovering fast enough to prompt the central bank to raise record low interest rates.
The dollar received help against the mark as some traders wagered that Germany's central bank would hold off on a rate increase.
"The last thing they need to do is raise interest rates," said Doug Lee, a corporate currency trader at Sakura Bank.
But the dollar pared some gains against the mark in afternoon trading after another Bundesbank council member, Helmut Hesse, suggested that the bank might defend the mark by raising rates or selling dollars if the dollar rose too far, too fast. "If the dollar climbs to 1.90 marks or more, the Bundesbank will act," Mr. Hesse said in an interview with the Dow Jones news service.
"His comments beat the dollar up pretty good," said Paul Spirgel, senior currency trader at the Royal Bank of Scotland.

LENGTH: 629 words

HEADLINE: Looking Back in Central Europe

 BODY:
"When Americans say something is history, that means it's irrelevant," the Polish journalist Konstanty Gebert likes to say. "When we say it, it means just the opposite." The Communist past is still very much present in Poland and Germany, which have recently taken controversial measures to punish Communist officials and collaborators. Germany's conviction of three East German leaders for shootings at the Berlin wall and Poland's new law to bar secret-police collaborators from government jobs raise questions about both nations' commitment to the rule of law.
This week a Berlin court convicted three members of East Germany's Politburo of responsibility for shooting deaths between 1984 and 1989. The former security chief, Egon Krenz, was sentenced to six and a half years. Two others will serve three years. None had any role in writing the laws, but prosecutors argued they had been told of shootings and had praised border guards who killed fleeing citizens. About 100 people have been tried for such shootings. Defense officials were convicted for writing the laws, and some border guards have received short or suspended sentences. 
 Like many other trials of former East German officials, these have been legally questionable. Many politicians and legal scholars see them as ex post facto justice, punishing people for acts that were not criminal when committed. German courts have ruled that the border policy was so unjust that an exception can be made. While international law would make such an exception for crimes like genocide, few scholars would say that border shootings qualify. But if highly indoctrinated young border guards have been convicted, their leaders should be held responsible as well.
Poland has just instituted a screening law designed to keep people who collaborated with the Communist secret police out of government jobs. The law requires top government officials and political candidates to declare whether they were informers. Later, a panel of judges will review the secret police files. Those who lied will be barred from office for 10 years.
The law is somewhat better than the controversial screening law in the Czech Republic. The Polish law will allow judges to take into account whether people were forced to inform by threats to themselves or their families. But it echoes many of the injustices of the Czech version. The screening judges in Poland must be approved by the justice minister, which could lead to a repeat of the politicization that occurred in 1992. That year a right-wing Government gave Parliament a list of 64 politicians supposedly named as informers in the files. A parliamentary investigation found that the list contained the names of many government opponents -- including Lech Walesa -- but in only 10 of the 64 cases was there real evidence of collaboration.
That episode also revealed that the files are full of holes. They contained signatures of supposed informants forged by secret police recruiters, who needed to meet a quota. Other people in the files who were pressured into collaborating gave the secret police no harmful information.
Before the screening courts start their work, the Polish Government must devise mechanisms to deal with the ambiguities of collaboration and the flaws of the files. But it should also ask why it is still worrying about informers. Poland is right to continue to prosecute Communist-era criminals, such as those who shot protesters. But informing was not a crime, and bad behavior under Communism is no longer any guide to whether a person is a market-oriented democrat today. Poles who worry that informers are sabotaging their nation should contemplate the spectacular progress Poland has made toward political and economic health.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

COUNTRY: GERMANY (96%); POLAND (96%); EUROPE (92%); UNITED STATES (92%); CZECH REPUBLIC (92%); CENTRAL EUROPE (91%);

HEADLINE: 4 Rocks on Mars Confound Scientists With Unexpected Elements

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
In the first major surprise of the mission, mineral studies by the little roving vehicle on Mars have revealed at least two distinct kinds of rocks on the planet, and neither bears a clear resemblance to volcanic rocks on Earth or meteorites presumed to come from Mars, scientists reported yesterday.
The findings have left planetary scientists confused, waiting for more data and looking for explanations of how the rocks were formed and what they imply about the planet's geologic history. Project officials said that both the Mars Pathfinder spacecraft and its rover Sojourner appeared to be in good health. 
 Of the four rocks so far examined in detail at the landing site, two contain much higher amounts of the common element silicon than are present in Mars meteorites, and the other two have more sulfur than is found in terrestrial volcanic rocks. Yet, all four rocks give the appearance of being volcanic.
Dr. Thanasis Economou, a University of Chicago geochemist who is a member of the Pathfinder science team, also said there were puzzling differences in composition between the soil and rocks at the site. The soil contains chromium not present in the rocks, and much higher concentrations of sulfur and chlorine. But silicon and aluminum are more abundant in the rocks.
"So far, it's a problem," Dr. Economou said at a news conference at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., where the mission is directed. "There seem to be two distinct rock populations at the site, but we can't explain any of the differences."
Other geologists suggested several possible explanations. Perhaps the rover's spectrometer for determining surface chemistry was detecting only dust coating the rocks, not the rocks themselves. The dust, a mixture of material from far and near, could yield puzzling chemical traces. Or the sulfur concentrations, geologists said, could be a sign of past water reactions.
Another Chicago geologist, Dr. Robert Clayton, said in a telephone interview: "I don't know what it means. But if you take the analysis at face value, it means Mars geology is a lot more complicated than we previously thought. It makes Mars an even more interesting planet."
As a specialist in meteorites, Dr. Clayton determined from trapped gases that the meteorite ALH84001, which landed in Antarctica, came from Mars. Scientists a year ago reported possible evidence of signs of past life in the Martian meteorite.
Dr. Clayton said that it was not clear how the chemical differences between the rover's samples and meteorites could be reconciled. He defended his research on the Martian origin of several meteorites, but conceded that he must now "keep an open mind" on whether they are indeed Martian.
Among the new photographs made public yesterday were views of clouds visible just before sunrise at the landing site. Scientists said the wispy clouds contained icy water particles and had a blue tint.
Despite communications problems and other minor setbacks, project scientists said, the remote-controlled rover is ready to complete the analysis of several more rocks in the next week in a boulder-rich area nicknamed the Rock Garden.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As scientists puzzled over the latest rocks inspected by the Sojourner rover, others marveled at a Mars sunset image from NASA television. (NASA via Associated Press)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Slip a Bit In Light Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities dropped slightly in light trading yesterday. Still, bonds' price levels continued to attract buyers, despite a poor Treasury auction of new five-year notes.
"The market is in the last throes of summer vacations and the impact on trading cannot be emphasized enough," said David Ader, director of fixed income for Technical Data. "Conditions are very thin. There is a tremendous amount of apathy, and as a result a lot of volatility. The weakness we've experienced has made the auctions easier to digest and brought in some interest." 
 Yesterday, the price of a 30-year Treasury bond fell 1/32, to 96 16/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.65 percent, from 6.64 percent on Tuesday.
Bonds rose early in the day, bolstered by carry-over buying from Tuesday and by a firmer dollar. The only negative, according to John Canavan, a market analyst with Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, was speculation that the German central bank might raise some interest rates.
"It added some pressure to bond prices in the morning," Mr. Canavan said, "which fell further on the results of the auction."
The Treasury auctioned $11.5 billion of five-year notes yesterday, and the notes were awarded at the high yield of 6.253 percent, more than the 6.23 percent that had been expected.
Some analysts said the auction might have suffered from investors' reluctance to buy ahead of economic data to be released this week and next, including today's report on revised second-quarter gross domestic product and weekly labor data.
The auction, Mr. Canavan said, "shot us down to the day's low."
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of fixed income at J. W. Charles Securities of Boca Raton, Fla., said yesterday's session was no different than those preceding it.
"What we're seeing in the market is a classic case of interest-rate paranoia," he said. "You have people sitting on edge of their seats, waiting for one bad number to come along. The disappointing note auction was not the real reason the market sold off, but it probably gave investors the impetus to sell.
"Market participants are from the old school and it's hard for them to believe that the economy can grow with low unemployment and little inflation. So everyone is waiting for something to happen. This is as good as it gets and we should accept it and revel in it."
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new five-year notes:

HEADLINE: NORTH KOREANS QUIT ARMS TALKS OVER DEFECTIONS

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27

 BODY:
North Korea withdrew from long-scheduled negotiations over its exports of missiles today in an angry protest against the Clinton Administration's decision to grant asylum to two North Korean diplomats.
The negotiations, which were to have begun this morning in New York City, were called off abruptly late Tuesday night after North Korea protested the Administration's decision to take in the diplomats, who defected over the weekend with the help of American intelligence agents, and who are already being interviewed, according to Administration officials. 
 The defections also appeared to throw into question whether broader talks including North Korea, South Korea, the United States and China to negotiate a formal end to the Korean War would take place. For now, those negotiations, known as the "four-party" talks, are scheduled to resume in New York on Sept. 15.
North Korea's Government in Pyongyang called on the United States to turn over its Ambassador to Egypt, Chang Sung Gil, and his brother, Chang Sung Ho, who was a trade official at Pyongyang's mission in Paris. It denounced the two men as criminals who were facing charges back home in connection with leaking state secrets and "economic corruption."
Li Gun, North Korea's deputy representative to the United Nations, called the Administration's decision to grant asylum and its role in the defections "a grave insult" that showed "hostility" toward his country. In addition to disrupting the missile talks, he said, the American actions would have "a serious effect" on the broader peace talks.
"The U.S. offer of shelter to the criminals seriously damaged the climate and prevented our Government from resuming the talks," Mr. Li said in a telephone interview.
The Administration sought to play down North Korea's decision, suggesting the defections would not have to permanently derail the long effort to entice North Korea out of its diplomatic isolation through a series of negotiated agreements.
On Martha's Vineyard, where President Clinton is vacationing, the White House expressed disappointment at North Korea's withdrawal from the talks. A spokesman, Barry Toiv, said the Administration nonetheless hoped that North Korea would remain committed to negotiations.
"While this decision by the North was not unexpected, it is nonetheless disappointing," he said. "We see no linkage between the defection and missile talks, and we believe it is in North Korea's interest to remain engaged in the talks."
However, the Administration appeared to have no second thoughts about the defections, which officials are describing as a potential intelligence coup, offering rare insight into North Korea's foreign policy and its arms sales in the Middle East.
"The alternative of turning down a bona fide plea for asylum from a state like North Korea is pretty unthinkable," an Administration official said.
When asked at a news conference today whether the Administration still considered it wise to grant asylum at the cost of disrupting delicate negotiations with North Korea, the State Department's spokesman, James P. Rubin, replied simply. "That's easy," he said. "Yes."
Mr. Chang is the first Ambassador to defect from North Korea and the highest-ranking North Korean ever to defect to the United States, rather than to South Korea.
As Ambassador to Egypt, holding one of North Korea's most important diplomatic posts, Mr. Chang would have had direct knowledge of arms trading with countries like Egypt, Iran and Syria, officials said.
In particular, the Administration is eager to know more about the sale of ballistic missiles, which it considers dangerous and threatening to allies in the region, like Israel. Mr. Chang might also shed light on the extent of North Korea's cooperation with China in the proliferation of missiles and missile technology.
North Korea has developed its own variations of Scud missiles, first designed by the Russians, and sold them around the world. In 1993, it tested its latest version, the Nodong I missile, which has a range of more than 1,000 kilometers and raises special concerns in the Administration.
North Korea has agreed in principle to join the Missile Technology Control Regime, a voluntary set of export controls to limit sales of ballistic missiles that can deliver 1,000-pound warheads more than 180 miles. With few other viable commodities to export, however, North Korea has relied on arms sales for hard currency.
The Administration officials said North Korea's secretive Government might have left Mr. Chang out of some decisions. One official, who like all the others spoke only on condition of anonymity, said it was not yet clear "to what extent he was privy" to his country's dealings. A Pentagon official added, "We may be hopeful and expect that he knows more than he does."
Negotiations with the North Koreans have moved in fits and starts. An early effort to begin the peace talks with South Korea, China and the United States, was postponed last fall when a North Korean submarine carrying commandos ran aground off South Korea's coast. In February, the defection to South Korea of Hwang Jang Yop, a former member of Pyongyang's ruling body, brought diplomacy to a halt for a while. After each case, however, talks resumed.
"Our diplomats are determined," Mr. Rubin said at the State Department today. "They're in it for the long haul."
In the case of this week's talks, North Korea's delegation, led by Li Hyong Chol, a director in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, had already arrived in New York for the talks when they were ordered to return home around midnight on Tuesday.
The official response came from Mr. Li, the diplomat at North Korea's mission to the United Nations. While it was tartly worded, a senior Administration official said, it did not include any mention of withdrawing from the four-party peace talks, as Mr. Li's public remarks today did.
That official and others said the Administration still believes that North Korea's desperation and isolation, worsened by economic collapse and natural catastrophes, would ultimately bring Pyongyang back to the negotiating table.
"All I can say is that we believe those talks are in the interests of both sides," Mr. Rubin said.

HEADLINE: Pledge to Stay in City Wins Bear Stearns a Tax Break

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration announced yesterday that it had granted Bear Stearns & Company a $75 million tax break to stay in New York for the next 50 years, although the global investment bank acknowledged that, unlike many Wall Street firms, it had never threatened to leave the city.
Bear Stearns, which has scoured midtown Manhattan for a new home for more than two years, plans to build a technologically advanced, 1.1-million-square-foot tower on a block bounded by Madison and Vanderbilt Avenues and 46th and 47th Streets. After 20 months of on-again, off-again negotiations, the investment bank signed a 99-year lease on Tuesday for the site near Grand Central Terminal, where a vacant, soot-covered building now stands. 
 Under the terms of what the city described as a "corporate retention deal," Bear Stearns would get $45 million in sales tax exemptions -- helping it buy office furniture, computers and other equipment when it moves into the new building -- in return for keeping its 5,800 employees in the city for the next 50 years. The firm would get up to $30 million more in sales tax exemptions if it created at least 13,300 new jobs in that period.
Bear Stearns currently occupies space in midtown, at 245 Park Avenue at 47th Street and 575 Lexington Avenue at 51st Street, and in Brooklyn and Whippany, N.J.
"Bear Stearns is very important to New York City's financial community," Mayor Giuliani said. "Whenever you see a development like this it's a sign of the city moving in exactly the right direction."
Asked at a news conference at City Hall whether Bear Stearns had gotten the $75 million tax break after threatening to leave New York, the Mayor responded that it was a "silly question," adding: "It doesn't matter. I don't really care."
James E. Cayne, chief executive of Bear Stearns, then answered the question: "No," he said.
"The Mayor and the Governor have made New York a business-friendly place. We didn't threaten to leave," Mr. Cayne said later in a telephone conversation. "We're not going down that road. Other companies do it. We've been in New York 75 years. This is our home."
The agreement is the 33d corporate retention deal signed by the Giuliani administration since 1993. The administration says the program has saved 77,880 jobs from leaving the city in return for over $600 million in tax breaks. But budget watchdogs, conservative anti-tax groups and liberal politicians have denounced the tax breaks as tantamount to "corporate welfare."
"A company with the earnings of Bear Stearns doesn't need the helping hand of the taxpayers," said Thomas Carroll, the president of Change-NY, the state's largest taxpayer organization. "The problem with this approach to economic development is that it always focuses on the companies with the biggest brand names and best political connections. The small and medium-sized companies, which are responsible for more job growth, are often left in the dust."
During the recession in the early 1990's, city officials argued that the incentives were necessary to persuade corporations not to abandon the city. But midtown vacancy rates, which had soared as high as 18 percent, are now at about 10.6 percent, the lowest since 1986, according to Cushman & Wakefield, one of the largest brokerages in Manhattan. In the past year, the average asking rent for office space in midtown Manhattan rose about 6.6 percent to $38.09 per square foot.
Now, city officials argue that the city economy is so robust that the real estate market has tightened up to the point that companies cannot find large blocks of prime office space and cannot afford new construction without city subsidies. "You couldn't get this building built without these incentives in today's market," said Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation. "The Mayor now has a commitment from Bear Stearns to stay here for 50 years. We didn't have that two days ago. And New York City will get a major development. The Mayor's package makes that possible."
The Bear Stearns site has a star-crossed history that dates back to the 1980's real estate boom. In an alliance with some Arab investors, Credit Suisse First Boston and the developer G. Ware Travelstead bought the site in 1982 for what was originally described as the tallest building in the world. But the project failed to gain city approval and the site lay fallow.
In December 1995, Bear Stearns thought it had struck a deal with First Boston to buy the site for $55 million. But First Boston's partner, the al-Babtain family of Saudi Arabia, upset the plans when it suddenly took control of the property.
After several futile attempts to strike a deal with the al-Babtains, Bear Stearns began looking elsewhere for a new home. The company considered building a tower on a site known as Rock West, at Seventh Avenue and 50th Street, and renewing its lease at 245 Park Avenue. Neither option bore fruit. Once again, Bear Stearns resumed negotiations with the al-Babtains. The two sides sealed a deal after Bear Stearns doubled its price and Abdul Wahab S. al-Babtain agreed to grant a long-term lease granting full control of the property to the investment bank. According to one person involved in the negotiations, the current value of the deal is more than $100 million.
The project will be developed by Fred Wilpon, a director of Bear Stearns and the owner of the Mets, and Gerald Hines, the Houston-based developer. Under the city's zoning rules, the developer would be allowed to put up a smaller building. But Bear Stearns plans to purchase additional development rights from nearby Grand Central Terminal, if the city approves the final plans.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Eke Out Gains After Early Losses
Blue-chip stocks rose for the first time in a week as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.11 points, to 7,787.33, overcoming an 84-point drop. Small stocks, as gauged by the Russell 2000 index, did slightly better.
Stocks were buffeted by an unusually large number of computer-guided buy and sell programs, traders said. But big oil companies received a lift from an analyst's recommendation that investors increase their holdings of the stocks. [D8.] 

Treasury securities prices dropped slightly amid a poor Treasury auction of new five-year notes. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.65 percent from 6.64. [D18.]
 
Lawyers Win. But Consumers?
Insurers accused of duping customers into buying unnecessary or overrated policies are adopting a settlement strategy from other industries, giving consumers discounts on future services instead of cash. While lawyers do well under these arrangements, critics say they are simply marketing gimmicks for the insurers. [A1.]
 
Matsushita Profit Surges
Matsushita of Japan, the world's largest maker of home electronics products, said that quarterly net income rose 42 percent. [D9.]
 
Arguments in Trade Case
The computing director of the weather laboratory that touched off a high-tech trade fight said that the lab had decided last year to buy Japanese supercomputers because an American maker, Cray Research, could not deliver machines that were fast enough. Cray says the Japanese were dumping them -- that is, selling them below cost. [D2.]
 
Anti-dumping laws, remnants of an era when imports mattered little to Americans' standard of living, are intended to give domestic producers an edge over foreign rivals. Thanks to the tilted playing field, consumers stand to lose -- as shown by a case in which Louisiana crawfish growers seek sanctions against Chinese competitors. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
 
I.B.M. Thinks Small
I.B.M. is bringing out what executives are describing as their first comprehensive worldwide advertising campaign aimed at owners of small businesses. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]
 
Florida Settlement Raises Question
The settlement of Florida's case against cigarette makers has stirred a debate over whether to adopt the proposed nationwide tobacco accord or to continue state-by-state lawsuits. [A1.]
 
Citicorp to Buy Mexican Bank
Citicorp plans to acquire Confia, a cash-short Mexican bank, in a transaction valued at as much as $245 million. [D9.]
 
Tax Break for Bear Stearns
New York City has granted Bear Stearns a $75 million tax break to stay in New York for the next 50 years, though the investment bank acknowledged that, unlike many Wall Street firms, it had never threatened to leave. [B6.]
 
Dollar Gains Ground
The dollar rose on policy makers' hints that interest rates in Germany and Japan would not rise soon. [D15.]
 
Dow Jones in Derivatives Deals
Dow Jones said that it had licensed Bankers Trust and Merrill Lynch to offer contracts that will enable investors to make bets on the direction of the Dow industrials. [D8.]
 
New Labels for a Diet Prescription
The F.D.A. said it would require new labels warning users of the diet pill combination known as fen-phen of the potential danger of heart-valve damage. [A19.]
 
Ex-Agriculture Secretary Indicted
Mike Espy, the former Agriculture Secretary, was indicted by a grand jury that said he, his brother and his girlfriend received favors from several companies with important interests before the Government. [A1.]

HEADLINE: As Washington (D.C.) Loses Power, Outlook Is Up

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
The announcement generated little fanfare in the District of Columbia, beyond the city's finance department. But there, it was worthy of a man-bites-dog headline.
On Aug. 7, two days after President Clinton signed the 1998 budget bill, which included a $1 billion bailout of the District over five years, Standard & Poor's put the city on "credit watch with positive implications," a signal to investors that its lowly B rating for general obligation bonds could improve in the next few months. 
 "That shows things are moving in the right direction," said Anthony A. Williams, the District's chief financial officer, basking in the glow of a little positive news.
For residents of the nation's capital, such news has been hard to come by. For the third September in four years, the schools will open late, this time by three weeks, so roof and safety repairs can be completed. Just 2 of 34 street-cleaning machines are in working condition, and garbage has piled up on many streets and alleys, because more than a dozen garbage trucks are inoperable.
And many city agencies, including those for tax collection and housing, are still untangling problems that Mr. Williams says have cost the city tens of millions of dollars a year through waste, fraud and mismanagement. As one example, the city last year lost $55 million in Federal grant money for housing, sewers, parks and day care by not spending it within the allotted time.
But Mr. Williams, as well as experts in municipal finance, economists and local developers, contend that after years of decline, the District has bottomed out.
They say change is well under way -- not just because of the Federal bailout but also because part of the budget bill expands the powers of the city's two-year-old financial control board, allowing it to run every major agency of the city government. That authority was once held by the Mayor and City Council.
While Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has led the jeers against the bill, saying it "raped democracy and freedom," city officials, economists and developers say it is integral to any meaningful turnabout in providing confidence to residents and investors that city agencies will be managed properly, at least over the next few years.
"The economic issue is driving the bus right now," said Dick Heidenberger, a restaurateur and real estate developer who is turning a vacant downtown apartment building, now a crack house, into a restaurant.
"The potential is there for so many business opportunities," Mr. Heidenberger said, "and it will only get better.
"The writing is on the wall for Marion Barry. I know he inherited a lot of the mess, but he made a lot of the mess. For me, the control board was an absolute positive."
After the President signed the budget bill, the control board moved swiftly to replace members of the Mayor's cabinet and install a new chief financial officer in each city agency, all of whom answer to the control board, not the Mayor. The legislation also gives cabinet heads broad new authority to dismiss any employee for cause, a power added to the measure to satisfy residents' complaints that many city agencies are unresponsive to citizens' needs.
Further, the control board is now searching to fill a position no other major American city has -- chief management officer -- who would be, in effect, the city manager, coordinating the agencies and reporting directly to the control board.
While the control board is viewed by Mr. Barry and some other residents as the worst intrusion on home rule since Congress granted it almost 25 years ago, others say the shift will accelerate economic developments already under way. Among them are these:
*Job growth in the District's private sector has grown every month this year, compared with the same same period in 1996, according to a monthly survey conducted by Stephen Fuller, a professor of public policy at George Mason University in Northern Virginia. For May and June, the most recent months for which statistics are available, the increase was 8,800 jobs.
*Construction of the MCI Center, an indoor arena for the city's professional basketball and hockey teams being built on the fringe of downtown, has begun attracting new retail development to the area. Mr. Heidenberger said the building he planned to develop was one of many facing the MCI Center that are to be renovated.
*Thousands of Federal employees working in Northern Virginia are scheduled to be moved soon to new quarters in the city, at the Navy Yard and the Government's second-largest building, after the Pentagon -- the new Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center on Pennsylvania Avenue.
*The District has taken in $50 million more than expected this year through more aggressive tax collection, largely from properties sold to satisfy debt. Mr. Williams predicted that the additional money would help cut the annual deficit to its lowest level in years, $74 million, for the fiscal year ending on Sept. 30. Two years ago, it was $334 million.
*The Standard & Poor's credit watch was the first change in the District's bond rating since April 11, 1995, when a BBB rating was dropped to B, the equivalent of junk bond status. The District's rating had fallen steadily, from A in 1984.
"It's too soon to make a direct connection," said Mr. Fuller, referring to the expanded powers of the control board and the city's economy. "But there are signs. A number of things have broken out before on their own steam that are not tied to the rescue package, but the rescue package won't hurt."
Mr. Heidenberger, the developer, predicted that with the construction of the arena, and plans for a new downtown convention center and opera house, Washington could experience the kind of rebirth that occurred 15 years ago in Baltimore, where investors turned a drab downtown into a rainbow of new hotels, restaurants and specialty shops.
"Things are happening that predate the Federal action," said Philip Dearborn, president of the Greater Washington Research Center. "But that may have a value reassuring people that the city is going to be managed and will survive. With it or without it, the city is on a good track."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Among the positive economic news in Washington, this vacant downtown building, now a crack house, is going to be turned into a restaurant. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: More Questions About Incentives To Get Those on Welfare to Work

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27

 BODY:
It seems like an idea that no one could fault: let welfare recipients keep more of their benefits when they get jobs, and more of them will get jobs. Indeed, the idea has so much appeal that at least 30 states are now trying it as part of their new welfare programs.
But decades of research have shown that such financial incentives do little to coax people from welfare to work. And a study released today -- seeming to show new promise for the policy -- may have inadvertently reawakened doubts about it, even as it is being embraced from New York to California. 
 The study was conducted by the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a nonprofit group in New York City that for the past decade has played an influential role in welfare policy. It examined the effect of these incentives, known as earnings disregards, on three groups of welfare recipients in seven Minnesota counties.
For two of the three groups, the incentives had the same effect they have had in the past: they did little to encourage people to work. In fact, for one group, welfare recipients who had generous incentives earned less from work than those who did not receive the incentives.
But when tried in a third group -- in combination with mandatory work requirements -- the incentives did increase earnings and reduce poverty.
Pointing to that finding, Judith Gueron, the president of the research group, said the study held out new hope for the efficacy of the incentives.
"The conventional view is that they don't make much difference," Ms. Gueron said. "I think that view is being challenged here."
But critics of the financial incentives continue to argue that they do as much or more harm than good. By allowing more workers to collect welfare, they say, the incentives may encourage more people to come on the rolls. Similarly, by allowing poor people to collect welfare after they get a job, the incentives encourage longer stays on the rolls. Since states now impose lifetime limits on the number of months the poor can collect benefits, those longer stays could inadvertently lead some poor people to use up their eligibility faster.
In an era of time limits, this could unintentionally lead the poor to exhaust their eligibility more quickly.
The critics say that the study, rather than vindicating the incentives, undermines them in its fine print. Even the group that increased its employment collected an additional 8 percent in welfare benefits.
"The study tells us what we've always known, that earnings disregards are not an effective tool in promoting self-sufficiency and reducing dependency," said Robert Rector of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group in Washington.
The dispute serves as a reminder that state programs often pursue disparate, and even conflicting, goals: raising overall income, raising earned income, and reducing welfare receipts. It is difficult to do all three at once. By allowing people to more easily combine welfare and work, for instance, the incentives may raise overall income. But they may also increase reliance on welfare.
Welfare analysts have held out hope for the incentives since at least 1967, when Congress first passed rules allowing recipients to keep some of their earnings without having their welfare checks correspondingly reduced.
In 1981, however, President Reagan sharply reduced the incentives, arguing that workers should work -- not collect welfare. Critics argued that the changes would lead many people to quit their jobs and rely solely on welfare. But subsequent studies, including a comprehensive one by Prof. Robert Moffitt, now of Johns Hopkins University, found that the incentives had little effect one way or the other.
By the early 1990's, a new enthusiasm for the incentives arose among supply-side conservatives like Jack Kemp who believed in the power of economic incentives. Other conservatives, like Mr. Rector, argued that incentives alone, without work requirements, were too weak to change behavior.
The Minnesota study began in January 1993, under a waiver from the Federal Government that long pre-dated last year's welfare law.
Among those studied was a group of "new applicants" who had received benefits for less than 18 months. Those given the financial incentives were slightly more likely to be employed than members of a control group. That is, 78 percent of those with the incentives had jobs, versus 73 percent of those without the incentives.
But those with the incentives earned 6 percent less, and collected 27 percent more in cash welfare and food stamps. Their total income rose 7 percent. But it still remained low, just $14,600 in 18 months.
Taken together, that is, the incentives seemed to make little overall difference in the lives of the poor -- a finding consistent with past research.
The same incentives were tested on a second group of recipients, this one considered "long-term recipients." Here, too, they seemed to have little effect.
It was only for a third group that the incentives seemed to have an effect. But this group faced both the "carrot" of the incentives, and the "stick" of modest work requirements. For this group, the results seemed more robust. Those employed rose by 39 percent compared with a control group. Total income rose by 13 percent. And the percentage of those in poverty fell by 16 percent.
Ms. Gueron had that group in mind in promoting the program. When combined with work requirements, she said, the incentives "can both promote work and reduce poverty, which has been an elusive goal."
But Mickey Kaus, another critic of earnings disregards, said the results that the group attributed to the combination of carrot and stick may simply have come from the stick alone -- the work requirements.
"The carrot alone flopped," Mr. Kaus said. "The carrot and the stick worked. Why didn't they also test the stick alone, the work requirements?" Ms. Gueron said previous studies found that such an approach did less to reduce poverty than the mix of policies tried in Minnesota. But Mr. Kaus said the research group was making the financial incentives look overly promising.
"Earnings disregards," Mr. Kaus said, "are one of those palliatives designed to get around the need to get rid of welfare."

INTERNATIONAL A3-12
 
Israel Ends Blockade Of Bethlehem
Israel announced an end to a four-week military blockade of the West Bank city of Bethlehem, removing a small but important irritant in the troubled Israeli-Palestinian partnership. Bethlehem had been sealed off since a suicide bombing in a Jerusalem market killed 16 people. A1
 
Pyongyang Ends Missile Talks
North Korea angrily withdrew from long-scheduled negotiations over its exports of missiles and denounced the United States decision to grant asylum to two of its diplomats. The defections appeared to throw into question whether talks among North Korea, South Korea, the United States and China to negotiate a formal end to the Korean War would occur in September. A1 

Italians Arrest Bomb Suspect
The Italian police arrested a 40-year-old Libyan wanted in Germany for the 1986 bombing of a Berlin discotheque that killed two American soldiers and a Turkish woman and injured about 200 others. The man was identified as Musbah Abulgasem Eter, a former member of the Libyan secret services who is believed to be the last fugitive sought in connection with the Berlin bombing. A5
 
China Sets Next Congress
The Chinese Communist Party set Sept. 12 for its next Congress, a major event held every five years, when 2,000 delegates assemble at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing and formally approve a slate of leaders and a sweeping plan for political and economic policy. Though the voting is almost always unanimous, the gathering's drama is the presentation of personnel and policy decisions that have already been worked out in back rooms. A12
 
Protest by Mexican Doctors
Thousands of doctors and nurses staged a two-hour strike in Ciudad Juarez to protest the killing of four doctors whose bodies were dumped along a road hours after they were called to treat a wounded man, apparently a drug trafficker. The walkout underlined the growing anger in Mexico over the Government's failure to combat proliferating criminal and drug violence. A6
 
Cuba Pursues Attack Claim 
Representatives of countries that have signed the Biological Weapons Convention agreed to further investigate Cuba's accusation that the United States launched a biological attack by using a cropduster to spew insects over the island in 1996. Washington has rejected Cuba's complaint but lost its effort to end the investigation. A7
 
Zambia Suspends Officers
The Zambian police suspended two senior provincial police officers over the wounding last week of the former President, Kenneth Kaunda, and another opposition leader. Inspector General Francis Ndhlovu told a news conference that police mistakenly used live ammunition to disperse the illegal opposition rally at which Mr. Kaunda appeared. (Reuters)
