HEADLINE: For Plaintiffs, More of Same in Insurance Accords

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
A funny thing is happening on the way to the courthouse, as class-action lawyers and the insurance industry mop up some of the worst sales abuses heaped upon consumers in recent years.
While lawyers are walking away with upward of $150 million in cold, hard cash for representing customers who said they had been duped into buying policies that may have been unnecessary or overrated, millions of policyholders are being offered something far less tangible to settle class action lawsuits. 
 They can take their chances of getting cash through arduous arbitration or they can take a package of low-interest loans and discounts on a handful of insurance, annuity and mutual fund products. In short, they would be ponying up more cash to do new business with the same institutions that let them down.
The insurers and the plaintiffs' lawyers are celebrating these deals, some of which still await court approval, as being worth billions of dollars to consumers and a brilliant way to end the litigation. But critics of the settlements argue that the discounts are nothing more than a marketing gimmick for the insurers -- a low-cost way to hold on to their customers -- and a way for lawyers to collect large fees by inflating the settlements' value.
This is only the latest variety of a series of settlements criticized for handing consumers scrip in lieu of cash. People who thought that they had overpaid for airline tickets because of price-fixing wound up with a small discount off the price of another trip. Owners of leaky Mustang convertibles got a $400 coupon toward the purchase of a new Ford. Contact lens wearers who said they were overcharged by Bausch & Lomb were given a little cash and certificates for more products.
Now the coupon craze is being embraced by life insurance companies, including the New York Life Insurance Company, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the Transamerica Occidental Life Insurance Company and the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.
While the details of each settlement differ, the deals usually consist of a low-interest loan to cover the premiums on an existing policy and a discount on the purchase of a new product. (In some cases, policyholders might qualify for a small enhancement of the cash value of an existing life insurance policy, without putting additional money down.)
But in most cases the insurers have confined the price breaks to a narrow universe of so-so products while insisting on the broadest possible release from liability for past and future claims.
"I think it's a brilliant concept," said Melvyn I. Weiss, a prominent class-action lawyer in New York whose firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, served as lead counsel in many of the cases that have resulted in noncash settlements. "It's a great solution to policyholders; it's a great solution to the company."
But critics, who include consumer advocates, state regulators, academics and even some plaintiffs' lawyers, are not so sure.
The settlements are "being copied because plaintiffs' lawyers want fees, and the defendant knows it's a wonderful way to buy peace," said Michael Malakoff, a Pittsburgh lawyer who is seeking a reversal of the Prudential settlement reached last September on the ground it shortchanges Prudential's victims.
A lot of the problem lies in the settlements' sheer breadth. Unlike other coupon settlements, which are typically limited to the people who bought the car with the faulty design or were taken advantage by the unfair pricing practices, these settlements are much more sweeping in nature. They include anyone who bought a life insurance policy when the deceptive sales techniques were being employed, sometimes for more than 15 years. As a result, the critics say, the people who were actually deceived could end up with much less than if they were the sole beneficiaries of the settlement, and people who do not yet know they were harmed may also come up short. The very fact that the insurers are willing to be so expansive and include all potential claimants, critics argue, is a sign that these enhancements do not "cost" the companies much at all.
"It's a marketing tool for the defendants and a cheap way to buy out of liability," said Susan Koniak, a visiting law professor at Cornell University.
The liability that so concerns the industry giants arises from three types of unsavory sales practices aimed at generating commissions that have become the focus of scandals and class-action lawsuits in recent years.
Some cases involve "churning" -- pressuring customers to use the cash value of their old policies to buy new ones no better than the ones they replaced. Other cases accuse agents of overstating how much policies would earn in the late 1980's when interest rates were in the double digits, sometimes going so far as to offer "vanishing premium" policies, where the income was eventually supposed to cover the annual premiums. When interest rates fell, policyholders were hit with bills they had never expected. The third category of complaints involve policies that were inappropriately billed as investment or retirement vehicles.
To be sure, some people who were deceived will end up getting cash. All the settlements give policyholders a brief window of opportunity to opt out to pursue their own lawsuit, an option few people may even realize they have. The settlements also offer cash to those who can prove that they were harmed. Under the Prudential settlement, the largest of its kind and which involves nearly 9 million customers who bought 10.7 million policies between 1982 and 1995, the insurance company has agreed to pay out at least $410 million in cash relief and could eventually pay out more than $1 billion. About 1.1 million policyholders have indicated that they want to go through arbitration, according to the company.
For the bulk of customers, the plan's architects had alternative relief in mind. Hence, at Prudential, a package of low-interest loans and discounts on whole-life insurance, annuities and some in-house mutual funds that by some estimates might be worth another $800 million. "When we looked at the kinds of problems people were having, people were just disappointed in the performance of the product," said Paul Lang, a vice president of policy owner relations for Prudential, explaining why the company did something for them, too.
Certainly, the company has not made it easy for people who want cold, hard cash to get it. Prudential, for instance, requires policyholders to complete a 19-page claim form if they choose arbitration, one reason why consumer advocates urge anyone interested in arbitration to seek the help of a state insurance department, a lawyer or financial adviser rather than go it alone. "I think you need expert advice," said J. Robert Hunter, director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America.
What is more, critics put little value on the package of discounts and low-interest loans being offered to consumers as part of these settlements. "It is not relief at all; it does not remedy the harm done," said Gary Betz, special counsel to the Attorney General in Florida.
The package in the New York Life settlement, which was reached two years ago and was the first insurance deal of this type, represents "minimal or token compensation for class members," agreed Joseph M. Belth, editor of The Insurance Forum newsletter. Short of arbitration, it offered "no benefit to an individual who desires to avoid further transactions" with a company that may have misled them.
Consumers tend to agree. In the case of New York Life, for example, only 4,000 people out of the 3 million who were eligible opted to take a discounted annuity or life insurance policy. Only 500,000 out of the nearly 9 million covered by the Prudential settlement expressed an interest in one of their products, about a fraction of the one million or more initially estimated.
Besides luring fewer takers than initial projections, these settlements will cost the companies much less than the economic value assigned to them because the insurers will be bypassing their high-cost sales forces.
New York Life, for example, offered to knock half off the first year's premium on new insurance policies covered by the deal, meaning it should net the same as if an agent had made the sale at full price. That is one reason it estimates it will only spend $65 million to deliver $250 million in promised benefits. The deal was structured that way, according to Robert J. Hebron, vice president and associate general counsel, so that the company, which is owned by its policyholders, would not be "robbing Peter to pay Paul."
From the perspective of the policyholders, where the money is coming from is irrelevant, Mr. Weiss argues. But it is hard to argue that the settlements will do much to inhibit the insurers from misbehaving again.
And consumer advocates would certainly be happier if the discounts could be sold for cash or applied to any of the insurers' products.
"Is it better than nothing? Yes," said Peter Katt, a life insurance adviser in Kalamazoo, Mich., who has clients who are Prudential policyholders. But he and other financial advisers argue that the discounts being offered are no better than what is available from other companies if consumers bother to shop around.
The discounted annuities and insurance policies can generally be matched by buying from a low-cost company in the first place, while the discounted mutual funds that are being offered, at least in the case of Prudential and the Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company, which has also reached one of these settlements, tend to have high expenses and be mediocre performers. Though Prudential says it may yet alter the deal, policyholders can only buy "B" class shares in the the seven funds now eligible for the discount. This class carries steep annual marketing fees that would often outweigh the value of the initial discount after four years' time.
Only one fund, the Prudential Diversified Bond Fund, has been a top performer at least in the last year, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund research company. The rest were beaten by most of their peers over the last three years, including Prudential Municipal Fund-Intermediate Series, which placed close to the bottom of its group.
The dozen funds Phoenix is offering its policyholders also have high yearly marketing fees. Most of those funds have been poor performers as well, like the Phoenix Growth Fund, which trailed its peers the last year.
The insurance companies' eagerness to offer millions of policyholders these deals suggests they may do more for their bottom lines than they let on. Steven S. Oscher, an accountant retained by Florida to look into the Prudential settlement, said in a report that the increase in sales of insurance, mutual funds and annuities that Prudential will enjoy from the discount program "may ultimately allow Prudential to underwrite the payment" of the arbitration program.
Prudential denies it would ever come out ahead. "This wasn't a sales campaign," Mr. Lang said. "It was solely designed to help people who thought they didn't have what they wanted."
Maybe so. But the settlements may do more to help the insurance companies and class-action lawyers who created them. As two of the New York Life policyholders complained in court in a written objection to the settlement, "We don't see the law firm taking its compensation in the form of a negligibly favorable annuity from New York Life the way it would have its clients do."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Prudential Deal at a Glance"
In the settlement reached last September, nearly nine million policyholders were told they could seek arbitration or sign up for the discounts with no questions asked.
 
ARBITRATION (Estimated cost upward of $410 million)
 
About 1.1 million policyholders indicated that they want to go through arbitration. After filling out a 19-page claim form, they will be assigned a score of 0, 1, 2 or 3. Those who score 0 will get nothing. Those who score 1 get whatever discounts they would have otherwise received outside of arbitration. All others would either receive a cash award, have their policy reinstated if it lapsed or have future premiums waived. Policyholders have the option of appealing to an independent reviewer.
 
THE DISCOUNT PROGRAM (Estimated cost up to $800 million)
 
About 490,000 people have indicated that they are interested in participating in this program.
 
Anyone with an existing policy that has a premium due may be eligible to take out a low-interest loan priced at Prudential's short-term cost of borrowing. They may also choose one of the following:
 
A whole life insurance policy -- Prudential will contribute 50 percent of the first-year's premium, 25 percent of the third-year's premium, 25 percent of the fifth-year's premium and 15 percent of the seventh-year's premium.
 
An annuity -- Prudential will contribute 2 percent of the initial payment for smaller annuities; 3 percent for larger ones. Prudential will contribute another 2 percent of the initial payment at the end of the second year and another 1 percent at the end of the third year.
 
A mutual fund -- Prudential will waive 4 percent of the purchase price on the B class shares for any one of seven mutual funds. These B-shares carry some baggage, though, in the form of higher-than-usual marketing fees in the early years. (pg. D4)
 
Table: "Bartering to Satisfy Dissatisfied Policyholders"
 Virtually every major life insurance company has been sued by policyholders who said that their agents had engaged in deceptive sales practices. Agents have been accused of churning policies or pressuring customers to cash out their existing policies to buy new ones, selling vanishing premium policies in which the earnings were supposed to be sufficient to pay for the premiums within a short period and inappropriately calling some policies investment or retirement vehicles.
 The insurers either denied the accusations or argued that these practices were not widespread. But many, including those below, have chosen to settle the lawsuits by offering policyholders a choice of arbitration or discounted products. HEADLINE: Going Down A New Road, Then Back;
New-Media Executives Often Lose Their Way

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
For nearly two years, Stephen A. Weiswasser has worked in Los Angeles but lived in Washington. The coast-to-coast commute has been brutal, but he said he was determined not to uproot his family for his job.
Today, that looks like a shrewd move. The company Mr. Weiswasser joined, Americast, has shut down two divisions, laid off more than a dozen of its 100 employees, and throttled back its ambitions to develop a futuristic television service for its five telephone company backers. 
 And Mr. Weiswasser himself may soon negotiate to leave the company, according to several executives there. "I have a contract and I plan to live up to it," said Mr. Weiswasser, who was recruited to run Americast after a decade in senior posts at ABC. But he acknowledged that "things are not rolling out as fast as we had hoped."
If Mr. Weiswasser does leave Americast, he will join an elite but growing fraternity: new-media refugees. These are prominent executives who traded their careers in conventional media companies for the glamorous but treacherous world of new media. New media, which encompass everything from interactive television to the Internet, offered these people the tantalizing prospect of creating something new and perhaps even striking it rich.
But three years after the new-media wave first swept the industry, it has left some woozy players in its wake. After struggling with balky partners, financial losses and the vagaries of technology, many of these executives found that the new frontier got old very quickly.
Some, like Howard Stringer of the Sony Corporation and Walter Isaacson of Time magazine, have returned to old-line media jobs. A few, like the former AT&T executive Robert M. Kavner, are still laboring in the new-media vineyards, trying to realize their dreams on a more modest scale. And one executive, Paul Sagan, has dropped out altogether, moving to Switzerland.
Of course, each of these men had his own reasons for jumping into -- or back out of -- new media. But there are enough common strands in their stories to illuminate a basic truth: while digital technology is enabling companies to start all sorts of new-media ventures, the profits have been elusive.
Whether it is a World Wide Web site like Time Inc.'s Pathfinder, or a television service like Americast, turning an idea into a business is tricky. Some companies are struggling even to figure out why they are in this business. For Time Warner, it may be a logical extension of its print publications. But other companies, including the Baby Bells, may simply be fighting a rear-guard action -- afraid that if they do not get into the business, someone else will.
"We all operated on a flush of hype that perhaps blinded us to the difficulties of the business," Mr. Weiswasser said. "Now we're all wiser. It is harder than we thought it was going to be."
Americast embodies many of the woes that afflict new-media ventures. The company was started in 1995 as a joint venture of the Walt Disney Company and five telephone companies -- Ameritech, BellSouth, GTE, SBC Communications and Southern New England Telephone -- with the lofty goal of creating a television service that could be delivered over telephone wires.
The partners pledged $100 million a year over five years to develop the building blocks for such a system: an interactive device to help viewers navigate through hundreds of channels of programs, a set-top convertor box, and some original, interactive programming.
And they lured Mr. Weiswasser from Capital Cities/ABC, where he had held several weighty positions, including general counsel and executive vice president of ABC News.
But problems crept into the venture from the start. One of Americast's phone-company backers, SBC, announced it was no longer interested in the television business. And some of the other phone companies delayed their plans to offer video services so they could concentrate on other businesses, like long-distance service.
Moreover, Disney's aggressive television programmers came into conflict with Americast over which company should control the programming and marketing for the venture, according to executives involved in the dispute. Several weeks ago, the partners essentially backed Disney -- shutting down those divisions and moving the activities from Americast to Disney.
Mr. Weiswasser insisted that Americast would continue to supervise the development of the service. And he said the phone companies were still committed to offering video to their customers over time. But with Americast losing its role as a programming company, Mr. Weiswasser would seem to have little incentive to stay with the venture.
What lessons has he learned from the experience? "It is important," Mr. Weiswasser said, "that the partners coming into a venture are absolutely sure that they understand and agree on each other's mission and role."
The same lesson could be applied to Mr. Weiswasser's former competitor, Howard Stringer. Mr. Stringer, who was once president of CBS, left the network in late 1994 to run a similar programming venture, Tele-TV, which was backed by Bell Atlantic, Nynex and the Pacific Telesis Group.
Partly, Mr. Stringer was lured by the challenge of doing something fresh after 30 years at CBS. But he also feared that with CBS about to change ownership he was not likely to remain president for long.
As it happens, he might have lasted longer at CBS than at Tele-TV. After the venture's first year, two of its backers -- Bell Atlantic and Nynex -- simply decided that investing heavily in television was no longer critical to their future. But they were initially loath to admit their retreat, so Mr. Stringer was forced to spend a restless year at the office with little to do, waiting for his employers to buy out his contract.
"Americast and Tele-TV were deterrents to keep the cable industry out of the phone business," said Michael J. Wolf, a partner in the media practice at Booz, Allen & Hamilton. "When the cable companies decided not to get into that business, the phone companies didn't care anymore."
Looking back, Mr. Stringer said Tele-TV's backers were also understandably impatient because the digital technology they wanted to use was proving to be too expensive to deploy in their phone networks.
"The problem is that you're running on the theory of the technology before the technology proves itself," he said.
Mr. Stringer finally wriggled out of Tele-TV last May with a severance deal that industry executives estimate was worth more than $8 million. Now he is the president of the Sony Corporation of America, where he is coordinating Sony's effort to get into digital television.
The fickleness of partners also torpedoed Mr. Kavner, another new-media executive. As executive vice president of the AT&T Corporation, Mr. Kavner oversaw the company's multimedia activities. In 1994, he was approached by Michael Ovitz, the legendary talent agent, to help him get into the nascent business of new media.
Drawn by the glamour of Hollywood, Mr. Kavner left AT&T's Basking Ridge, N.J., headquarters for Mr. Ovitz's chic quarters in Beverly Hills, Calif. Among other things, he helped Mr. Ovitz to broker the deal that created Tele-TV.
But barely a year after Mr. Kavner came aboard, Mr. Ovitz stunned the entertainment industry by leaving his company, Creative Artists Agency, to join Disney as its president. Mr. Kavner knocked around C.A.A. for another year, helping to finance several small technology companies. But with Mr. Ovitz gone, the grander projects simply vanished in the smog.
Through some serendipitous financial dealings, Mr. Kavner finally landed at the helm of the On Command Corporation at the end of 1996. On Command, which was cobbled together from the assets of Spectravision, is the nation's largest pay-per-view service for hotel rooms.
Until now, it has largely subsisted by offering adult films to traveling businessmen and other guests. But Mr. Kavner has big plans for On Command, and they have a distinctly new-media tincture. He intends to bring Internet service into On Command's 920,000 rooms, offering viewers everything from on-line games to electronic shopping.
Mr. Kavner has few illusions that cyberspace will supplant pornography. "But if you offer people a wide, more interesting, set of choices, they will buy it," he said.
He'll soon find out. Though On Command had only $147.5 million in 1996 revenue, Mr. Kavner has found a business in which one can measure success clearly -- by the revenue per room that its services generate. That clarity is sorely lacking in other new-media ventures, particularly those involving the Internet.
Two of Time Warner's most promising executives briefly grappled with this problem. Under Walter Isaacson and later Paul Sagan, Time Inc. New Media developed one of the most elaborate sites on the Web, called Pathfinder, which encompasses many of Time Inc.'s magazines and other publications.
Mr. Sagan, who helped start Time Warner's New York 1 cable news service, said he was frustrated as president of the new-media division because it was hard to determine whether Pathfinder was successful.
"With New York 1, we measured success by how often we were cited in the media," he said. "With on-line services, you have 'hits,' which don't really mean anything. So you were always grabbing at clouds."
Time Warner sells about $10 million worth of advertising a year on Pathfinder, according to executives with knowledge of the venture, but it still loses about $10 million a year. Mr. Sagan said Pathfinder, like most magazine start-ups in the old media, was not supposed to turn a profit in its early years. And he is frustrated by critics who label the venture a failure.
His predecessor, Mr. Isaacson, said Pathfinder was among the top five Web sites, measured by the number of visits and ad revenues. And despite its losses, he said it cost "a lot less than the hundreds of millions of dollars News Corp. spent with MCI or Microsoft spent on various things."
Notwithstanding these explanations, neither Mr. Isaacson nor Mr. Sagan spent much time in new media. Mr. Sagan resigned after only a year to fulfill a longtime dream of taking his family overseas for a year of travel in Europe. Earlier, Mr. Isaacson was plucked out of the job after two years to fulfill his longtime ambition of editing Time magazine.
Despite its aggravations, both men said they had no regrets. Mr. Sagan, who moved to Geneva this week, has signed a consulting contract with the World Economic Forum to help the Geneva-based foundation make better use of the Internet.
Mr. Isaacson, meanwhile, has made the information revolution a prime editorial focus at Time. "This is the biggest story of our time," he said. "Having been there in the trenches, I've got a much better feel for it. I've felt with my own fingers the power of the Web."
Yet for all his enthusiasm, Mr. Isaacson said his foray into new media left him more optimistic about the future of the old media. "A lot of newspapers and magazines are threatened," he said. "But I came back with more respect for the power of magazines to tell rich tales."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Photos: "Changing Directions"
In recent years, several prominent executives in old media businesses like television and publishing were lured away to take jobs in the new interactive media ventures. But so far, profits have been elusive and most have returned, sadder but wiser, to their roots.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Protecting America's shores from those Chinese crawfish.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
ANTI-DUMPING laws, remnant of an era when imports mattered little to Americans' standard of living, are intended to give domestic producers an edge over foreign rivals. And thanks to the tilted playing field, consumers pay more for everything from cement to honey.
Few cases illustrate the point better than Louisiana's crawfish growers' suit against their Chinese competitors, likely to be decided tomorrow by the quasi-judicial United States International Trade Commission. Indeed, few so clearly make the point that the real thrust of anti-dumping laws is to limit foreign competition. "Most anti-dumping cases are nasty," said Greg Rushford, publisher of the Rushford Report, a newsletter on trade policy. "This one is super-nasty." 
 Crawfish, freshwater crustaceans that are used in jambalaya, etouffee and all manner of other Creole dishes, used to come almost exclusively from Louisiana. Fresh whole crawfish command premium prices from local gourmets, while the frozen tail meat ends up in a thousand restaurants across the country. But since weather problems severely disrupted production in 1994 and 1995, the state has lost its market dominance. Some 80 percent of the frozen variety now come from private farmers in Jiangsu Province, China.
Last year the Louisiana businesses that process raw crawfish persuaded the State Legislature to appropriate $350,000 to petition the Commerce Department for protection, charging that Chinese farmers were selling crawfish below cost. That might seem a bit counterproductive for the state government. "Louisiana taxpayers are, in effect, paying a lawyer in Washington to drive up the price of their gumbo," Mr. Rushford noted."
But it is certainly no odder than the Commerce Department's response. Because China is not a member of the World Trade Organization and is officially viewed as a "nonmarket economy," the department was not required to rely on the actual cost of production to determine the "fair" price of crawfish grown in ponds by Chinese farmers.
Instead, it used the cost of fish caught at sea in "comparable" economies with free markets -- India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Indonesia. Transport costs within China were estimated from a 1994 newspaper report on trucking costs in India. And for good measure, the bean counters threw in some numbers on the cost of Spanish imports of live crawfish from Portugal.
Absurd? Of course. But legal, according to Lawrence White of New York University's Stern School of Business. "Loony Tunes assumptions" are built into the anti-dumping laws in order to give domestic producers maximum advantage, said Mr. White, the former chief economist for the Justice Department's antitrust division.
The calculations got the Commerce Department's Import Administration, which generally looks to protectionists in Congress rather than the White House for inspiration, where it wanted to go. The agency has set anti-dumping duties ranging from 85 to 201 percent of the price the Chinese charge, implying that Chinese crawfish farmers have been dumb enough to sell their product for just one-third to two-thirds of production costs.
For the anti-dumping duties to go into effect, the International Trade Commission must also rule that Louisiana producers have been "injured" by Chinese sales. And while the commission is also inclined to give the benefit of the doubt to special-interest pleadings, it has historically been more willing to take the interests of consumers into account, too.
To try to sway the commissioners, lawyers for the Chinese exporters are arguing that the anti-dumping petition was the culmination of a failed campaign by Louisiana business to run up the price of crawfish and to persuade the Chinese to cooperate in cartelizing the market. They introduced a letter from a Louisiana import company, New Phoenix/Sterling, to China's Ambassador to the United States, asking Beijing to lean on crawfish producers to limit exports to three million pounds annually.
"As long as China is working with New Phoenix/ Sterling on the above mentioned base, Chinese crawfish can be in the market for a long time without facing the anti-dumping threat and lose the $10 million/year business," wrote Eugene Ji, the company's president.
The International Trade Commission (or the courts) will have to decide whether the motives of importers are germane to the legal issue of injury. But this relatively minor trade brouhaha does neatly illustrate the core asymmetry built into America's anti-dumping laws. Ford can charge any price to grab market share from Chrysler, unless the intent is to put Chrysler out of business. But foreigners are held to a different standard -- one that puts the Commerce Department in the position of setting and enforcing minimum prices when the low-cost producer is not American.
"The laws invite attempts to monopolize" that would never be tolerated in a purely American industry," Mr. White concluded.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Surge on Favorable Reports About Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities rose strongly yesterday, after the Commerce Department reported that inflation pressures were not building in the second quarter. Securities were also bolstered by an afternoon report citing unnamed Federal Reserve economists as saying strong growth was not really a problem as long as inflation remained tame.
Traders said the market was helped along, as well, by end-of-the- month index buying. 
 Yesterday, the price of a 30-year bond surged 31/32 , to 97 15/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.57 percent, from 6.65 percent on Wednesday and the lowest level in more than a week.
Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, said he was amazed at how much credence market participants put in the report from the unnamed Fed economists.
"Today's data generated a wide variety of crosscurrents for market investors," Mr. Chan said. "On one hand, many investors were relieved to learn that very little damaging information was gleaned from the real gross domestic product report, the widely most anticipated report of the day, while the report on initial unemployment claims first encouraged some caution by investors."
First-time jobless claims dropped by 16,000, to a seasonally adjusted 323,000 in the week ended Aug. 23. Analysts had expected a 7,000 decline.
Mr. Chan said that the positive sentiment in the market stemmed from a huge upward revision in business inventories, which convinced investors that the large inventories might slow future production and, hence, dampen some of the potential inflationary pressures.
Traders also said that investors were seeking the relative safety of short-term Treasuries, because of the turmoil in the stock market.
Other data released yesterday included the Conference Board's help wanted index for July, which was unchanged at 88. Mr. Chan explained that the index remains near its highs for 1996 and still continues to suggest that labor remains fairly tight.
Prices of Government securities were bolstered after a revision in second-quarter G.D.P. to 3.6 percent, lower than the 4 percent some had expected but in line with the 3.5 percent most were expecting.
Also a couple of other minor reports registered declines, which convinced even more investors that moderation was the key rule of the day.
Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, an economic forecasting firm, said the G.D.P. report gave little reason for the Fed to want to increase interest rates. "Domestic demand is growing at a moderate pace, and the evidence does not yet suggest a strong rebound in consumer spending in the third quarter," he said. "Over all, the Fed has to be extremely happy with this report. The economy grew at a 4.4 percent annual rate in the first half of the year, yet inflation by any and every measure has declined."
Yesterday the Government sold $25 billion of 13-day cash management bills at an average rate of 5.47 percent, which was anticipated. From time to time the government sells cash management bills through auction to meet its short-term cash needs outside the regular borrowing schedule.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Against the Mark But Rises a Bit Against the Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the German mark yesterday, hurt by losses in the American stock market and by nagging concerns about a German interest-rate increase.
But the dollar posted modest gains versus the Japanese yen, helped indirectly by renewed focus on Japan's weak economy and the mark's sharp gains against the yen. 
 The dollar was quoted at 1.7961 marks late in the day, down from 1.8025 on Wednesday. It rose to 119.12 yen, from 118.88 yen on Wednesday.
Hans Tietmeyer, president of the Bundesbank, the German central bank, said late on Wednesday that the bank was closely watching a rise in German import prices and that it remained an open question whether the bank would move on interest rates any time soon.
But Mr. Tietmeyer tempered his comment by saying he was happier with the dollar's exchange rate now than he was 10 days ago, when the dollar traded at roughly 1.85 marks. A weak mark drives up the cost of imported goods in Germany.
"They don't see incipient inflation as a big concern, but they do see a relatively strong competitive position of the mark, which is helping exports, but at the same time creating imported inflation," said Diego Giurleo, a vice president at Royal Bank of Canada. "That is what the Bundesbank is looking at right now."
Mr. Giurleo called a rate increase "not totally unlikely" given the concern over imported inflation, though such concern is offset by other fundamentals like Germany's high unemployment, a problem that higher rates would would only aggravate.
Prospects for higher interest rates in Germany joined with a struggling Japanese economy to foster strong buying of marks for yen, traders said. The mark hit a two-month high against the yen, and the dollar rose, too.
Traders said the dollar was held back by a drop in American stocks, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 92.90 points, to 7,694.43. Some investors also continue to book profits from the dollar's sharp gains earlier this year.
"There's so much profit in dollar-mark right now that the long-term players are going to get concerned, just like in the equity market, about just when is a good level to take profits," Mr. Giurleo said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Furman Selz is joining ING, as takeover candidates dwindle.

BYLINE: By Peter Truell 

 BODY:
COMMERCIAL banks continue to prowl Wall Street for acquisitions, trying to increase their nascent investment banking businesses. In the latest deal, ING Group, the Dutch insurance and banking company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Furman Selz L.L.C., a privately held New York securities firm, for $600 million in cash.
ING is one of the largest European financial companies, and has grown aggressively through acquisition. It has made little secret of its ambition to build substantial American investment banking and fund management businesses through both growth and acquisition. It was a disappointed suitor in the recent sales of two other securities firms, Dillon, Read & Company of New York, which is going to the Swiss Bank Corporation, and Montgomery Securities of San Francisco, which is being acquired by Nationsbank. 
 Several other big banks, including Fleet Financial Group, BankBoston and Societe Generale of France showed interest in buying Furman Selz, according to people involved in the sale, and analysts generally expect more such sales of securities firms in the coming months.
Analysts generally seemed neutral about ING's acquisition. "This isn't really big enough to make a difference to ING, but it is big enough to get an investment banking and equity business started in the U.S.," said John Keefe, an independent New York financial analyst who characterized Furman as "a hard-working, fairly creative small company that serves middle-market companies." Mr. Keefe, in common with other analysts, said the price seemed high but noted that few acquisition candidates were left for the many banks interested in entering the New York securities markets.
Like other recent buyers of securities firms, though, ING sought to play down the $600 million price tag, adding that the amount of money that will change hands now is considerably lower. Under its agreement with Furman Selz, ING will pay $333 million now, and the remaining $267 million in three years. That later payment includes $100 million to be distributed to key employees in incentive bonuses. Thus, ING says, the net present value of the purchase is $425 million.
"We want to expand in the U.S. investment banking market and particularly in equity research and underwriting," Cees Maas, ING's chief financial officer, said. The Furman acquisition would almost double ING's presence in the American investment banking market.
Still, ING's stock fell yesterday, despite the fact that the company also posted financial results for the first half of the year that exceeded analyst forecasts.
ING reported net income of 1.94 billion guilders, or $960 million, for the six months that ended on June 30, up from 1.51 billion guilders, or $748 million, in the corresponding period a year earlier. But in Amsterdam, ING's shares fell 3 guilders, to 90.5 guilders, yesterday; the American depository receipts fell 56.25 cents, to $45.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
As for Furman Selz, Edmund A. Hajim, the firm's chairman, said that there was little overlap between the two companies, adding that he expected no layoffs or cost-cutting. "We're very excited," he said. "This is a new era for Furman Selz. We feel we have found the right partner."
The acquisition will not affect Furman Selz's planned move to a new headquarters at 280 Park Avenue from the current offices at 230 Park Avenue, Mr. Hajim said.
ING has a good record for making its acquisitions work. It has, for example, made a considerable success of its 1995 purchase of Barings, the London investment bank. Barings, which at the time was reeling from huge losses attributed to a trader in Singapore, became the flagship for ING's global investment banking ambitions. The ING Barings investment banking subsidiary now has 1,300 of its 9,000 employees in the United States, with offices in New York, Atlanta, Chicago and Los Angeles.
ING has also been buying American insurers. Last month, it acquired the Equitable Companies of Iowa for $2.2 billion in cash and stock, and has further acquisitions in mind. Aad Jacobs, ING's chairman, said yesterday that the company still had some $2.5 billion to $3 billion available for acquisitions, and indicated that ING was interested in buying a big European bank. ING officials would not disclose what banks it had in mind, but the company is clearly interested in expanding in the Continent's major economies.
"Our next step is to prepare for the further integration in the European markets, and to strengthen our position in the European banking market," Mr. Maas said.

HEADLINE: Loretta Blum, 64, a Luminary of Fashion in Texas

BYLINE: By ANNE-MARIE SCHIRO 

 BODY:
Loretta Blum, a fashion retailer in Dallas for more than 20 years, died on Saturday at Baylor University Medical Center in Dallas. She was 64 and lived in Dallas.
The cause was a stroke, said Bud Knight, a friend and former colleague. 
 At the time of her death, Ms. Blum was operating the Loretta Blum Boutique in Preston Center Plaza. She had no business partners or immediate family, and the boutique will close on Saturday after a memorial service for Ms. Blum.
Ms. Blum became prominent on the Dallas fashion scene with the opening of the first boutique bearing her name in 1973 in the Highland Park area. There she sold the designs of Emanuel Ungaro, Valentino, Krizia, Oscar de la Renta, Scaasi and Franco Moschino, among others. Her clientele, Mr. Knight said, was "the Dallas woman who had a passion for fashion, as she did."
She also opened an Ungaro boutique next door to her main store, a Miss B shop for the younger customer, and a Christofle boutique. Her shops flourished during the Texas boom years of the 1970's and 1980's but succumbed to the economic downturn in the late 80's. Ms. Blum managed to hold on until 1992, when she closed her businesses.
The next year she returned with a boutique in the Lester Melnick store. In 1994 she opened the current Loretta Blum shop.
She had worked as a buyer for Bergdorf Goodman, Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue before going into business for herself.
Ms. Blum was born in Kehoka, Miss., attended Ohio State University and graduated from the Tobe-Coburn fashion school in New York City.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
In East Village, a Spirited Pace for Rental Project Development

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
With strong demand for rentals in Manhattan continuing, development activity is spreading into the East Village, where a nine-story apartment building is under construction and a seven-story structure has just opened for leasing.
"These two buildings are evidence that the rental market is moving back into fringe neighborhoods," said Brian G. Edwards, director of leasing at the Halstead Property Company, pointing to the residential activity in the downtown financial district and in the West 30's and 40's. 
 One of the rental buildings in the East Village, the seven-story Hudson East, at 225 East Sixth Street, started leasing last week. The building occupies part of the site that was the home of the Fillmore East, the storied rock concert hall, and later the Saint, a discotheque. The 86-unit project is being developed by the Hudson Companies of Brooklyn.
The other project, with 85 units, is under way at 94 East Fourth Street. The nine-story building is being developed by Bettina Equities of Manhattan.
The new buildings join a few other rental projects and a spate of renovations that have taken place in recent years in the East Village. Brokers say the area, known for its counterculture character, is becoming an appealing address for young professionals seeking a less costly alternative to neighborhoods like Greenwich Village and SoHo.
Estimates from Community Board 3, which guides growth in the area, are that about six other projects are also in various stages of development in the East Village. The projects could produce more than 200 low-income to market-rate residences, said Susan Vaughn, the board's chairwoman.
Also boding well for the East Village is the economic activity around it with, for example, the continued revival of Union Square and the resurgence of the Lower East Side retail area, where restaurants and retail outlets -- including Tahari and Kenar, which sell women's fashions -- are opening along main corridors like Orchard Street.
In the last year, the upper floors of eight five-story buildings along Orchard Street, long used for storage, also have been converted to about 128 apartments and others are planned, said Matthew A. Bauer, executive director of the Lower East Side Business Improvement District.
The rental market in the East Village is tight, with the vacancy rate under 5 percent, and rents are rising, brokers said. Rents in the area are $1,500 to $1,800 a month for one-bedroom units and $2,200 to $2,500 for two-bedroom apartments, Mr. Edwards of Halstead said. Those rents, he added, are still 10 to 15 percent lower than rents for comparably sized units in established areas like central Greenwich Village and the Upper East and West Sides.
Igal Feibush, a principal of Citi Habitats, a Manhattan residential brokerage concern, said the East Village also has the advantage of being accessible to the commerical cores of midtown and downtown while maintaining a sense of neighborhood.
Cathe Le Blanc, managing director of the rental division at the Corcoran Group, another brokerage concern, said, "What it comes down to is if developers offer the product at a price renters cannot get elsewhere, there will be a draw."
Of the 86 units in Hudson East, the newly completed rental building, most have one and two bedrooms, although there are a few studios and three-bedroom models. Eighty percent of the 438- to 1,556-square foot units are renting at market rates, which start at $1,700 a month for studios, $1,950 for one-bedrooms, $2,350 for two-bedrooms and $3,300 for three-bedrooms, said Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a residential brokerage company that is the project's leasing agent.
The remaining 20 percent will be subsidized and offered to tenants whose annual incomes are $13,700 to $22,050, depending on family size. Monthly rents for those units are $332 to $510.
Since leasing began at Hudson East, deposits have been taken on more than 60 percent of the market-rate units. "The popularity of the East Village, the shortage of new product and the strength of the city's rental market are the primary driving forces," said William Fowler, a Hudson principal.
Nearby, the Fourth Street building is rising on the site of the old Anderson Theater. Plans call for 85 studio to two-bedroom units, with 400 to 900 square feet each, and 12,000 square feet of first-floor retail space, said Sy Churgin, a principal of Architects Design Group, the project's architect.
The builder last spring redeveloped the four-story building that housed the theater's Second Avenue entry and lobby by adding a fifth floor and creating eight apartments, Mr. Churgin said. The rest of the theater, boarded up for the last two decades, was razed to make way for the new rental building, which is to be completed next spring, he said.
Officials at Bettina Equities, the building's developer, declined to give information about rental rates.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Rental projects in the East Village include an apartment building at 94 East Fourth Street, left, and Hudson East at 225 East Sixth Street. (Photographs by Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bad News Bearers

 BODY:
As usual, Joseph Kennedy didn't get it quite right. The Massachusetts Congressman announced yesterday that he had decided against running for governor. All over Washington, spinmasters will be laughing about how Mr. Kennedy blew a chance for a media age triple play. He could have announced bad news on a Friday, in August, just before a national holiday. Instead he marches out on a Thursday, leaving plenty of time for the high-audience news shows and a weekday paper. Duh.
Look, it's all right with us. Those Friday bombshells are a pain at deadline. They are also a calculated insult to the voters, reflecting the politicians' view that few confessions are so heinous, few blunders so stupid as to be remembered for two whole days. Washington does not believe in much these days, except that soft money is good and that negative news dies fast over a weekend. 
 Dropping news late on a Friday afternoon is a bipartisan Beltway institution. But history will record that it was the Reagan Administration that turned an occasional tactic into a strategic weapon. In 1982 it chose a Friday to announce that Bob Jones University could retain its tax-exempt status despite powerful evidence that it discriminated against blacks. President Reagan used a Friday in 1983 to inform the public that he had ordered 2,000 marines to the Mediterranean to protect the 1,370 marines already ashore in Lebanon. Six months later, in what was regarded by the Democrats as an admission of failure, Mr. Reagan informed Congress -- on a Friday, of course -- that they were coming out.
President Bush invented what reporters called "stealth veto days," which tended to be Black Fridays for the little people. Legislation that authorized higher taxes for millionaires, allowed federally financed abortions, provided additional benefits for the unemployed and required unpaid leave for new parents all fell to the veto pen in the fading light of several Fridays. Right after Tiananmen Square, Mr. Bush used a Friday to lift trade sanctions against two Chinese companies.
The Clinton Administration has built on the lessons of the G.O.P. Most of its incriminating Whitewater news has been dropped on Fridays, including embarrassing admissions about Hillary Clinton's billing records, tax returns dealing with the Clintons' Whitewater investments and, of course, those really lucky commodity trades.
Friday was "don't ask, don't tell" day. The Travelgate report suggesting that there may have been a little politics involved in the messy sacking of the White House transportation staff came out on the Friday before the Fourth of July. Maybe this year will be different. Or maybe, as you read this, somewhere in Washington or perhaps on Martha's Vineyard, employees of your Government are arming fax machines for a 4 P.M. launch. Just in case, let's go to DefCon 4.

HEADLINE: Robert Switzer, Co-Inventor Of Day-Glo Paint, Dies at 83

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Because Bob Switzer fell off a loading dock as a teen-ager six decades ago, Allied troops were not accidentally bombed by their own planes during World War II, boxes of Tide detergent glow on supermarket shelves and black light is big at rock concerts.
Mr. Switzer, who died on Aug. 20, and one of his two brothers invented fluorescent dyes, paints and penetrants that today are marketed under such names as Day-Glo and Magnaflux. Mr. Switzer, who was 83, died of Parkinson's disease at his home in Shaker Heights, Ohio, his daughter, Ann Switzer Swander, said. 
 During the Depression, Mr. Switzer was attending the University of California at Berkeley on a scholarship and had a job unloading crates of food from rail cars for the Safeway grocery store chain when he fell and hit his head on a rail.
Months later he awoke from a coma, his vision blurred. The family doctor recommended a darkened room during recuperation, which led to an interest in ultraviolet light, his youngest brother, Fred, said.
One day in 1934 the youth, who was then 20 and had his health back, and the middle brother, Joseph, who was 18 and a chemistry student at Berkeley, took a black light into the storeroom of their father's drugstore looking for naturally fluorescent organic compounds.
Soon they envisioned brightening up Joseph's amateur magic act and started mixing fluorescent compounds with shellac in the family bathtub, tests that their mother quickly ordered be moved out of the house. Their experiments yielded the first fluorescent paint, which they applied to a mask and headdress, creating for an audience in a darkened auditorium the illusion that a dancer went one way while her head floated off in another direction.
"They immediately realized the economic potential in entertainment and that there would be other opportunities," Brian Switzer, Robert Switzer's son, said.
Soon the brothers were in Cleveland creating all sorts of products, including bright fabric panels that troops in North Africa used to identify themselves as friendly to Allied dive bombers. The material also allowed warplanes to operate at night from aircraft carriers in the Pacific, a capability not enjoyed by the Japanese Navy, whose planes had to land on their carriers before nightfall.
The brothers developed fluorescent inks that bombardiers used during blackouts and fluorescent penetrants to find hidden flaws in machined parts, such as engine pistons and rockets' liquid oxygen tanks.
After the war the two older brothers created their own company in Cleveland, which they eventually named the Day-Glo Color Corporation, and their "coldfire" fluorescents brightened everything from swimsuits to Tide boxes to Hula-Hoops to traffic cones. They also developed fluorescents for the fire retardants that aerial tankers drop on forest fires, allowing the next plane to know where its load is not needed.
Fluorescents differ from ordinary paints in how they are affected by light waves. Ordinary paint absorbs some of the spectrum from white light and reflects the rest; thus, red paint absorbs blue and green wavelengths and reflects red.
Fluorescent paint, however, absorbs energy from short wavelength light (including ultraviolet light) and then re-emits the energy by converting it into photons of longer wavelength. Thus, ultraviolet light goes in and its energy is converted into visible light emitted by the chemicals in the paint, creating the bright fluorescent quality.
Lawrence A. Caughlin, who was for years a Day-Glo executive, said that Mr. Switzer "was a serious, unassuming man who despite his wealth often wore the same checked coat with pants that didn't match and a bow tie, and he didn't care."
Mr. Switzer was also scrupulous about complying with environmental laws, often spending more money than was required to meet the legal minimum standards for pollution control, Tom Gray, the company's longtime counsel, said.
Mr. Switzer's brother Joseph died in 1973. In 1985, with no one in the family interested in the complex chemistry needed to help the business grow, Mr. Switzer retired and Day-Glo was sold, with part of the proceeds being used to create the Robert and Patricia Switzer Foundation, which finances the Switzer Environmental Fellowships and a related program that are administered by the San Francisco Foundation and the New Hampshire Community Foundation. Over the last 11 years about 200 fellows, most of them graduate students in environmental sciences, have received $10,000 grants.
Jane Rogers, a grants officer at the San Francisco Foundation, said that "what Bob saw as an executive of an environmentally regulated company, and as a lifelong environmentalist, was that nobody had the science to answer the questions that arose about regulations. He wanted to advance the environmental science fields by producing practical problem-solvers in those fields as opposed to theoretical researchers."
In addition to his wife of 61 years, Patricia; his son Brian of Strongsville, Ohio; his daughter, Ann Switzer Swander of Ross, Calif., and his brother Fre of Fullerton, Calif., Mr. Switzer is survived by another son, Dr. Paul Switzer of New Bern. N.C.; seven grandchildren, and a great-granddaughter.

HEADLINE: Despite New, and Criticized, State Budget, S. & P. Raises Bond Rating

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 28

 BODY:
A major Wall Street firm raised its gauge of New York State's creditworthiness by a notch today, a move that offered a tempered endorsement of Gov. George E. Pataki's fiscal policies.
Even with the improvement, New York remains one of the two lowest-rated states, and analysts say the change is unlikely to have much effect on the cost to the state of borrowing money. 
 The firm, Standard & Poor's, raised its rating for the state's general obligation bonds, the bellwether that is considered a broad gauge of the state's fiscal health, from A-, the lowest rating of any state, to A, tied for the lowest with Louisiana. The firm had downgraded New York's rating in 1990 and 1992. (The highest rating is AAA.)
The timing of the rating change seems paradoxical, coming just after completion of a $67.4 billion state budget that was roundly criticized by independent budget monitors, including credit agencies.
The budget increases spending at double the rate of inflation; it spends $1 billion more than the state will take in for the year; it promises huge tax cuts and spending increases in future years, and it was a record 126 days late.
In fact, the rating shift had little to do with the new budget, said Robin Prunty, a director at Standard & Poor's. The company's report on the change praised just one feature of the budget: its setting aside of more than $900 million to cover expenses next year. Instead, she said, the new rating was prompted by the relative frugality of Mr. Pataki's first two budgets and the flood of revenue the state has received from the nearly three-year-old stock market boom, which produced a $1.4 billion surplus in the last fiscal year.
"The new rating is a reflection of changes that have occurred over a multiyear time frame," Ms. Prunty said. She added a note of caution, saying that recent tax and spending measures signed by the Governor "do pose some risks in the years 2000 and beyond, and that's still a concern to us."
Analysts said that the change was unlikely to affect the state's cost of borrowing money, but Mr. Pataki seized on it as evidence that he has brought some measure of restraint to a state known for late budgets, high spending and large debts, releasing a statement that said, "Our policies continue to pay dividends for the taxpayers of New York State."
The other major municipal credit rating agency, Moody's Investors Service, has given New York the second-lowest rating of any state, ahead of Louisiana. Renee Boicourt, vice president of Moody's, said the firm was unlikely to change its rating of New York's bonds in the near future.
The Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit group that monitors the city and state budgets, took issue with the new credit rating, in light of the new budget. "We look at a budget with a $1 billion deficit, a budget that gives you a $5 billion deficit in 2002, as a disaster, not something to be rewarded," said Cynthia Green, vice president of the commission.
A government agency's credit rating is the primary factor in determining the interest rates it must pay when it sells bonds, which is the way it borrows money. Past changes in the state's credit rating have raised or lowered the price of borrowing by as much as 2 percent, a difference of millions of dollars a year.
But Wall Street analysts said today's move would probably have little or no effect in the bond market because several factors had long moderated Standard & Poor's low rating of New York bonds.
One reason is that Moody's, which uses a different scale, rates New York's general obligation bonds at A2, which is equivalent to an A from Standard & Poor's, so today's action merely brings the two into agreement.
Also, for three years, Standard & Poor's has softened its New York credit rating by attaching to it a "positive outlook," an indication that the firm thought the state's condition was more likely to improve than not.
If there were a change in the interest rate the state paid, it could be particularly significant now, because the Governor and the Legislature have agreed to put on the November ballot a $2.4 billion bond issue, one of the largest in state history, for school construction and rehabilitation.

HEADLINE: Ball Fields For Housing: A Trade-Off Is Contested

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
For all its social problems, like drugs, poverty and unemployment, Harlem has always had one asset lacking in other parts of Manhattan: lots of available, unused land. Over the last 30 years, as landlords abandoned properties, the city turned some of them over to youth baseball leagues, leaving the neighborhood with an unusually large number of diamonds compared with other parts of the borough.
But lately, as Harlem has enjoyed the fruits of economic revival, the city has decided to take back some of that land for housing development. It is a trade-off that some feel the city should not be making, given the scarcity of recreational alternatives for the children of Harlem. 
 The latest dispute concerns the city's plan to build 30 affordable homes on a parcel of city-owned land on 100th Street between First and Second Avenues. Yesterday, some 150 community leaders, along with parents and players from two East Harlem leagues that would be affected, gathered at City Hall to denounce the move.
For the last six years, the 3.5-acre plot has been home to Harlem RBI New York, a nonprofit agency that runs baseball programs and after-school tutorial programs for 300 children. The city's plan could also temporarily close down another field, where 600 children in the East Harlem Little League play, opponents say.
"Nine hundred children are more important than 30 homes, which people in East Harlem cannot afford," said Richard A. Berlin, the executive director of Harlem RBI.
Housing officials say that the city has offered the leagues alternatives: leaving one field at the same site, and relocating the other, to a site 16 blocks away. But the groups have been reluctant to accept the trade-off, citing distance, interrupted play and crowding.
The 100th Street plot was originally cleared for low-income housing 30 years ago. But three lawsuits against the city kept it from development.
In 1991, a group of community volunteers cleaned the garbage-strewn lot and raised $1 million from the private sector to put in the baseball fields, a popular recreational oasis in the neighborhood.
Yesterday, even the threat of rain could not stop the children from their games there. While waiting for lunch of barbecued hot dogs and chips, Christopher Cespedes, 10, Frankie Ortiz, 12, and Isac Asencio, also 12, were anticipating their runs around the bases.
"If I don't play here, I'll be alone at home," Christopher said. "I don't want to stay home."
But earlier this year, the lawsuits against the city were resolved, freeing the land for development.
Richard T. Roberts, the Commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said all the youth leagues understood that their agreement with the city to use the land for baseball was only temporary.
"The site has always been a housing site," Mr. Roberts said. "The city now has the authority to move forward with housing development. They should have consulted with us before putting in all the money."
Mr. Roberts said his agency has offered to convert one of the two Harlem RBI ball fields into a permanent one, next to the new housing. The agency would also relocate the other field, to 111th Street between Park and Madison Avenues, he said: it would expand the lot, now home to a ball field used by the East Harlem Little League, so two fields could be accommodated.
His agency is also working with the Parks Department to add two more ball fields in East Harlem, one in Mount Morris Park, the other on a strip of park land on 96th Street and Second Avenue, near the High School for Cooperative Education, Mr. Roberts said.
"We recognized that the recreational space and the ball field issue is an important one, and we're trying to work through it," Mr. Roberts said. "We're trying to identify sites and figure out how these things will be financed. We're serious about it."
But both Mr. Berlin and Olga Seda, who is on the board of East Harlem Little League, say they are unconvinced about the deal.
Mr. Berlin said that the 100th Street site would be too crowded for both a ball field and the housing development.
And, he added, there is no guarantee that the swap would not disrupt the playing season.
Work to expand the 111th Street field would, in the meantime, shut down the field used by the East Harlem Little League, Mrs. Seda said.
They also said that neither the Housing Department nor the Parks Department has come up with concrete plans to pay for the additional ball parks.

HEADLINE: New Jersey and New York Plan Harbor Cleanup

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

 BODY:
The Governors of New York and New Jersey joined with Federal environmental officials yesterday to unveil an ambitious plan to help restore and protect New York Harbor, the rivers and streams that empty into it, and the ocean waters stretching from Montauk Point, N.Y., to Cape May, N.J.
It is the first time that both states have agreed on a comprehensive regional approach to clean up the harbor and ocean waters. The plan, which is the culmination of almost eight years of discussion and debate, will cost billons of dollars and take almost two decades to implement fully. 
 Although the plan does not impose any new regulations or include any new state or Federal dollars, it will serve as a blueprint and a guide for government officials and environmental groups reviewing existing regulations and looking to spend dollars on the cleanup.
Both New York and New Jersey have agreed to implement 75 percent of the report's 380 specific recommendations, which vary from tightening limits on copper and mercury levels from municipal wastewater plants to preserving habitats for shore birds and other wildlife in Jamaica Bay and the Arthur Kill off Staten Island.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Gov. George E. Pataki reached agreement on the plan in the spring, but unveiled it yesterday during a news conference at Battery Park City, with New York Harbor and the Statue of Liberty as a backdrop.
"Our estuary and ocean waters will be healthy because we are going to work together, New Jersey and New York and the Federal Goverment, to build on the successes we have already achieved individually," Governor Whitman said. "And the results of this partnership will be impressive."
Governor Pataki said he was confident that the plan would lead to significant improvement in water quality and natural habitat. "You'll see a resurgence in the waterfronts of Manhattan, Brooklyn, Staten Island and New Jersey."
Since 1992, the two states and the Federal Government have made tremendous strides in cleaning up the harbor and waterways. Steps have also been taken to reduce the amount of debris washing up on beaches. But serious problems persist.
The fish and shellfish population, which continues to decline, is often found to be contaminated. Beaches are sometimes closed to swimmers because of high bacteria levels in the water.
The most costly recommendation in the plan is for both states to address the biggest source of fecal bacteria in the New York Harbor Harbor area and the New York Bight: combined-sewer overflows. The Whitman administration has pledged to spend more than $1.1 billion to improve municipal systems in which combined sewer and storm drains discharge raw sewage into the waterways during heavy rains. New York City is to spend up to $5 billion to make similar improvements.
The plan does not offer a solution, however, for what some environmentalists and economists say is the most pressing problem facing New York Harbor today. And that is what to do about the mud, tainted with industrial pollutants, that is dredged from the harbor to deepen shipping channels and help maintain the harbor as a world-class port.
Beginning on Sept. 1, the dredged mud can no longer be deposited in a century-old dump six miles east of Sandy Hook, N.J., because of stricter Federal environmental standards. Officials from both states, which share the economic benefits of the harbor, are still trying to come up with a long-term plan to find a new dump for the more than 3 million tons of tainted mud dredged each year.
But the new plan is aimed at reducing some of the pollutants that now flow into the harbor from the silt-laden Hudson, Hackensack, Passaic and Raritan Rivers. For the first time, state and Federal officials said, there is a strong commitment by both states to enhance monitoring of toxic chemicals in the waterways, and to track down and eliminate the sources that they are coming from. The toxic chemicals not only contaminate fish and shellfish, causing restrictions on consumption, but also contaminate the sediment, limiting the options for its disposal.
The new plan, covering 26,000 square miles of ocean and estuary, also covers the preservation and restoral of habitats for wildlife. As an example, the plan recommends the construction of fish ladders to help species like herring and shad make their way upstream to spawn.
Dennis J. Suszkowski, science director for the Hudson River Foundation, praised the plan. "It is very important because it is a long-term commitment to cleaning up the harbor and the estuary," he said. "There are a lot of problems that are out there that have not been resolved."
But Benjamin Longstreth, a spokesman for the Baykeeper program of the American Littoral Society, based in Sandy Hook, N.J., said he believed that the plan could have gone further.
"The real key is going to be the implementation of it," he said. "It could make great strides towards improving the health of the harbor and the estuary."
Jeanne M. Fox, regional administrator for the U.S. Department of Environmental Protection, called implementation of the plan "quite a challenge."
"However, I am confident that with the commitment from the states, local governments, and others," Ms. Fox said, "we will achieve our objectives for a vital environment and a vital economy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In an at-the-scene announcement of a plan to clean up New York Harbor and the waterways that empty into it, Gov. George E. Pataki made his announcement while Gov. Christine Todd Whitman waited her turn. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)(pg. B5)

HEADLINE: North Koreans Seek Famine's Antidote in U.S.

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: KENYON, Minn., Aug. 26

 BODY:
Choe Kang Ryong was a long way from the scorched cornfields, ruined rice paddies and hungry, skeletal children of North Korea. Alone and silent, he stood for a little while today on the edge of hundreds of acres of healthy corn, food for the plump hogs of the Cannon Valley Cooperative. Wading into the dense bumper crop that closed over his head, the slender North Korean reached down to crumble the soil. He felt the girth of a strong green stalk.
"They seem to like the farm," a co-op manager remarked to an American colleague. 
 Mr. Choe is director of seed production and management in the Agricultural Commission of North Korea. For a week, he and five colleagues -- two livestock specialists, a crop production official and two economic advisers to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Pyongyang -- are touring America to see how and why farming works the way it does here.
Their visit, organized by a North Korean-born American seed expert from Minnesota, Pilju Kim Joo, is a first. When Dr. Joo, an agricultural consultant who has been visiting North Korea regularly since 1994, proposed the trip, it was a gamble. But to her surprise, Pyongyang responded quickly and affirmatively.
North Korea is desperate. Two years of floods, a summerlong drought and decades of economic mismanagement by a totalitarian leftist Government that thought it did not need the outside world has left North Koreans malnourished and facing famine -- and the crisis has not yet bottomed out, international aid organizations say. Seventy percent of the North Korean corn crop may already be lost, raising fears about how millions of people will feed themselves this winter.
The officials on this trip told of useless irrigation pumps disabled by an absence of spare parts, deforested and eroding hillsides planted with the wrong crops, cutworms devouring fields because there are no pesticides and seed corn of such low quality that it is sowed in practice patches from which green survivors are later transplanted to the real cornfields. Double cropping -- planting one grain in summer and another in winter on the same field -- is still experimental.
This week, notebooks in hand, the North Koreans have scribbled their way through a goat farm, a pig nursery, genetics laboratories, seed stores, grain elevators and dairies. They have plowed on foot through thigh-high prairie grassland to ask questions and take notes on a herd of beef cattle grazing on ranch land beyond where the dirt road ends. They also staggered through the Minnesota State Fair.
Next stop is Missouri and after that Georgia, where another Korean-American, Park Han Sik, director of the University of Georgia's Center for Global Issues, will be the host.
Mr. Choe, 54, had one word today for what he's been seeing. "Impressive," he said as he traveled along another spacious freeway to another neat Midwestern town under its shade trees. He also had a word for himself: "Envious."
In a week when North Korean diplomatic defections were in the news, the agriculture team is traveling largely unattended, although it is assumed that at least one of them is watching the others.
North Korea and the United States do not have diplomatic relations, but the visitors were issued American visas in Beijing. The Clinton Administration has pledged about $100 million in emergency food aid to North Korea, $55 million of which in grains being distributed by five agencies: Amigos Internationales, CARE, Catholic Relief Services, Mercy Corps and World Vision. Dr. Joo is a consultant for the last two groups.
Dr. Joo, a former seed company executive who is now vice president of Agglobe Technologies, a consulting firm in Minneapolis, had to raise the money for the North Koreans' visit to Minnesota from private sources. She also collects money and donations of seed and other farming material and equipment for the North Koreans because trading with North Korea is prohibited by an American embargo.
The North Koreans said they were given 10 days' notice that they were going to the United States, news that shocked their families, one said. North Koreans are more accustomed to trips to Cuba and Vietnam or other third-world nations. Mr. Choe remembers going to Ghana to teach traditional farming methods. Until the early 1970's, when the North Korean economy began its steady decline, Dr. Joo said, North Koreans compared their living standards favorably with those of South Korea. The gap is now huge.
Here in Minnesota, Mr. Choe and his teammates have collected a lot of statistics, an impressive reading list and a few books from teaching institutions and farmers' shelves -- all in English, a language only one of the officials reads. They all acquired baseball caps from the University of Minnesota, a gift from Kent Crookston, head of the department of agronomy and plant genetics, who opened his laboratories to them.
The North Koreans have asked a lot of questions that dance around the one important lesson of this visit that may be most difficult to absorb: Minnesota's green wealth has its roots in independent farming families, in self-help cooperatives and lately in private research paid for by seed and pharmaceutical companies. Government may have a role -- at the University of Minnesota, the Koreans learned about land-grant colleges -- but not the role they know.
North Korea has a rigid state economy. An official tried to explain its relation to agriculture today during a conversation about the American cooperative movement and the very different North Korean cooperative farm, where production goals and methods are determined by the Government. "We have no private farmers," he said. "We have cooperatives. Of course, the farmer joins voluntarily."
The North Koreans asked many questions about productivity: "How many people does it take to raise this many pigs?" "How many farmers work on this field?"
Often the answers seemed to puzzle them: "A guy and his family." "The farmer and maybe two sons."
Dr. Joo, 60, who grew up in South Korea after the Korean War and came to the United States as a student in 1962, says that the North Korean worker is as good as any in Asia, with a strong work ethic and easy grasp of new technologies. The North Koreans are just short of many things. One of them is an understanding of what makes economies take off.
"A centralized economy is good up to a point for poor countries," she said. "Then you need human desire -- the drive for a superior life style, a better life. Growth comes with desire."
Dr. Joo, who received a Ph.D. from Cornell, said that for the moment, North Koreans are limited to carrying out the policies of the founding "Great Leader," Kim Il Sung, or his son and heir, Kim Jong Il.
In what were almost literally his last words before his death in 1994, Kim Il Sung was reported to have urged greater productivity in agriculture and the greater use of livestock "to turn grass into milk and meat." That left a good deal of room, and the North Koreans are apparently no longer afraid to interpret.
Mr. Choe, for example, talked today about how impressed he was with the ingenuity demonstrated by Vincent Maefsky of the Poplar Hill Dairy Goat Farm in Scandia, Minn., who had designed his own mechanical milking system for maximum efficiency. Through interpreters, Mr. Maefsky, who was born in Brooklyn, convinced Mr. Choe that bringing grain and grass to the goats rather than taking the goats out to pasture meant that more goats could be raised more efficiently in a relatively small space.
Dr. Joo said that she and her husband, Young Don Joo, a South Korean-born livestock trader in the Midwest, were members of the last generation of Koreans to remember the country whole, before the Korean war in the 1950's, and she makes a point of bringing young Koreans from North and South together whenever she can. This week, she invited a South Korean researcher at the University of Minnesota, Huh Ho Kil, to talk to the visitors on his specialty, soil. He didn't realize until just before the lecture that his audience would be North Koreans.
"I couldn't believe it; I had never met North Koreans," he said later, when he and a few South Korean agronomy students joined the visitors at the Joo home for a Korean dinner prepared with the help of Korean restaurants and a Korean American professor of veterinary science who wanted the visitors to feel at home in Minneapolis. The atmosphere was relaxed, the conversation only gently probing. There were drinks, toasts and general merriment. Both sides said later that Korea would someday be reunited and that they were eager to know their estranged neighbors.
Over lunch that day, Dr. Huh had struck up a conversation with the North Korean party's soil specialist.
"I looked at them and talked with them," Dr. Huh said. "And I saw in them something of me."
"They did not have horns," he said, laughing and holding fingers up over his ears. "They did not have horns."
