HEADLINE: Alabama G.O.P. Governor Sees a Different New South

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala.

 BODY:
As Republican governors have taken control of statehouses around the South, their most exalted models have been Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina and Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, two former Governors who built broad support by moving aggressively to improve education and to recruit industry.
But here in Alabama, a state with a history of go-their-own-way governors, Fob James Jr. is defiantly bucking the pattern. While other governors open their treasuries to industrial prospects, Mr. James has attacked big tax breaks and other economic incentives as "corporate welfare." While others emphasize education, Mr. James has suggested shrinking the state's expansive university system by 10 percent. 
 Ask Alabamians how they regard Mr. James these days, and they are likely to revisit his February threat to use the National Guard to block a court order demanding the removal of the Ten Commandments from a Gadsden courtroom. Or they may mention the 34-page letter he recently sent to a Federal judge arguing that the Constitution's Bill of Rights did not apply to the states.
They will chortle over his Fob isms, like this summer's recommendation that state workers study the Waffle House chain, the Governor's favorite restaurant, as a model for government efficiency and consistency. "They're all good," Mr. James told the state personnel board. "That's the thing I like about it. There ain't no surprises."
Concerned that Mr. James's style and his emphasis on states' rights are only accentuating Alabama's image as a backwater and discouraging economic development, the state's industrial recruiters have grown increasingly critical of the Governor. And only a year before he faces re-election, Mr. James is beginning to alienate the state's normally Republican business leaders.
One little-known Republican businessman, Lewis Leslie McAllister Jr., a manufacturer of shower doors, has already announced a primary challenge. A more prominent Republican, Winton Blount 3d, a former chairman of the Business Council of Alabama and of the State Republican Party's finance committee, is considering running.
There are other signs of disunity. Republican lawmakers recently rejected the Governor's call for a slight decrease in college financing in a special legislative session. When Mr. James wrote his letter challenging the Federal courts' jurisdiction over the states, Alabama's Attorney General, Bill Pryor, a fellow Republican, quickly declared that the Governor's views "do not state the legal position of the State of Alabama."
And while most political analysts believe Mr. James will be difficult to defeat next year, 49 percent of 407 Alabamians questioned in a recent poll, including 30 percent of Republicans, said they would vote for someone other than Mr. James. The poll's margin of sampling error was plus or minus five percentage points.
Such intraparty dissent is becoming more common as Republicanism gains momentum in the South. In South Carolina this year, Gov. David Beasley, a Republican, called for the Confederate battle flag to be lowered from atop the State Capitol, only to have legislators from his own party quickly bury the proposal.
Some political scientists see such fractures as signs of the maturation of Republican politics in the South. In Alabama, the party now claims six out of eight state constitutional officers, both United States Senators and five out of seven members of Congress.
"It shows the growth of the Republican Party in one way because they have the luxury of some disunity now," said William H. Stewart, the chairman of the political science department at the University of Alabama. "They feel they can afford to speak out without giving advantage to the Democrats."
To Alabamians who remember Gov. George C. Wallace, Mr. James's brand of populism has a familiar feel, even if his defense of states' rights is rooted in religion rather than race.
In late June, Mr. James wrote Judge Ira DeMent of Federal District Court, asking him to reverse a decision that struck down a 1993 state law intended to restore voluntary prayer to Alabama schools.
In his letter, Mr. James argued that the Supreme Court had overstepped its authority in separating church and state.
"The Supreme Court recognizes no authority greater than itself," he wrote. "Not the Constitution. Not the Almighty. In the name of separation of church and state, the Court seeks to rule the church. It tells the believing community -- the church -- where and when they may not pray. How dangerous a situation when human government steps over this line."
Judge DeMent responded by reminding Mr. James that the Supreme Court's primacy on constitutional interpretation was established in 1803. The Governor's request, he wrote in denying Mr. James's motion, "threatens to erode this principle and, consequently, poses a serious threat to our system of democratic self-government."
The Governor, an Episcopalian, has made no secret of his belief that religion has a role in public life. His legal adviser, Bill Gray, came under attack last year after it was disclosed that he questioned judicial candidates about their religious preferences and churchgoing.
And when one state judge ordered another state judge to remove the Ten Commandments from his courtroom wall, Mr. James said he would call out the National Guard to defend the tablets. If the Supreme Court eventually orders the removal of the tablets, Mr. James said in a recent interview, "I won't obey that order unless I have a call from the President to do it."
To many prominent Alabamians, Mr. James's positions on the Bill of Rights and the Ten Commandments were final straws.
"Why he does some of these things is beyond me," said David G. Bronner, a political independent who served as Mr. James's finance director in a previous James administration and is now chief executive officer of the state's public employees pension fund. "He focuses on things that, at best, the public may like to hear but in reality do not do much for a poor state. It has a lot of the same synergies of the Wallace era: get people all riled up and not accomplish anything."
In the interview, the 62-year-old Governor, who was born Forrest H. and inherited a family nickname, made it clear that he was not much concerned about his state's image. An All-American halfback at Auburn University who made a fortune by manufacturing plastic-coated barbells, Mr. James said that industrial prospects looked far more carefully at the bottom line than at the outside perception of a state.
"Maybe they think people come in because of the way the government combs its hair," Mr. James said of the state's economic development recruiters. "I think it has to do with return on investment."
As for his critics, Mr. James said: "They can keep squawking. I like for those kind of people to squawk, the louder the better."
Even Mr. James's opponents do not question the earnestness of his commitment to the issues he has embraced. And they acknowledge that his stands appeal to a large segment of Alabama's electorate.
Merle Black, an Emory University political scientist and an authority on Southern Republican politics, said Mr. James and his ideological soul mate, Gov. Kirk Fordice of Mississippi, had adopted a "hard right, almost primitive Republicanism aimed at attracting huge majorities of white voters who are primarily concerned with cultural issues."
The instinct to give those voters what they want, Mr. Black suggested, may explain Mr. James's reintroduction of chain gangs for state inmates, his support for voluntary school prayer, his expenditure of $3,000 in state money to send biology teachers a book on creationism and his encouragement to teachers to give troublesome students "a pop on the fanny." Speaking to pastors last November, Mr. James offered this solution to the problem of youth violence: "A good butt-whipping and then a prayer is a wonderful remedy."
In one of his few racially charged stands, Mr. James has asserted that it was a mistake four years ago for the state to accede to a state court's ruling that the Confederate battle flag be lowered from atop the State Capitol.
In the interview, Mr. James said he was not convinced that the flag offended the state's black population.
"Does it?" he asked. "Maybe it does. Maybe it doesn't. I don't know that."
He added: "I think it's a sick form of political correctness for everybody to act like they're offended because history is portrayed like history was."
When confronted with criticism of his economic development efforts, Mr. James points to the state's unemployment rate of 4.5 percent, the lowest in 20 years and among the lowest in the South. The national unemployment rate in July was 4.8 percent. Mr. James also notes that new industrial investment in 1995, his first year in office, was nearly $3.8 billion, the highest in 14 years.
But industrial recruiters in Alabama attribute that spike to Mr. James's predecessor, James E. Folsom Jr., who lured a Mercedes-Benz manufacturing plant to Vance, Ala., with nearly $300 million in government incentives. In 1996, investment dropped to $2.6 billion. And Thomas A. Harris, senior managing director of Merchant Capital, an investment banking firm in Montgomery that underwrites industrial bond deals around the South, predicted that investment would drop by at least another $1 billion in 1997.
When the Economic Development Association of Alabama surveyed 400 members at its July meeting about their most pressing concerns, a majority listed Mr. James's inattentiveness to recruiting industry as their top complaint.
Economic development officials say that while Mr. James will make calls to prospects when asked, he rarely takes the initiative. And by the Governor's own admission, he has "trashed" the state's incentive program by eliminating a number of provisions, including one that allowed relocating companies to keep state taxes they normally would have paid.
That move, the development officials said, was the equivalent of unilateral disarmament for a state like Alabama. They accuse the Governor of squandering a unique opportunity to capitalize on the Mercedes deal by using the auto maker's decision to put a plant in the state as a marketing tool.
"We're not even talking to the prospects because they're not coming," Mr. Harris said. "That's the problem. It's hard to swing at a pitch when you're in the dugout."
Mr. James has switched parties twice, from Republican to Democrat in the early 1970's, before his first successful run for Governor in 1978 (he served one term and chose not to run again), and then back to Republican before winning again in 1994. With the business community grumbling, that rootlessness may make it more difficult for Mr. James to caulk the growing fissures in his party, political scientists said.
And Q. Whitfield Ayres, a Republican pollster in Atlanta, said many of Mr. James's stands on social issues were harmful to the party because they "evoke all the most negative stereotypes of the Old South."
There is nothing wrong with Republicans talking about social issues, Mr. Ayres said. But Mr. James is talking about them, he said, "in a way that makes it easy for the anti-Southern snobs to say, 'See, nothing's changed.' "

HEADLINE: Low Inflation Seen Amid Solid Growth In Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28

 BODY:
The economy grew at a 3.6 percent annual pace during the spring, far higher than the 2.2 percent rate estimated a month ago, the Government said today. Even with the more robust growth, inflation remained subdued during the second quarter.
The report on gross domestic product -- the total output of goods and services within the nation's borders -- was the latest to show the economy continuing to grow robustly despite earlier predictions of a sharper slowdown from the first quarter's 4.9 percent annual rate. A report last week showing a marked narrowing of the nation's trade deficit in June also pointed to a pickup in economic strength. 
 Today's G.D.P. revision was the sharpest in three and a half years. The Commerce Department gives three G.D.P. estimates each quarter as more information becomes available. The final second-quarter revision is due on Sept. 26.
What was remarkable about today's data was that despite the higher estimate of growth, the G.D.P. deflator, a measure of inflation followed by many on Wall Street, increased at a 1.5 percent pace in the second quarter, up slightly from a previous calculation of 1.4 percent and the lowest since 1964.
The signs of moderate inflation and relief that the revised growth number was not closer to the 4.9 percent annual rate recorded in the first quarter of 1997 prompted a rally in the bond market, pushing yields lower. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for consumer and corporate loans -- fell to its lowest level in more than a week.
Despite the relief that growth was not faster, a case is building for the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates to prevent unsustainably rapid growth from reviving inflation, analysts said.
The economy "is just whirling along," said M. Kathryn Eickhoff, a New York consultant, "way over the speed limit."
Federal Reserve policy makers next meet on Sept. 30.
"I think they're going to be concerned," Ms. Eickhoff added, about an economy growing perhaps twice as fast as growth in the labor force and productivity allow even if inflation, a lagging indicator, remains tame.
Paul W. Boltz, an economist at T. Rowe Price, mostly agreed, although he pointed to a huge buildup in inventories seen in the report, which will restrain growth in coming months. Inventories rose in the second quarter at a $77.7 billion annual rate instead of a rate of $66.8 billion -- the fastest pace since 1984. A backup in goods means that production could slow later in the year unless consumer spending picks up.
Indeed, today's report, Mr. Boltz said, "explains how the unemployment rate was able to drop as much as it did," to 4.9 percent for the April-June period from 5.3 percent in the first quarter.
But John Ryding, a senior economist at Bear, Stearns, contended that a new era had arrived, one in which strong growth and low inflation can coexist indefinitely.
Low inflation has been a result in part of "how much corporations are focusing on costs and putting the savings into investments" in new equipment, he said.
Business raised such investment at a 23.8 percent pace during the second quarter, today's report showed, up from the initial estimate of 20.4 percent and more than triple the first-quarter increase. This also represented the biggest surge in 14 years.
But the chief contributors to the 1.4-point, or $25.4 billion, revision in G.D.P. were exports of goods and services and inventories. Each of these was $10.9 billion higher, on an annual basis, than first estimated, with the inventory surge the biggest since the summer of 1984.
Personal spending was raised $2.1 billion through the revision, but that growth was still less than one-fifth of the increase in the first three months of the year.
As for the related inflation, the price index for gross domestic purchases rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter instead of the six-tenths of 1 percent estimated a month ago. This was far less than the 1.9 percent first-quarter pace, mainly reflecting a sharp drop in energy prices.
In its first estimate of corporate profits for the spring quarter, the department reported that growth slowed to 1.9 percent from 4.3 percent for profits from current production but rose 1.6 percent from six-tenths of 1 percent when gauged by current-production cash flow.
Confirming that the labor market remains tight, the Labor Department reported today that first-time applicants for unemployment benefits fell by 16,000 last week, to 323,000, a larger decline than expected. The four-week moving average, however, climbed 12,250, to 320,750.
The Conference Board's index of help wanted advertising was unchanged at 88 in July, remaining in the upper part of a narrow band over the last three years.

HEADLINE: Girl, 2, Slain For Crying, Officials Say

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
A 2-year-old girl found battered, unconscious and hemorrhaging internally in her Brooklyn home on Wednesday was beaten to death, apparently because she would not stop crying, investigators said yesterday as the child's mother and her boyfriend were charged with her killing.
An autopsy showed that the victim, Brenda Pena, suffered fatal lacerations of the pancreas, liver, small intestine and other organs and bled internally, as a result of "multiple blunt impacts to the torso," said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the New York City Medical Examiner's office, which ruled the death a homicide. 
 After a day of questioning, the girl's mother, Irene Loriano, 21, of 563 Crescent Street in East New York, and her boyfriend, Donald Coad, 21, of 108 Avenue D in Manhattan, were taken to the 75th Precinct station in Brooklyn and booked on homicide and other charges.
Investigators said both had made statements indicating that Mr. Coad had become enraged and beaten the girl Wednesday morning because she would not stop crying. When Brenda fell unconscious, the investigators said, someone in the household called the police, and the Emergency Medical Service took the child to Brookdale Hospital Medical Center, where she was pronounced dead on arrival.
In the tragic lists of fatal child abuse in New York City, where the perils of growing up in households tormented by alcohol, drug abuse and other problems are legion, the most common evil may be the senseless battering of infants by mothers' boyfriends, often because of a child's crying, officials say.
"It's fairly common," said one investigator, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "There's often a history of domestic violence, and it extends to a child. Men have this power."
It was unclear if drugs or alcohol had any role in Brenda Pena's death. And while some investigators said there were no signs of long-term abuse of the girl, other officials said that doctors at Brookdale had found bruises on her body in various stages of healing. These bruises did not necessarily indicate long-term abuse, but doubts remained.
However, the family had not come to the notice of child-welfare officials. "There was no prior report of abuse or neglect regarding the mother or this child," said Maggie Lear, a spokeswoman for the city's Administration for Children's Services, which began an inquiry. She said that Brenda's 4-year-old brother, who has been placed in foster care, showed no signs of abuse or neglect.
Brenda Pena, who was born in February 1995, lived with her mother, brother and an aunt in a neighborhood of well-kept, two-story brick houses. Neighbors, stunned at news of her death, recalled a little girl who frequently played with other children in a yard behind the house on Crescent Street, or toddled along with her mother to the store.
At 11:20 A.M. on Wednesday, a caller, described only as a member of the victim's household, brought the police and an Emergency Medical Service team to the family's first-floor apartment. They found Brenda unconscious; her torso, arms and back were streaked with dark bruises. "She had been very badly beaten," said an official familiar with the investigation, who also insisted on anonymity.
The medical team administered cardiopulmonary resuscitation at the apartment, investigators said. But efforts to save her life were unsuccessful.
After making statements yesterday, investigators said, Mr. Coad was charged with three counts of homicide -- one of intentional killing, one of causing the girl's death by depraved indifference and one of causing the death of a person under 11 by depraved indifference. The charges carry varying penalties, up to 25 years to life in prison.
Ms. Loriano was charged with criminally negligent homicide, an accusation that she failed to protect the child in a deadly situation, a Class E felony with a maximum penalty of four years in prison. Both suspects were charged with endangering the welfare the child, a misdemeanor.
Little was known yesterday about the nature or duration of the mother's relationship with Mr. Coad. A woman who said she was a sister of Mr. Coad said in a brief telephone interview that he had never before been in trouble, though he was an unemployed school dropout.
Asked if her brother had a temper or was subject to angry outbursts, the woman said: "Only if somebody wears his pants." Asked what she meant, she said, 'You know, if you put on my shirt, I get angry."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: CONNECTICUT;
Yale Appointee to Lead Local and State Affairs

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
Yale University yesterday named Bruce Alexander, an expert in urban real estate ventures and redevelopment, as its vice president and director of New Haven and state affairs.
Mr. Alexander, a Yale alumnus, retired in January 1996 as senior vice president and director of new business for the Rouse Corporation, having served 15 years as director of the company's commercial development division. 
 Mr. Alexander was responsible for Rouse's retail and mixed-use properties throughout the United States. Among the projects developed under his direction were the South Street Seaport in lower Manhattan, Harborplace in Baltimore, Grand Avenue in Milwaukee, Pioneer Place in Portland, Ore., and Riverwalk in New Orleans.
"This appointment reinforces this administration's commitment to the economic and human development of the city and region," President Richard C. Levin of Yale said in announcing the appointment.
Yale, in recent years, has been working on revitalizing the city by drawing in retail outlets and encouraging Yale faculty and staff to purchase homes in New Haven.
Mr. Alexander, who graduated from Yale in 1965, is the founding chairman of the university's New Haven urban advisory committee and is a member of the Yale Corporation's buildings and ground committee. He will assume the new position in May.

Serbs Fight NATO Troops; 2 Americans Are Hurt

Tensions at Zionism Centenary
The recent disputes over money from Nazis and Holocaust victims stored in Swiss banks loomed over a conference in Basel to mark the 100th anniversary of Zionism. Hate mail sent to the vice president of the Swiss Jewish Federation reflects a deterioration in Switzerland's relationship with Jews, Israel and America since the Swiss handling of the money became an issue. A1
 
Rabin Considered Ceding Golan
In secret talks in 1994, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel told the American Secretary of State that he could consider a peace with Syria in which Israel would withdraw to pre-1967 borders, effectively ceding the Golan, a former Israeli official said. Mr. Rabin's purported willingness to discuss such a plan went well beyond what has widely been understood to have been his position. A3
 
Suspicious Blast in Russia
The Clinton Administration said Russia may have detonated a nuclear weapon on a remote Arctic island in spite of its support for a moratorium on nuclear tests. The officials said "a seismic event" took place on Aug. 16 near Novaya Zemlya, a nuclear testing site. Moscow denied the suggestion that it had tested nuclear weapons. A7
 
U.N. Restricts Angolan Rebels
Frustrated by years of fruitless efforts to lure the Angolan rebel leader Jonas Savimbi to cooperate with the Government of Angola, the Security Council voted to impose an international travel ban on all senior officials of Mr. Savimbi's organization. The Council also voted to prohibit flights to areas under rebel control and banned certain contracts for the Savimbi forces. A8
 
France Admits 2d-Rate Status
France, in a rare admission that it was a second-ranking power, would accept the global supremacy of the United States "without acrimony," Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine told an annual conference of French ambassadors, though he said the nation would oppose Washington when legitimate interests were at stake. While Mr. Vedrine said Paris should maintain an open and friendly dialogue with Washington, his remarks were an unusual admission for France, which often portrays itself as a rival in world diplomacy.

Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d announced that he would not run for governor of Massachusetts, ending a campaign that had been engulfed by controversy over his family even before it was officially launched. Mr. Kennedy said he had concluded that the race would focus not on issues but on "personal and family pressures." A1
 
Affirmative Action Ban Begins
California's ban on preferences went haltingly into effect almost a year after voters approved a sweeping end to affirmative action programs in the state. With issues of the law still to be decided by state appellate courts and the United States Supreme Court, the day was marked by protests and quiet celebration, but also by a great deal of confusion. Newt Gingrich, Paleontologist
Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House, took one of his oddest detours ever from politics, interrupting a two-week-long national tour to fulfill a lifelong fantasy -- digging for dinosaur bones -- which he pursued with such dogged determination that he refused to leave a private ranch just east of Bozeman, Mont., until he came up with a find. A10
 
Scientists Find a Sun in Flux
Scientists have discovered immense "rivers" of hot, electrically charged gas flowing beneath the surface near the polar regions of the Sun, a surprising phenomenon that could help them understand sunspots and other disturbances that often cause electromagnetic storms and power failures on Earth. In their analysis of observations by a European-American spacecraft, the scientists also have determined that the entire outer layer of the Sun, to a depth of at least 15,000 miles, is slowly flowing from the equator to the poles. A12
 
Judge Rules Against Nichols
Lawyers for Terry L. Nichols, who will stand trial next month in the Oklahoma City bombing, lost their bid to block the possibility of a death sentence against him as well as a request that the judge exclude what one prosecutor described as more than 60 percent of the Government's evidence against him. A8
 
Warning on Squirrel Brains
Doctors in Kentucky have issued a warning that people should not eat squirrel brains, a regional delicacy, because squirrels may carry a variant of so-called "mad cow" disease that can be transmitted to humans and is fatal. In the last four years, 11 cases of a human form of transmissible spongiform encephalopathy called Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease have been diagnosed in rural western Kentucky. Of the 11 patients, at least 6 have died. A10
 
Guilty Plea in Campaign Case
The son of Ronald H. Brown, the late Commerce Secretary, pleaded guilty to illegally funnelling $4,000 from an Oklahoma company into the Senate campaign of Edward M. Kennedy three years ago. A10

Police Charge 'Zoo Crew' With Running Drug Ring
Many people in the poor sections of Newark saw the "Zoo Crew" as young, community-minded entrepreneurs who, in addition to bringing shiny new businesses to boarded-up blocks, donated money for basketball clinics for neighborhood children. But authorities said an 18-month investigation had shown that the Zoo Crew was, in fact, a drug gang that used its businesses as fronts for a "sophisticated and lucrative" street trade in cocaine and heroin. Armed with arrest warrants, some 200 law-enforcement agents raided 13 locations and arrested 21 people, seizing cash, weapons and thousands of vials of heroin and cocaine. A1
 
Immigrant's Condition Worsens
The medical condition of Abner Louima, the Haitian immigrant allegedly brutalized by the police in a Brooklyn precinct house, took a sharp turn for the worse, and he underwent surgery again. Doctors at Brooklyn Hospital changed Mr. Louima's condition from stable to critical. B1

Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said reports of assault, weapons possession and other violent offenses in New York City's public schools fell during the last school year, but that less serious offenses like disorderly conduct and harassment rose, particularly in elementary schools. B2
 
Governors Unveil Harbor Plan
The governors of New York and New Jersey joined with Federal environmental officials to unveil a new strategic plan to help restore and protect New York Harbor, the surrounding estuaries and the ocean waters of the New York Bight, stretching from Montauk to Cape May, N.J. B1

The police believe that a stolen car they recovered was used in the gangland-style execution of Ralph C. Dols, an off-duty housing police officer who was fatally shot Monday night outside his Brooklyn apartment. B3

Some 150 community leaders from Harlem, along with parents and youth baseball league players, gathered at City Hall to denounce a move by the city to relocate a ball field in order to make room for housing. City official say that it has tried to offer the groups alternative sites for the fields. But some groups, like the East Harlem Little League, said the new sites are too far away. B1

HEADLINE: Gumshoes With White Collars;
Deal Spotlights New Shrewdness in Detective Business

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Jules B. Kroll has made a career of directing delicate and confidential investigations. Most often his clients have been foreign governments, major Wall Street firms and the biggest corporations.
But for several months this year, he engaged in a quiet operation for perhaps the most important clients of all: he and his colleagues. The operation ended with Mr. Kroll's backing away from a merger deal with an old friend and going with another suitor who had offered considerably more money and authority. 
 Mr. Kroll shook hands with his friend Derek V. Smith last December on a plan to fuse Kroll Associates, the world's leading business investigations firm, with Mr. Smith's big insurance data collection organization, which was about to be spun off from the consumer credit checking company, Equifax Inc. In April, they publicly announced their intentions.
But beginning early in the year, Mr. Kroll was courted relentlessly by Thomas O'Gara, an Ohio entrepreneur who made a small fortune building bombproof, bulletproof limousines and wanted to be a big player in the more glamorous side of the corporate security industry. By all accounts, Mr. Kroll, whose firm tracked down Saddam Hussein's hidden fortune and helped redo security at the World Trade Center after the bombing in 1993, repeatedly told Mr. O'Gara that he expected to go through with the deal with Mr. Smith.
But Mr. O'Gara did not take no for an answer, and Mr. Kroll never entirely closed the door. After several meetings and phone calls with Mr. Kroll and his bankers this summer, Mr. O'Gara, chairman of the company, and his brother Bill, who served as chief executive, sweetened their proposal with an offer to put Mr. Kroll in charge of a new combined company to be called Kroll-O'Gara.
The final deal represents something of a coming of age not only for Kroll Associates but also for many in the investigations industry that Mr. Kroll pioneered. "Corporate entities are starting to understand the value of what Jules does and what we do," said Terry Lenzner, a former Watergate investigator and founder of Investigative Group in Washington.
Three days after the O'Garas made their final pitch, Mr. Kroll, over dinner at an East Side restaurant, told Mr. Smith the original deal was off. "It was probably the most difficult dinner of my life," Mr. Kroll said the other day at his glass and steel office tower on Third Avenue near East 56th Street in Manhattan.
Mr. Smith, while disappointed, said he had no hard feelings and planned to continue working with Kroll. "I respect Jules," he said through a spokeswoman.
One question that remains, however, is whether Kroll, whose subcontractors have sometimes been accused of skirting the edge of propriety in the firm's quest for valuable intelligence, can continue to operate as successfully as part of a public company.
"Lawyers have told us we would not get their business if we were publicly held," said Bart M. Schwartz, a former Kroll executive who now runs the competing Decision Strategies International in New York. "They feel that a publicly held company is more likely to be the subject of lawsuits and, therefore, because of the discovery process, more likely to be required to give up confidential material. There are many more authorities looking at a public company."
For years, Mr. Kroll, a master negotiator and salesman, has been trying to figure out how he could join forces with another company. In 1992, he sold a 22 percent stake in the firm to American International Group, the insurance giant. But he still needed what he called plasma -- money to expand his global empire. And he wanted to be able to cash in on his life's work without giving up control. He had been unable to reach agreement with other investigative firms. And last December, he broke off talks with the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand partly over the issue of control.
The planned merger with Mr. Smith's company, for all its advantages for Mr. Kroll and his 42 managing directors, was still not ideal. While Kroll would have its own identity, Mr. Kroll and his colleagues still worried that they would be swallowed up. The proposal from the O'Garas, Mr. Kroll said, was more of "a merger of equals."
In some ways, it was even better. Instead of Mr. Kroll's becoming a subordinate, as usually happens when a company is bought, the O'Garas agreed to give up their own titles at the O'Gara Company to grant Mr. Kroll the post of chairman and chief executive. And instead of scratching for expansion money, as he had for years, Mr. Kroll, by joining with a company that had just gone public, would obtain much easier access to capital markets.
"It's kind of a lifetime dream come true," Mr. Kroll said.
The merger will create one of the world's biggest investigations and security companies. Combined, the company will employ more than 950 people in 39 outposts worldwide and will have annual revenues, analysts said, of more than $200 million in 1997, nearly three times the take for Mr. Kroll's company last year. Once the deal is completed, Mr. Kroll's personal wealth will jump nearly $50 million.
With American companies venturing into new global markets and mergers and acquisitions popping along at a record pace, the corporate security and intelligence business is soaring. Corporations are hiring investigators and security experts to dig into the backgrounds of business rivals and potential partners and are asking for help navigating the twisted byways of the global economy.
Following Mr. Kroll's lead, several dozen white-collar investigative firms have sprung up in recent years, creating an industry with hundreds of millions of dollars in annual revenues. The investigators are part of an even bigger business in corporate and personal security, which includes everything from providing guard services and antiterrorist driving schools to producing James Bond-style hardware, including the armored cars and battery-powered, 5.5-pound satellite telephone kits O'Gara produces in Cincinnati and a half-dozen plants around the world.
Kroll is still the biggest name in the business, but it faces increasing competition from several of the Big Six accounting firms, which have begun providing some of the same services and have hired away prize employees from Kroll and other firms.
Mr. Kroll, a former assistant district attorney in Manhattan, commanded respect from the start with his choice of top-of-the-line operatives. He recruited former Federal and state prosecutors; agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Central Intelligence Agency and the Internal Revenue Service, and former diplomats and Congressional aides -- men and women with advanced degrees, board-room manners and dogeared passports.
In pinstripes and expensive shirts, Mr. Kroll has become the model for a new generation of sleuths far different from the Mickey Spillane characters of old with their rumpled trench coats and who spied mostly on wayward spouses. They do not carry guns or brag about flirting with death. They meet most clients in the restaurants of Paris rather than the back alleys of Phnom Penh.
And they are supplying a service that barely existed not that long ago. They deal with clients who a decade ago would probably never even have thought of ordering a background check on a potential joint-venture partner, but who now run the risk of shareholder lawsuits if they do not take just such precautions.
"With globalization has come a whole new cadre of scam artists," said Michael J. Hershman, the president of Fairfax Group Ltd., a competing firm just outside Washington which only last week merged with Decision Strategies.
To bring Kroll under its wing, O'Gara is paying 6.75 million shares, which valued the transaction at $81 million given the stock's starting bid price of $12 a share when the deal was announced on Aug. 7. That was $11 million more than Mr. Smith's firm was offering. The stock was changing hands at $14.125 yesterday.
O'Gara is also kicking in another $14 million to wipe out Kroll's debt. As the owner of about 60 percent of the investigative firm, Mr. Kroll is getting about 4 million shares, putting him on par with Thomas O'Gara, who had previously been far and away the biggest shareholder in the O'Gara Company.
Thomas O'Gara first met Mr. Kroll in 1990, when he sought Mr. Kroll's help in recommending his armored cars to Kroll clients. Having no way to evaluate the cars, Mr. Kroll declined. Nevertheless, Mr. O'Gara kept in touch.
Last fall, the O'Garas, whose customers pay up to $150,000 to have their cars turned into rolling vaults, raised $17 million in an initial public offering. By March, they had bought a small American-owned investigative agency in Mexico, a French armored-car maker, a distributor of satellite communications equipment in England and a counterterrorist training company in Virginia.
And, by then, Thomas O'Gara was in hot pursuit of Kroll. When Mr. O'Gara first laid out his proposal, he recalled, Mr. Kroll said that he was "well down the road" with Mr. Smith and expected "the deal to be done."
But Mr. O'Gara never went away. When he learned that Mr. Kroll had a speaking engagement in Aspen, Colo., and was taking his wife along, Mr. O'Gara sent his corporate jet to New York to pick them up. When Mr. and Mrs. Kroll climbed aboard they were greeted by Mr. O'Gara's investment banker, Jeff Brausch from J. Jeffrey Brausch & Company, near Cleveland. On the way to Aspen, the plane stopped to pick up Mr. O'Gara.
The plan with Mr. Smith was that his division at Equifax would go public as a company called Choicepoint. Kroll Associates would become one of five divisions of Choicepoint. Mr. Kroll, 56, would be president of the division and would report to Mr. Smith, 42. He would also have a seat on the Choicepoint board. A formal contract was never drawn up, though, and at the end, several loose ends remained.
The game began to swing in Mr. O'Gara's favor one week before the dinner with Mr. Smith when Mr. Kroll agreed to meet the brothers at O'Gara headquarters. In what he calls his best shot, Mr. O'Gara flashed on a big screen his proposed name for the new firm: Kroll-O'Gara. Immediately beneath that, it read: Jules Kroll, chairman. It was the first time, Mr. O'Gara said, that the company name and titles had come up. The O'Gara engineers and managers briefed Mr. Kroll, and when they were finished, Mr. O'Gara said, Mr. Kroll turned to him and responded, "I'm knocked out."
The last big piece fell into place at a meeting at the offices of Kramer, Levin, Naftalis & Frankel, the law firm representing Mr. Kroll, on Sunday, Aug. 3, three days before the dinner with Mr. Smith.
"That was when Jules made it known," Bill O'Gara said, "that he wanted to be C.E.O." No problem, the O'Garas replied and, they figured, the deal was essentially done.
As to whether going public will make some clients reluctant to deal with the firm in the future, Mr. Kroll disagrees. Since word began circulating that Kroll was going to merge with somebody, he said, "business has done nothing but increase."

HEADLINE: Divorce And Our National Values

BYLINE: By Peter D. Kramer; Peter D. Kramer, a clinical professor of psychiatry at Brown University, is the author of "Listening to Prozac" and the forthcoming "Should You Leave?"

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

 BODY:
How shall we resolve a marital crisis? Consider an example from the advice column of Ann Landers. An "Iowa Wife" wrote to ask what she should do about her husband's habit, after 30 years of marriage, of reading magazines at table when the couple dined out. Ann Landers advised the wife to engage her husband by studying subjects of interest to him.
Readers from around the country protested. A "14-Year-Old Girl in Pennsylvania" crystallized the objections: "You told the wife to read up on sports or business, whatever he was interested in, even though it might be boring to her. Doesn't that defeat the basic idea of being your own self?" Chastened, Ann Landers changed course, updated her stance: Reading at table is a hostile act, perhaps even grounds for divorce. 
 When it comes to marriage, Ann Landers seems a reasonable barometer of our values. In practical terms, reading the sports pages might work for some Iowa wife -- but we do not believe that is how spouses ought to behave. Only the second response, consider divorce, expresses our overriding respect for autonomy, for the unique and separate self.
Look south now from Iowa and Pennsylvania to Louisiana, where a new law allows couples to opt for a "covenant marriage" -- terminable only after a lengthy separation or because of adultery, abandonment, abuse or imprisonment. The law has been praised by many as an expedient against the epidemic of divorce and an incarnation of our "traditional values."
Whether the law will lower the divorce rate is an empirical question to be decided in the future, but it is not too soon to ask: Does covenant marriage express the values we live by?
History seems to say no. American literature's one great self-help book is "Walden," a paean to self-reliance and an homage to Henry David Thoreau's favorite preacher, Ralph Waldo Emerson, who declaimed: "Say to them, O father, O mother, O wife, O brother, O friend, I have lived with you after appearances hitherto. Henceforward, I am the truth's. . . . I must be myself. I cannot break my self any longer for you, or you."
The economic philosophy we proudly export, fundamentalist capitalism, says that society functions best when members act in a self-interested manner. The nation's founding document is a bill of divorcement. Autonomy is the characteristic American virtue.
As a psychiatrist, I see this value embedded in our psychotherapy, the craft that both shapes and expresses the prevailing common sense. In the early 1970's, Carl Rogers, known as the "Psychologist of America," encapsulated the post-World War II version of our ideals: A successful marriage is one that increases the "self-actualization" of each member. Of a failed union, he wrote: "If Jennifer had from the first insisted on being her true self, the marriage would have had much more strife and much more hope."
Rogers was expressing the predominant viewpoint; for most of the past 50 years, enhanced autonomy has been a goal of psychotherapy. Erik Erikson began the trend by boldly proclaiming that the search for identity had become as important in his time as the study of sexuality was in Freud's. Later, Murray Bowen, a founder of family therapy, invoked a scale of maturity whose measure is a person's ability to maintain his or her beliefs in the face of family pressures. The useful response to crises within couples, Bowen suggested, is to hold fast to your values and challenge your partner to rise to meet your level of maturity.
But autonomy was a value for men only, and largely it was pseudo-autonomy, the successful man propped up by the indentured wife and overburdened mother. (No doubt Thoreau sent his clothes home for laundering.)
The self-help movement, beginning in the 1970's, extended this American ideal to women. Once both partners are allowed to be autonomous, the continuation of marriage becomes more truly voluntary. In this sense, an increase in divorce signals social progress.
It signals social progress, except that divorce is itself destructive. So it seems to me the question is whether any other compelling value counterbalances the siren song of self-improvement.
Turning again to psychotherapy, we do hear arguments for a different type of American value. Answering Erikson's call for individual identity, Helen Merrell Lynd, a sociologist at Sarah Lawrence College, wrote, "Nor must complete finding of oneself . . . precede finding oneself in and through other persons."
Her belief entered psychiatry through the writings of her pupil, Jean Baker Miller. A professor of psychiatry at Boston University, Dr. Miller faults most psychotherapy for elevating autonomy at the expense of qualities important to women, such as mutuality. To feel connected (when there is genuine give-and-take) is to feel worth. Miller wants a transformed culture in which mutuality "is valued as highly as, or more highly than, self-enhancement."
Mutuality is an ideal the culture believes it should honor but does not quite. Ours is a society that does a half-hearted job of inculcating compromise, which is to say that we still teach these skills mainly to women. Much of psychotherapy addresses the troubles of those who make great efforts at compromise only to be taken advantage of by selfish partners.
Often the more vulnerable spouse requires rescue through the sort of move Ann Landers recommends, vigorous self-assertion, and even divorce.
Mutuality is a worthy ideal, one that might serve as a fit complement and counterbalance to our celebration of the self. But if we do not reward it elsewhere -- if in the school and office and marketplace, we celebrate self-assertion -- it seems worrisome to ask the institution of marriage to play by different rules.
What is insidious about Louisiana's covenant marriage is that, contrary to claims on its behalf, it is out of touch with our traditional values: self-expression, self-fulfillment, self-reliance.
 The Louisiana law invites couples to lash themselves to a morality the broader culture does not support, an arrangement that creates a potential for terrible tensions.
Though we profess abhorrence of divorce, I suspect that the divorce rate reflects our national values with great exactness, and that conventional modern marriage -- an eternal commitment with loopholes galore -- expresses precisely the degree of loss of autonomy that we are able to tolerate.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

LENGTH: 377 words

HEADLINE: Swedish Scandal

 BODY:
Sweden's self-image is built around its humane social welfare system at home and its promotion of racial harmony and economic development in the third world. That makes the revelation of a decades-long Swedish policy of coercing welfare recipients into racially motivated sterilizations all the more jarring, to Swedes and Americans as well. Nothing can undo the human damage already inflicted. But Swedish authorities must move swiftly to uncover the full story, acknowledge official responsibility and decently compensate the surviving victims.
A leading Swedish newspaper, Dagens Nyheter, reported this month that Social Democratic governments between 1935 and 1976 coerced some 60,000 women into being sterilized. Labeled genetically or racially "inferior," they were threatened with loss of benefits and separation from their existing children if they refused. Typical victims were the very poor, the learning disabled and people with non-Nordic or mixed ethnic backgrounds. 
 Responding to public and political pressure, Prime Minister Goerran Persson has pledged a thorough investigation. It must unflinchingly expose the true facts of this episode so that the present generation may learn from its elders' mistakes.
Destructive forays into eugenics have been all too common, in America as well as Europe. More than 60,000 people regarded as mentally deficient were involuntarily sterilized in this country in the first six decades of this century. Racial minorities were disproportionately targeted. No society seems immune from racism, bureaucratic abuse of the weak and the pseudo-science of social Darwinism.
Sweden's once-lustrous reputation has already been battered this year by revelations of wartime iron exports that fed Hitler's military machine and of postwar Swedish hoarding of the German gold, much of it looted from Nazi victims, received in payment. A Swedish inquiry is now looking into the issue of wartime relations with Germany as well.
By responding honestly and generously on the sterilization scandal and the gold issue, Stockholm could begin rebuilding its lost international credit. It could also set a good example for other countries confronted with evidence of indefensible behavior in the recent past.

HEADLINE: The New Indo Chic;
Beyond Yoga, Curry and Nehru Jackets Into Film, Publishing and Body Painting

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
Ever since the Beatles popularized Hinduism and Nehru jackets in the late 1960's, Indian cultural artifacts have had a vague currency in the American imagination. But lately, India and its inhabitants are indisputably chic.
With 50th-anniversary celebrations this summer of India and Pakistan's freedom from British rule, perhaps the starkest example of Indo chic can be found in the new popularity of literature out of India and its diaspora. Flip through a major American magazine, for instance, and you are likely to encounter a photo of Arundhati Roy, gazing dreamily, beckoning the reader to open her debut novel, "The God of Small Things," published with much fanfare this year by Random House. Or consider the unexpected success of a recent issue of Granta, entirely devoted to writings on India: the British journal sold twice as many newsstand copies as it ordinarily does in this country. 
 Indo chic is not limited to the highbrow, however. Consider the kitsch appeal of Bollywood cinema, Bombay's flourishing movie industry. Or among American teen-agers, the madness over the ancient Indian and North African art of body painting known as mehndi, now sold in do-it-yourself kits at Urban Outfitters.
But why all the fuss now? Does this Indofrenzy, as the University of Chicago anthropology professor Arjun Appadurai calls it, signal a kind of cultural renaissance on the subcontinent, in literature, art and film? Or is it that Americans are just craning their necks East and taking notice?
The answers are as varied as the subcontinent itself. The Indian-American writer Shashi Tharoor says that although Indians have long produced good books in Indian languages (the country has more than a dozen) and some have written in English, only recently has there been a bumper crop of English writings by Indians there and abroad. (This has prompted the British Indian writer Salman Rushdie to proclaim -- audaciously, in the view of his critics -- English writing to be the finest work being produced in India today.)
Mr. Tharoor, the author of "India: From Midnight to the Millennium," was recently featured on the Web site of amazon.com, the Internet bookstore, as part of a package on Indian literature. "India's literary scene," the headline asserted, "has never been richer." It is the company's first such display on India and with 2,000 "clicks" a day, one of the most popular items on the Web site.
"We knew this was something on people's minds," said the company's vice president and executive editor, Rick Ayre. "Indian writing is surfacing today in a big way, and it's something we would like to make readers aware of."
But the literary explosion, Mr. Tharoor said, does not explain the sudden attention other aspects of Indian culture are receiving. "Americans are noticing Bollywood because Americans are noticing India," he argued. "It's true of music. It's true of fashion. I think Americans are just taking notice."
To be sure, America's fascination with India isn't new. Thirty years ago, many Americans regarded India as a place of snake charmers and sage swamis, as a destination for an entire generation of flower children.
But today's Indo chic is fed by another set of desires. "It is a different kind of moment of cultural appropriation than in the 60's," said Nicholas Dirks, an India specialist who directs the Columbia University anthropology department.
For one thing, he said, from Los Angeles to New York, there has been a flurry of cultural events all summer to celebrate the anniversary of India's independence from British rule 50 years ago this month. Moreover, immigrants from the Indian subcontinent are now, for the first time, a visible part of the American landscape (there were nearly one million of them at last count) and their music and masala and mehndi are now readily available in every major city in the United States.
Finally, India scholars note, India's economic and political relationship to the United States has changed radically since the last round of Indo-mania in the mid-1980's when the movie "Gandhi" was released. For the first time since it threw out the British East India Tea Company, India has embraced market capitalism, avidly promoting tourism and seeking American foreign investment. With the end of the cold war, India is aggressively seeking to be a part of the global economy. Look at the way Indian culture is being bought and sold in this country, said Professor Appadurai, who also directs the globalization project at the University of Chicago.
"India is now the jewel in a new U.S.-centered crown whose key elements are capital, leisure and high technology," he said.
 
Art Exhibitions Throughout the U.S.
Indo chic seems to be everywhere. In the art world, several high-profile exhibitions of Indian art have opened recently in museums from New York to Washington to San Francisco. And the Asia Society in Manhattan, which has long promoted the arts of the subcontinent, has witnessed a surge of interest in tours to India by its high-end donors.
Promoters of South Asian classical music report increased attendance at concerts, prompted in part by the crossover success of the late Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan, the Pakistani vocalist. Even the British-Asian musical punch, which combines North Indian pop music with hip-hop and reggae, has quietly begun to penetrate the Manhattan multi-culti set.
As American cinephiles turn their gaze from Hong Kong action films to the flashy movie musicals of Bombay, a Seattle distributor is bringing Bollywood classics to national retail outlets, like Blockbuster Video. More English-language films directed by Indians are being released in the United States Zeitgeist Films was sufficiently impressed with the popularity of Mira Nair's "Kamasutra" to distribute "Fire," another English-language film about two Indian housewives in love.
Even a few years ago, "Fire" would have been considered a risky venture in this country, an obscure tale in search of a mainstream audience. But the movie has opened in theaters in New York and nine other cities nationwide. "Now, I'm seeing it as less risky," said Nancy Gerstman, a president of Zeitgeist. "There seems to be a great deal of interest in all things Indian. It's just a huge trend."
Understanding what Indo chic is requires understanding what Indo chic is not. For the most part, Indo chic is not about South Asians in America. Though most of them live outside India and many live in the United States, their experience is generally not the subject of the dozen or so books by Indian authors that have recently hit the shelves, or are about to.
The exceptions are Meena Alexander's novel "Manhattan Music" (Mercury House) and Chitra Divakaruni Bannerjee's "Mistress of Spices" (Anchor), which was packaged with a bundle of Indian spices.
 
An Aura, Removed From Harsh Reality
Indo chic, especially in art, tends not to be modern, says Vishakha N. Desai, vice president for cultural and interdepartmental programs at the Asia Society. In spite of the recent explosion of contemporary art in India, the bulk of Indian art in major American museums today is centuries old. Nor does Indo chic, for the most part, concern any of the other countries of the Indian subcontinent. (The Pakistani singer Mr. Khan's popularity is an exception.)
Celebrations of independence from British rule have all but ignored Pakistan, which was born during the independence years in a violent struggle pitting the subcontinent's Hindus against its Muslims. And according to its critics, Indo chic obscures the persistent problems of the subcontinent, from AIDS to foreign debt to radical religious fundamentalism.
"As more U.S. companies are interested in exploring the Indian market, there is also an effort to promote a more positive image of India in the media," said Sucheta Mazumdar, a history professor at Duke University. "And this inevitably turns to romanticizing and orientalizing India."
Gita Mehta, whose latest book of essays, "Snakes and Ladders," was published this year by Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, put it this way: "It's easier to deal with mehndi than to deal with reality."
Many Indian-Americans and students of Indian culture are of mixed minds about this latest round of Indo chic. On the one hand, it is a boon to South Asian artists, writers and musicians. Robert Browning, the executive director of World Music Institute, who has sponsored South Asian music concerts in this country for the last 25 years, has seen a surge of interest in his shows over the last few years. And literary agents representing Indian writers report a more enthusiastic market for their clients today.
But some critics see within the new literary Indofrenzy a kind of nostalgia for a lost world. "India is again a place where the triumph of English, as a language, a literature and a way of being" can be celebrated, argued Dr. Appadurai. "If the monkey is so brilliant, can the organ grinders have been so bad?"
 
Still Yearning For Understanding
 Still others say they hope the new fascination with India will foster a deeper, more serious understanding of the place and its people. "It is the bane of our existence," said Ms. Desai, a native of India. "All of us who care about promoting India have an opportunity to connect. But it does play into the idea of India as the land of exoticism, mysticism, alternative life styles. India has always played into that."

HEADLINE: Growth Slows For Incomes; Spending Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29

 BODY:
Personal income grew at a slower pace in July than it did a month before, while spending rose at the fastest pace since January, suggesting that the economic expansion will continue well into next year.
The Commerce Department said today that personal income increased one-tenth of 1 percent in July after having climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in June, a figure unchanged from the initial report. It was the weakest showing since October, and mainly reflected a drop in hours worked. 
 Consumer spending rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in July. June's increase was revised to two-tenths of 1 percent from three-tenths of 1 percent. July's gain was the largest since a 1.1 percent advance in January.
The savings rate fell to 3.7 percent in July from 4.3 percent in June.
The increases in income and spending were close to analysts' expectations.
Trends in income can portend future business activity because they indicate how much consumers will be able to spend. Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's output of goods and services.
"Consumers are firmly determined to spend more in the months ahead," said Anthony Chan, chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio. The decline in the July savings rate underscored that point, he said.
Consumer spending is likely to accelerate further in the months ahead, partly because sales of residential real estate continue to be strong, and people who buy homes tend to buy goods to furnish or refurbish them. Indeed, a separate report today showed that sales of new single-family homes unexpectedly rose for the third consecutive month in July, evidence that low mortgage rates continued to attract buyers.
Also, consumer confidence is running at some of the highest levels since the late 1960's, and unemployment is likely to remain below 5 percent of the labor force for an extended period, according to corporate executives and economists.
July's slowdown in income reflected a drop in the average number of hours worked and a shorter average workweek. That slowdown stemmed in part from the annual shutdown of auto plants to retool for the new model year. Businesses have also gone to great lengths to contain labor costs, restraining wage growth.
The Commerce Department also said today that disposable income, or the money left over after taxes, increased one-tenth of 1 percent in July after having risen half a percent during June.
In the home sales report, the Commerce Department said sales nationwide rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in July, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 817,000. June's gain was revised to 5.2 percent, to an 810,000 rate, down from the initial report of a 6.1 percent increase, to 819,000, just shy of an 11-year record.
However, all of the July gain came in the West, where sales were at their highest level in almost four years. Other regions registered declines.
Sales rose 11 percent in the West, to 253,000, the highest annual rate since November 1993. They dropped 5.1 percent in the Midwest, to 149,000; 2.5 percent in the South, to 348,000, and 4.3 percent in the Northeast, to 66,000.
Today's home sales report also showed that a measure of consumer demand, the supply of homes for sale nationwide, was unchanged in July at an annual rate of 287,000. The inventory of vacant homes held steady at a 4.3-month supply; a level above six or seven months suggests real estate markets are saturated.
The average price of a new home decreased 1.2 percent in July, to $176,400, from $178,500 in June, while the median price rose 2 percent, to $146,700 from $143,800.
The average rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage fell to 7.36 percent in the week ended Aug. 1, the lowest level in more than a year. Since the beginning of the month, rates have climbed only a little, rising to 7.58 percent in the last week.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Owners Take First Shot Against the D.H.

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
As the designated hitter nears the end of its 25th year of existence, baseball's club owners yesterday made their first official effort to eliminate it.
Looking ahead to possible realignment of the major leagues, Randy Levine, the clubs' chief labor negotiator, proposed to union officials a phaseout of the designated hitter and, as a tradeoff, the addition of a 26th player to each team's roster. The union officials did not jump at the chance to eliminate the d.h., even in several years. 
 "We said they had a better chance of convincing the National League to adopt it than convincing us to abandon it," Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, said afterward.
The American League introduced the d.h. in 1973 in an effort to add hitting to the game. It has since spread throughout all levels of baseball, everywhere except the National League.
N.L. owners have steadfastly resisted the elimination of hitting pitchers, contending that their game creates more scintillating strategy than the game with the d.h.
Major League Baseball has played with those two sets of rules, even in the World Series. At the meeting yesterday, Levine and his delegation told Donald Fehr, the head of the union, and his aides that the d.h. was divisive and should be eliminated because it is highly unlikely the National League will ever adopt it.
The position could be phased out over a number of years, the owners' representatives proposed, so that existing designated hitters, like Paul Molitor of Minnesota and Edgar Martinez of Seattle, could finish their careers as d.h.'s.
In exchange, the management delegation said, the owners would create 30 new roster spots, which is double the number of jobs the d.h. provides. The timing of the start of the 26-man rosters would be subject to negotiation, as would the number of years it would take to phase out the d.h.
The union has long opposed eliminating the d.h., in part because it is, on average, a high-paying position. But Orza said continuation of the d.h. went beyond simple economics.
"It's not a union issue," he said. "The issue is the good of the game and the game is better when players are producing runs. The d.h. produces more offense. Why wouldn't you want more offense when the people want more offense?
"All sports have moved to this idea: when on offense, put your best offense together. You're trying to produce as much offense as possible."
The Molitors and the Martinezes, Orza added, have been some of the best hitters in the game.
"We've had so many wonderful d.h.'s," he said. "Why phase them out of existence? The next Paul Molitor right now is 11 years old. In 30 years, why shouldn't the game have the benefit of that type of player?"
The owners need the players' approval to eliminate the d.h. If they cannot secure their approval, they would have to continue using the position in one of the leagues, however they are realigned.

HEADLINE: The Sticky Side of Privatization;
Sale of U.S. Nuclear Fuel Plants Raises Host of Conflicts

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
There is big money in nuclear energy. While most nuclear-power plants in America may be economic albatrosses, the little-known Government-owned enterprise that supplies the bulk of their uranium fuel is highly profitable.
So profitable that Washington has already incorporated into the budget the billions it expects to bank when the United States Enrichment Corporation, which has operated with considerable autonomy since 1993, is sold to private investors early next year. It will be the largest divestiture of a Federal production operation ever attempted. But the road from here to there is tortuous. 
 For one thing, transferring the corporation to private hands raises thorny issues ranging from the wish to preserve a domestic source of uranium fuel and the need to secure global stockpiles of bomb-grade uranium from nuclear terrorists. "The sale is not just about maximizing value," said a senior Administration official who requested anonymity.
For another, the Government must soon choose whether to sell USEC in one piece, or to parcel out shares in a public offering. That has touched off a quiet game of backbiting among potential acquirers, USEC's union and USEC's current managers, with Washington caught in the middle.
A half-dozen big American corporations with experience in nuclear power, including Lockeed Martin, Westinghouse Electric, General Atomics, Allied Signal and Babcock & Wilcox, are reportedly pondering bids. But the catch they are eyeing has so many question marks -- a sagging market for the product, outmoded technology and reliance on cheap electricity that will probably be cut off in eight years -- that the estimated value is low compared with its current earnings.
USEC, which operates plants in Paducah, Ky., and Portsmouth, Ohio, for enriching uranium to reactor-grade strength, reported earnings of $250 million on revenues of $1.578 billion in the fiscal year ended June 30. That was down from $304 million in 1996, but largely because USEC spent more on research in 1997. J. P. Morgan, USEC's financial adviser, estimates that the projected profits translate into a market value of $1.5 billion to $1.8 billion -- the equivalent of $3 billion for Uncle Sam, since the privatized corporation would also pay income tax.
If offers from bidders deemed worthy fall short of that range, the Treasury Department and USEC's White House-appointed board will have to decide whether to accept the most attractive offer, or to allow USEC to sell shares through a public offering. "It should all be over in six months -- maybe even less," said a senior Administration official.
One rumored high-profile bidder has dropped out of the race. "We have absolutely no interest in acquiring the Enrichment Corporation," said Bruce Bunch, a spokesman for General Electric.
Others are sitting on the fence. Don Washington, speaking for Babcock & Wilcox, said the company was not prepared to talk about its plans. And Westinghouse was equally noncommittal. "Of course we're interested," said a spokeswoman, Mimi Limbach. "But we won't be making any decisions until we see the specs."
Lockheed Martin, the giant military contractor whose subsidiary now operates USEC's plants, remains an obvious candidate. It has formed an alliance with Allied Signal and General Atomics to buy USEC. And while the companies will not divulge specifics, Bill Corcoran, a spokesman for Allied Signal, confirmed the consortium's strong interest. "We're looking closely at it," he said.
But potential rivals have been quick to point out that Lockheed Martin has long been at odds with USEC's current managers over a failure to meet productivity and safety targets in its operating contract. By the same token, they note that in the early 1990's a General Atomics subsidiary was shut down by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for safety reasons.
Certainly the most unusual player in the acquisition game is Pleiades Group. The consortium is headed by a former Commerce Secretary, Robert A. Mosbacher; advised by a former Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, and provided legal counsel by Mr. Baker's son, Jamie. The Pleiades chief executive, a Russian-American named Alexander Shusterovich, acknowledges his close working relationship with Viktor Mikhailov, the head of Minatom, the Russian competitor to USEC.
While official Washington will not comment publicly on the suitability of Pleiades to own USEC, there is opposition from the national security establishment. USEC controls technology that could be used to produce bomb-grade uranium. Moreover, USEC serves as the "executive agent" for the 1993 deal in which Washington agreed to buy 500 tons of bomb-grade uranium from Russia's Atomic Energy Ministry, or Minatom, after it had been blended down for use as commercial reactor fuel.
Pleiades points out, however, that Washington has considerable experience in protecting sensitive technology where military contractors work with foreign corporations. And Naseer Hashim, the Pleiades senior vice president, argues that the Russian connection should be viewed as an asset, not a liability. "Pleiades, unlike other American owned enterprises, has cultivated its capacity to engage in constructive dialogue with Minatom," he said.
To bolster its credibility, Pleiades promised the labor union at the enrichment operations, the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers, a seat on USEC's governing board if Pleiades is allowed to buy the company. And the union president, Bob Wages, accepted, perhaps to settle scores with USEC's current managers. William Timbers, the president of USEC, "does not have the best interests of the workers and facilities at heart," Mr. Wages told a reporter for Nuclear Fuel, an industry weekly.
Whoever takes over the enterprise, the debate over USEC's key role in the swords-to-plowshares agreement is unlikely to go away. Richard A. Falkenrath, executive director of Harvard's Center for Science and International Affairs, argues that it creates "an inherent tension" between the public objective of getting as much surplus bomb material out of Russia as fast as possible and the wish of USEC to maximize profits from it own production of nuclear fuel. Tim Ryan of J. P. Morgan, USEC's financial adviser, acknowledges that the overhang of surplus Russian uranium could reduce the future profitability of USEC.
But the Clinton insiders who made the decision to go forward on privatization do not seem perturbed. "USEC's willingness last year to nail down the terms for delivery of the first 150 tons shows that an independent enrichment company can put national security first," said one former Administration official.
The more important question from the perspective of investors is whether USEC can continue to prosper. For much of its current vitality derives from cost advantages that will not last forever.
It makes up for its inherent efficiency deficit -- the gaseous diffusion separators now consume as much electricity as a large city -- with cheap energy from private power contracts that will all expire by 2005. "Without low-cost power, USEC can't make money with gaseous diffusion," said Tom Neff, a senior research scientist at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Moreover, USEC is hardly alone in the business of separating U-235 from nonfissionable isotopes of uranium. Two European consortiums, Eurodif, owned by the Governments of France, Spain, Belgium, Italy and Iran, and Urenco, owned by Britain, the Netherlands and Germany, were created in the 1970's to reduce Europe's dependence on what was then an American monopoly in the non-Communist world. And Russia's Minatom has become a major exporter. Since all three competitors' operations were built long after USEC's plants were completed in the 1950's, they largely employ centrifuges to separate the uranium isotopes -- a major cost advantage.
USEC does own exclusive rights to exploit atomic vapor laser isotope separation, a technology developed at the Federal Government's Lawrence Livermore Laboratory that uses just 5 percent as much electricity as gaseous diffusion. If the isotope separation technology stumbles, though, and an attractive electricity contract cannot be renegotiated, USEC would probably have to turn to centrifuges -- a technology largely controlled by competitors.
Indeed, Pleiades is apparently betting that the future lies in centrifuge-based joint ventures with the Russians. And Louisiana Energy Systems, a consortium backed by Urenco and a handful of American nuclear utilities, has applied for a license to build new centrifuge capacity in the United States.
From this perspective, betting on USEC is mostly a bet about the future of uranium separation technology. Current estimates of USEC's market value amount to little more than the positive cash flow it can expect before the cheap electricity runs out. If atomic vapor laser isotope separation works and USEC remains the cost leader in the industry, it could well become a cash cow.
And at least some observers think USEC is making a good technology bet. "The view here is that we're further along than is generally recognized," said Mr. Ryan, the financial adviser to USEC.
