HEADLINE: Asian Stock Damage Has Wider Effects

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
With declines of 5 percent or more in Hong Kong and Indonesia, Southeast Asian stock markets continued to tumble yesterday as the tremors from a summerlong plunge began to be felt in world markets.
But the plunges in Asia are not expected to cause significant damage in markets in the United States and Europe, or in Latin America, the world's other core of emerging markets. And whatever fallout there is should be less severe than that from the Mexican peso crisis that led to a $50 billion international bailout in 1995. 
 "If the market in the U.S. is going to come down hard," said David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, "it will because the market is overvalued and interest rates are going up. Asia will be part of the process, but not a major part."
Still, many American investors have become worried enough to take millions of dollars out of mutual funds that invest in Asia. Cash flows out of Asia funds, including those that invest in Japan, have been running $110 million to $115 million a week for the last four weeks, according to AMG Data Services.
This retreat by American investors began when market turmoil erupted in July with the floating of Thailand's currency, the baht, and a 16 percent devaluation.
The devaluation process was set in motion by currency speculators, who were betting that unbalanced economic policies that favored growth left the Government unable to defend the baht. The problems in Thailand, and the speculative attacks on national currencies, spread to the Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia. The Thais now have a $16 million assistance package backed by the International Monetary Fund, and the Philippines is also getting I.M.F assistance.
Recent downturns in the stocks of multinational companies like Coca-Cola, Gillette, General Electric and McDonald's may be accelerated as investors worry that their earnings will be eroded by the sharp rise in the value of the dollar against Asian currencies in the last month or two.
And in the last week, the declines in stock markets in Asia have begun to drag down the markets in countries that are not thought to have the major economic problems faced by Thailand and its neighbors. That selling was mostly generated by investors' uncertainty and efforts to hedge Thai and other losses by taking profits elsewhere in Asia.
The Hong Kong stock market, Asia's second largest after those of Japan, dropped about 5 percent yesterday and is down 9 percent in the last two days. Markets in Latin America have also had a bad week. But the declines in both regions have been aided by drops on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.4 percent for the week.
"It has already had an impact on the way people see the markets," said Lawrence J. Brainard, global head of emerging-market research at Chase Securities. "Investors have become more cautious; they're sensitized to risk."
But Mr. Brainard argued that there should not be a major reverberation from Asia to Latin American because the economic policies of Latin American countries are more committed to stability than growth. In addition, he said, Latin American officials have learned from the Mexican peso crisis.
Yesterday, Southeast Asian stock markets all fell sharply. Among these, the Kuala Lumpur composite index in Malaysia fell almost 1 percent and is down 11 percent for the week. The Malaysian Government set off sharp selling through much of Asia when it introduced rules Wednesday night to limit the short-selling of stocks. In selling short, an investor borrows the stock and sells it in hopes the price will fall and he can buy it back at a lower price.
But the surprise ruling just seemed to aggravate the situation, as investors sought to protect themselves from losses there by selling stocks elsewhere, like in Hong Kong.
The Stock Exchange of Thailand fell 1.9 percent yesterday and is down 10 percent for the week; in Indonesia, the Jakarta composite index plunged 6.9 percent and 14 percent for the week, and the SES all-share index of Singapore dropped 1.4 percent and 5.9 percent all week.
The plunges in Asia helped push markets in Latin America lower. In Brazil, the Bovespa index of Sao Paulo fell 5.8 percent yesterday and 7.1 percent for the week. The Bolsa index in Mexico City dropped 2.9 percent and 7 percent for the week. Argentina's Merval index fared better, down 3.74 percent yesterday but shedding only 1.29 percent for the week.
John Lipsky, chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, said the most important impact in the United States from the Asian turmoil would be on inflation and growth, rather than in financial markets. He said the sharp rise in the dollar against the Thai baht, up 40 percent since July 1, and other Asian currencies would make imports from these countries cheaper, adding to the downward pressure on inflation. But, at the same time, he said, the slower growth in these countries will mean that American export sales will slow.
The most immediate stock effect could come on the popular multinational stocks that until August had helped lead the stock market higher all year.
But many of these companies, said Elizabeth J. Mackay, chief investment strategist at Bear, Stearns & Company, depend on sales in Asia. Slower growth there will cut sales, and the rise of the dollar will reduce their value when they are translated back into dollar earnings.
"Maybe the market is saying something," she said, alluding to the recent decline of the big stocks. McDonald's was taken off the Salomon Brothers' recommended list yesterday in part because of the Asian impact.
Money has been flowing out of mutual funds that invest in Asia for the last nine weeks, according to Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services.
In Asia funds, excluding those for Japan, the outflows peaked at an average of $185 million a week during the four weeks ending on July 16, just after the Thai currency devaluation. For the four weeks ending on Aug. 27, the average outflow has been $120 million.
T. Rowe Price Associates' $1.3 billion New Asia Fund has seen substantial outflows in the last two months, Steven Norwitz, a Price spokesman, said.
Investors with clear recollections of the Mexican peso crisis are running for cover, he added.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said at a meeting yesterday in Jackson Hole, Wyo., that Thailand's economic problems underscored the need for better economic data, which, he said, could have helped avert the crisis.

HEADLINE: A Durable Operation On Too Solid Ground

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
For years, even as rivals like First Union and Nationsbank gobbled up banks across the country and moved into Barnett Banks Inc.'s backyard, Barnett prided itself as being "Florida's bank."
The claim was not without justification. With 660 branches across the state and assets of $42 billion, Barnett, based in Jacksonville, had the biggest share of a market that by most measures is a banker's paradise because of its healthy economy and affluent consumer base. 
 "We characterize it as being trapped in heaven," Allen L. Lastinger Jr., Barnett's president and chief operating officer, said in an interview earlier this summer.
Analysts have little but praise for the company, which was founded in 1877 by William B. Barnett and is the largest, oldest independent bank in Florida.
"It was a very coveted franchise," said Henry C. Dickson, an analyst with Smith Barney.
But if they have a quibble, it is that Barnett, which vigorously guarded its independence, took too long to broaden its vision beyond the borders of the state.
"They were a land-locked bank," said Thomas A. Hanley, an analyst at UBS Securities, "and they went into nonbank expansion rather late."
"I don't know if they should have expanded outside the state in the 1980's as First Union and Nationsbank were doing and become a bigger powerhouse in the Southeast," he added. "But if they had an Achilles' heel, that was it."
Indeed, it is only in the last few years that Barnett expanded its horizons in a bid for faster growth.
While keeping the Barnett name and banking operations in Florida, the company has been buying and building a network of consumer lending operations throughout the country the last two years.
"If we had had this conversation two years ago, I would have said they were a good banking company and a somewhat sleepy corporation," said Moshe A. Orenbach, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
"But in the last two years they have sharpened their focus."
Barnett did this only after spending much of the early 1990's dealing with a raft of problems that crimped its earnings, problems that included bad commercial real estate loans, a questionable credit card portfolio and the cost in time and money of consolidating its fragmented banking operations within Florida.
Most recently, in April it spent $670 million to buy Oxford Resources Inc., the nation's largest independent auto leasing company, with a customer base in 21 states. And early in 1995, Barnett purchased the Equicredit Corporation, a consumer finance company that has offices in 41 states.
"The company is evolving into one with a customer-centric focus and away from a Florida-centric and county-centric focus," Mr. Dickson, the Smith Barney analyst, said.
But, as Mr. Hanley suggested, they did not move fast enough, a fact Charles E. Rice, the company's long-time chairman and chief executive, acknowledged yesterday in a conference phone call with analysts and reporters.
Mr. Rice said Barnett did not have the breadth and reach required to compete with organizations like the Nationsbank Corporation and the First Union Corporation in the future.
Recognizing that, Mr. Hanley and others give Mr. Rice credit for picking a perfect moment to sell, and getting an extremely handsome price for shareholders in the process.
"The timing was right to sell," said Stephen A. Hansel, president and chief executive of the Hibernia Corporation, a New Orleans bank holding company.
Referring to the repercussions the combination will have in the state, Mr. Hansel, who spent more than two decades at Barnett, said the acquisition "makes Florida a banking colony, which is really sad in a way." "But," he added, "that is the way of the world."

HEADLINE: Dow Concludes Rough Month By Dropping 72.01 Points

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
July giveth and August taketh away.
That was the story by the end of trading yesterday, after all the gains made in July, the year's best month for the Dow Jones industrial average, were surrendered in August, its worst monthly setback in seven years. 
 Yesterday, the Dow lost 72.01 points, or just under 1 percent, in another choppy session, to close at 7,622.42. For the month, the blue-chip average lost 600.19 points, or 7.3 percent. And from its Aug. 6 high, the index is down 7.7 percent -- its biggest setback since March and April, when the Dow lost 9.8 percent. Still, the Dow is up 18 percent since the start of the year.
"In effect, we had a speculative run-up in July, and in August it was just taking off the fluff," Elizabeth J. Mackay, chief investment strategist at Bear, Stearns, said.
There were two reasons, Ms. Mackay said: Interest rates stopped going up, and indeed backed off, and several blue-chip companies, including Coca-Cola and Gillette, came out with negative earnings news.
"When two marquee names of the new Nifty Fifty warn of slowing earnings growth, that causes investors to say, 'Hey, wait a minute, those share prices are high,' " she said.
Technology and smaller-company stocks, however, extended a monthlong run of outperforming the blue chips. The Russell 2000 rose 1.84, to a record 423.43 yesterday, and the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 6 points, to 1,587.32. In August, the Russell index gained 2.2 percent, while the Nasdaq was flat.
Still, yesterday's session seemed to be a microcosm of the month of August. The day began with McDonald's warning of an earnings slowdown, the third Friday a blue-chip company gave such a warning this month. Weakness in the bond market also helped pull down the Dow and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which closed down 4.20 points at 899.47.
In a shortened session ahead of the holiday weekend, the bond market gave back many of the gains made a day earlier on renewed inflation jitters. The Government said new-home sales rose a robust nine-tenths of 1 percent in July and consumer spending jumped eight-tenths of 1 percent.
As a result, bond prices fell. The price of a 30-year Treasury bond declined 14/32, to 97 1/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.60, from 6.57 Thursday. A month earlier, the yield stood at 6.30.
The dollar showed some strength against the Japanese yen and the German mark. The dollar closed at 120.80 in New York, up from 119.12 Thursday. The dollar was quoted at 1.8095 marks, up from 1.7961. The British pound rose to $1.6200 from $1.6155.
Although some Wall Street analysts discounted yesterday's session, noting that volume was light and many traders and investors had taken off early for the holiday weekend, the disparity between large-cap and small-cap stocks continued. Analysts said discomfort with the high price-to-earnings ratios of some of bluest of the blue chips had finally begun to shift some allegiances in the market.
While Coca-Cola and Gillette have both lost about 20 percent from their highs in recent weeks, many stocks with lower price-to-earnings ratios have been bid higher.
"You're finally starting to see what every bull market has had, a broadening out," Barbara Marcin, senior equity portfolio manager at Citibank Global Asset Management, said. "You're starting to see the small-cap stocks beating the large-cap stocks."
Ms. Marcin said that investors had finally tired of paying high prices for companies like Coca-Cola, and that it was a healthy sign that investors were now choosing better values. The shift in buying, she said, might also benefit portfolio managers, a large majority of whom have underperformed the S.& P. 500 index.
"It's the first month in a very long time in which it has been easier to beat the indexes," she said. Of course, portfolio managers have beaten the S.& P. 500 by suffering less. While the average United States equity fund was down 1.96 percent in August, according to Lipper Analytical Services, the S.& P. 500 lost 5.7 percent.
Ms. Marcin said some of the excesses in prices might have been trimmed because of a decline in the bond market. As interest rates rose, valuations began to look even frothier, she said, particularly after July's sharp run-up in prices, when the Dow gained 7.2 percent.
And so, while the blue chips stumbled, several battered issues gained. AT&T, one of the dogs of the Dow this year, gained about 6 percent in August, making it the Dow's best-performing issue. And McDonald's, which had fallen 15 percent since July 30, actually rebounded on yesterday's earnings news, gaining 9/16, to 47 5/16.

HEADLINE: Biggest Southeast Bank Buying Florida Giant for $15.5 Billion

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Spending more for a bank than any company has in history, the Nationsbank Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Barnett Banks for $15.5 billion in stock.
Barnett, which dominates the rapidly growing Florida market, has long been seen as the most attractive banking franchise in the country and it attracted heated bidding when it started to auction itself off last week. 
 With its winning bid, Nationsbank, based in Charlotte N.C., will become the nation's third-largest banking company, with $290 billion in assets, after Chase Manhattan and Citicorp. Based on stock market valuation, Nationsbank will be worth about $57 billion, a very close second to Citicorp, which is worth $59 billion.
Barnett is one of the great success stories in banking, growing over the last 20 years from a tiny Jacksonville bank to 660 branches that control 20 percent of the Florida market today.
Still, regional banks are losing ground to a handful of increasingly nationwide banking companies. The huge consolidation that has swept through the industry in recent years -- and that has seen Chase Manhattan merge with Chemical, First Interstate with Wells Fargo, and U.S. Bancorp with First Bank System -- has made the remaining banking giants more powerful, with marketing muscle and cost efficiency that regional banks cannot hope to match.
The top 10 banks now control 32 percent of the nation's deposits, up from 19 percent at the end of 1990. With this deal, Nationsbank alone will have 4.8 percent of the deposits. Federal law limits one bank to have no more than 10 percent of the country's deposits.
The prospect of the giant companies -- epitomized by Nationsbank -- dominating banking coast to coast led Barnett to sell.
"Over the next few years we could be very viable, but beyond that we would be in a disadvantaged position," Allen L. Lastinger Jr., Barnett's president, said at a news conference yesterday afternoon.
To make the acquisition pay off, Nationsbank said that it would eliminate $915 million a year in costs, about 55 percent of Barnett's total expenses. That implies that perhaps half of Barnett's 19,500 jobs would be eliminated.
Officials of both companies declined to say how many jobs would be cut. They said both companies would institute a hiring freeze immediately and that many of the jobs eliminated would be among Nationsbank's 88,000 positions because some processing functions will be moved to Florida from other states and some of the branches closed in Florida will be among the 400 that Nationsbank has there.
"This is a management that knows how to cut costs, sometimes brutally," said Thomas A. Hanley, an analyst with UBS Securities. "I would expect that the pattern would be the same at Barnett."
Barnett chose a time to sell, analysts said, when bank stocks have been at record highs.
Analysts expect that these high prices will cause other successful regional banks that have been trying to maintain their independence to instead choose to put themselves up for sale in coming months.
And the banks that lost the bidding for Barnett -- said to include Banc One, First Union, Suntrust and Wachovia -- will be among the companies eagerly trying to buy other banks that become available.
Nationsbank will exchange stock worth $75.18 -- based on Thursday's closing price -- for each Barnett share. That represents a 43 percent premium to the price of Barnett's shares before word of the deal began to leak out Thursday. It is also a valuation that would have been seen as absurdly high even a year ago.
"At 4 times book value and 24 times earnings, this is the highest price ever paid for a bank," Mr. Hanley with UBS Securities. Still, he contended that Nationsbank would be able to make the acquisition pay off and be left with a powerful franchise in the Southeast. "This looks to be an outstanding deal," he said.
Since Nationsbank already has 12 percent of the deposit market in Florida and Barnett has 20 percent, the deal would put Nationsbank over the 30 percent maximum share allowed under Federal banking law. Nationsbank expects to sell about $3.5 billion in deposits to comply with the regulations, with most of the divestitures in the Tampa Bay area, where the combined bank would have more than a 40 percent share.
Nationsbank first exploited a loophole in laws that had prevented banks from moving across state lines to buy a bank in Tampa in 1981. It has grown rapidly since then through a series of adroit mergers. Led by the savvy and ambitious Hugh L. McColl Jr., Nationsbank built its reputation for merger mastery as a bottom fisher, buying big distressed banks at what turned out to be very low prices. But as the market has bid up bank stocks and the healthy economy wiped away loan problems, such bargains have been harder to find.
Nationsbank increasingly has come to the conclusion that it can afford to pay high prices for banks because its superior computer systems and products allow it to increase the profitability even of well- run banks.
In 1995, it bought BankSouth for $1.6 billion, giving it the dominant share in Atlanta. And in 1996, it bought Boatmen's Bankshares, a St. Louis company with the leading franchise in seven Midwestern states, for $9.5 billion.
The valuation of those deals shows how rapidly prices have been bid up for banks. Nationsbank paid 2.4 times book value for Bank South and 2.7 times book for Boatmen's. The other deals this year have been at much higher levels. First Bank System paid 3.4 times book for U.S. Bancorp in March. And last month the First Union Corporation agreed to pay 3.5 times book for the Signet Banking Corporation of Richmond. The book value of a company is its assets minus its liabilities.
Nationsbank has also been active in buying nonbanking companies. In June, it agreed to buy Montgomery Securities, the San Francisco brokerage firm, for $1.2 billion.
Charles E. Rice, the chairman of Barnett, will assume the chairman's title at Nationsbank next April when Andrew Craig, the former chairman of Boatmen's, retires. Mr. McColl, as Nationsbank's chief executive, remains fully in control.
Mr. Rice owns 448,000 shares of Barnett, worth about $33 million, and he has options on another 496,000 shares.
Nationsbank's stock fell $3.5625, or 5.6 percent, to $59.75 yesterday. That reaction was more muted than the 8 percent hit that the company's stock took after the Boatmen's acquisition was announced on the day before Labor Day last year.
Yesterday, Barnett's stock jumped $13.3125, to $68.125.

HEADLINE: Cuban Military, Long a Political Force, Takes Role in Economy, Too

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Aug. 29

 BODY:
Having ended its mission to spread revolution abroad, Cuba's military is undertaking a new mission at home: promoting support for the Castro Government during hard times.
The armed forces, probably Cuba's most powerful institution, has dropped its habitual secrecy to rally the nation during its economic crisis, when many people are grumbling about how hard it is even to feed their families. 
 Since 1989, when the collapse of the Soviet bloc cut off crucial aid and training, the military has played a larger role in Cuba's economy, starting farms, businesses and construction crews. Now it is playing a larger political role as well.
"The military is basically showing that it is behind the Government," said Wayne Smith, a Washington academic and formerly the chief American diplomat in Havana. "While it is considered an important force for reform, it is loyal to Castro and will not break ranks."
For the first time, officers are giving Government-approved interviews to Cuban journalists for books and magazine articles, mostly about the country's revolutionary past. Most notable was "Secrets of Generals," a collection of interviews with 41 officers.
Despite the title, the book revealed no military secrets -- just a rare glimpse into the background of the men who fought alongside Fidel Castro to overthrow the dictator Fulgencia Batista four decades ago.
Gen. Harry Villegas, a member of the party's politburo, delivered much the same message in two recent books about fighting alongside Che Guevara, who was killed by Bolivian troops in 1967 while trying to export Cuba's revolution.
In 1992, Mr. Castro announced that Cuba would no longer provide military help to insurgent groups abroad. At the time, the military was bruised by a 1989 drug-trafficking scandal that led to the execution of a war hero, Maj. Gen. Arnaldo Ochoa. Several military leaders defected.
In 1990, as Communism fell apart in the Soviet Union itself, bringing lasting economic hardship, Cuba's troop strength was cut from an estimated 180,000 -- roughly the size of the military in Mexico, a much larger country.
In December the armed forces staged their first sizable parade in a decade. With Mr. Castro and other heroes of the 1959 revolution looking on, veterans of the uprising marched past in Revolution Plaza.
So far, Cubans seem to appreciate the newly open military.
"There is a new policy to tell people about what happened over all those years," said an electrical engineer in Havana who refused to give her full name. "Before, those military leaders never appeared or spoke in public, except during political acts."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Nationsbank to Acquire Barnett for $15.5 Billion
Nationsbank agreed yesterday to acquire Barnett Banks for $15.5 billion in stock, creating the nation's third-largest banking company behind Chase Manhattan and Citicorp. The combined entity will have assets of $290 billion. 
 Barnett, which dominates the rapidly growing Florida market, has long been seen as the most attractive banking franchise in the country and it attracted many bidders. News of the deal was greeted favorably on Wall Street, where shares of Barnett rose 24.3 percent yesterday. [Page 1.]
 
Barnett prided itself on being a bank devoted solely to the state of Florida, but that may have been its Achilles' heel. Analysts say that the bank took too long to broaden its vision beyond the borders of the state. [36.]
 
Personal Income and Spending Rise
Americans' personal income increased one-tenth of 1 percent in July, while consumer spending rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, suggesting that the economic expansion will continue into next year. [39.]
 
Jury Award Is Reduced
A Federal judge ruled yesterday that ABC and two of its employees should pay the Food Lion supermarket chain only $315,000 in punitive damages, rather than the $5.5 million a jury had awarded in January as punishment for an investigative report that used hidden cameras to show unsanitary practices in the handling of meat and poultry. [1.]
 
A Laxative Is Pulled From Shelves
The maker of the laxative Ex-Lax, Novartis Consumer Health, is withdrawing from the market all versions of the drug containing phenolphthalein, citing concerns by Federal health officials over the ingredient. [8.]
 
Debt Inquiry by G.E. Unit
GE Capital is investigating whether it illegally collected credit card debts from more than 17,000 customers who filed for personal bankruptcy. [37.]
 
Giving Power to Agriculture
One week after the biggest meat recall in the United States, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman has proposed legislation that would broadly strengthen his department's powers over companies found to have produced tainted meat and poultry. The measure would give the Agriculture Department authority to order the recall of a contaminated product. The department can now only try to persuade a company to do so voluntarily. [1.]
 
Trader Ousted at First Boston
Credit Suisse First Boston's London office has dismissed an employee for unauthorized options trading that caused losses of about $10 million and referred the matter to British regulators. [45]
 
Election Overseer Might Leave
The Federal election overseer who annulled Ron Carey's re-election as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has said privately that she intends to resign, officials involved in monitoring the union have said. The overseer, Barbara Zack Quindel, had at first been praised by both Mr. Carey and his chief rival, James P. Hoffa, for her neutrality. But she has since been criticized. [8.]
 
El Nino Talk Sends Wheat Prices Up
Wheat prices climbed to their highest level in more than three months on fears that the El Nino weather pattern will cut overseas crop production. On other markets, coffee and soybean prices rose. [45.]
 
Duncan Hines on the Block
Procter & Gamble is accepting bids for its Duncan Hines line of baking mixes, which it says does not fit with its strategy of market-leading food and beverage brands. [37.]

HEADLINE: Clothes Shoppers Waiting on the Brink of a Break

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
On the eve of New York's second tax-free holiday on clothing this year, Lisa Leonard is taking stock of her 4-year-old son's wardrobe. Winter jacket? Last year's is a little tight. Pants? He needs more. Turtlenecks? Those, too.
"It's definitely an incentive," said Mrs. Leonard, a special-events coordinator for Walt Disney World, pausing on the Upper West Side yesterday as her son Jesse dozed in a stroller. "We'll put a list together of the things he really needs and take advantage of the tax break. When you spend $50 on clothing and then look at the tax, you say, 'Whoa.' " 
 Welcome to Round 2 of the weeklong apparel tax repeal. Despite Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's intense lobbying to get rid of the state and city sales taxes on clothing this year, the State Legislature voted to postpone a repeal for two years. But shoppers are still getting a bone to placate them, in the form of a respite from sales taxes on certain items of clothing starting on Monday.
"It's a gift to the people," said Sheldon Silver, the Speaker of the State Assembly and a Democrat from New York City who had pushed, unsuccessfully, to repeal the state and city taxes this year.
The good news is that this time around, the seven-day break, which runs Monday through next Sunday, coincides with back-to-school week, a time when parents need to do a lot of shopping anyway. (The earlier tax break, in January, came as many people were depleted, financially and physically, after the holidays.)
But not everyone is happy. Unlike the last reprieve, the tax-free week does not apply to footwear and also lowers the ceiling for each exempt article of clothing to $100, from $500. Some shoppers say they are irritated because the repeal will not take the sting out of bigger purchases, like a winter coat or a suit, and shoe store owners are crestfallen.
"We're very disappointed," said William Rood, the controller of Harry's Shoes on Broadway at 83d Street on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. "My personal opinion is that footwear is a greater necessity in the streets of New York than clothing is."
Harry's is "making a political statement," however, by discounting all nonsale shoes that sell for less than $100 by 8 1/4 percent, Mr. Rood said.
All but 3 of New York's 62 counties have agreed to participate in the tax-free week by waiving their local sales taxes on clothing in addition to the state's tax break. In New York City, consumers will save 8 1/4 percent -- 4 percent from the state, 4 percent from the city, and one-quarter of 1 percent levied by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
For years local retailers have complained that they were losing business to New Jersey and surrounding states, where clothing is not taxed. The weeklong tax hiatus in January was a chance for the city and state officials to gauge the benefits of a permanent repeal, and for the most part they deemed it a success.
Charles Millard, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said sales on apparel and footwear from Jan. 18 to Jan. 24 were 73.6 percent higher than the same week the year before. And apparel sales for the month of January rose by 29 percent from the year before, while nonapparel sales also rose, by 12 percent.
"When you cut tax on apparel it will increase shopping on clothes and other items as well," Mr. Millard said. "You have many facts that may not compel this conclusion but certainly lead us right toward it."
A study by the city's economic development agency said the city could add 11,000 retail jobs as a result of a permanent repeal of the sales tax on clothing priced under $100 and estimated that retail sales would increase by $570 million a year.
In January, there was some confusion leading up to the tax-free week, since some retailers were uncertain about what was tax exempt and what was not. This time, the state issued lists well in advance, with scores of categories and their status. Aprons, shawls and hand muffs are exempt, for instance, while shower caps, golf gloves and children's costumes are not.
Store owners were preparing yesterday for what they hoped would be a surge in shopping next week. Daffy's, a discount apparel chain with stores in the New York region, scrambled to fill up the racks of childen's clothes in the city.
"I pulled children's merchandise from our stores in Philadelphia and New Jersey and sent it into our New York stores," said Elida Behar, a children's apparel buyer for the chain. "I have high hopes. Our customers are very price-sensitive, and if you're buying $300 to $400 worth of clothing it makes a big difference."
Even high-end children's clothing shops on the Upper East Side, where parents often spend $1,000 in a visit, were confident that the tax-free week would draw additional customers.
"Everybody loves a bargain," said Paulina Vegas, the manager of Jacadi, a boutique at Madison Avenue and 91st Street that sells French-made apparel for boys and girls. "People can take the savings on the taxes and buy another blouse."
Indeed, some shoppers said the tax exemptions would mean more clothes in their closets rather than extra money in their wallets. Darlene Rodriguez, a junior at Louis D. Brandeis High School in Manhattan, said she was waiting for the week to start before spending $300 on her back-to-school wardrobe. "It's great," she said, checking the fall fashions at a Gap store, "because then you can buy more things."

GRAPHIC: Photo: One store says its prices are already cut as much as the tax break will drop them. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Poll Detects Widespread Skepticism About Proposed Tobacco Deal

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29

 BODY:
Americans are highly suspicious of the proposed tobacco deal, saying it would not achieve even the prime objective of reducing teen-age smoking unless cigarette prices rise much more than expected, an Associated Press poll shows.
More than half of those surveyed say the deal is not worth the main concession that cigarette makers demand, a ban on class-action lawsuits. Two-thirds expect tobacco companies to sell as many cigarettes as ever. 
 Seventy percent say the price of a pack of cigarettes would have to rise by more than $1 -- much more than expected under the deal -- to significantly curtail teen-age smoking.
The telephone poll was conducted Aug. 20-24 by I.C.R. of Media, Pa., among a random sample of 1,003 adult Americans in all states except Alaska and Hawaii. The margin of error was estimated at plus or minus three percentage points.
Congress and President Clinton are to begin grappling with the proposed deal next month, and such poll findings are bound to figure in the debate.
"This reflects a huge amount of cynicism and skepticism about tobacco," said Scott Harshbarger, the Massachusetts Attorney General, who insists that the public is missing the deal's good points.
If the debate remains as polarized as it is today, Mr. Harshbarger said, "We will miss an opportunity that may not come again, and tobacco wins."
The findings present a dilemma for the deal's supporters, who would like to toughen some provisions but without causing tobacco companies to back out.
Critics of the proposed settlement seized on the poll's findings.
"The American people have it right," Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, said in a statement. "They're not against a settlement; they're against a bad settlement. It's exactly this kind of public opposition to the deal that's going to force Congress to make significant changes."
The proposed deal would settle state lawsuits against tobacco companies by forcing companies to pay $368.5 billion over 25 years, curb advertising and marketing and pay fines if teen-age smoking does not fall by roughly 30 percent over five years. In return, the industry would benefit from the class-action ban and other legal protections, plus restrictions on pending Government control over nicotine levels.
Mr. Clinton has said he will stiffen the deal, demanding full Government regulation of nicotine. The poll found that 58 percent of Americans support such regulation.
Fifty-four percent of those polled said a deal was not worth the ban on class-action lawsuits. But smokers were split evenly: 39.5 percent said a deal was worth that concession, and 41 percent said it was not.
The proposal would force companies to raise cigarette prices by about 62 cents a pack. A pack now averages $1.74, including tax.
Eight in 10 Americans said a jump of even 75 cents would not cut smoking among teen-agers significantly. Seventy percent of those polled, and 61 percent of smokers, said prices would have to rise more than $1 a pack to accomplish that.
Jeffrey Harris, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said prices would have to rise from $1.15 to $1.50 a pack to reduce teen-age smoking by 30 percent. But even a small price increase would cut cigarette sales, he said.
Every 10 percent increase in price would reduce the number of cigarettes sold by 4 percent, Mr. Harris's calculations indicate.

HEADLINE: Odyssey of a Bosnian Serb: From Karadzic Ally to Foe

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: BANJA LUKA, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Aug. 28

 BODY:
When the Bosnian Serb President, Biljana Plavsic, returned from talks with British officials in London at the end of June, she got a nasty surprise. Bosnian Serb police officers met her at the airport in Belgrade, ushered her into a waiting car and whisked her against her will toward the Bosnian Serbs' mountain capital at Pale, where her one-time political mentor, Radovan Karadzic, holds court.
NATO troops were alerted, and they intervened to prevent what officials believe was a kidnapping intended to intimidate and, presumably, silence Ms. Plavsic, who had already begun to turn from Dr. Karadzic's political stand-in to a bitter rival for power. 
 In the months since then, as the rivalry and the power struggle have deepened, so has the commitment of the American-led NATO force to backing Ms. Plavsic. In the last week alone, NATO forces have used armor and helicopters to help her extend her voice and influence in the Serbian enclave by taking control of police stations and media centers while fending off angry mobs of Karadzic supporters.
But in many ways she is an odd choice as a NATO partner, and a questionable hope as a peacemaker.
She rose to the Bosnian Serb presidency a year ago as an ideological partner of Dr. Karadzic, after NATO forced him to step aside because he has been indicted by an international war crimes tribunal on genocide charges. Indeed, she owed her rise in the governing Serb Democratic Party to Dr. Karadzic, and two years ago, as one of the most strident Serb nationalists, she bitterly condemned the NATO bombing campaign that shattered the resolve of the Bosnian Serb army and its dream of taking Sarajevo, the prize for which much of the war had been waged.
Now, even after having broken with Dr. Karadzic, Ms. Plavsic does not criticize him and his allies for the atrocities committed during the war, or for their radical brand of Serb nationalism. Her big complaint is that Dr. Karadzic and his allies are corrupt.
And she is clearly no match -- not yet, at least -- for Dr. Karadzic in raw power in the Bosnian Serb community. As in her escape from the kidnapping attempt, success in her recent efforts to take control of broadcast outlets and police stations have depended, in the end, on the backing of NATO forces willing to confront Serbs loyal to Dr. Karadzic.
A 67-year-old former biology professor, Ms. Plavsic may already owe her life to NATO. A Western diplomat described the incident at the airport this way: "We suspect the idea was to take her to Pale where she would have been committed to psychiatric treatment or simply disappear, perhaps in what would have later been described as a suicide. The car, however, entered Bosnia at the wrong border crossing and did not meet up with its escort. NATO troops, who had been alerted to halt the kidnapping, were able to intervene."
The ride from the airport appears to have been a pivotal event in Ms. Plavsic's metamorphosis. A few days later, on July 2, she made a stunning announcement over Bosnian Serb television that was tantamount to a declaration of war on Dr. Karadzic and the Pale leadership, denouncing them for amassing tens of millions of dollars from the control of cigarette and gasoline sales and for running a state "in which the budget does not actually exist, where police are involved in smuggling and stealing from their own state and where a majority of the population is living in abject poverty."
She went on to call for the Minister of Interior, Dragan Kijaca, a close Karadzic ally, to resign.
That speech triggered the current power struggle between Pale and the western Bosnian city of Banja Luka, where Ms. Plavsic has her offices.
Ms. Plavsic and NATO seem to have little love for each other, but it is clear that NATO needs her as much as she needs NATO. If NATO forces are to withdraw as scheduled from Bosnia in June 1998, they must break Dr. Karadzic's grip on power. And Ms. Plavsic, whatever her views on nationalism, is the only Bosnian Serb political leader now willing to defy Pale.
The arguments she musters for opposing Pale are economic. She and those around her contend that unless the economy is rescued from its downward spiral and the corruption of senior Serbian officials, the Serbian enclave will disintegrate.
"My struggle against the leaders in Pale is a struggle to save the Serb Republic," she said recently.
Ms. Plavsic, who now refuses to answer questions about the Serbian "ethnic cleansing" campaign and atrocities committed during the war, describes herself as a "pragmatic nationalist." But while she still opposes the arrest of Dr. Karadzic, who was twice indicted by the war crimes tribunal in The Hague on genocide charges, she says she will honor the Dayton agreement and cooperate with the international community. Her refusal to condemn Serbian behavior during the war, however, leaves many outsiders skeptical.
"The international community does not back Plavsic," said a Western diplomat. "It backs what she champions. She says she is for the Dayton agreement, democracy and against corruption. To the extent she carries out these reforms, we support her. If she backs away from these principles we will take stock again."
Ms. Plavsic, who is deeply religious in addition to being a fierce nationalist, joined Dr. Karadzic's Serb Democratic Party in 1990 and left Sarajevo in April 1992 to join the rebels in the mountain town of Pale just outside Sarajevo. She was one of the few rebel Serb leaders who never belonged to the Communist Party.
During the war she was one of two vice presidents of the Serbian enclave. She frequently toured the front lines, often in a flowing fur coat, and oversaw the distribution of war relief aid to citizens. She was not involved in operational plans to prosecute the war or in planning the attacks on ethnic Croat and Muslim minorities that left tens of thousands of people dead and saw over a million people driven from their homes, Bosnian officials say.
She did, however, say during the war that Serbs were genetically superior to Muslims. She called for the division of Sarajevo, with most of the city going to the Serbs, since, she said, it was well known that Muslims liked to live piled on top of one another.
She also publicly rejoiced in the savage rampages through Muslim towns by the notorious paramilitary leader Zeljko Raznatovic, known as Arkan. When Arkan's militia drove the Muslims out of Zvornik early in the war, she arrived shortly afterward to congratulate him in front of television cameras, embracing and kissing him.
"I always kiss heroes," she said at the time.
Nicknamed the "Serbian Empress" for her imperial style, she opposed every peace plan drawn up by international mediators, including, at the time, the Dayton agreement, as "unfair" to the Serbs. She refused to shake hands with the Serbian President of Yugoslavia, Slobodan Milosovic, during his only visit to the Serbian enclave in 1993 because he had supported the Vance-Owen peace plan.
Mr. Milosovic has often told foreign diplomats that Ms. Plavsic belongs in "a lunatic asylum."
There were also moments during the war when Ms. Plavsic, who was briefly married and divorced, exhibited streaks of remarkable cruelty.
She ordered, for example, that a convoy of 78 Muslim children being evacuated from Sarajevo in April 1992 be taken hostage and held without food and water, until her brother was released from a jail in Sarajevo. When the Muslim authorities freed her brother and sister-in-law the next day, she ordered the children released.
She also said the term "ethnic cleansing" was the international community's way to describe what was "a natural phenomena."
Today, though, Bosnian Serb colleagues in Pale say that she seems to have remained honest in a world where war profiteering is believed to be widespread among her fellow officials. During closed-door sessions of the Bosnian Serb parliament, she denounced the senior officials for corruption, including Mr. Kardazic.
In July 1996 the international community brokered a deal with Dr. Karadzic to step down and withdraw from public life in return for participation by his governing party in the internationally monitored elections. Ms. Plavsic was elevated to the role of acting President and was named by the governing party to stand for the post of President of the Bosnian Serb Republic, evidently on the expectation that she would prove pliable. But Dr. Karadzic, following her election last September, did not relinquish his hold on power. He sent her to Banja Luka, where she had little to do and faded from public view. Ms. Plavsic smoldered there, and focused on her objections to the wealth amassed by the leadership while teachers, doctors and government workers received their small salaries months late or not at all. Early this year she started an investigation and recruited as an ally in Pale the former vice president and Shakespeare professor Nikola Koljevic, who had been shunted aside after the elections.
Mr. Koljevic, however, was found dead in his office in January with a bullet wound to his head. The official explanation for his death is that it was a suicide, but Ms. Plavsic and Mr. Koljevic's family say he was killed because of his support for Ms. Plavsic's anti-corruption campaign.
In one of the last meetings she attended with senior officials in Pale this spring, the Serbian member of the Bosnian tripartite Presidency, Momcilo Krajisinik, a close Karadzic ally who does not smoke, called for a break so Ms. Plavsic could go outside and have a cigarette. The word he used for smoke, however, also has a vulgar second meaning. As the party officials chuckled in amusement, Ms. Plavsic stormed out of the room.
The latest stage of the confrontation between Ms. Plavsic, backed by NATO, and Dr. Karadzic took shape two weeks ago when British soldiers, in an effort to prevent Ms. Plavsic's arrest by police officers loyal to Dr. Karadzic, seized all of the police stations in Banja Luka and disarmed the Karadzic supporters. Since then, NATO troops have been crucial in her effort to take over other police stations and television transmitters.

HEADLINE: 2 Communities Illustrate Debate Over Census

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 27

 BODY:
One neighborhood is urban, largely black and poor. The other is suburban, virtually all white, and middle and upper class. But they represent two sides of the same coin, the yin and the yang of the problems the Census Bureau experiences in trying to carry out a modern-day count of the nation's population.
Statisticians estimate that in 1990, the Census Bureau counted too few residents on the Hill, the low-income neighborhood on the south side of this state capital, while it tallied too many in New Cumberland, a small bedroom community across the Susquehanna River from Harrisburg. 
 Census officials acknowledged the problems in its last survey, when nearly 10 million people were missed nationwide and 4.4 million were counted twice or were made up by frustrated census takers who could not gain access to homes, according to the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress. And the Census Bureau has a remedy for the next scheduled head count, in 2000. It is called sampling, a method similar to that used in public opinion polls that extrapolates the characteristics of a large group by talking to a representative part of it.
If the bureau can use sampling -- a plan strongly opposed by Republican leaders in Congress -- it may avoid the problems that stem from situations like those of Cory Layton, who lives on the Hill. Mr. Layton, who is 20 and married and has two children, has not been getting along with his wife, Angel, who is 19. So he moved out of Hall Manor, the public housing project where they lived, and in with his mother, who lives in another part of the city.
If a census form was to arrive in the mail today, no one is sure who would list Mr. Layton. His wife said she definitely would not include him as living with her. And he strongly doubted that his mother would indicate he lived with her, if she bothered to fill out a census form at all.
"I don't care" about being listed, Mr. Layton said, standing in the doorway of his wife's apartment. "It's not affecting me."
Mr. Layton might not believe that such an oversight affects him directly, but if the Census Bureau could correct for it through sampling, the resulting revisions in its 60,000 census tracts could have a high-stakes effect on the national political map. The census is used to apportion seats in the House of Representatives and to draw Congressional and state legislative districts across the land.
And there is the rub. To Republicans in Congress, sampling has become a dirty word. They say it invites manipulation of figures for partisan purposes and insist that the Constitution requires an actual count of every resident.
What those Republicans rarely add is that many of those undercounted tracts, like the Hill in Harrisburg, are overwhelmingly Democratic and many tracts that were overcounted like the one in New Cumberland are solidly Republican. Republicans fear that adjustments for undercounts and overcounts could cost them Congressional seats.
The Census Bureau said the problems that occurred in 1990 might get worse if Congress, as it has threatened, forbade the bureau to supplement its count with estimates based on samples of the population.
"Every indication since 1990 suggests that the census-taking environment is likely to be even more difficult in 2000 than it was in 1990," the bureau wrote in a report to Congress last month. The difficulties stem from a rise in the numbers of two-income couples, who are often too busy to fill out the forms; immigrants with limited English and college students, who are often counted twice.
A plan by the Republicans to derail sampling earlier this year was put aside because it was stalling emergency flood relief for Midwestern states. But when Congress returns from its recess after Labor Day, the Republican leadership will try to forbid the Census Bureau to spend any money on preparations to use sampling.
Census officials say sampling is needed to help smooth out the discrepancies it has found in places like Harrisburg. Using mathematical models of the types of communities where miscounts are likely, bureau statisticians estimate that the official count of 5,658 people in the census tract on the Hill was short by about 5.4 percent. In contrast, the 3,991 people officially listed in the New Cumberland tract was reckoned to be about 2 percent too many.
Mr. Layton is emblematic of the people unlikely to be counted: inner-city males, especially black and Hispanic men, with only a tenuous hold on any permanent residence. In 1990, an estimated 14 percent of black men aged 30 to 34 were not counted, the highest undercounting of any group in the country.
"When boys start to get about 15 years old in many low-income communities, they start going from one house to another," said Alan Zaslavsky, a professor of statistics at Harvard University who serves on a panel to evaluate census methodology. "They are often too old to remain with the family discipline and they can't afford to stay in one place. They might live with an aunt one week, a grandmother the next." Demographically, the Hill is awash with people who are prone to be missed. The poor are much more likely to be missed than middle and upper income people, and the 1990 census indicated that 50.3 percent of the people living on the Hill had incomes below the poverty line.
Children are much more likely not to be counted than older people, and more than 41 percent of those living in the census tract on the Hill were under the age of 18 in 1990. Renters are more likely to be missed than homeowners. Nearly half of the residents in this inner-city tract rent apartments.
In contrast, New Cumberland has all the attributes of an area where everyone tends to be counted, and some groups tend to be overcounted. Women tend to be counted twice at a higher rate than men. Adult females make up 43 percent of the population of the New Cumberland tract. The elderly -- especially the retirees who spend part of the year in warmer climates -- are much more prone to double counting. Nearly 42 percent of the residents of the New Cumberland tract are 50 and over.
"The guy across the street from me has a house in New Cumberland," said John R. Murray, president of the New Cumberland Borough Council. "He also has a place in Florida. About a month from now he'll pack up and head down there for six months. Being an older population, we have a great many retired people in town and a lot of them do that."
Because census forms are sent to every address in the country, those with two residences receive two. Though the forms admonish the recipients to return only the one that has been mailed to their primary residence, many people, especially retirees with more time on their hands, fill out both. In 1990, this duplication was often not caught.
"Much of overcount is simply due to human error," said Eugene Ericksen, a professor of sociology and statistics at Temple University in Philadelphia. "There are computer matches that are supposed to catch duplications. But the problem can be as simple as bad handwriting or poor spelling."
Census officials said they would have enhanced computers for the 2000 census that would better identify duplication.
In the Hall Manor housing project, where 1,675 people are supposed to reside in 10 red-brick, two-story buildings, the problem is not people returning too many forms, it is people often not mailing back any at all. Distrust of authority abounds.
"Any outside people, any whites, or any people who seem to be of any kind of authority might not be welcome," said Betty Watkins, the manager of Hall Manor.
And sometimes the residents believe there are good reasons not to divulge information. The regulations at Hall Manor allow only those who are officially listed on the lease -- generally a mother and her children -- to stay in an apartment for longer than two weeks. Violating this rule could mean eviction for the legitimate tenant.
Thus, tenants would be hesitant to name boyfriends or family members who are illegally staying with them, even if the census form says the information is confidential.
"I sometimes let my sister or my brother or a friend of mine stay with me, if they don't have a place to stay," said Brigett Pattillo, 32, who lives with her four children and a husband who shows up every now and then."
Even if it does not use sampling, the Census Bureau hopes to reduce undercounting by making it easier for people to respond to the census. Special census forms, called "Be Counted" forms, will be available at public libraries, post offices and convenience stores. In addition, people can provide census information via an 800 telephone number.
Census officials acknowledge that these new methods could add to overcounting because there is no way of assuring that two or more people from the same household might not pick up the form and fill it out independently.
Officials hope to catch these duplications with the bureau's enhanced computer capabilities. And if an unreasonable number of "Be Counted" forms are returned from a given area, enumerators will be sent to double-check the information in person. But officials acknowledged that they did not yet know what constitutes a unreasonable number.
"We don't have an answer for that yet," said Peter Bounpane, assistant to the census director.
 
How Bureau Plans to Use Sampling in Its 2000 Census
The sampling that the Census Bureau wants to use to supplement the 2000 Census has been compared to the public opinion polls used in political campaigns. But while the underlying principle is the same -- extrapolating the characteristics (or opinions) of a large group by talking to a representative sample -- the bureau's plans are far more sophisticated.
The plans involve three sets of samples. The first would check a selection of houses in a given census tract that are presumed to be vacant. The second would check a proportion of residences from which forms were not returned. And the last would be a random sampling nationwide as a final check of the accuracy of their methods.
The United States Postal Service in 2000 will probably estimate that 5 percent of the 119 million residential addresses in the country are vacant, the bureau said. In past years, those addresses would not be sent a census form. But studies have shown that at least 11 percent of the homes the Postal Service said were empty, were, in fact, occupied. The bureau, rather than sending forms, would send counters to 1 in 10 of the houses that Postal Service records say are vacant. The number of those dwellings found to be occupied and the number of people living in them would then be used to estimate the population in housing units that were thought to be vacant across the country.
In 1990, the bureau repeatedly sent enumerators to the 35 percent of all addresses that did not return their mail-in census forms. In 2000, the bureau plans to send people to only a fraction of the households from which forms are not returned. The percentage visited would depend on how many households in each census tract -- a neighborhood containing about 1,700 households -- have mailed their forms in.
If 80 percent of the households in a tract have sent the form in, the bureau would visit 1 in 2 of those houses that did not respond. If only 30 percent of the addresses mailed the forms, census takers would visit 6 out of 7 of those dwellings that did not. The goal is to have a response either by mail or by visit from 90 percent of the dwellings in each of the country's 60,000 census tracts. Using the information gathered, the bureau would estimate the number and characteristics of the remaining 10 percent.
Finally, the bureau would randomly select 750,000 households nationwide, making sure that each state and all racial, age, economic and other demographic groups were represented. This sample would be used as a "quality control" to check the accuracy of the bureau's efforts and to make adjustments where necessary. STEVEN A. HOLMES

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL;
A Coaching Partnership Reshapes the Jets

BYLINE: By GERALD ESKENAZI 

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Aug. 29

 BODY:
In many ways, the Jets team that was reconfigured this week, as it prepares for a new era that starts Sunday at Seattle, is the result of a joint venture: Bill Parcells, king for the millennium, with Bill Belichick sitting to the right of the throne. Of all the relationships between coach and assistant in the National Football League, none is as encompassing and significant as this one.
Belichick's title of assistant head coach does not begin to cover the job description. He was at Parcells's side when they looked at hundreds of tapes of players to pluck from the draft or free agency. 
 "Ninety percent of it here is the way it was with the Giants," said Belichick, known here as Little Bill. The two were on the Giants together from 1981 to 1990.
The sandy-haired, boyish Belichick is a reserved 45-year-old. On the field, he is effusive by comparison -- correcting and instructing. His defenses are smart and minimize mistakes.
He was the Browns' leader for five years, taking them to an 11-5 record in 1994, and then saw them collapse the next season once the decision was made to leave for Baltimore.
That was not his only head coaching job. Belichick was the Jets' head coach for a week back in February. That was the tumultuous time when the team was trying to get Parcells, who had severed his stormy relationship with the Patriots.
"When I became the Jets' head coach, there were a lot of things to be done and that had to be started," Belichick said. "I knew it was going to switch at some time. We did a lot that week -- bringing people on the staff, starting talks with players, arranging to hire the three holdover coaches."
But as soon as the Jets made their deal with the Patriots' owner, Bob Kraft, to get Parcells, Belichick yielded his head-coaching duties and shifted into his current role.
Belichick says he has no problem being an assistant after being the head man for five years.
"There's plenty of jobs to do," he said. "There are some things Bill asked me to do because of my experience. He's working 24 hours a day. I'm working 24 hours a day."
What's special about the relationship?
"The whole thing is building a mentality and commitment, not only to the program, but to each other," Belichick said. "It's thinking, 'I don't want to let anyone down.' "
Parcells explains the symbiosis more succinctly. "We both like football," he said. "We don't have much in common. Different backgrounds. But we've got one thing in common."
Belichick was raised around football in Annapolis, Md., where his father, Steve, was a longtime coach and scout for Navy. At Wesleyan, Belichick majored in economics and was contemplating a master's degree and perhaps a career in business, with football as a way to foot the freight.
"I was a senior in 1975 when Lou Holtz at North Carolina State was ready to get me as a graduate assistant," Belichick said. "But he lost the scholarship."
So Belichick went to work under Ted Marchibroda at the Baltimore Colts. Four years later, he became the Giants' special-teams coach and began his association with Parcells.
They were reunited last year at New England. Parcells made him the Patriots' assistant head coach. Kraft now talks of having wanted Belichick in the wings to replace Parcells in the event he left.
But when Parcells left, Kraft instead hired Pete Carroll, the former coach of the Jets. Why not Belichick?
"I had plans to talk to Bill Belichick about coaching," Kraft said. "But Parcells's departure had created such a whirlwind, a storm, and I couldn't talk to his people. We were just left in such turmoil and uncertainty, and I knew that Parcells would be taking the staff with him. We thought it was better to start fresh."
 
EXTRA POINTS
An indication of a team in transition: linebacker PEPPER JOHNSON, in his first season here, has been elected defensive captain, and quarterback NEIL O'DONNELL, in his second year, is offensive captain. . . . The Jets have fewer than 100 seats available, in scattered single locations, for their eight home games.

HEADLINE: Bill Won't Erode Native Americans' Sovereignty

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Senate Measures Would Deal Blow to Indian Rights" (front page, Aug. 27): 
 Accountability and equity are the central principles behind the two provisions I wrote. One would restore to non-Indian citizens the constitutional right to seek redress in a Federal court over civil grievances against an Indian tribe. The other creates a formula to prioritize the allocation of Federal financing to tribes based on economic need.
The tribes' sovereignty will in no way "erode" by giving citizens the right to bring civil suits before an impartial court. And what of the erosion of the constitutional rights of United States citizens currently denied due process? Moreover, my provision does not alter the substantive principle of tribal self-governance.
Under the current system of allocating Federal money, tribes that have grown rich from casino gambling and other enterprises are de facto denying the poorest tribes a fair share of Federal dollars. My provision would alter this discrepancy, not exacerbate the inequity.
I also take issue with the characterization that I have a long-running "dispute" with the tribes and seek to use my position to pursue a vendetta. True, we have disagreed in the past, and may in the future. But because there are two competing views about the proper legal relationship between non-Indians and Indians, and between the Federal Government and the tribes, it does not mean principle is being subjugated to my personal whims. Rather, it is an illustration of the democratic process at work.
 
SLADE GORTON
U.S. Senator from Washington
Washington, Aug. 27, 1997

HEADLINE: QUICK SIP;
Whipping Up a Prize-winning Dairy Drink

 BODY:
Josephine Lutz calls her creation Quick & Easy Nutritious & Delicious Refreshing Drink.
It is, indeed, all of those things. And it was special enough to win the grand prize in the 11th annual Jersey Fresh Dairy Recipe Contest. 
 The competition is sponsored by the state Agriculture Department and the New Jersey State Dairy Princess Committee, which seeks to to educate consumers about the importance of dairy products in the diet and the economic impact of the state's dairy industry.
Contestants were judged on how they used dairy products and fresh fruit from New Jersey to create something that looked good, tasted good and was good for you. Mrs. Lutz, who is from Sussex, stuck with the basics and came up with this recipe, which takes five minutes to make and serves four people:
1 1/2 cups milk (skim, low fat or regular)
1 1/2 cups New Jersey fruit in season (strawberries, peaches, blackberries, blueberries, raspberries or cherries)
4 full scoops of ice cream, frozen yogurt or plain yogurt (your choice, depending on how rich you want the drink to be)
 1/4 teaspoon vanilla
Sugar to taste
Dash of nutmeg
Whipped cream
Prepare fruit (stem berries, pit cherries or peaches, etc.) and slice.
Pour milk in blender, add fruit and vanilla; blend for approximately 1 1/2 minutes. Add ice cream or yogurt to fruit mixture; blend until smooth, about two minutes. Pour mixture in glass and top with whipped cream and a dash of nutmeg.
When Mrs. Lutz made the deluxe version of her recipe for judges in June, strawberries were in season. On Sept. 6, when she claims her $150 prize at the Somerset County 4-H Center in Bridgewater, farmstands should still have plenty of blueberries and peaches.
No matter what the season, and no matter how rich a drink she whips up, she likes to top it off with a cherry -- Jersey Fresh, if possible.

HEADLINE: A Spectacular Mess of a Marriage

BYLINE: By Angeline Goreau; Angeline Goreau is writing a novel set along the Mississippi in the 19th century.

 BODY:

INTIMATE ENEMIES
 The Two Worlds
 of the Baroness de Pontalba.
 By Christina Vella.
 Illustrated. 426 pp. Baton Rouge:
 Louisiana State University Press.
 $29.95. 
 On Nov. 8, 1834, Stendhal wrote to a friend about a recent scandal that was the talk of Paris, commenting smugly: "I know the husband and the wife. Who was the indirect author-hero of all this mess?"
The "mess" in question was, even by contemporary standards, fairly spectacular: on the morning of Oct. 19, the 80-year-old Baron de Pontalba, dueling pistols in hand, burst into the sleeping quarters of his 40-year-old daughter-in-law (the future Baroness de Pontalba) and fired three shots into her chest. Perceiving that she was wounded but not yet dead, he pursued her through several rooms of their country estate, repeatedly shooting - but missing. Finally, he gave up, rewrote his will in favor of a military school and killed himself. The Baron's son, Clestin, took care of his wounded wife until it became clear she would recover. Then he served her with a summons - in the most recent of two decades' worth of lawsuits.
One suspects, with some reason, that Stendhal had his eye on the aristocratic scandal as material for a story. He kept several newspaper accounts of the incident in a file, along with biographical information about various members of the family. And he had already begun to ask the kinds of questions novelists ask.
He never used the story - at least not in any recognizable form - and its remarkable particulars languished in obscurity for more than 150 years. Now Christina Vella, a historian at Tulane University, has framed them in the form of a biography, meticulously reconstructed from court records, family papers, household accounts and government archives. She focuses on the Baroness de Pontalba, but at the same time ambitiously sets out to unravel the complexities of class, marriage, family economy, politics and the law, both in France and in Louisiana, spanning four generations of two families.
The Pontalba debacle begins in America. The Baroness was born Micaela Almonester (called Micael), daughter of the richest man in New Orleans and a poor but well-connected Creole mother. Her father, already 67 when she was born, died when she was 2. Micael's mother, having first married a man old enough to be her father, subsequently married a man younger than she, who succeeded in alienating a healthy part of her fortune. This matrimonial reverse may have made the widow Almonester (now Madame Castillon) cautious in negotiating her own daughter's marriage contract.
When the girl was 15, Madame Castillon's cousin, Joseph Delfau de Pontalba, the Baron, wrote from France to suggest an alliance between Micael and his son, Clestin. He sent his wife and son to New Orleans to conclude the business, and the couple returned to France after their marriage, both mothers in tow. Micael's dowry was substantial, but Pontalba was apparently disappointed to find that only about a third of it was to be paid immediately. The rest, Madame Castillon stipulated, would come in increments over time. Vella argues convincingly that by standards of the period, there was nothing out of the ordinary in the marriage contract, but the Baron de Pontalba nevertheless dramatically averred that the bride had "arrived despoiled." The real insult, one suspects, was that her mother had dared to pose conditions. To lay hands on the rest of Micael's dowry, the elder Pontalba had to sign over an equal sum to his son.
The wily Baron promised to give Clestin the money, then made him sign a secret agreement stating he would never under any circumstances ask for it. Clestin's 16-year-old bride came across the paper by accident one day, after which (as her lawyer later stated) "life became complicated." Baron de Pontalba's "complication" proved to be merely the first salvo of a guerrilla war that lasted nearly four decades.
Micael was still amenable enough at 17, however, to be persuaded to sign a paper giving up complete control of her money, real estate and possessions, as well as the right to represent herself in court. With this document in hand, her husband and father-in-law proceeded to attack her mother in court, challenging the distribution of the inheritance from Almonester. Under French law, the husband controlled a wife's dowry but not her inheritance.
Micael's mother, a superbly competent businesswoman who had greatly increased the inheritance since Almonester's death, fought back ably in court. But she was defeated on the home front: the Pontalbas removed her daughter to their country estate just as she was about to give birth to her first child, denying the eager grandmother access. Capitulating, Madame Castillon signed over still more of her American property: all the houses on the left side of what is now New Orleans's Jackson Square. As a condition, however, she stipulated that Clestin surrender the power of attorney Micael had assigned him.
Clestin and his father seem to act as a single malevolent force in the endlessly protracted legal wranglings, but despite this, there is evidence that between the son and his wife there was considerable affection. Even after Clestin blackmailed her into signing over half of the assets Madame Castillon had protected with a legally watertight will, Micael wrote to her notary: "My husband is too devoted to me not to love me always; they can't take away the friendship which is in the depths of his heart for me." She gave birth to five children in five years. Only two died - a fairly good rate of survival for the times.
It is interesting to speculate whether Micael's capacity for taking independent action grew as a result of the extreme measures her husband and father-in-law adopted to exert control over her every action, or whether her character gathered strength of purpose despite them. At any rate, after 20 years of marital life, Micael finally decided it was "urgent for her to become enlightened as to her own rights." The lawyer she consulted informed her that her husband had no claim to any of her property in America (except that specified in the original marriage contract), but that she would have to go to Louisiana to reclaim her rights.
Micael's departure for New Orleans set off the chain of events that led to her shooting. The legal system in France held that a woman who abandoned her husband's household could be stripped of all assets - including the right to act as mother to her children. While Micael was away, the Pontalbas obtained a judgment against her, giving her two months to return. When she did, on the last possible day allowed by the court, her relatives began devising exquisite tortures to drive her away. The entire household was instructed to pretend she was invisible; even guests were warned not to address a word to Micael. She proved as indomitable as her enemies, however, and in the end her clever father-in-law was driven to the crudest possible of remedies.
Incredibly enough, after the shooting a French court once again ordered Micael back to her husband's chateau. But Clestin's sense of invincibility now led him to commit a fatal error. The couple's eldest son had paid the journal that reported on the juiciest of trials not to publish the transcript. Clestin, however, now the Baron, paid the same journal a matching sum to print his lawyer's arguments but not hers. Clestin was so pleased with the results of this strategy that he engaged a publisher to print the one-sided transcript in a little rose booklet, to be distributed to 500 friends. People began to shun the Baroness.
Shooting wasn't sufficient cause to obtain a separation for Micael, but the loss of reputation was. Her husband had failed in his duty to protect his wife's good name, and the court punished him by granting her complete autonomy. She still had two bullets in her chest, but, at 41, she finally had her freedom.
The mere fact of Micael's survival, both emotional and physical, was remarkable enough, but the career she now began was perhaps equally surprising for a woman of her time. She inherited her parents' affinity for building and astute business instincts, and their "passion for contracts, pricing, drawings and all the reckoning associated with construction." She began by demolishing an 18th-century Paris mansion whose wainscoting, paneling and other appurtenances she admired, instructing an architect to design a house for her that would incorporate these elements. She had to sue the architect to get what she wanted. But the magnificent house she built is now the American Ambassador's residence in Paris.
Serving to a large degree as her own architect on the next project, the Baroness also built two huge apartment buildings in New Orleans, on either side of Jackson Square. They may well have been the most ambitious buildings of their kind up to that time in America, cleverly combining architectural elements from several different vernaculars. Certainly their innovative use of iron grillwork set a style that defined the look New Orleans came to be known for.
In the end, it was Micael who survived. Whether or not she prevailed is open to question. After several years of separation, her husband called her back to take charge of his affairs, then slowly lost his mind. Did she become his prisoner, then, in a different sense? She spent last 23 years of her life taking care of him - and never built another building.
Vella interlards the telling of Baroness de Pontalba's story with discussions of the position of women in France and in America in the 19th century, strategies of upward mobility, political practices of Napoleon and his successors, the history of the Paris Commune and countless details of the material lives people a century and a half ago negotiated their way through.
In general, this approach adds greatly to the biography's interest - with one glaring exception. The book begins with a very long summary of early New Orleans history and the politics of the Spanish court (it was a Spanish possession then), wandering through subjects that contribute little to our understanding of the Baroness's life. The reader would do well to skip through these encumbering initial chapters.
Christina Vella has done a spectacular job of excavating the historical record but, as she herself points out, "the documents of Micael's and Clestin's marriage are clumsy guides to a complicated relationship" because they leave "much to be imagined and presumed." We long for a novelist who could explore the intricate workings of motivation, who could trace the seesawings of power and control, who could ask the tricky question of who the "author" of this family's story finally was.
Stendhal may have been too busy with other projects to take up the Pontalba scandal as a subject - he was, after all, working on another novel at the time. But there may have been another reason he shied away: the too-muchness of it all. Henry James would have thought so. He worked from "the stray suggestion, the wandering word . . . any more than the minimum of which spoils the whole operation."
Too-muchness has never been an impediment to serialization, however. And public consideration of the Pontalba doings might offer up an interesting historical corrective to current notions about family values. We tend to blame the demise of the manners and traditions of the extended family and community for the epidemic of violence and abuse that seems to plague the end of the 20th century. But here is abuse and violence flowering in the most traditional of societies, where family values held firm to a degree we can hardly imagine now. Even if we could, would we want to go back to the world we have lost?
