SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 1; Column 2; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1561 words

HEADLINE: Losing Business, Gaining Business

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
FINALLY, Leon Fassler, the co-owner of Kings Electronics in Tuckahoe, threw up his hands and decided the time had come to relocate. Citing prohibitive costs to rebuild his outmoded factory, along with high property taxes and other expenses, Mr. Fassler announced recently that he would move the company to South Carolina after 45 years in Westchester.
Harold Feinleib, president of Aperture Technologies in Valhalla, is also leaving. His young and growing software development concern is bursting at the seams, he said, explaining that a commercial landlord in nearby Stamford made him a deal he could not refuse: more office space at a lower rate. 
 Property taxes and high rent are not the main reasons for the move out of the county by Simplex Knowledge of White Plains, a developer of Internet products. That company is relocating to lower Manhattan to have better access to computer-savvy workers schooled in the latest technologies, Patricia Martin, a co-owner, said. "That kind of a labor force," she said, "simply is not here in Westchester."
On the plus side of the ledger, however, two major employers have recently made heroes out of business leaders like Terence J. Masterson, the executive director of the Westchester Partnership for Economic Development, a public-private organization.
Mr. Masterson pulled many of the strings that persuaded the Nine West Group, a women's shoe company, to move its headquarters to the county and persuaded Prodigy Services, the nation's first online service, not to leave White Plains.
"You win some; you lose some," Mr. Masterson said last week, peering out from behind a stack of documents and business clippings on his desk. His organization, a privatized version of the county's former Office of Economic Development, is charged with attracting new businesses to Westchester and retaining existing ones.
But with a limited number of attractions in its basket of incentives for businesses, the county is losing some companies to better deals offered elsewhere, Mr. Masterson conceded.
Still, companies like Prodigy looked far and wide to move and then decided to stay -- discovering after all that the grass is not necessarily greener in places like Connecticut, which it had considered.
And companies like Nine West are moving in, despite higher property taxes and other expenses in the county, saying they could not be more pleased with Westchester's school systems, its high quality of life, major highways and proximity to New York City -- attributes that Margaret S. Soter, Westchester's business liaison, called compelling.
Although the range of business incentives is limited, at least in the case of Prodigy and Nine West there were enough plusses to persuade the companies to choose Westchester over Fairfield County. Alex DelCielo, executive vice president of operations for Nine West, described state and county officials as very aggressive in luring the shoe company from Stamford to White Plains, although he would not disclose details of the incentive package.
But Charles A. Gargano, chairman and Commissioner of Empire State Development, the state's umbrella organization for economic development, said the state package amounted to about $1.8 million, along with some personal cajoling from Gov. George E. Pataki.
The first group of Nine West employees has just moved in to the 336,000-square-foot building on Westchester Avenue that was formerly occupied by Nynex, and the others are to arrive by November. In all, the move is expected to bring 1,400 new jobs to the county.
In Prodigy's case, there was a $50,000 training grant for employees, a $25,000 export development grant and a guarantee for the new landlord that the state would pay up to $500,000 the first year and $300,000 the second year if the Internet service provider, which has experienced financial difficulties in recent years, could not pay the rent. The retention of Prodigy means that about 450 jobs will remain in the county.
Barry D. Kluger, Prodigy's senior vice president for communications, said that even though Connecticut was similarly persuasive in trying to lure the company there, "White Plains always was our first choice."
But in the case of Kings Electronics, the state and county incentive packages were obviously not sufficient to counter South Carolina's offer -- a new factory at a reasonable price in Rock Hill and a training program for workers through a college there, among other things.
"I don't know where South Carolina gets its money," Mr. Gargano of Empire State Development said.
From Mr. Fassler's point of view, it was a matter of wanting to stay in Westchester but not being able to afford to do so.
"For one and a half years, we explored the options, until finally prudent business judgment dictated that we move out," Mr. Fassler said.
The costs of refurbishing his existing 89,000-square-foot factory, a former ice warehouse, were too high, and "it came to a point where adding on only exacerbated the existing inefficiencies," Mr. Fassler said. The company manufactures precision components like cable connectors used in broadcast television studios, among other things. His move means a loss of 300 jobs to the county.
The move by Aperture Technology means a loss of 60 jobs, and Simplex Knowledge, while it employs only 5 people, now is in a major expansion mode, Mrs. Martin said.
Mr. Masterson at the Westchester Partnership for Economic Development, said he was heartened by recent developments under Governor Pataki's administration that have allowed Westchester to develop a more user-friendly environment for businesses.
"For a long time, we kept seeing companies slipping out of our hands," Mr. Masterson said.
In the last several years, the corporate tax surcharge and other business taxes have been eliminated, and more than 400 government regulations have been simplified.
The surcharge on the corporate franchise tax and on gains from transfers of commercial real property values at $1 million or more were similarly disposed of.
Also gone are the gross receipts tax on trucking and railroad companies and the petroleum business tax on fuel used by commercial enterprises, railroads and utilities. Workmen's compensation costs have also been reduced.
And while those changes have represented steps in the right direction, most business leaders agree that New York in general and Westchester in particular still have a long way to go.
For starters, utility costs remain especially high in Westchester, with Con Edison charging businesses 10 cents to 12 cents a kilowatt hour, said Jim O'Toole, a spokesman for the company. In the northern counties of the state, other utility companies negotiate rates as low as 7 cents to 9 cents a kilowatt hour.
Outside of New York, energy rates drop to 3 cents to 5 cents a kilowatt hour.
High property taxes likewise place Westchester at a disadvantage, running $3 a square foot on commercial buildings, which translates to $1.5 million in taxes yearly on a 500,000-square-foot building. By contrast, Connecticut in some cases waives property taxes for new businesses.
In Westchester, Mrs. Soter, the business liaison, said the county's Industrial Development Agency can offer loans to new companies, sales tax exemptions on major office supplies, deals that include payments in lieu of taxes and up to 25 percent discounts on electric rates for the first 10 years.
"We do have some tricks up our sleeve," she said. "Still, the cost of doing business in Westchester remains high."
Another drawback for Westchester is a state law that prohibits counties -- as opposed to cities like New York or Buffalo -- from offering cash grants as enticements to new businesses.
Meanwhile, vacancy rates in the county remain staggeringly high, with more commercial space being returned to the real estate market than absorbed, according to a market report issued by Insignia/Rostenberg-Doern, a corporate real estate service.
At midyear the office vacancy rate in White Plains was 30.81 percent, up from 26.7 percent at the end of the first quarter of this year. Countywide it was 17.07 percent, up from 16.65 percent at the end of the first quarter.
But commercial rental rates for Westchester are significantly lower than in other areas, observed William V. Cuddy Jr., managing director of Insignia/Rostenberg-Doern. Class A and B properties in the county rent for an average of $20.90 a square foot, compared with Stamford, where the same types of properties are $30 to $40 a square foot, and rents in Midtown Manhattan range from $33 to $45 a square foot.
Despite the higher rents in Greenwich and Stamford, vacancy rates there are only 11 percent.
Westchester was hit by the downsizing of large Fortune 500 companies in the early 1990's and has not fully recovered.
"Slowly but surely," Mr. Cuddy said, "landlords are backfilling those large blocks of vacant real estate with small- and moderate-sized companies."
Throughout the rest of the state, Mr. Gargano said, the state was trying to make a comeback. Admitting that New York still came out the loser in some incentive wars -- South Carolina is an example -- he promised that the gains of the last several years would prove to be just the beginning.
"There's more to come down the pike," he said, referring to new incentives for businesses.

HEADLINE: Where Has WSTC In Stamford Gone?

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
WHETHER it's providing a breaking local news story or giving school lunch menus for the day, a radio station is an integral part of a community, especially when it's the only one in town.
That was the case with WSTC in Stamford for 56 years. Its reporters would be seen checking the blotter at police headquarters or stopping at the Stamford central fire station to read the fire log for the night before. They would turn up at events to tape interviews and then hurry back to the station's studios on Atlantic Street. And when a controversial issue was being debated by the city's Board of Representatives, the station often would broadcast the hearing from gavel to gavel, sometimes into the early hours of the morning. 
 "During the big ice storm in the late 1970's, John Roman, our news director, and I were on duty for 46 straight hours," recalled Don Russell, who was the station's morning man for many years and its best-known broadcaster.
But since April Stamford has been without the presence of an AM radio station for the first time since September of 1941, just months before the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. That month, WSTC -- which last fall had been consolidated with WNLK-AM in Norwalk and WINE-AM in Danbury into the Fairfield County Newsradio Network -- moved, along with its FM stations, into a building in the Staples Shopping Plaza on Westport Avenue in Norwalk.
The move, like the earlier announcement that WSTC was being consolidated with WNLK and WINE, was distressing to many Stamfordites. "We were very disappointed at their leaving, and we encouraged them to relocate and stay," said the Stamford Mayor, Dannel P. Malloy. "We even offered them the use of our economic development office in the hope that they'd stay. Their leaving is a significant loss to the city."
Mr. Russell, who was with the station, on and off, for about 40 years, went further. "Here we have the biggest potential market, and the fastest growing city in the state, and they pick this time to leave," he said. Mr. Russell, now the general manager of Connecticut Public Television and Radio/Fairfield County in Stamford, added: "I think it's terrible. And many people I talk to, tell me they miss the personal touch now that the station has been combined and has left town."
But executives of Atlantic Star Communications, which owns the three combined AM station, along with their FM stations, say that Stamford will not be without an active AM radio presence for long.
"We definitely will keep a studio in Stamford and have some news originate there," said Bill Hess, regional vice president for programming and operations for Atlantic Star. "For example, we did some of our broadcasting on the Alex Kelly trials from our old Stamford studios, and we still broadcast a show called 'Emerging Society' from Stamford."
That show, and any other broadcasts emanating from Stamford, will now come from new studios that Atlantic Star moved into in August in the Landmark Square building. "We eventually plan to have a news staffer in Stamford," said Peter Mutino, the station manager for the Fairfield County NewsRadio network.
But not for now. Nor has there been a news staffer at the Stamford studios since the network moved in April, without any announcement of the shift. Indeed, Stamfordites unaware of the move, as most of them apparently are, still may call WSTC (and Fairfield County NewsRadio) at its old location and get a ring -- but no answer.
Callers in the Danbury area who phone WINE-AM will have their calls answered, at least during the daytime when a news staffer, Tony Savino, is on duty, along with a parttime newscaster and reporter. Mr. Savino, whose studios are in Brookfield, just outside of Danbury, said he reports for work at 4:15 A.M. Monday through Friday. In the Stamford-Norwalk area, the broadcast anchors in the Norwalk studios report on happenings. "The primary reason we relocated our news studios and sales offices to Norwalk is economics," said Scott Bacherman, the president of the Northeast region of Atlantic Star. "We were able to secure a very good longterm deal. Beyond that, it's better operationally and economically to put all of our operations under one roof. At the same time, we're going to maintain our obligation as a Stamford radio station."
To some observers, the "Fairfield County NewsRadio" title is something of a misnomer, if indeed not downright misleading. The round-the-clock broadcasting schedule includes far more talk programming than it does news. There is an all-news block from 5:30 to 9 A.M. Monday through Friday, followed by a midday report from 11:30 A.M. to noon. From 3 to 7 P.M., "The Afternoon Report" with David Smith, includes interviews, discussions of issues and news, traffic and weather reports.
Otherwise, apart from local newscasts that range from 30 seconds to 6 minutes, along with network news broadcasts, the Fairfield County NewsRadio format consists of syndicated programming. On Satudays and Sundays, apart from local news on the hour and half-hour, the format includes non-news shows involving gardening tips, a "Shop and Save" program and several syndicated talk shows.
The Fairfield County NewsRadio programming also includes broadcasts of Boston Red Sox baseball games. Red Sox games in Yankee country? The station had no choice if it wanted to broadcast baseball games, since the Yankees and the Mets already have radio outlets in the Fairfield County area.
"Regardless of who's playing, baseball is popular on radio," said Mr. Hess. "And you're always going to have baseball fans, who while they may not root for the Red Sox, do root for teams that play the Red Sox. And, of course, Mo Vaughn of the Red Sox is from Norwalk."
Moreover, Mr. Mutino says, "Advertisers have warmly embraced them, and the sale of time for the games has exceeded expectations."
Starting this fall, Fairfield County NewsRadio also will broadcast Boston Celtics basketball games and, later, both men's and women's UConn basketball games. "And this fall, we'll also do high school football," Mr. Hess said.
In a way, that fragmentation of broadcasting will be the only link to the past when the three stations had distinct identities.
Mr. Hess said the network did plan to add more news personnel. At present it has five fulltime news staffers and five parttimers working out of the Norwalk studios, compared with four fulltime staff members and one parttime worker last fall.
"We have far more people out now than we did at the start," Mr. Hess said. "And we're covering important meetings and other events. But as for covering entire meetings, as was sometimes done in the past, my sense is that it's a better use of air time when you get the key people in a controversial issue together for a forum-type program where they can discuss the issue."
Mr. Hess also said he thinks that the talk shows on Fairfield County NewsRadio can help keep listeners tuned in. "People don't stay with all-news stations for a long period of time because much of the programming can be repetitive," he said. "Talk shows, when they're interesting, can keep people listening."
One possible addition to the existing format could be local talk shows. "Our main objective now is to build a real good local news operation covering Fairfield County from Greenwich to Westport," Mr. Hess said.
Mr. Mutino, the network station manager, said advertising revenues have increased by about 30 percent since the three stations were combined (the three FM stations have retained their individuality).
John Roman, a former news director at WSTC-AM who spent 30 years with the station as a newsman, lamented the fact that the station had in a physical sense left Stamford. "But then AM radio isn't like it used to be," he said, "and one reason is because the local retail dollar for advertising just isn't there like it was."
He continued: "Back in the 60's and 70's, and even before that, the station's commercial anchors were local banks, car dealers and locally owned stores. But the local banks are gone and so are practically all of the stores and a lot of the car dealers. Now you have the malls and a lot of chains, and those stores don't spend much money on AM radio stations."
Mr. Roman, who left WSTC in 1995, recalled how his news staff totaled as many as 13 people. "And in the 1980's, we did three hours of news and talk in the morning and then in the afternoon there was another three-hour block of news," Mr. Roman said. At least, he said, Fairfield County NewsRadio is "doing more than anybody else in the state as far as news goes."
Officials of the new network were heartened by the Arbitron ratings for this past spring, which showed that WSTC's share of the audience had increased since last fall, albeit very slightly. The ratings of WINE in Danbury increased almost imperceptibly while the Norwalk rating dropped by three-tenths of a percentage point.
The really bad news, though, is that the ratings of all three AM stations were higher for the spring of 1996 when the three AM stations still operated independently.

HEADLINE: Economy Diversifies, Regaining Momentum

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
TEN years after a stock market crash marked the beginning of the end of an earlier boom, Long Island is climbing toward a new economic peak that has economists, planners and businesses gushing.
Key indicators portray a regional economy that has emerged with new vitality from a long recessionary period in which defense manufacturing, the economic engine of the mid-1980's and the region's greatest source of strength since World War II, declined precipitously. 
 Experts say that what has evolved is what the region had hoped for: a more diversified, stronger regional economy based on high technology industries and expanding service sectors, with the prospect of growth in high-paying manufacturing jobs.
Pearl M. Kamer, the chief economist for the Long Island Association, said no indicator was more important than a recent net gain in manufacturing jobs, the first since 1986.
"And these," Dr. Kamer pointed out, "are not jobs flipping hamburgers."
She added that an influx of new retailers, including the recently opened Nordstrom store at Roosevelt Field, and plans for new and expanded regional malls, were also positive signs.
"The reason these retailers are coming is that we have so much purchasing power," she said.
The region's challenge, she said, would be educating a new work force with skills for the high technology industries that would power the region's economy.
"The Long Island economy is in the best shape it's been in since the mid to late 1980's," said Irwin L. Kellner, president of Kellner Economic Advisers of Port Washington and a professor of economics at Hofstra University.
"Defense and aerospace wound down as factors," Dr. Kellner said. "But they have been replaced by computer hardware and software, biotechnology, health care, tourism, and growth in business services like accounting, law and financial consulting. In many respects, it is a healthier economy."
The region's high cost of living, while not declining, has been held in check as local governments and school districts, compelled to cut spending during the long recessionary period, continue to limit property tax increases.
Local schools, often accounting for more than half the property taxes a typical Long Island homeowner pays, have held budget increases to 2 or 3 percent in many districts. Budgets were defeated this year in only seven of the Island's 126 school districts. The new state budget, school officials said, also deals generously with the region.
Alice F. Willett, the executive director of the Nassau and Suffolk School Boards Association, said districts were gratified by state aid levels this year but also had "grave reservations" about future financing.
"If the economy doesn't continue on its rosy path, then the state may have to pull back on some of its promises," Ms. Willett said. She said school officials were particularly concerned about financing for meeting higher minimum academic standards and for Gov. George E. Pataki's initiative to give school tax relief to senior citizens.
But if there were clouds over the horizon, the present looks sunny to Long Island's county governments, whose use of the sales tax continues to provide revenues while eliminating the need for property tax increases.
As the regional economy has strengthened, carried by the record stock market advances, low interest and near-record low unemployment, strong sales tax revenues reflecting consumer confidence and strong retail sales have relieved the counties of the specter of fiscal crisis.
In Nassau, county property taxes have been cut or frozen for five years, county officials said. County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, who is running for re-election this fall, has pledged to cut taxes again in next year's budget.
In Suffolk, where revenue shortfalls and job furloughs rocked county government at the start of the 1990's, property taxes have also been flat for five years, with costs for county police accounting for increases offset by declines in other spending including for social services.
"The sales tax is now our major revenue source," said Frederick B. Pollert, the director of the Budget Review Office for the Suffolk County Legislature. "The difficulty is, when you become dependent on one major revenue source, particularly one that is sensitive to overall economic trends, you are vulnerable."
On virtually every front, the economic news has been positive. Unemployment in July was 3.9 percent in Nassau and 4.8 percent in Suffolk, "right in the range of the historic lows of the 1986-1987 period," said Gary E. Huth, an associate economist for the New York State Department of Labor.
"The fact is, there's a labor shortage," said Lee E. Koppelman, the executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. "It's a very good time for Long Island. We have finally overcome some of the problems of the recession."
Mr. Koppelman said the construction industry, another casualty of the recession, had been revived. Construction of new homes and offices was up, he said, "and we have seen more government spending on highway construction this year than in the last five years."
Some economists and experts in commercial real estate continued to predict the return to premier office buildings on speculation, a practice that ended in the late 1980's.
"Rental fees for class A office space are now in the $26- to $28-per square-foot range," said Dr. Kamer. "Most industry watchers believe that when it reaches $30 you are going to have a new round of office construction."
Ronald S. Cooper, a managing partner of Ernst & Young, an accounting and business service firm, said business clients appeared to be expecting continued strength in the regional economy. "I won't call it euphoria, but there seems to be a much higher level of confidence in their futures," Mr. Cooper said. "I am very bullish on Long Island."
Stock prices, rising to levels that would have been hard to imagine a decade ago, continued to spill money into a region where Wall Street is a significant employer, and where investment is as much a part of the Long Island life style as shopping for many people.
The real estate market has continued to rebound. Real estate brokers said there was demand for expensive homes in some of the most wealthy communities in the country, many on the North Shore of Nassau County, where sales rise and fall with the fortunes of the stock market.
Housing prices were beginning to approach levels of the late 1980's, but lower mortgage interest rates continued to make homes more affordable.
Demographers predict that Long Island's population will remain stable in coming years. But even without the demands for new housing rising population brings, construction of second homes has increased sharply on eastern Long Island, where areas of Southampton, Riverhead and Southold have been under intense building pressure.
In the Northville hamlet of Riverhead, a long-dormant housing development on bluffs overlooking Long Island Sound was revived with a massive clearing of trees that were reduced to wood chips heaped in towering piles. Town officials suspended the developers' permit after finding violations.
Environmentalists said the project, called Maidstone Landing, had destroyed songbird and animal habitats and was an example of the excesses rapid development was bringing the last remaining rural areas of Long Island.
"Especially in boom times, you have to be careful or greed can undercut planning and produce land use excesses that everybody on Long Island will pay for after the bloom is off the rose," said Richard L. Amper Jr., the co-founder of East End Forever, a group advocating preservation of farms and open space.
As the 10-year anniversary of the 1987 stock market plunge arrived, economists said the stock market and interest rates set by the Federal Reserve would affect Long Island more than many other parts of the country because of high levels of personal investment and Wall Street-related employment.
"I think the Fed may think twice before raising interest rates because of the nervousness of the stock market," said Mr. Kellner, who noted that the 1987 plunge followed closely on a Federal Reserve decision to raise interest rates.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Mortgage Brokers And Lenders

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
BORROWERS are often told that going to a mortgage broker is a no-lose proposition. The broker's fee, the reasoning goes, is more than justified by the broker's ability to get a loan at a lower interest rate than the customer could get on his own. And usually that's the case.
But while brokers may often get better deals for their borrowers, they don't always get the best deal. 
 In fact, brokers have a financial incentive not to get the best possible deal for borrowers, because of a practice called yield spread premium pricing. Yield spread premiums are payments brokers receive from many lenders for arranging loans with a higher interest rate than the lender is prepared to accept -- terms somewhere between the wholesale rate lenders offer brokers and the retail rate available to direct customers.
"A lot of brokers are making a lot of money on yield spread premiums," said Richard J. Russell, president of Richland Equity Resources, a Manhattan mortgage broker. "It's legal as long as it's disclosed. But this is all about disclosure."
Mortgage brokers get better rates, he said, because they prepare the paperwork and deal in volume with lenders. For example, a borrower who goes directly to a lender might obtain a $150,000, 30-year fixed-rate mortgage at 8 percent with the payment of one point -- one percent of the mortgage amount -- to the lender.
If that borrower went through a mortgage broker, he might get the same mortgage at 7.5 percent by paying one point to the broker instead of the lender.
The benefit to the customer would be one-half of a percentage point in interest -- a difference of more than $100 a month in mortgage payments and more than $18,000 over the life of the loan.
But if the broker negotiated the mortgage at 7.75 percent -- plus the point to the broker -- instead of 7.50 percent, making it more valuable to the lender, the lender may compensate the broker with a yield spread premium. And while the amount of the payment varies from lender to lender, it would not be unusual, Mr. Russell said, , for a broker to be paid one or more points for delivering such a loan to a lender.
The customer gets a lower interest rate than he would have if he had gone to the bank directly, the lender gets a higher rate and the broker gets more money. So everybody wins, right? Well, not exactly.
"It is ludicrous to believe that any fully informed borrower would pay a mortgage broker for any other purpose than to obtain a loan on the best terms possible," said John G. Hall, a Staten Island lawyer who is chairman of the Real Property Section of the New York State Bar Association.
Mr. Hall said that whenever a broker gets a yield spread premium from a lender, it's a good bet the broker's customer is not getting a loan on the best terms. In New York, he said, brokers must disclose in writing and at the time of application that they may be paid a fee by the lender in the form of a yield spread premium. (Such fees are generally expressed in points or fractions of a point, again representing a percentage of the loan itself.) Just making that disclosure, however, provides little useful information to the customer.
"The broker tells the customer: 'You don't have to worry because you're only paying one point; the rest are being paid by the lender,' " Mr. Hall said, adding that the broker often doesn't disclose that to receive those extra points, he must deliver a loan at terms more favorable to the lender than the lender would otherwise require. "Even with adequate disclosure," he said, "consumers cannot be expected to be savvy enough to know that the broker is not working in their best interest."
In most cases, Mr. Hall said, the amount the broker is being paid will usually not be known until the lender issues the mortgage commitment. At that point it is too late for the borrower to do anything. "What do you do?" Mr. Hall said. "Apply to another lender with only two days left on your mortgage contingency and 15 days left until closing?"
Most borrowers, he said, simply go through with the deal without fully realizing the impact a yield spread premium may have had on their interest rate. And even when a specific reference to a yield spread premium is noted on the closing statement, the reference is still unlikely to be understood by many borrowers. Mr. Hall said that a typical reference on a HUD-1 form -- the closing statement required by the Department of Housing and Urban Development under the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act -- might read: "YSP paid from Lender to Great Mortgage Brokerage Corp. -- $2,000 P.O.C."
The term "P.O.C.," Mr. Hall said, refers to a payment made "outside of closing." Since such payments have no effect on the amount the borrower has to bring to the closing, they are often ignored.
Eric Gonchar, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that in his experience, most deals involving brokers also involve yield spread premiums.
"It's on almost every HUD-1 that we do," Mr. Gonchar said, adding that the payment of such premiums has become a hot topic in the mortgage industry as the result of a ruling by a United States District Judge in a Virginia case earlier this year.
The judge ruled that the payment of yield spread premiums violates the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act because such payments are not compensation -- which is permitted under the act -- but are referral fees -- which are prohibited. The ruling, now being appealed, is the first to question the legality of yield spread premiums. Mortgage industry experts, however, view the case as an anomaly and expect it to be reversed on appeal.
"Yield spread premiums are nothing more than a payment by a lender to a broker for the services rendered by that broker," said E. Robert Levy, executive director of the Mortgage Bankers Association of New Jersey, a trade organization in Springfield.
In fact, he said, yield spread premiums are what make it possible for brokers to arrange "zero-point" loans for cash-strapped borrowers. In such cases, he said, the borrowers accept a mortgage with an interest rate that is higher than the current market rate. Doing so enables the lender to pay the broker a yield spread premium of several points, thereby making it unnecessary for the broker to charge the borrower.
"If starting tomorrow, there were no more yield spread premiums," Mr. Levy said, "there would be no more zero-point loans either."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
In a Busy Life, Taking Time To Hear What People Say

BYLINE: By Melinda Henneberger; Melinda Henneberger writes about politics from Washington.

 BODY:
As Bill Bradley headed to the shore on Friday for the walk at the beach that has been a New Jersey tradition since 1980, a kind of town meeting-in-motion along the water's edge, the former Senator just didn't sound like a guy gearing up for the run of his life.
Perennially mentioned as a possible Presidential contender, he is not among those who are overtly mulling a challenge to the Vice President, like his fellow Democrats Dick Gephardt and Paul Wellstone. Along with a slew of Republicans, they are already traveling in key states, staking contrast-and-compare positions and eagerly seeking press attention. All are demurring sweetly, saying they have no immediate designs on the Presidency -- and leaving no doubt about their ambitions. 
 But Mr. Bradley is doing none of the above. He seems pleased to have "moved from life in 15-minute segments to more of a free flow" since leaving elected office.
In an interview in Manhattan last week, over a breakfast of berries and herbal peppermint tea -- he seemed almost alarmed ('Oh, no!") when a waiter offered him real coffee -- he spoke with great enthusiasm about the pleasures of this new chapter in his life. He was just back from his longest vacation in 18 years, two weeks in England, Scotland and Greece, where, he said, "I reached a level of relaxation you couldn't reach in the Senate."
He's exercising more regularly than he has in years, going for a "three or four times a week endorphin fix" and has become a fan of the Women's National Basketball Association, which he said he likes even more than the men's game because "more teams in the W.N.B.A. play real team basketball."
In these last days of summer, he's been reading some fiction, Louise Erdrich's "Love Medicine," along with a biography of Elvis, and enjoying taking in theater and concerts with his wife, Ernestine. She just had another good check-up, five years after a mastectomy, and their 20-year-old daughter is in college.
The question of whether he will run for President seems to weary him. "I am where I've been for a while. I haven't ruled anything out, but I'm involved in all these other activities and all of them are interesting."
To list just a few of these, he's working in media, doing two-minute segments for the CBS Evening News, and on an A & E series called "Uncommon Americans." He's also taken jobs in business, as J. P. Morgan's senior adviser on geopolitics, and in academia, at both Stanford University and the University of Maryland at College Park.
He's spent time thinking seriously about the problems facing children, and about ways to support their working parents with after-school programs. And now he's "trying to think through where the economy is headed, not in macro but real-life numbers and trying to figure out how we get good jobs for good wages."
"The children thing I have a pretty good handle on," he says. "The economics is more complicated."
He's also working with his friend the former Republican Senator Alan Simpson to encourage campaign finance reform. And he has not altogether abandoned political life, either. On this year's beach walk, he'll be campaigning for Jim McGreevey, the State Senator who is running for Governor, and for other New Jersey Democrats.
When he left the Senate, Mr. Bradley said he wanted to get out and do more of the kind of listening to Americans that he does on the annual beach walk, meeting them where they are.
And so far, he says, he's heard people feeling better about the economy but still insecure about the future.
The Clinton Administration, in his view, can take a bow for the strong economy, but must answer for why more hasn't been done to "get the middle moving and keep the bottom from dropping." He is proud of Mr. Clinton for speaking out on race, but deeply skeptical of recent changes in welfare.
"The welfare system was an embarrassment and needed an overhaul," he said, 'but not the abandonment of a Federal commitment" to the poor. He said he fears what will happen when the now-booming economy slows, but believes Mr. Clinton "did this in the heat of a campaign and will now try to clean it up with every passing year."
With all the activity in his life, Mr. Bradley says he never misses his old gig -- mostly because he feels he left at the right time, and in the right way.
As a member of the Democratic minority in the Senate, he says, he found himself spending much of his energy on the energy committee trying to "stop bad things from happening -- I was delaying, asking questions, offering amendments to amendments."
"I said, 'I know how to do this,' but the moment I felt comfortable I felt uncomfortable. It was time to push out."
And when he left, he said, he let himself feel the loss of the only public office he ever held, and what he still calls the best elective job in the world. The night before they came for the furniture in his office of 14 years, he said: "I stayed and made phone calls, and had a good cry. I allowed myself to grieve."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST FLATBUSH;
Calypso Contestants Sing of Nostalgia and of Today's News

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Scanty sang about the good old days, and Lady Venus about the power of women. Lady Guymine pitched a "granny fit." And Giant, who is blind, sang that "disability is not inability," proving his words with dance moves that propelled the crowd out of its seats.
The house was packed and steamy at the Tropical Reflections nightclub Wednesday night for the finals of the First U.S.A. Calypso Monarch Competition. Six hours after the marathon of words, music, humor, drums and dancing began, Scanty was the winner in the contemporaries category and Lady Guymine was queen of the veterans. 
 Calypso originated in Trinidad and Tobago, and most of the singers and audience did too, part of a Caribbean community that has grown in New York as economic opportunity has shrunk in the islands. Trinidadians have not lost their longing for home or their love of their culture, and so they had come to celebrate an art form, born out of slavery, that has become a symbol of a country's and a region's verbal proficiency, musicality and spiritual endurance.
The lyrics of calypso, said Hollis (Flash) Lashley, who along with a Trinidadian calypso king, Gypsy, was master of ceremonies, "mirror the social consciousness of a people, the hopes, dreams, feelings of the country." Calypso has always incorporated universal themes -- love, sex, nostalgia -- as well as pointed social commentary about race, class and politics in Trinidad. The challenge, Mr. Lashley said, is for calypsonians in New York to speak to life in America, and contemporary controversies, rather than just memories of their homeland.
There is ample material here, he said, given the club's location less than a mile from the spot where Abner Louima was allegedly beaten by the police en route to the 70th Precinct station house. A few calypsonians had wasted no time in weaving the incident into their repertory. Andrew Joseph, whose stage name is Buntin, appeared as a caveman, plunger in hand to punctuate lyrics on the barbarism that lurks beneath humanity's civilized veneer.
The contest was part of the lead-up to carnival, which will culminate with the annual West Indian Labor Day Parade down Flatbush Avenue tomorrow. Mr. Lashley noted that carnival had always offered a way to bridge divides among classes, races and sexes and release tensions among those groups "that otherwise might come out in antisocial ways."
But not all was serious. There were folk dancers brilliant with shine, color and sparkle, and plenty of ribald humor and double-entendres. Then there was Lady Guymine, who, with the energy if not the body of a gymnast, shed her hot pink lame robe during her second number and did the macarena in tights and a leotard. The crowd went wild, and to judge by her victory, apparently so did the five impassive judges. AMY WALDMAN

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
How to Fight Back If Your Credit Card's Rate Climbs

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
THEY are tiny slips of paper that can have a real bite. Millions of holders of Advanta credit cards have received them in recent months -- small notices inserted into their monthly bills advising them that their interest rates were being increased, sometimes to as much as 25 percent. For those with outstanding balances, that change could cost several hundred dollars a year.
For several years, credit card companies have increased rates for customers who miss payments or go over their credit limits. Now, with their losses rising from bad loans, some companies are raising rates for customers who just look potentially risky. 
 "You could be paying your credit card precisely on time and staying within your credit limit," said Robert McKinley of RAM Research, a credit card tracking company in Frederick, Md."If you missed one car payment or just took out too many other cards, that may be enough to trigger a 24.99 percent rate."
The Advanta Corporation is the most prominent of the increasing number of credit card issuers that have decided to "reprice" -- in industry jargon -- many of their accounts. Advanta, based in Horsham, Pa., has high loan losses and in April put itself up for sale. Other banks, including Capital One Financial of Falls Church, Va., have also been raising rates on accounts that they deem potentially risky.
Mr. McKinley and other credit card experts say consumers can fend off the rising rates in several ways:
* Read everything you receive from your card issuer. Most banks put rate and fee changes on separate pieces of paper inserted in their bills. Sometimes they print the notice on the statement itself.
* Keep copies of all terms and conditions. Issuers sign up accounts with so many different deals that they sometimes lose track of who got what. One Advanta customer said he was promised a rate of 9.9 percent, guaranteed not to change. When the bank tried to raise his rate to 16 percent less than a year later, he said, his copy of the initial offer allowed him to fight back.
* Be scrupulous in making minimum payments on time and in not exceeding your credit line. Card issuers may seize on the most minor infraction as an excuse to impose huge fees or rate increases.
* Consider freezing your account. In most states, you can reject an interest rate increase by writing a letter within a set period to the issuer and making no new purchases with the card. This gives you the right to pay your balance at the original rate.
* Call the bank and ask for a lower rate. Some companies will back down, at least partially, for customers who complain. If you think you have been treated unfairly, write a letter to a senior bank officer. If that doesn't work, complain to the bank's regulator. For nationally chartered banks, complaints may be made to the Comptroller of the Currency, a part of the Treasury Department. For state-chartered banks, write to the banking department in the state where the bank has its headquarters.
* Consider a different card. If you have other cards or other types of accounts with different banks, ask them if they will offer a special deal to move your balance to their card. Consider any low-rate offer you get in the mail, but check what the rate will be after the introductory period. Mr. McKinley says Wachovia, First Union, Key, USAA Federal Savings and AFBA Industrial banks all have cards with lower-than-average rates. Many of the lowest-rate cards, however, still have annual fees.
* Think about paying off your balance. Many people would be better off using savings or a lower-rate home equity loan with tax advantages to pay down card bills.
Finally, it may be prudent to have two or three accounts so that if one changes its terms you can freeze it and use another. But too many accounts may make you look like a bad credit risk, causing some card companies to send you that dreaded little slip of paper with the big rate increase on it.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ASTORIA;
Artists Arrive. Cafes, of Course, Follow . . .

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
Two young lovers lay flared out on the crushed velvet couch, strung out on their own hipness. He stared at a fan, contemplating infinity. She picked the polish off her nails. A typical night in the Village. Except this was Astoria, Queens. Archie Bunker land. First stop U.S.A.
Traditionally, this northwestern Queens neighborhood, which lies about a dozen good stone throws from Manhattan, has been a point of entry for Europeans looking to build the better life in America. More recently, young immigrant families from Romania, Central America and Pakistan have taken their places. 
 But there is also another type of immigrant carving out a piece of Astoria in the southern section of the neighborhood bounded by Broadway and 37th Avenue and 31st and Steinway Streets. They have not just arrived from overseas but from over the East River. They are the hipsters, the serious artists, the writers, the nouveau Manhattan Bohemes and our lovers on the velvet couch.
"People have gotten tired of living in the belly of the beast," said Monica Constantinides, a 32-year-old native of Cyprus who recently opened a spacious cafe across from Kaufman Astoria Studios, the TV and film production center, on 34th Avenue called Cafe Bar, a former carpet warehouse.
Live jazz is featured at Cafe Bar as well as a fully stocked bar and a menu of sandwiches and desserts. She also owns the velvet couch. "They are coming here because they are fleeing the tyranny of high rent, congestion and crime," Ms. Constantinides said.
Anchored by the Kaufman Studios, the American Museum of the Moving Image and their thousands of actors and artisans, the neighborhood has become an economically viable place to make business, make art and make a life.
"This area is the new horizon," said Joseph Pistilli of the Pistilli Realty Group, based in Astoria. Prices for a one-bedroom apartment or an artist's studio are typically half that of Manhattan, which is only a 10-minute train ride away. It is a rare mix of residential and commercial space. The artists have arrived and the restaurants, bars and clubs have followed. More than 10 establishments have opened in the area over the last two years. Gone is the old Croatian club. In is a new gay club, Crash, with a black and Latin clientele.
"That was unthinkable 10 years ago," said Patrick Poladian, a jazz pianist who is to appear at Cafi Bar this Wednesday night. "It used to be that the gays would get their heads kicked in around here."
Kaufman Studios has unspecified plans to expand. The newly refurbished P.S. 1, an exhibition and studio space in Long Island City, is scheduled to reopen in October. This may mean even more bars and more cafes.
Predictably, rents have risen nearly 30 percent in the last two years, Mr. Pistilli said, a barometer of the area's growing popularity. Sadly, some say, the bubbleheads in berets misquoting Nietzsche have also come.
"There is a problem about becoming too hip too fast," said Demetrius Manouselis, an architect and painter who has lived in Astoria for a decade. "I'd hate to see it turn into another East Village." CHARLIE LeDUFF

HEADLINE: JERSEYANA;
A Plea for New Jersey to Take Advantage of Its History

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
Even though George Washington and his soldiers set up three winter camps in New Jersey's hills, tourists who want to see where the Revolutionary War troops shivered in the cold are likely to think first of a trip to Valley Forge, Pa.
While other states lure millions of tourists to historic sites each year, New Jersey continues to neglect both its rich history and the history's economic potential, according to a recent report by the Task Force on New Jersey History. 
 But the task force members said money and jobs weren't the only benefits of doing more with the state's historic sites, from the 51-room mansion of the ironmaster Abram S. Hewitt to the barracks of mule drivers who worked on the Delaware and Raritan Canal.
"Our state is notorious as the target of jokes," the report said. "Outsiders see us, and we too often see ourselves, as simply a landscape of poor cities, shoddy strip malls and crowded highways. But it does not have to be that way. New Jersey has one of the richest and most vibrant histories of any state in the Union."
The group, which spent 18 months studying what could be done to promote the state's history, found many cases of neglect.
State-owned structures, like the tower erected to honor Thomas Edison's invention of electric light, are crumbling. Irreplaceable manuscripts are disintegrating because of inadequate temperature and humidity controls. And more than one-third of the state's public and private historic sites are open to the public less than 10 hours a week because of a lack of employees.
Dr. Barbara J. Mitnick, a historian and a resident of Morristown who was head of the task force, offered another example. At Ringwood Manor, the Hewitt family's former home, some pieces of furniture have deteriorated to the point that they are now losing their stuffing. "If you would go to that place, you would wonder how the state of New Jersey could do that," she said.
Task force members said they were also concerned about what students were learning in public school, where New Jersey history lessons are required. The task force said that when it asked 371 high school students to take a 15-question test on state history, the results were "devastating."
Only 22 percent of the 11th and 12th graders knew that a majority of New Jersey's voters had not supported Abraham Lincoln when he ran for President. Only 32 percent knew that Alice Paul was a women's rights advocate. And only 64 percent knew why New Jersey has been called the "cockpit of the Revolution": because more Revolutionary War battles took place in New Jersey than in any other colony.
In the report, delivered to Governor Whitman in June, the task force members recommended that more state money go to museums, historic sites, local historical societies and other groups dedicated to preserving New Jersey's past. They also recommended that the state sell more bonds to pay for historic preservation. Even though the New Jersey Historic Trust has given out more than $50 million since 1967, the last of its available bond money is to be awarded next year.
The task force also recommended that the state Division of Travel and Tourism do more to promote historic sites. Already, the travel and tourism market is one of the state's top three businesses, creating almost five percent of all jobs. But most of those visitors come to New Jersey either to visit friends or relatives, Atlantic City's casinos or the Jersey Shore.
Gene Herman, a spokesman for Mrs. Whitman, said the Governor was still reviewing the task force's recommendations. "The Governor is very committed to preserving historic sites," he said.
The report by the Task Force was not the first to criticize New Jersey's neglect of its history.
In 1846, an Episcopal Bishop, George Washington Doane, observed: "We have well nigh forgotten that we have a history. We have almost lost the very sense of our identity."
And 140 years later, Tom Dunkel wrote in an 1986 article in the New Jersey Monthly: "New Jerseyans have never been inclined to pamper the past. History bashing is commonplace. We seem to yearn for a heritage made of carefree, unbreakable plastic."
But the task force members said they were encouraged by a recent poll by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University that found that 65 percent of New Jersey residents polled favored an increase in state support of history.
"We're very optimistic that this is going to change," Dr. Mitnick said.
 
From the Pages of New Jersey History
The Task Force on New Jersey History surveyed 100 11th graders, selected at random to represent the students of the state, to find out what they knew about New Jersey history. Here are some of the questions. The answers, along with the percentage of students who knew the right answer, appear below.
 
1. New Jersey has been called "a barrel tapped at both ends." What is meant by that characterization?
A. The state's longstanding efforts against the consumption of alcoholic beverages.
B. The extraordinary influence of New York City and Philadelphia on New Jersey's identity.
C. The importance of the New Jersey Turnpike.
 
2. Which of the following places served as a winter encampment for Gen. George Washington and his troops during the American Revolution?
A. Hoboken
B. Morristown
C. Camden
 
3. Which of the following was the first Governor of New Jersey after the Declaration of Independence?
A. William Livingston
B. Woodrow Wilson
C. Alfred Driscoll
 
4. New Jersey has been called the "cockpit of the revolution" for the following reason.
A. There were a number of bird sanctuaries in the state at the time.
B. More Revolutionary War battles took place here than in any other colony.
C. The first battle of the Revolution took place in New Jersey.
 
5. Which of the following New Jersey cities was the site of the famous silk strike of 1913?
A. Trenton
B. Camden
C. Hoboken
D. Newark
E. Paterson
 
6. New Jersey's Constitution stood out from all others when it was ratified in 1947 because of the following:
A. It gave women the right to vote.
B. It provided for a state income tax.
C. It prohibited racial segregation in the public schools and in the state militia.
D. It legalized gambling in Atlantic City.
 
7. Which of the following statements is true about New Jersey in the era of the Civil War?
A. New Jersey voted against Abraham Lincoln for President.
B. New Jersey joined the Confederate States of America.
C. Several major battles of the Civil War were fought in New Jersey.
 
8. Which of the following was a New Jersey women's rights activist?
A. Alice Paul
B. Julia Hart Beers Kempson
C. Doris Duke
 
Answers:
1. B. The extraordinary influence of New York City and Philadelphia on New Jersey's identity; 71 percent correct.
2. B. Morristown; 51 percent correct.
3. A. William Livingston; 56 percent correct.
4. B. More Revolutionary War battles took place here than in any other colony; 64 percent correct.
5. E. Paterson; 23 percent correct.
6. C. It prohibited racial segregation in the public schools and in the state militia; 28 percent.
7. A. New Jersey voted against Abraham Lincoln for President; 22 percent correct.
8. A. Alice Paul; 32 percent correct.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;
Evicted Service Is Still Putting Copters in Air

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
When National Helicopter was evicted from the East 34th Street heliport on Aug. 13, the change seemed to fulfill Mayor Giuliani's April promise to reduce helicopter traffic over Manhattan by up to 40 percent by denying landing space to National, the city's largest operator of helicopter tourist flights.
But a spokesman for National, also known as Island Helicopter, said the company was simply shifting much business to heliports at West 30th Street and downtown. The company has long been at odds with City Hall over back rent and other issues, as well as being the focus of protests by community advocates, who contend that its flights are noisy and disruptive. 
 Unlike the East 34th Street heliport, which is owned by the city, the West 30th Street center is owned by the state and the downtown heliport, near Wall Street, is owned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. By law, those heliports must accept customers paying the required landing fees. A Port Authority spokesman acknowledged that National was using the downtown heliport, and a State Department of Transportation spokesman confirmed that National was using West 30th Street.
National estimated that it flew about 19,000 flights annually from East 34th Street, about a quarter of the total flown from the three heliports in Manhattan. A spokesman, Leslie Roberts, said the company hoped to fly an equal number of flights from the other two heliports, "but whether we can no one can predict at this time."
"We're dealing in a highly charged election year and people are being very cautious," he said.
Opponents disagreed. "National doesn't have the right to impose on the public whether it's an election year or not," said Joy Held, the executive director of the Helicopter Noise Coalition, a leading opponent of National and other helicopter companies. "What's happened to the Mayor's promise to reduce traffic by 30 to 40 percent? This is just musical chairs. They are going to slip through every loophole until we close the loopholes."
Ms. Held's organization has filed suit to close the East 34th Street heliport and advocates the closing of all Manhattan heliports.
The company's eviction from East 34th Street ended a decadelong legal fight. Under the plan announced in April, the Giuliani administration sought to evict National, move the 60th Street heliport operator, Johnson Controls, to 34th Street and close the 60th Street site. The Mayor's Office and the Economic Development Corporation, the landlord for the East 34th Street heliport, did not return telephone requests for comment. ANTHONY RAMIREZ

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Reassurances, Despite a Bouncing Bull

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
WHEN Paul A. Volcker was chairman of the Federal Reserve Board in the late 1970's and early 1980's, he was invariably asked by reporters for an interest rate forecast.
"Interest rates will fluctuate," Mr. Volcker would invariably respond. 
 So, too, will stock prices.
But over the last few months, swings in stocks have grown increasingly wide, a development that has scared some investors and raised questions about the durability of the bull market.
This has happened before. Last summer, for example, prices of technology stocks fell sharply, and on July 15, 1996, the Dow Jones industrial average fell just less than 3 percent, prompting some pundits to say that one of the best stock market runs in history was over. The Dow finished that day at 5,349.51. This year, as traders went off to celebrate the end of summer on Friday, the Dow stood at 7,622.42.
While the recent swings may prick one's psyche, analysts cautioned investors not to interpret the moves as impending Armageddon.
"Financial assets can bob all over the place, but they do not collapse unless there is evidence the fundamentals are eroding," said Eric H. Sorensen, global head of quantitative research at Salomon Brothers. "Stocks are moving around more than they typically have, but the macroeconomic fundamentals still seem good."
Mr. Sorensen said that in the current environment investors might consider stocks with moderate price-earnings ratios, especially in the oil, paper, insurance and specialty retail sectors. "We think buying conservative stocks is probably more advisable now," he said.
STILL, rising volatility is worrisome, if only because people who are paid to study such things have no clear answers as to why it is happening now. And it is occurring after an extended period in which stock prices, while moving higher, did so within historically narrow bands.
"Over the last 100 years in the United States, when you have periods of fairly stable markets, prices usually go up," Mr. Sorensen said.
"Volatility tends to increase when we get what I call an information shock," he continued. "The last time that happened and caused a down market was in 1990, at the beginning of the gulf war."
In this century, Mr. Sorensen said, the average yearly range of change in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has been 13 percent. The end of the Persian Gulf war ushered in a period, which seems to have ended last year, in which the S.& P. 500 oscillated in a range of 8 percent to 9 percent.
"In the last six months or so, volatility has slowly risen to above 20 percent," Mr. Sorensen said, "and we haven't had a major selloff."
Abby Joseph Cohen, a managing director and portfolio strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, began advising clients to expect markets to become bouncier early in the year, if only because stock prices had been so stable for so long.
"What we are seeing now is much closer to normal," she said.
Investors who are alarmed by daily swings of 100 points or more in the Dow or 10 points or more in the S.& P. 500 should look at those moves in the context of the market's level, Ms. Cohen said.
"Using Dow points or S.& P. points, rather than looking at how much change the market has seen in percentage terms, magnifies the perception of volatility," she said. "With the averages at higher levels, it takes more points to move them."
"At current levels," said Ravi Singh, head of global portfolio trading at Lehman Brothers, "for the market to decline 10 percent would take a drop of more than 700 Dow points."
Indeed, the market averages' lofty levels, and uncertainty about the future, are probably the most important reasons stocks have been seesawing so much recently.
"There is not complete confidence in where the market is going," Mr. Singh said. "Add to that the usual amount of rotation within the market and other things that add to volatility, like progress to European monetary union and the upcoming German elections."
"This is not just an American phenomenon," he added, noting that on Thursday the Hong Kong stock market fell nearly 5 percent.
LASZLO BIRINYI, who has been analyzing stock-price volatility for nearly two decades, first at Salomon Brothers and now at his own stock research firm, said computer-driven program trading was having a greater-than-normal effect on price swings.
"We have always seen this in these periods when volatility picks up," he said, "because investors are confused or hesitant, and in that situation program trades seem to have more of an impact. Currently, the bulls are not that bullish, and the bears think the market could go a bit higher before correcting. In the land of the blind, program trading takes on a whole new dimension."
Mr. Birinyi said that for the last two months his analysts had tracked an average of about 15 program trades a day, roughly double the average for the year. Still, only in the last few weeks has volatility increased noticeably, he said.
According to his model, which tracks the daily high and low prices for the 30 Dow stocks, the swings during August have averaged 2 percent a day, up from an average rate of 1.41 percent for the first seven months of the year.
Nor does he see this as a harbinger. "I don't see how this is an indicator of what the market will do," he said.
Other analysts agree.
"The fundamentals appear to be reasonably sound, and we remain somewhat bullish on the market," said Mr. Sorensen at Salomon Brothers, adding that his view would change if something happened in the bond market.
Ms. Cohen at Goldman, Sachs said that after the drop in stock prices last summer, which was accompanied by a rise in volatility, she reviewed underlying fundamentals and concluded that what had happened was a "Wall Street problem, not a Main Street problem."
The current period has prompted the same examination, she said.
"Sometimes you look at the volatility and wonder if it is telling you something," she said. "Right now we are paying a great deal of attention to corporate profits, labor costs and the like. And we have not seen anything that has surprised us."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Replowing A Garden, For Housing

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Mary Emma Harris still laughs when she recalls when the youngsters from Public School 76 struck oil. They were digging holes for trees that would help turn a small vacant lot opposite their school, on West 121st Street near Frederick Douglass Boulevard, into a garden.
Children yelled, "Miss Mary, Miss Mary, we struck oil," recalled Ms.Harris, a landscape developer from Greenwich Village who directed the children. Alas, the oil was oozing out of an abandoned tank. 
 The labors of Ms. Harris and more than 300 P.S. 76 pupils over the last four years have yielded something more precious than oil -- 1,500 square feet that the community calls the Children's Garden of Love. It has 12 trees and more than 30 bushes, including "butterfly bushes," so called because they are popular with Monarch butterflies.
The garden is to be demolished on Sept. 30, and replaced by a development of three-family homes. It is one of 16 community gardens in Manhattan to be replaced this year mainly by housing. All are in Harlem.
In the 1970's and 80's, the city let community groups plant gardens in vacant lots, with the understanding that the city could reclaim them for development. Officials of Green Thumb, the city agency that oversees the community-garden program, said there are 776 such gardens in the five boroughs covering 150 acres, equal to nearly a fifth of Central Park. Half of those gardens are set for demolition at some point,26 of them in the next few months.
Like other garden advocates, Ms. Harris said the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which oversees the city's urban renewal programs, should build on gardens only as a last resort.
Advocates say the agency should also make clear which lots are the sites of community gardens. "Too often the designation just says a lot is vacant," said Felicia Young, a member of the New York City Coalition for the Preservation of Gardens.
A spokeswoman for the housing preservation agency, Noel E. Jefferson, said it already develops community gardens as a last resort. The problem is community groups planted on sites that were already prime candidates for development, she said. As for a special designation for the gardens, Ms. Jefferson said, "I'm sure policy makers are not voting blindly." ANTHONY RAMIREZ

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
For a Projector Maker, Multiplexes Are a Ticket to Growth

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
FOR a sense of how the movie business is growing, consider Ontario Mills, a shopping mall in the flatlands 40 miles east of here. In addition to its dozens of stores, this huge emporium boasts an AMC megaplex with 30 screens -- and just across the street is an Edwards cinema complex with 22 screens.
The country is experiencing a movie theater building boom, and that is good news not only for people like Mel Gibson and Demi Moore, but also for Ballantyne of Omaha Inc. Ballantyne, though little known and based far from Hollywood, is the country's largest maker and distributor of movie projection equipment. Every time a megaplex goes up, Ballantyne is likely to get the orders for the projection booths -- the projectors and related equipment -- at about $20,000 a pop. (Indeed, Ballantyne's Sharp International division sold AMC the 30 projection booths at Ontario Mills. Other customers include Cineplex Odeon, Cinemark USA and Imax.) 
 Ballantyne recently raised fresh capital, expanded its factory, broadened its investor base and is poised to make a big acquisition, according to Arnold S. Tenney, its chairman, but he declined to specify potential targets. Many analysts find the company's stock, if not hot, at least an interesting way to play the theater building boom.
"This company really has the ability to grow pretty rapidly, and I think there could be a blockbuster acquisition," said Lawrence J. Horan, an analyst at Prudential Securities who recently began covering Ballantyne. Mr. Horan speculated that Ballantyne might go after its largest international rival, the projector maker Cinemeccanica S.p.A., a privately held Italian company.
Ballantyne's stock closed on Friday at $19.50, more than double its price at the beginning of the year, though down from its peak of $22.50 on July 30. Mr. Horan said he expected the price to reach at least $24 in the next year.
Ray Schleinkofer, who follows the company for Cowen & Company, which did its last share underwriting, said Ballantyne was "becoming a standard in that business, and they're a great play on the multiplex boom."
New theaters are opening rapidly, both in the United States and abroad, as uneconomical single-screen theaters close their doors. Sustained growth in the industry should help Ballantyne, which has roughly 65 percent of the domestic market for projection booths. The principal domestic competitor is Christie Electric.
According to the National Association of Theater Owners, a trade group, the number of screens in the country rose to 29,731 at the end of last year, from 23,814 in 1990. Another report, from Baskerville Communications, said that the number of screens outside the United States declined to 66,513 last year from 79,033 in 1990 because of closings. But it estimated that a construction boom would lift the number to nearly 76,000 in 2005.
Ballantyne's revenues, which were a bit more than $10 million in 1988, climbed to $51.7 million last year. Net income in the same period rose to $5 million from less than $1 million. Analysts predict revenues of $64 million this year, with perhaps $7 million in profit.
Mr. Horan of Prudential Securities said he expected Ballantyne's sales of projection booths to rise to 2,500 this year from 2,140 last year, and to 2,800 in 1998.
A key to Ballantyne's profitability is that its business has been requiring almost no new investment. The company recently spent about $1.5 million expanding its factory in Omaha, but it spends only about $500,000 a year on research and development, said Brad French, the company's chief financial officer.
"Projectors have not changed considerably from the way they were made in the 1920's," Mr. French said.
There have been efforts by companies like Sony to develop digital movie technology, but there are no products on the market, nor are any expected for some time.
John Wilmers, the chief executive of Ballantyne, said: "New technology is always discussed, but the issues are quality and economics. In the next 10 years, they're not going to change the way we show movies."
Mr. French said the company was increasingly shipping its projection booths to lucrative overseas markets. About 27 percent of sales now come from abroad, but that will grow to more than 50 percent in three years, Mr. French said.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Tenney said the company intended to grow rapidly or, if that failed, to sell off its small but profitable food service equipment business. Its larger focus for acquisitions, he said, would be in the areas of movie lighting or projection booths.
"We definitely have the cash, and we have the lines of credit," he said.
Ballantyne's largest shareholder is Arc International, a Canadian company of which Mr. Tenney is also the chairman. Arc took Ballantyne public in September 1995 and recently lowered its holdings from 50 percent to about 23 percent. That decision was difficult, Mr. Tenney said, because of Ballantyne's growth, but Arc needed the cash to pursue its main business -- the construction of skating rink complexes.
He said Arc would keep its remaining Ballantyne shares because of the expected growth, but some people are skeptical about how much higher the shares can rise.
Kevin B. Skislock, head of research at L. H. Friend, Weinress, Frankson & Presson Inc., said he was a great fan of Ballantyne, but he recently downgraded the stock slightly, to "buy" from "strong buy." He cited a recent slowdown in the growth rate for projector orders and the fact that the stock had already risen so much. He said he expected the price to climb no higher than $22 over the next 12 months.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Junk Here, Junk There: Hey, That's Big Money!

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
"There is nowhere else for the money to go." That's Martin S. Fridson, chief of high-yield research at Merrill Lynch & Company, explaining the rush of billions of dollars this year into C-rated and nonrated bonds, the bottom of the junk bond heap.
The appetite for junk's junk has been huge: at $9 billion, issuance of low-rated junk is running nearly 50 percent higher than last year at this time, according to Commscan Debtdesk, a financial research firm. And when dollar-denominated bonds of emerging-market countries are included, issuance of low-rated debt has nearly doubled, to more than $12 billion. 
 Most of it is taking the private-placement-to-sophisticated-investors route and is sold so quickly that rating agencies do not have enough time to evaluate the new issues. As of this week, Standard & Poor's had 48 issues already sold and still awaiting ratings. Most of these issues are expected to be given C's.
One money manager who is buying is Daniel Johnedis, fixed-income director in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for the Richmont Corporation, where he manages $100 million in high-yielding junk bonds.
"You get an extra 7 percent if you do your homework," he said, referring to the higher interest paid on low-rated bonds compared with investment-grade corporate issues. "So, why not? It is a lot easier to manage credit risk than interest-rate risk."
The demand for lower-quality credits is a byproduct of the same Goldilocks economy that has helped drive the stock market, despite its 3.4 percent slump last week, to perform better than expected this year. The belief that everything is working just right -- a growing economy with falling default rates -- is making money managers comfortable when they dip into the lower levels of credit.
"There is less chance now that these companies will default because it is a much better environment financially," Mr. Johnedis explained.
But the new issues data also indicate that while more low-rated and nonrated bonds are being gobbled up, the mix of the credit quality in the high-yield market has not shifted significantly in recent years. In 1996 and this year, the portion of C-rated and nonrated debt of the overall high-yield market has been 10 percent to 11 percent, below the levels of the previous three years.
"It is surprising that the quality of paper has held up as well as it has," Mr. Fridson said, adding that mutual funds have apparently been more picky than some have thought.
Jack Malvey, chief global fixed-income strategist at Lehman Brothers, thinks a "fundamental shift" is pushing money managers to take more risk. "You've got to have more of this lower-quality stuff," he said, or you cannot perform well anymore.
But the shift to more risk does not always pay off. Last year, the total return in the overall high-yield market, which includes double-B-rated bonds down though the C's, was 11.3 percent, according to Salomon Brothers' index, compared with 3.3 percent for investment-grade corporate bonds. So far this year, the overall high-yield return is lower, 8.7 percent, compared with 5.5 percent for investment-grade bonds, meaning there is less of a premium to be had for the extra risk. But the C-rated paper that many investors are chasing has returned 12.8 percent this year, up from 9 percent.
"This market is a market of extremes," warned Robert Waldman, head of corporate bond research at Salomon Brothers.
